01024045 “Before I finished praying in my heart, Rebekah came out, with her jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water, and I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’
01024046 “She quickly lowered her jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I’ll water your camels too.’ So I drank, and she watered the camels also.
01024047 “I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ “She said, ‘The daughter of Bethuel son of Nahor, whom Milkah bore to him.’ “Then I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her arms,
01024048 and I bowed down and worshiped the Lord. I praised the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me on the right road to get the granddaughter of my master’s brother for his son.
01024049 Now if you will show kindness and faithfulness to my master, tell me; and if not, tell me, so I may know which way to turn.”
01024050 Laban and Bethuel answered, “This is from the Lord; we can say nothing to you one way or the other.
01024051 Here is Rebekah; take her and go, and let her become the wife of your master’s son, as the Lord has directed.”
01024052 When Abraham’s servant heard what they said, he bowed down to the ground before the Lord.
01024053 Then the servant brought out gold and silver jewelry and articles of clothing and gave them to Rebekah; he also gave costly gifts to her brother and to her mother.
01024054 Then he and the men who were with him ate and drank and spent the night there. When they got up the next morning, he said, “Send me on my way to my master.”
01024055 But her brother and her mother replied, “Let the young woman remain with us ten days or so; then you may go.”
01024056 But he said to them, “Do not detain me, now that the Lord has granted success to my journey. Send me on my way so I may go to my master.”
01024057 Then they said, “Let’s call the young woman and ask her about it.”
01024058 So they called Rebekah and asked her, “Will you go with this man?” “I will go,” she said.
01024059 So they sent their sister Rebekah on her way, along with her nurse and Abraham’s servant and his men.
01024060 And they blessed Rebekah and said to her, “Our sister, may you increase to thousands upon thousands; may your offspring possess the cities of their enemies.”
01024061 Then Rebekah and her attendants got ready and mounted the camels and went back with the man. So the servant took Rebekah and left.
01024062 Now Isaac had come from Beer Lahai Roi, for he was living in the Negev.
01024063 He went out to the field one evening to meditate, and as he looked up, he saw camels approaching.
01024064 Rebekah also looked up and saw Isaac. She got down from her camel
01024065 and asked the servant, “Who is that man in the field coming to meet us?” “He is my master,” the servant answered. So she took her veil and covered herself.
01024066 Then the servant told Isaac all he had done.
01024067 Isaac brought her into the tent of his mother Sarah, and he married Rebekah. So she became his wife, and he loved her; and Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
01025001 Abraham had taken another wife, whose name was Keturah.
01025002 She bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak and Shuah.
01025003 Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan; the descendants of Dedan were the Ashurites, the Letushites and the Leummites.
01025004 The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanok, Abida and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.
01025005 Abraham left everything he owned to Isaac.
01025006 But while he was still living, he gave gifts to the sons of his concubines and sent them away from his son Isaac to the land of the east.
01025007 Abraham lived a hundred and seventy-five years.
01025008 Then Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man and full of years; and he was gathered to his people.
01025009 His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah near Mamre, in the field of Ephron son of Zohar the Hittite,
01025010 the field Abraham had bought from the Hittites. There Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah.
01025011 After Abraham’s death, God blessed his son Isaac, who then lived near Beer Lahai Roi.
01025012 This is the account of the family line of Abraham’s son Ishmael, whom Sarah’s slave, Hagar the Egyptian, bore to Abraham.
01025013 These are the names of the sons of Ishmael, listed in the order of their birth: Nebaioth the firstborn of Ishmael, Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
01025014 Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
01025015 Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish and Kedemah.
01025016 These were the sons of Ishmael, and these are the names of the twelve tribal rulers according to their settlements and camps.
01025017 Ishmael lived a hundred and thirty-seven years. He breathed his last and died, and he was gathered to his people.
01025018 His descendants settled in the area from Havilah to Shur, near the eastern border of Egypt, as you go toward Ashur. And they lived in hostility toward all the tribes related to them.
01025019 This is the account of the family line of Abraham’s son Isaac. Abraham became the father of Isaac,
01025020 and Isaac was forty years old when he married Rebekah daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan Aram and sister of Laban the Aramean.
01025021 Isaac prayed to the Lord on behalf of his wife, because she was childless. The Lord answered his prayer, and his wife Rebekah became pregnant.
01025022 The babies jostled each other within her, and she said, “Why is this happening to me?” So she went to inquire of the Lord.
01025023 The Lord said to her, “Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples from within you will be separated; one people will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger.”
01025024 When the time came for her to give birth, there were twin boys in her womb.
01025025 The first to come out was red, and his whole body was like a hairy garment; so they named him Esau.
01025026 After this, his brother came out, with his hand grasping Esau’s heel; so he was named Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when Rebekah gave birth to them.
01025027 The boys grew up, and Esau became a skillful hunter, a man of the open country, while Jacob was content to stay at home among the tents.
01025028 Isaac, who had a taste for wild game, loved Esau, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
01025029 Once when Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau came in from the open country, famished.
01025030 He said to Jacob, “Quick, let me have some of that red stew! I’m famished!” (That is why he was also called Edom. )
01025031 Jacob replied, “First sell me your birthright.”
01025032 “Look, I am about to die,” Esau said. “What good is the birthright to me?”
01025033 But Jacob said, “Swear to me first.” So he swore an oath to him, selling his birthright to Jacob.
01025034 Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and some lentil stew. He ate and drank, and then got up and left. So Esau despised his birthright.
01026001 Now there was a famine in the land—besides the previous famine in Abraham’s time—and Isaac went to Abimelek king of the Philistines in Gerar.
01026002 The Lord appeared to Isaac and said, “Do not go down to Egypt; live in the land where I tell you to live.
01026003 Stay in this land for a while, and I will be with you and will bless you. For to you and your descendants I will give all these lands and will confirm the oath I swore to your father Abraham.
01026004 I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and will give them all these lands, and through your offspring all nations on earth will be blessed,
01026005 because Abraham obeyed me and did everything I required of him, keeping my commands, my decrees and my instructions.”
01026006 So Isaac stayed in Gerar.
01026007 When the men of that place asked him about his wife, he said, “She is my sister,” because he was afraid to say, “She is my wife.” He thought, “The men of this place might kill me on account of Rebekah, because she is beautiful.”
01026008 When Isaac had been there a long time, Abimelek king of the Philistines looked down from a window and saw Isaac caressing his wife Rebekah.
01026009 So Abimelek summoned Isaac and said, “She is really your wife! Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’?” Isaac answered him, “Because I thought I might lose my life on account of her.”
01026010 Then Abimelek said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the men might well have slept with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us.”
01026011 So Abimelek gave orders to all the people: “Anyone who harms this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.”
01026012 Isaac planted crops in that land and the same year reaped a hundredfold, because the Lord blessed him.
01026013 The man became rich, and his wealth continued to grow until he became very wealthy.
01026014 He had so many flocks and herds and servants that the Philistines envied him.
01026015 So all the wells that his father’s servants had dug in the time of his father Abraham, the Philistines stopped up, filling them with earth.
01026016 Then Abimelek said to Isaac, “Move away from us; you have become too powerful for us.”
01026017 So Isaac moved away from there and encamped in the Valley of Gerar, where he settled.
01026018 Isaac reopened the wells that had been dug in the time of his father Abraham, which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham died, and he gave them the same names his father had given them.
01026019 Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and discovered a well of fresh water there.
01026020 But the herders of Gerar quarreled with those of Isaac and said, “The water is ours!” So he named the well Esek, because they disputed with him.
01026021 Then they dug another well, but they quarreled over that one also; so he named it Sitnah.
01026022 He moved on from there and dug another well, and no one quarreled over it. He named it Rehoboth, saying, “Now the Lord has given us room and we will flourish in the land.”
01026023 From there he went up to Beersheba.
01026024 That night the Lord appeared to him and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham. Do not be afraid, for I am with you; I will bless you and will increase the number of your descendants for the sake of my servant Abraham.”
01026025 Isaac built an altar there and called on the name of the Lord. There he pitched his tent, and there his servants dug a well.
01026026 Meanwhile, Abimelek had come to him from Gerar, with Ahuzzath his personal adviser and Phicol the commander of his forces.
01026027 Isaac asked them, “Why have you come to me, since you were hostile to me and sent me away?”
01026028 They answered, “We saw clearly that the Lord was with you; so we said, ‘There ought to be a sworn agreement between us’—between us and you. Let us make a treaty with you
01026029 that you will do us no harm, just as we did not harm you but always treated you well and sent you away peacefully. And now you are blessed by the Lord.”
01026030 Isaac then made a feast for them, and they ate and drank.
01026031 Early the next morning the men swore an oath to each other. Then Isaac sent them on their way, and they went away peacefully.
01026032 That day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well they had dug. They said, “We’ve found water!”
01026033 He called it Shibah, and to this day the name of the town has been Beersheba.
01026034 When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and also Basemath daughter of Elon the Hittite.
01026035 They were a source of grief to Isaac and Rebekah.
01027001 When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he could no longer see, he called for Esau his older son and said to him, “My son.” “Here I am,” he answered.
01027002 Isaac said, “I am now an old man and don’t know the day of my death.
01027003 Now then, get your equipment—your quiver and bow—and go out to the open country to hunt some wild game for me.
01027004 Prepare me the kind of tasty food I like and bring it to me to eat, so that I may give you my blessing before I die.”
01027005 Now Rebekah was listening as Isaac spoke to his son Esau. When Esau left for the open country to hunt game and bring it back,
01027006 Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “Look, I overheard your father say to your brother Esau,
01027007 ‘Bring me some game and prepare me some tasty food to eat, so that I may give you my blessing in the presence of the Lord before I die.’
01027008 Now, my son, listen carefully and do what I tell you:
01027009 Go out to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare some tasty food for your father, just the way he likes it.
01027010 Then take it to your father to eat, so that he may give you his blessing before he dies.”
01027011 Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, “But my brother Esau is a hairy man while I have smooth skin.
01027012 What if my father touches me? I would appear to be tricking him and would bring down a curse on myself rather than a blessing.”
01027013 His mother said to him, “My son, let the curse fall on me. Just do what I say; go and get them for me.”
01027014 So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and she prepared some tasty food, just the way his father liked it.
01027015 Then Rebekah took the best clothes of Esau her older son, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob.
01027016 She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the goatskins.
01027017 Then she handed to her son Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made.
01027018 He went to his father and said, “My father.” “Yes, my son,” he answered. “Who is it?”
01027019 Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.”
01027020 Isaac asked his son, “How did you find it so quickly, my son?” “The Lord your God gave me success,” he replied.
01027021 Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can touch you, my son, to know whether you really are my son Esau or not.”
01027022 Jacob went close to his father Isaac, who touched him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.”
01027023 He did not recognize him, for his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he proceeded to bless him.
01027024 “Are you really my son Esau?” he asked. “I am,” he replied.
01027025 Then he said, “My son, bring me some of your game to eat, so that I may give you my blessing.” Jacob brought it to him and he ate; and he brought some wine and he drank.
01027026 Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come here, my son, and kiss me.”
01027027 So he went to him and kissed him. When Isaac caught the smell of his clothes, he blessed him and said, “Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the Lord has blessed.
01027028 May God give you heaven’s dew and earth’s richness— an abundance of grain and new wine.
01027029 May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you. Be lord over your brothers, and may the sons of your mother bow down to you. May those who curse you be cursed and those who bless you be blessed.”
01027030 After Isaac finished blessing him, and Jacob had scarcely left his father’s presence, his brother Esau came in from hunting.
01027031 He too prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. Then he said to him, “My father, please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.”
01027032 His father Isaac asked him, “Who are you?” “I am your son,” he answered, “your firstborn, Esau.”
01027033 Isaac trembled violently and said, “Who was it, then, that hunted game and brought it to me? I ate it just before you came and I blessed him—and indeed he will be blessed!”
01027034 When Esau heard his father’s words, he burst out with a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me—me too, my father!”
01027035 But he said, “Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing.”
01027036 Esau said, “Isn’t he rightly named Jacob ? This is the second time he has taken advantage of me: He took my birthright, and now he’s taken my blessing!” Then he asked, “Haven’t you reserved any blessing for me?”
01027037 Isaac answered Esau, “I have made him lord over you and have made all his relatives his servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?”
01027038 Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, my father!” Then Esau wept aloud.
01027039 His father Isaac answered him, “Your dwelling will be away from the earth’s richness, away from the dew of heaven above.
01027040 You will live by the sword and you will serve your brother. But when you grow restless, you will throw his yoke from off your neck.”
01027041 Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. He said to himself, “The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob.”
01027042 When Rebekah was told what her older son Esau had said, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, “Your brother Esau is planning to avenge himself by killing you.
01027043 Now then, my son, do what I say: Flee at once to my brother Laban in Harran.
01027044 Stay with him for a while until your brother’s fury subsides.
01027045 When your brother is no longer angry with you and forgets what you did to him, I’ll send word for you to come back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
01027046 Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I’m disgusted with living because of these Hittite women. If Jacob takes a wife from among the women of this land, from Hittite women like these, my life will not be worth living.”
01028001 So Isaac called for Jacob and blessed him. Then he commanded him: “Do not marry a Canaanite woman.
01028002 Go at once to Paddan Aram, to the house of your mother’s father Bethuel. Take a wife for yourself there, from among the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.
01028003 May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful and increase your numbers until you become a community of peoples.
01028004 May he give you and your descendants the blessing given to Abraham, so that you may take possession of the land where you now reside as a foreigner, the land God gave to Abraham.”
01028005 Then Isaac sent Jacob on his way, and he went to Paddan Aram, to Laban son of Bethuel the Aramean, the brother of Rebekah, who was the mother of Jacob and Esau.
01028006 Now Esau learned that Isaac had blessed Jacob and had sent him to Paddan Aram to take a wife from there, and that when he blessed him he commanded him, “Do not marry a Canaanite woman,”
01028007 and that Jacob had obeyed his father and mother and had gone to Paddan Aram.
01028008 Esau then realized how displeasing the Canaanite women were to his father Isaac;
01028009 so he went to Ishmael and married Mahalath, the sister of Nebaioth and daughter of Ishmael son of Abraham, in addition to the wives he already had.
01028010 Jacob left Beersheba and set out for Harran.
01028011 When he reached a certain place, he stopped for the night because the sun had set. Taking one of the stones there, he put it under his head and lay down to sleep.
01028012 He had a dream in which he saw a stairway resting on the earth, with its top reaching to heaven, and the angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
01028013 There above it stood the Lord, and he said: “I am the Lord, the God of your father Abraham and the God of Isaac. I will give you and your descendants the land on which you are lying.
01028014 Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread out to the west and to the east, to the north and to the south. All peoples on earth will be blessed through you and your offspring.
01028015 I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you.”
01028016 When Jacob awoke from his sleep, he thought, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I was not aware of it.”
01028017 He was afraid and said, “How awesome is this place! This is none other than the house of God; this is the gate of heaven.”
01028018 Early the next morning Jacob took the stone he had placed under his head and set it up as a pillar and poured oil on top of it.
01028019 He called that place Bethel, though the city used to be called Luz.
01028020 Then Jacob made a vow, saying, “If God will be with me and will watch over me on this journey I am taking and will give me food to eat and clothes to wear
01028021 so that I return safely to my father’s household, then the Lord will be my God
01028022 and this stone that I have set up as a pillar will be God’s house, and of all that you give me I will give you a tenth.”
01029001 Then Jacob continued on his journey and came to the land of the eastern peoples.
01029002 There he saw a well in the open country, with three flocks of sheep lying near it because the flocks were watered from that well. The stone over the mouth of the well was large.
01029003 When all the flocks were gathered there, the shepherds would roll the stone away from the well’s mouth and water the sheep. Then they would return the stone to its place over the mouth of the well.
01029004 Jacob asked the shepherds, “My brothers, where are you from?” “We’re from Harran,” they replied.
01029005 He said to them, “Do you know Laban, Nahor’s grandson?” “Yes, we know him,” they answered.
01029006 Then Jacob asked them, “Is he well?” “Yes, he is,” they said, “and here comes his daughter Rachel with the sheep.”
01029007 “Look,” he said, “the sun is still high; it is not time for the flocks to be gathered. Water the sheep and take them back to pasture.”
01029008 “We can’t,” they replied, “until all the flocks are gathered and the stone has been rolled away from the mouth of the well. Then we will water the sheep.”
01029009 While he was still talking with them, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she was a shepherd.
01029010 When Jacob saw Rachel daughter of his uncle Laban, and Laban’s sheep, he went over and rolled the stone away from the mouth of the well and watered his uncle’s sheep.
01029011 Then Jacob kissed Rachel and began to weep aloud.
01029012 He had told Rachel that he was a relative of her father and a son of Rebekah. So she ran and told her father.
01029013 As soon as Laban heard the news about Jacob, his sister’s son, he hurried to meet him. He embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his home, and there Jacob told him all these things.
01029014 Then Laban said to him, “You are my own flesh and blood.” After Jacob had stayed with him for a whole month,
01029015 Laban said to him, “Just because you are a relative of mine, should you work for me for nothing? Tell me what your wages should be.”
01029016 Now Laban had two daughters; the name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.
01029017 Leah had weak eyes, but Rachel had a lovely figure and was beautiful.
01029018 Jacob was in love with Rachel and said, “I’ll work for you seven years in return for your younger daughter Rachel.”
01029019 Laban said, “It’s better that I give her to you than to some other man. Stay here with me.”
01029020 So Jacob served seven years to get Rachel, but they seemed like only a few days to him because of his love for her.
01029021 Then Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife. My time is completed, and I want to make love to her.”
01029022 So Laban brought together all the people of the place and gave a feast.
01029023 But when evening came, he took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob made love to her.
01029024 And Laban gave his servant Zilpah to his daughter as her attendant.
01029025 When morning came, there was Leah! So Jacob said to Laban, “What is this you have done to me? I served you for Rachel, didn’t I? Why have you deceived me?”
01029026 Laban replied, “It is not our custom here to give the younger daughter in marriage before the older one.
01029027 Finish this daughter’s bridal week; then we will give you the younger one also, in return for another seven years of work.”
01029028 And Jacob did so. He finished the week with Leah, and then Laban gave him his daughter Rachel to be his wife.
01029029 Laban gave his servant Bilhah to his daughter Rachel as her attendant.
01029030 Jacob made love to Rachel also, and his love for Rachel was greater than his love for Leah. And he worked for Laban another seven years.
01029031 When the Lord saw that Leah was not loved, he enabled her to conceive, but Rachel remained childless.
01029032 Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben, for she said, “It is because the Lord has seen my misery. Surely my husband will love me now.”
01029033 She conceived again, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “Because the Lord heard that I am not loved, he gave me this one too.” So she named him Simeon.
01029034 Again she conceived, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “Now at last my husband will become attached to me, because I have borne him three sons.” So he was named Levi.
01029035 She conceived again, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “This time I will praise the Lord.” So she named him Judah. Then she stopped having children.
01030001 When Rachel saw that she was not bearing Jacob any children, she became jealous of her sister. So she said to Jacob, “Give me children, or I’ll die!”
01030002 Jacob became angry with her and said, “Am I in the place of God, who has kept you from having children?”
01030003 Then she said, “Here is Bilhah, my servant. Sleep with her so that she can bear children for me and I too can build a family through her.”
01030004 So she gave him her servant Bilhah as a wife. Jacob slept with her,
01030005 and she became pregnant and bore him a son.
01030006 Then Rachel said, “God has vindicated me; he has listened to my plea and given me a son.” Because of this she named him Dan.
01030007 Rachel’s servant Bilhah conceived again and bore Jacob a second son.
01030008 Then Rachel said, “I have had a great struggle with my sister, and I have won.” So she named him Naphtali.
01030009 When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took her servant Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
01030010 Leah’s servant Zilpah bore Jacob a son.
01030011 Then Leah said, “What good fortune!” So she named him Gad.
01030012 Leah’s servant Zilpah bore Jacob a second son.
01030013 Then Leah said, “How happy I am! The women will call me happy.” So she named him Asher.
01030014 During wheat harvest, Reuben went out into the fields and found some mandrake plants, which he brought to his mother Leah. Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
01030015 But she said to her, “Wasn’t it enough that you took away my husband? Will you take my son’s mandrakes too?” “Very well,” Rachel said, “he can sleep with you tonight in return for your son’s mandrakes.”
01030016 So when Jacob came in from the fields that evening, Leah went out to meet him. “You must sleep with me,” she said. “I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.” So he slept with her that night.
01030017 God listened to Leah, and she became pregnant and bore Jacob a fifth son.
01030018 Then Leah said, “God has rewarded me for giving my servant to my husband.” So she named him Issachar.
01030019 Leah conceived again and bore Jacob a sixth son.
01030020 Then Leah said, “God has presented me with a precious gift. This time my husband will treat me with honor, because I have borne him six sons.” So she named him Zebulun.
01030021 Some time later she gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
01030022 Then God remembered Rachel; he listened to her and enabled her to conceive.
01030023 She became pregnant and gave birth to a son and said, “God has taken away my disgrace.”
01030024 She named him Joseph, and said, “May the Lord add to me another son.”
01030025 After Rachel gave birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me on my way so I can go back to my own homeland.
01030026 Give me my wives and children, for whom I have served you, and I will be on my way. You know how much work I’ve done for you.”
01030027 But Laban said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, please stay. I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you.”
01030028 He added, “Name your wages, and I will pay them.”
01030029 Jacob said to him, “You know how I have worked for you and how your livestock has fared under my care.
01030030 The little you had before I came has increased greatly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I have been. But now, when may I do something for my own household?”
01030031 “What shall I give you?” he asked. “Don’t give me anything,” Jacob replied. “But if you will do this one thing for me, I will go on tending your flocks and watching over them:
01030032 Let me go through all your flocks today and remove from them every speckled or spotted sheep, every dark-colored lamb and every spotted or speckled goat. They will be my wages.
01030033 And my honesty will testify for me in the future, whenever you check on the wages you have paid me. Any goat in my possession that is not speckled or spotted, or any lamb that is not dark-colored, will be considered stolen.”
01030034 “Agreed,” said Laban. “Let it be as you have said.”
01030035 That same day he removed all the male goats that were streaked or spotted, and all the speckled or spotted female goats (all that had white on them) and all the dark-colored lambs, and he placed them in the care of his sons.
01030036 Then he put a three-day journey between himself and Jacob, while Jacob continued to tend the rest of Laban’s flocks.
01030037 Jacob, however, took fresh-cut branches from poplar, almond and plane trees and made white stripes on them by peeling the bark and exposing the white inner wood of the branches.
01030038 Then he placed the peeled branches in all the watering troughs, so that they would be directly in front of the flocks when they came to drink. When the flocks were in heat and came to drink,
01030039 they mated in front of the branches. And they bore young that were streaked or speckled or spotted.
01030040 Jacob set apart the young of the flock by themselves, but made the rest face the streaked and dark-colored animals that belonged to Laban. Thus he made separate flocks for himself and did not put them with Laban’s animals.
01030041 Whenever the stronger females were in heat, Jacob would place the branches in the troughs in front of the animals so they would mate near the branches,
01030042 but if the animals were weak, he would not place them there. So the weak animals went to Laban and the strong ones to Jacob.
01030043 In this way the man grew exceedingly prosperous and came to own large flocks, and female and male servants, and camels and donkeys.
01031001 Jacob heard that Laban’s sons were saying, “Jacob has taken everything our father owned and has gained all this wealth from what belonged to our father.”
01031002 And Jacob noticed that Laban’s attitude toward him was not what it had been.
01031003 Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Go back to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.”
01031004 So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were.
01031005 He said to them, “I see that your father’s attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.
01031006 You know that I’ve worked for your father with all my strength,
01031007 yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times. However, God has not allowed him to harm me.
01031008 If he said, ‘The speckled ones will be your wages,’ then all the flocks gave birth to speckled young; and if he said, ‘The streaked ones will be your wages,’ then all the flocks bore streaked young.
01031009 So God has taken away your father’s livestock and has given them to me.
01031010 “In breeding season I once had a dream in which I looked up and saw that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled or spotted.
01031011 The angel of God said to me in the dream, ‘Jacob.’ I answered, ‘Here I am.’
01031012 And he said, ‘Look up and see that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled or spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.
01031013 I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a pillar and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land at once and go back to your native land.’ ”
01031014 Then Rachel and Leah replied, “Do we still have any share in the inheritance of our father’s estate?
01031015 Does he not regard us as foreigners? Not only has he sold us, but he has used up what was paid for us.
01031016 Surely all the wealth that God took away from our father belongs to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you.”
01031017 Then Jacob put his children and his wives on camels,
01031018 and he drove all his livestock ahead of him, along with all the goods he had accumulated in Paddan Aram, to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.
01031019 When Laban had gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father’s household gods.
01031020 Moreover, Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean by not telling him he was running away.
01031021 So he fled with all he had, crossed the Euphrates River, and headed for the hill country of Gilead.
01031022 On the third day Laban was told that Jacob had fled.
01031023 Taking his relatives with him, he pursued Jacob for seven days and caught up with him in the hill country of Gilead.
01031024 Then God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night and said to him, “Be careful not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad.”
01031025 Jacob had pitched his tent in the hill country of Gilead when Laban overtook him, and Laban and his relatives camped there too.
01031026 Then Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done? You’ve deceived me, and you’ve carried off my daughters like captives in war.
01031027 Why did you run off secretly and deceive me? Why didn’t you tell me, so I could send you away with joy and singing to the music of timbrels and harps?
01031028 You didn’t even let me kiss my grandchildren and my daughters goodbye. You have done a foolish thing.
01031029 I have the power to harm you; but last night the God of your father said to me, ‘Be careful not to say anything to Jacob, either good or bad.’
01031030 Now you have gone off because you longed to return to your father’s household. But why did you steal my gods?”
01031031 Jacob answered Laban, “I was afraid, because I thought you would take your daughters away from me by force.
01031032 But if you find anyone who has your gods, that person shall not live. In the presence of our relatives, see for yourself whether there is anything of yours here with me; and if so, take it.” Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen the gods.
01031033 So Laban went into Jacob’s tent and into Leah’s tent and into the tent of the two female servants, but he found nothing. After he came out of Leah’s tent, he entered Rachel’s tent.
01031034 Now Rachel had taken the household gods and put them inside her camel’s saddle and was sitting on them. Laban searched through everything in the tent but found nothing.
01031035 Rachel said to her father, “Don’t be angry, my lord, that I cannot stand up in your presence; I’m having my period.” So he searched but could not find the household gods.
01031036 Jacob was angry and took Laban to task. “What is my crime?” he asked Laban. “How have I wronged you that you hunt me down?
01031037 Now that you have searched through all my goods, what have you found that belongs to your household? Put it here in front of your relatives and mine, and let them judge between the two of us.
01031038 “I have been with you for twenty years now. Your sheep and goats have not miscarried, nor have I eaten rams from your flocks.
01031039 I did not bring you animals torn by wild beasts; I bore the loss myself. And you demanded payment from me for whatever was stolen by day or night.
01031040 This was my situation: The heat consumed me in the daytime and the cold at night, and sleep fled from my eyes.
01031041 It was like this for the twenty years I was in your household. I worked for you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flocks, and you changed my wages ten times.
01031042 If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been with me, you would surely have sent me away empty-handed. But God has seen my hardship and the toil of my hands, and last night he rebuked you.”
01031043 Laban answered Jacob, “The women are my daughters, the children are my children, and the flocks are my flocks. All you see is mine. Yet what can I do today about these daughters of mine, or about the children they have borne?
01031044 Come now, let’s make a covenant, you and I, and let it serve as a witness between us.”
01031045 So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a pillar.
01031046 He said to his relatives, “Gather some stones.” So they took stones and piled them in a heap, and they ate there by the heap.
01031047 Laban called it Jegar Sahadutha, and Jacob called it Galeed.
01031048 Laban said, “This heap is a witness between you and me today.” That is why it was called Galeed.
01031049 It was also called Mizpah, because he said, “May the Lord keep watch between you and me when we are away from each other.
01031050 If you mistreat my daughters or if you take any wives besides my daughters, even though no one is with us, remember that God is a witness between you and me.”
01031051 Laban also said to Jacob, “Here is this heap, and here is this pillar I have set up between you and me.
01031052 This heap is a witness, and this pillar is a witness, that I will not go past this heap to your side to harm you and that you will not go past this heap and pillar to my side to harm me.
01031053 May the God of Abraham and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us.” So Jacob took an oath in the name of the Fear of his father Isaac.
01031054 He offered a sacrifice there in the hill country and invited his relatives to a meal. After they had eaten, they spent the night there.
01031055 Early the next morning Laban kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them. Then he left and returned home.
01032001 Jacob also went on his way, and the angels of God met him.
01032002 When Jacob saw them, he said, “This is the camp of God!” So he named that place Mahanaim.
01032003 Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom.
01032004 He instructed them: “This is what you are to say to my lord Esau: ‘Your servant Jacob says, I have been staying with Laban and have remained there till now.
01032005 I have cattle and donkeys, sheep and goats, male and female servants. Now I am sending this message to my lord, that I may find favor in your eyes.’ ”
01032006 When the messengers returned to Jacob, they said, “We went to your brother Esau, and now he is coming to meet you, and four hundred men are with him.”
01032007 In great fear and distress Jacob divided the people who were with him into two groups, and the flocks and herds and camels as well.
01032008 He thought, “If Esau comes and attacks one group, the group that is left may escape.”
01032009 Then Jacob prayed, “O God of my father Abraham, God of my father Isaac, Lord, you who said to me, ‘Go back to your country and your relatives, and I will make you prosper,’
01032010 I am unworthy of all the kindness and faithfulness you have shown your servant. I had only my staff when I crossed this Jordan, but now I have become two camps.
01032011 Save me, I pray, from the hand of my brother Esau, for I am afraid he will come and attack me, and also the mothers with their children.
01032012 But you have said, ‘I will surely make you prosper and will make your descendants like the sand of the sea, which cannot be counted.’ ”
01032013 He spent the night there, and from what he had with him he selected a gift for his brother Esau:
01032014 two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
01032015 thirty female camels with their young, forty cows and ten bulls, and twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
01032016 He put them in the care of his servants, each herd by itself, and said to his servants, “Go ahead of me, and keep some space between the herds.”
01032017 He instructed the one in the lead: “When my brother Esau meets you and asks, ‘Who do you belong to, and where are you going, and who owns all these animals in front of you?’
01032018 then you are to say, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob. They are a gift sent to my lord Esau, and he is coming behind us.’ ”
01032019 He also instructed the second, the third and all the others who followed the herds: “You are to say the same thing to Esau when you meet him.
01032020 And be sure to say, ‘Your servant Jacob is coming behind us.’ ” For he thought, “I will pacify him with these gifts I am sending on ahead; later, when I see him, perhaps he will receive me.”
01032021 So Jacob’s gifts went on ahead of him, but he himself spent the night in the camp.
01032022 That night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two female servants and his eleven sons and crossed the ford of the Jabbok.
01032023 After he had sent them across the stream, he sent over all his possessions.
01032024 So Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him till daybreak.
01032025 When the man saw that he could not overpower him, he touched the socket of Jacob’s hip so that his hip was wrenched as he wrestled with the man.
01032026 Then the man said, “Let me go, for it is daybreak.” But Jacob replied, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.”
01032027 The man asked him, “What is your name?” “Jacob,” he answered.
01032028 Then the man said, “Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel, because you have struggled with God and with humans and have overcome.”
01032029 Jacob said, “Please tell me your name.” But he replied, “Why do you ask my name?” Then he blessed him there.
01032030 So Jacob called the place Peniel, saying, “It is because I saw God face to face, and yet my life was spared.”
01032031 The sun rose above him as he passed Peniel, and he was limping because of his hip.
01032032 Therefore to this day the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the socket of the hip, because the socket of Jacob’s hip was touched near the tendon.
01033001 Jacob looked up and there was Esau, coming with his four hundred men; so he divided the children among Leah, Rachel and the two female servants.
01033002 He put the female servants and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph in the rear.
01033003 He himself went on ahead and bowed down to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.
01033004 But Esau ran to meet Jacob and embraced him; he threw his arms around his neck and kissed him. And they wept.
01033005 Then Esau looked up and saw the women and children. “Who are these with you?” he asked. Jacob answered, “They are the children God has graciously given your servant.”
01033006 Then the female servants and their children approached and bowed down.
01033007 Next, Leah and her children came and bowed down. Last of all came Joseph and Rachel, and they too bowed down.
01033008 Esau asked, “What’s the meaning of all these flocks and herds I met?” “To find favor in your eyes, my lord,” he said.
01033009 But Esau said, “I already have plenty, my brother. Keep what you have for yourself.”
01033010 “No, please!” said Jacob. “If I have found favor in your eyes, accept this gift from me. For to see your face is like seeing the face of God, now that you have received me favorably.
01033011 Please accept the present that was brought to you, for God has been gracious to me and I have all I need.” And because Jacob insisted, Esau accepted it.
01033012 Then Esau said, “Let us be on our way; I’ll accompany you.”
01033013 But Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are tender and that I must care for the ewes and cows that are nursing their young. If they are driven hard just one day, all the animals will die.
01033014 So let my lord go on ahead of his servant, while I move along slowly at the pace of the flocks and herds before me and the pace of the children, until I come to my lord in Seir.”
01033015 Esau said, “Then let me leave some of my men with you.” “But why do that?” Jacob asked. “Just let me find favor in the eyes of my lord.”
01033016 So that day Esau started on his way back to Seir.
01033017 Jacob, however, went to Sukkoth, where he built a place for himself and made shelters for his livestock. That is why the place is called Sukkoth.
01033018 After Jacob came from Paddan Aram, he arrived safely at the city of Shechem in Canaan and camped within sight of the city.
01033019 For a hundred pieces of silver, he bought from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, the plot of ground where he pitched his tent.
01033020 There he set up an altar and called it El Elohe Israel.
01034001 Now Dinah, the daughter Leah had borne to Jacob, went out to visit the women of the land.
01034002 When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, the ruler of that area, saw her, he took her and raped her.
01034003 His heart was drawn to Dinah daughter of Jacob; he loved the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.
01034004 And Shechem said to his father Hamor, “Get me this girl as my wife.”
01034005 When Jacob heard that his daughter Dinah had been defiled, his sons were in the fields with his livestock; so he did nothing about it until they came home.
01034006 Then Shechem’s father Hamor went out to talk with Jacob.
01034007 Meanwhile, Jacob’s sons had come in from the fields as soon as they heard what had happened. They were shocked and furious, because Shechem had done an outrageous thing in Israel by sleeping with Jacob’s daughter—a thing that should not be done.
01034008 But Hamor said to them, “My son Shechem has his heart set on your daughter. Please give her to him as his wife.
01034009 Intermarry with us; give us your daughters and take our daughters for yourselves.
01034010 You can settle among us; the land is open to you. Live in it, trade in it, and acquire property in it.”
01034011 Then Shechem said to Dinah’s father and brothers, “Let me find favor in your eyes, and I will give you whatever you ask.
01034012 Make the price for the bride and the gift I am to bring as great as you like, and I’ll pay whatever you ask me. Only give me the young woman as my wife.”
01034013 Because their sister Dinah had been defiled, Jacob’s sons replied deceitfully as they spoke to Shechem and his father Hamor.
01034014 They said to them, “We can’t do such a thing; we can’t give our sister to a man who is not circumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.
01034015 We will enter into an agreement with you on one condition only: that you become like us by circumcising all your males.
01034016 Then we will give you our daughters and take your daughters for ourselves. We’ll settle among you and become one people with you.
01034017 But if you will not agree to be circumcised, we’ll take our sister and go.”
01034018 Their proposal seemed good to Hamor and his son Shechem.
01034019 The young man, who was the most honored of all his father’s family, lost no time in doing what they said, because he was delighted with Jacob’s daughter.
01034020 So Hamor and his son Shechem went to the gate of their city to speak to the men of their city.
01034021 “These men are friendly toward us,” they said. “Let them live in our land and trade in it; the land has plenty of room for them. We can marry their daughters and they can marry ours.
01034022 But the men will agree to live with us as one people only on the condition that our males be circumcised, as they themselves are.
01034023 Won’t their livestock, their property and all their other animals become ours? So let us agree to their terms, and they will settle among us.”
01034024 All the men who went out of the city gate agreed with Hamor and his son Shechem, and every male in the city was circumcised.
01034025 Three days later, while all of them were still in pain, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, took their swords and attacked the unsuspecting city, killing every male.
01034026 They put Hamor and his son Shechem to the sword and took Dinah from Shechem’s house and left.
01034027 The sons of Jacob came upon the dead bodies and looted the city where their sister had been defiled.
01034028 They seized their flocks and herds and donkeys and everything else of theirs in the city and out in the fields.
01034029 They carried off all their wealth and all their women and children, taking as plunder everything in the houses.
01034030 Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought trouble on me by making me obnoxious to the Canaanites and Perizzites, the people living in this land. We are few in number, and if they join forces against me and attack me, I and my household will be destroyed.”
01034031 But they replied, “Should he have treated our sister like a prostitute?”
01035001 Then God said to Jacob, “Go up to Bethel and settle there, and build an altar there to God, who appeared to you when you were fleeing from your brother Esau.”
01035002 So Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, “Get rid of the foreign gods you have with you, and purify yourselves and change your clothes.
01035003 Then come, let us go up to Bethel, where I will build an altar to God, who answered me in the day of my distress and who has been with me wherever I have gone.”
01035004 So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods they had and the rings in their ears, and Jacob buried them under the oak at Shechem.
01035005 Then they set out, and the terror of God fell on the towns all around them so that no one pursued them.
01035006 Jacob and all the people with him came to Luz (that is, Bethel) in the land of Canaan.
01035007 There he built an altar, and he called the place El Bethel, because it was there that God revealed himself to him when he was fleeing from his brother.
01035008 Now Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried under the oak outside Bethel. So it was named Allon Bakuth.
01035009 After Jacob returned from Paddan Aram, God appeared to him again and blessed him.
01035010 God said to him, “Your name is Jacob, but you will no longer be called Jacob; your name will be Israel. ” So he named him Israel.
01035011 And God said to him, “I am God Almighty ; be fruitful and increase in number. A nation and a community of nations will come from you, and kings will be among your descendants.
01035012 The land I gave to Abraham and Isaac I also give to you, and I will give this land to your descendants after you.”
01035013 Then God went up from him at the place where he had talked with him.
01035014 Jacob set up a stone pillar at the place where God had talked with him, and he poured out a drink offering on it; he also poured oil on it.
01035015 Jacob called the place where God had talked with him Bethel.
01035016 Then they moved on from Bethel. While they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth and had great difficulty.
01035017 And as she was having great difficulty in childbirth, the midwife said to her, “Don’t despair, for you have another son.”
01035018 As she breathed her last—for she was dying—she named her son Ben-Oni. But his father named him Benjamin.
01035019 So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
01035020 Over her tomb Jacob set up a pillar, and to this day that pillar marks Rachel’s tomb.
01035021 Israel moved on again and pitched his tent beyond Migdal Eder.
01035022 While Israel was living in that region, Reuben went in and slept with his father’s concubine Bilhah, and Israel heard of it. Jacob had twelve sons:
01035023 The sons of Leah: Reuben the firstborn of Jacob, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar and Zebulun.
01035024 The sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
01035025 The sons of Rachel’s servant Bilhah: Dan and Naphtali.
01035026 The sons of Leah’s servant Zilpah: Gad and Asher. These were the sons of Jacob, who were born to him in Paddan Aram.
01035027 Jacob came home to his father Isaac in Mamre, near Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had stayed.
01035028 Isaac lived a hundred and eighty years.
01035029 Then he breathed his last and died and was gathered to his people, old and full of years. And his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
01036001 This is the account of the family line of Esau (that is, Edom).
01036002 Esau took his wives from the women of Canaan: Adah daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite—
01036003 also Basemath daughter of Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth.
01036004 Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, Basemath bore Reuel,
01036005 and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam and Korah. These were the sons of Esau, who were born to him in Canaan.
01036006 Esau took his wives and sons and daughters and all the members of his household, as well as his livestock and all his other animals and all the goods he had acquired in Canaan, and moved to a land some distance from his brother Jacob.
01036007 Their possessions were too great for them to remain together; the land where they were staying could not support them both because of their livestock.
01036008 So Esau (that is, Edom) settled in the hill country of Seir.
01036009 This is the account of the family line of Esau the father of the Edomites in the hill country of Seir.
01036010 These are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz, the son of Esau’s wife Adah, and Reuel, the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
01036011 The sons of Eliphaz: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam and Kenaz.
01036012 Esau’s son Eliphaz also had a concubine named Timna, who bore him Amalek. These were grandsons of Esau’s wife Adah.
01036013 The sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah and Mizzah. These were grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
01036014 The sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon, whom she bore to Esau: Jeush, Jalam and Korah.
01036015 These were the chiefs among Esau’s descendants: The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau: Chiefs Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
01036016 Korah, Gatam and Amalek. These were the chiefs descended from Eliphaz in Edom; they were grandsons of Adah.
01036017 The sons of Esau’s son Reuel: Chiefs Nahath, Zerah, Shammah and Mizzah. These were the chiefs descended from Reuel in Edom; they were grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
01036018 The sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah: Chiefs Jeush, Jalam and Korah. These were the chiefs descended from Esau’s wife Oholibamah daughter of Anah.
01036019 These were the sons of Esau (that is, Edom), and these were their chiefs.
01036020 These were the sons of Seir the Horite, who were living in the region: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
01036021 Dishon, Ezer and Dishan. These sons of Seir in Edom were Horite chiefs.
01036022 The sons of Lotan: Hori and Homam. Timna was Lotan’s sister.
01036023 The sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho and Onam.
01036024 The sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. This is the Anah who discovered the hot springs in the desert while he was grazing the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
01036025 The children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah daughter of Anah.
01036026 The sons of Dishon : Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran and Keran.
01036027 The sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan and Akan.
01036028 The sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
01036029 These were the Horite chiefs: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
01036030 Dishon, Ezer and Dishan. These were the Horite chiefs, according to their divisions, in the land of Seir.
01036031 These were the kings who reigned in Edom before any Israelite king reigned:
01036032 Bela son of Beor became king of Edom. His city was named Dinhabah.
01036033 When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah succeeded him as king.
01036034 When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites succeeded him as king.
01036035 When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the country of Moab, succeeded him as king. His city was named Avith.
01036036 When Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah succeeded him as king.
01036037 When Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the river succeeded him as king.
01036038 When Shaul died, Baal-Hanan son of Akbor succeeded him as king.
01036039 When Baal-Hanan son of Akbor died, Hadad succeeded him as king. His city was named Pau, and his wife’s name was Mehetabel daughter of Matred, the daughter of Me-Zahab.
01036040 These were the chiefs descended from Esau, by name, according to their clans and regions: Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
01036041 Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
01036042 Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
01036043 Magdiel and Iram. These were the chiefs of Edom, according to their settlements in the land they occupied. This is the family line of Esau, the father of the Edomites.
01037001 Jacob lived in the land where his father had stayed, the land of Canaan.
01037002 This is the account of Jacob’s family line. Joseph, a young man of seventeen, was tending the flocks with his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and the sons of Zilpah, his father’s wives, and he brought their father a bad report about them.
01037003 Now Israel loved Joseph more than any of his other sons, because he had been born to him in his old age; and he made an ornate robe for him.
01037004 When his brothers saw that their father loved him more than any of them, they hated him and could not speak a kind word to him.
01037005 Joseph had a dream, and when he told it to his brothers, they hated him all the more.
01037006 He said to them, “Listen to this dream I had:
01037007 We were binding sheaves of grain out in the field when suddenly my sheaf rose and stood upright, while your sheaves gathered around mine and bowed down to it.”
01037008 His brothers said to him, “Do you intend to reign over us? Will you actually rule us?” And they hated him all the more because of his dream and what he had said.
01037009 Then he had another dream, and he told it to his brothers. “Listen,” he said, “I had another dream, and this time the sun and moon and eleven stars were bowing down to me.”
01037010 When he told his father as well as his brothers, his father rebuked him and said, “What is this dream you had? Will your mother and I and your brothers actually come and bow down to the ground before you?”
01037011 His brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept the matter in mind.
01037012 Now his brothers had gone to graze their father’s flocks near Shechem,
01037013 and Israel said to Joseph, “As you know, your brothers are grazing the flocks near Shechem. Come, I am going to send you to them.” “Very well,” he replied.
01037014 So he said to him, “Go and see if all is well with your brothers and with the flocks, and bring word back to me.” Then he sent him off from the Valley of Hebron. When Joseph arrived at Shechem,
01037015 a man found him wandering around in the fields and asked him, “What are you looking for?”
01037016 He replied, “I’m looking for my brothers. Can you tell me where they are grazing their flocks?”
01037017 “They have moved on from here,” the man answered. “I heard them say, ‘Let’s go to Dothan.’ ” So Joseph went after his brothers and found them near Dothan.
01037018 But they saw him in the distance, and before he reached them, they plotted to kill him.
01037019 “Here comes that dreamer!” they said to each other.
01037020 “Come now, let’s kill him and throw him into one of these cisterns and say that a ferocious animal devoured him. Then we’ll see what comes of his dreams.”
01037021 When Reuben heard this, he tried to rescue him from their hands. “Let’s not take his life,” he said.
01037022 “Don’t shed any blood. Throw him into this cistern here in the wilderness, but don’t lay a hand on him.” Reuben said this to rescue him from them and take him back to his father.
01037023 So when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of his robe—the ornate robe he was wearing—
01037024 and they took him and threw him into the cistern. The cistern was empty; there was no water in it.
01037025 As they sat down to eat their meal, they looked up and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. Their camels were loaded with spices, balm and myrrh, and they were on their way to take them down to Egypt.
01037026 Judah said to his brothers, “What will we gain if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?
01037027 Come, let’s sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay our hands on him; after all, he is our brother, our own flesh and blood.” His brothers agreed.
01037028 So when the Midianite merchants came by, his brothers pulled Joseph up out of the cistern and sold him for twenty shekels of silver to the Ishmaelites, who took him to Egypt.
01037029 When Reuben returned to the cistern and saw that Joseph was not there, he tore his clothes.
01037030 He went back to his brothers and said, “The boy isn’t there! Where can I turn now?”
01037031 Then they got Joseph’s robe, slaughtered a goat and dipped the robe in the blood.
01037032 They took the ornate robe back to their father and said, “We found this. Examine it to see whether it is your son’s robe.”
01037033 He recognized it and said, “It is my son’s robe! Some ferocious animal has devoured him. Joseph has surely been torn to pieces.”
01037034 Then Jacob tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and mourned for his son many days.
01037035 All his sons and daughters came to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. “No,” he said, “I will continue to mourn until I join my son in the grave.” So his father wept for him.
01037036 Meanwhile, the Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, one of Pharaoh’s officials, the captain of the guard.
01038001 At that time, Judah left his brothers and went down to stay with a man of Adullam named Hirah.
01038002 There Judah met the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shua. He married her and made love to her;
01038003 she became pregnant and gave birth to a son, who was named Er.
01038004 She conceived again and gave birth to a son and named him Onan.
01038005 She gave birth to still another son and named him Shelah. It was at Kezib that she gave birth to him.
01038006 Judah got a wife for Er, his firstborn, and her name was Tamar.
01038007 But Er, Judah’s firstborn, was wicked in the Lord’s sight; so the Lord put him to death.
01038008 Then Judah said to Onan, “Sleep with your brother’s wife and fulfill your duty to her as a brother-in-law to raise up offspring for your brother.”
01038009 But Onan knew that the child would not be his; so whenever he slept with his brother’s wife, he spilled his semen on the ground to keep from providing offspring for his brother.
01038010 What he did was wicked in the Lord’s sight; so the Lord put him to death also.
01038011 Judah then said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Live as a widow in your father’s household until my son Shelah grows up.” For he thought, “He may die too, just like his brothers.” So Tamar went to live in her father’s household.
01038012 After a long time Judah’s wife, the daughter of Shua, died. When Judah had recovered from his grief, he went up to Timnah, to the men who were shearing his sheep, and his friend Hirah the Adullamite went with him.
01038013 When Tamar was told, “Your father-in-law is on his way to Timnah to shear his sheep,”
01038014 she took off her widow’s clothes, covered herself with a veil to disguise herself, and then sat down at the entrance to Enaim, which is on the road to Timnah. For she saw that, though Shelah had now grown up, she had not been given to him as his wife.
01038015 When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute, for she had covered her face.
01038016 Not realizing that she was his daughter-in-law, he went over to her by the roadside and said, “Come now, let me sleep with you.” “And what will you give me to sleep with you?” she asked.
01038017 “I’ll send you a young goat from my flock,” he said. “Will you give me something as a pledge until you send it?” she asked.
01038018 He said, “What pledge should I give you?” “Your seal and its cord, and the staff in your hand,” she answered. So he gave them to her and slept with her, and she became pregnant by him.
01038019 After she left, she took off her veil and put on her widow’s clothes again.
01038020 Meanwhile Judah sent the young goat by his friend the Adullamite in order to get his pledge back from the woman, but he did not find her.
01038021 He asked the men who lived there, “Where is the shrine prostitute who was beside the road at Enaim?” “There hasn’t been any shrine prostitute here,” they said.
01038022 So he went back to Judah and said, “I didn’t find her. Besides, the men who lived there said, ‘There hasn’t been any shrine prostitute here.’ ”
01038023 Then Judah said, “Let her keep what she has, or we will become a laughingstock. After all, I did send her this young goat, but you didn’t find her.”
01038024 About three months later Judah was told, “Your daughter-in-law Tamar is guilty of prostitution, and as a result she is now pregnant.” Judah said, “Bring her out and have her burned to death!”
01038025 As she was being brought out, she sent a message to her father-in-law. “I am pregnant by the man who owns these,” she said. And she added, “See if you recognize whose seal and cord and staff these are.”
01038026 Judah recognized them and said, “She is more righteous than I, since I wouldn’t give her to my son Shelah.” And he did not sleep with her again.
01038027 When the time came for her to give birth, there were twin boys in her womb.
01038028 As she was giving birth, one of them put out his hand; so the midwife took a scarlet thread and tied it on his wrist and said, “This one came out first.”
01038029 But when he drew back his hand, his brother came out, and she said, “So this is how you have broken out!” And he was named Perez.
01038030 Then his brother, who had the scarlet thread on his wrist, came out. And he was named Zerah.
01039001 Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian who was one of Pharaoh’s officials, the captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.
01039002 The Lord was with Joseph so that he prospered, and he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
01039003 When his master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord gave him success in everything he did,
01039004 Joseph found favor in his eyes and became his attendant. Potiphar put him in charge of his household, and he entrusted to his care everything he owned.
01039005 From the time he put him in charge of his household and of all that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The blessing of the Lord was on everything Potiphar had, both in the house and in the field.
01039006 So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph’s care; with Joseph in charge, he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate. Now Joseph was well-built and handsome,
01039007 and after a while his master’s wife took notice of Joseph and said, “Come to bed with me!”
01039008 But he refused. “With me in charge,” he told her, “my master does not concern himself with anything in the house; everything he owns he has entrusted to my care.
01039009 No one is greater in this house than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?”
01039010 And though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.
01039011 One day he went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants was inside.
01039012 She caught him by his cloak and said, “Come to bed with me!” But he left his cloak in her hand and ran out of the house.
01039013 When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,
01039014 she called her household servants. “Look,” she said to them, “this Hebrew has been brought to us to make sport of us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.
01039015 When he heard me scream for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house.”
01039016 She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.
01039017 Then she told him this story: “That Hebrew slave you brought us came to me to make sport of me.
01039018 But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house.”
01039019 When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, “This is how your slave treated me,” he burned with anger.
01039020 Joseph’s master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king’s prisoners were confined. But while Joseph was there in the prison,
01039021 the Lord was with him; he showed him kindness and granted him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
01039022 So the warden put Joseph in charge of all those held in the prison, and he was made responsible for all that was done there.
01039023 The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph’s care, because the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success in whatever he did.
01040001 Some time later, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt offended their master, the king of Egypt.
01040002 Pharaoh was angry with his two officials, the chief cupbearer and the chief baker,
01040003 and put them in custody in the house of the captain of the guard, in the same prison where Joseph was confined.
01040004 The captain of the guard assigned them to Joseph, and he attended them. After they had been in custody for some time,
01040005 each of the two men—the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were being held in prison—had a dream the same night, and each dream had a meaning of its own.
01040006 When Joseph came to them the next morning, he saw that they were dejected.
01040007 So he asked Pharaoh’s officials who were in custody with him in his master’s house, “Why do you look so sad today?”
01040008 “We both had dreams,” they answered, “but there is no one to interpret them.” Then Joseph said to them, “Do not interpretations belong to God? Tell me your dreams.”
01040009 So the chief cupbearer told Joseph his dream. He said to him, “In my dream I saw a vine in front of me,
01040010 and on the vine were three branches. As soon as it budded, it blossomed, and its clusters ripened into grapes.
01040011 Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes, squeezed them into Pharaoh’s cup and put the cup in his hand.”
01040012 “This is what it means,” Joseph said to him. “The three branches are three days.
01040013 Within three days Pharaoh will lift up your head and restore you to your position, and you will put Pharaoh’s cup in his hand, just as you used to do when you were his cupbearer.
01040014 But when all goes well with you, remember me and show me kindness; mention me to Pharaoh and get me out of this prison.
01040015 I was forcibly carried off from the land of the Hebrews, and even here I have done nothing to deserve being put in a dungeon.”
01040016 When the chief baker saw that Joseph had given a favorable interpretation, he said to Joseph, “I too had a dream: On my head were three baskets of bread.
01040017 In the top basket were all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head.”
01040018 “This is what it means,” Joseph said. “The three baskets are three days.
01040019 Within three days Pharaoh will lift off your head and impale your body on a pole. And the birds will eat away your flesh.”
01040020 Now the third day was Pharaoh’s birthday, and he gave a feast for all his officials. He lifted up the heads of the chief cupbearer and the chief baker in the presence of his officials:
01040021 He restored the chief cupbearer to his position, so that he once again put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand—
01040022 but he impaled the chief baker, just as Joseph had said to them in his interpretation.
01040023 The chief cupbearer, however, did not remember Joseph; he forgot him.
01041001 When two full years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream: He was standing by the Nile,
01041002 when out of the river there came up seven cows, sleek and fat, and they grazed among the reeds.
01041003 After them, seven other cows, ugly and gaunt, came up out of the Nile and stood beside those on the riverbank.
01041004 And the cows that were ugly and gaunt ate up the seven sleek, fat cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
01041005 He fell asleep again and had a second dream: Seven heads of grain, healthy and good, were growing on a single stalk.
01041006 After them, seven other heads of grain sprouted—thin and scorched by the east wind.
01041007 The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven healthy, full heads. Then Pharaoh woke up; it had been a dream.
01041008 In the morning his mind was troubled, so he sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but no one could interpret them for him.
01041009 Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, “Today I am reminded of my shortcomings.
01041010 Pharaoh was once angry with his servants, and he imprisoned me and the chief baker in the house of the captain of the guard.
01041011 Each of us had a dream the same night, and each dream had a meaning of its own.
01041012 Now a young Hebrew was there with us, a servant of the captain of the guard. We told him our dreams, and he interpreted them for us, giving each man the interpretation of his dream.
01041013 And things turned out exactly as he interpreted them to us: I was restored to my position, and the other man was impaled.”
01041014 So Pharaoh sent for Joseph, and he was quickly brought from the dungeon. When he had shaved and changed his clothes, he came before Pharaoh.
01041015 Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I had a dream, and no one can interpret it. But I have heard it said of you that when you hear a dream you can interpret it.”
01041016 “I cannot do it,” Joseph replied to Pharaoh, “but God will give Pharaoh the answer he desires.”
01041017 Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile,
01041018 when out of the river there came up seven cows, fat and sleek, and they grazed among the reeds.
01041019 After them, seven other cows came up—scrawny and very ugly and lean. I had never seen such ugly cows in all the land of Egypt.
01041020 The lean, ugly cows ate up the seven fat cows that came up first.
01041021 But even after they ate them, no one could tell that they had done so; they looked just as ugly as before. Then I woke up.
01041022 “In my dream I saw seven heads of grain, full and good, growing on a single stalk.
01041023 After them, seven other heads sprouted—withered and thin and scorched by the east wind.
01041024 The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven good heads. I told this to the magicians, but none of them could explain it to me.”
01041025 Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, “The dreams of Pharaoh are one and the same. God has revealed to Pharaoh what he is about to do.
01041026 The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good heads of grain are seven years; it is one and the same dream.
01041027 The seven lean, ugly cows that came up afterward are seven years, and so are the seven worthless heads of grain scorched by the east wind: They are seven years of famine.
01041028 “It is just as I said to Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what he is about to do.
01041029 Seven years of great abundance are coming throughout the land of Egypt,
01041030 but seven years of famine will follow them. Then all the abundance in Egypt will be forgotten, and the famine will ravage the land.
01041031 The abundance in the land will not be remembered, because the famine that follows it will be so severe.
01041032 The reason the dream was given to Pharaoh in two forms is that the matter has been firmly decided by God, and God will do it soon.
01041033 “And now let Pharaoh look for a discerning and wise man and put him in charge of the land of Egypt.
01041034 Let Pharaoh appoint commissioners over the land to take a fifth of the harvest of Egypt during the seven years of abundance.
01041035 They should collect all the food of these good years that are coming and store up the grain under the authority of Pharaoh, to be kept in the cities for food.
01041036 This food should be held in reserve for the country, to be used during the seven years of famine that will come upon Egypt, so that the country may not be ruined by the famine.”
01041037 The plan seemed good to Pharaoh and to all his officials.
01041038 So Pharaoh asked them, “Can we find anyone like this man, one in whom is the spirit of God ?”
01041039 Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one so discerning and wise as you.
01041040 You shall be in charge of my palace, and all my people are to submit to your orders. Only with respect to the throne will I be greater than you.”
01041041 So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I hereby put you in charge of the whole land of Egypt.”
01041042 Then Pharaoh took his signet ring from his finger and put it on Joseph’s finger. He dressed him in robes of fine linen and put a gold chain around his neck.
01041043 He had him ride in a chariot as his second-in-command, and people shouted before him, “Make way !” Thus he put him in charge of the whole land of Egypt.
01041044 Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, but without your word no one will lift hand or foot in all Egypt.”
01041045 Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-Paneah and gave him Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, to be his wife. And Joseph went throughout the land of Egypt.
01041046 Joseph was thirty years old when he entered the service of Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from Pharaoh’s presence and traveled throughout Egypt.
01041047 During the seven years of abundance the land produced plentifully.
01041048 Joseph collected all the food produced in those seven years of abundance in Egypt and stored it in the cities. In each city he put the food grown in the fields surrounding it.
01041049 Joseph stored up huge quantities of grain, like the sand of the sea; it was so much that he stopped keeping records because it was beyond measure.
01041050 Before the years of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph by Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
01041051 Joseph named his firstborn Manasseh and said, “It is because God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father’s household.”
01041052 The second son he named Ephraim and said, “It is because God has made me fruitful in the land of my suffering.”
01041053 The seven years of abundance in Egypt came to an end,
01041054 and the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was famine in all the other lands, but in the whole land of Egypt there was food.
01041055 When all Egypt began to feel the famine, the people cried to Pharaoh for food. Then Pharaoh told all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph and do what he tells you.”
01041056 When the famine had spread over the whole country, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians, for the famine was severe throughout Egypt.
01041057 And all the world came to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph, because the famine was severe everywhere.
01042001 When Jacob learned that there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, “Why do you just keep looking at each other?”
01042002 He continued, “I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us, so that we may live and not die.”
01042003 Then ten of Joseph’s brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
01042004 But Jacob did not send Benjamin, Joseph’s brother, with the others, because he was afraid that harm might come to him.
