01042005 So Israel’s sons were among those who went to buy grain, for there was famine in the land of Canaan also.
01042006 Now Joseph was the governor of the land, the person who sold grain to all its people. So when Joseph’s brothers arrived, they bowed down to him with their faces to the ground.
01042007 As soon as Joseph saw his brothers, he recognized them, but he pretended to be a stranger and spoke harshly to them. “Where do you come from?” he asked. “From the land of Canaan,” they replied, “to buy food.”
01042008 Although Joseph recognized his brothers, they did not recognize him.
01042009 Then he remembered his dreams about them and said to them, “You are spies! You have come to see where our land is unprotected.”
01042010 “No, my lord,” they answered. “Your servants have come to buy food.
01042011 We are all the sons of one man. Your servants are honest men, not spies.”
01042012 “No!” he said to them. “You have come to see where our land is unprotected.”
01042013 But they replied, “Your servants were twelve brothers, the sons of one man, who lives in the land of Canaan. The youngest is now with our father, and one is no more.”
01042014 Joseph said to them, “It is just as I told you: You are spies!
01042015 And this is how you will be tested: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you will not leave this place unless your youngest brother comes here.
01042016 Send one of your number to get your brother; the rest of you will be kept in prison, so that your words may be tested to see if you are telling the truth. If you are not, then as surely as Pharaoh lives, you are spies!”
01042017 And he put them all in custody for three days.
01042018 On the third day, Joseph said to them, “Do this and you will live, for I fear God:
01042019 If you are honest men, let one of your brothers stay here in prison, while the rest of you go and take grain back for your starving households.
01042020 But you must bring your youngest brother to me, so that your words may be verified and that you may not die.” This they proceeded to do.
01042021 They said to one another, “Surely we are being punished because of our brother. We saw how distressed he was when he pleaded with us for his life, but we would not listen; that’s why this distress has come on us.”
01042022 Reuben replied, “Didn’t I tell you not to sin against the boy? But you wouldn’t listen! Now we must give an accounting for his blood.”
01042023 They did not realize that Joseph could understand them, since he was using an interpreter.
01042024 He turned away from them and began to weep, but then came back and spoke to them again. He had Simeon taken from them and bound before their eyes.
01042025 Joseph gave orders to fill their bags with grain, to put each man’s silver back in his sack, and to give them provisions for their journey. After this was done for them,
01042026 they loaded their grain on their donkeys and left.
01042027 At the place where they stopped for the night one of them opened his sack to get feed for his donkey, and he saw his silver in the mouth of his sack.
01042028 “My silver has been returned,” he said to his brothers. “Here it is in my sack.” Their hearts sank and they turned to each other trembling and said, “What is this that God has done to us?”
01042029 When they came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, they told him all that had happened to them. They said,
01042030 “The man who is lord over the land spoke harshly to us and treated us as though we were spying on the land.
01042031 But we said to him, ‘We are honest men; we are not spies.
01042032 We were twelve brothers, sons of one father. One is no more, and the youngest is now with our father in Canaan.’
01042033 “Then the man who is lord over the land said to us, ‘This is how I will know whether you are honest men: Leave one of your brothers here with me, and take food for your starving households and go.
01042034 But bring your youngest brother to me so I will know that you are not spies but honest men. Then I will give your brother back to you, and you can trade in the land.’ ”
01042035 As they were emptying their sacks, there in each man’s sack was his pouch of silver! When they and their father saw the money pouches, they were frightened.
01042036 Their father Jacob said to them, “You have deprived me of my children. Joseph is no more and Simeon is no more, and now you want to take Benjamin. Everything is against me!”
01042037 Then Reuben said to his father, “You may put both of my sons to death if I do not bring him back to you. Entrust him to my care, and I will bring him back.”
01042038 But Jacob said, “My son will not go down there with you; his brother is dead and he is the only one left. If harm comes to him on the journey you are taking, you will bring my gray head down to the grave in sorrow.”
01043001 Now the famine was still severe in the land.
01043002 So when they had eaten all the grain they had brought from Egypt, their father said to them, “Go back and buy us a little more food.”
01043003 But Judah said to him, “The man warned us solemnly, ‘You will not see my face again unless your brother is with you.’
01043004 If you will send our brother along with us, we will go down and buy food for you.
01043005 But if you will not send him, we will not go down, because the man said to us, ‘You will not see my face again unless your brother is with you.’ ”
01043006 Israel asked, “Why did you bring this trouble on me by telling the man you had another brother?”
01043007 They replied, “The man questioned us closely about ourselves and our family. ‘Is your father still living?’ he asked us. ‘Do you have another brother?’ We simply answered his questions. How were we to know he would say, ‘Bring your brother down here’?”
01043008 Then Judah said to Israel his father, “Send the boy along with me and we will go at once, so that we and you and our children may live and not die.
01043009 I myself will guarantee his safety; you can hold me personally responsible for him. If I do not bring him back to you and set him here before you, I will bear the blame before you all my life.
01043010 As it is, if we had not delayed, we could have gone and returned twice.”
01043011 Then their father Israel said to them, “If it must be, then do this: Put some of the best products of the land in your bags and take them down to the man as a gift—a little balm and a little honey, some spices and myrrh, some pistachio nuts and almonds.
01043012 Take double the amount of silver with you, for you must return the silver that was put back into the mouths of your sacks. Perhaps it was a mistake.
01043013 Take your brother also and go back to the man at once.
01043014 And may God Almighty grant you mercy before the man so that he will let your other brother and Benjamin come back with you. As for me, if I am bereaved, I am bereaved.”
01043015 So the men took the gifts and double the amount of silver, and Benjamin also. They hurried down to Egypt and presented themselves to Joseph.
01043016 When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the steward of his house, “Take these men to my house, slaughter an animal and prepare a meal; they are to eat with me at noon.”
01043017 The man did as Joseph told him and took the men to Joseph’s house.
01043018 Now the men were frightened when they were taken to his house. They thought, “We were brought here because of the silver that was put back into our sacks the first time. He wants to attack us and overpower us and seize us as slaves and take our donkeys.”
01043019 So they went up to Joseph’s steward and spoke to him at the entrance to the house.
01043020 “We beg your pardon, our lord,” they said, “we came down here the first time to buy food.
01043021 But at the place where we stopped for the night we opened our sacks and each of us found his silver—the exact weight—in the mouth of his sack. So we have brought it back with us.
01043022 We have also brought additional silver with us to buy food. We don’t know who put our silver in our sacks.”
01043023 “It’s all right,” he said. “Don’t be afraid. Your God, the God of your father, has given you treasure in your sacks; I received your silver.” Then he brought Simeon out to them.
01043024 The steward took the men into Joseph’s house, gave them water to wash their feet and provided fodder for their donkeys.
01043025 They prepared their gifts for Joseph’s arrival at noon, because they had heard that they were to eat there.
01043026 When Joseph came home, they presented to him the gifts they had brought into the house, and they bowed down before him to the ground.
01043027 He asked them how they were, and then he said, “How is your aged father you told me about? Is he still living?”
01043028 They replied, “Your servant our father is still alive and well.” And they bowed down, prostrating themselves before him.
01043029 As he looked about and saw his brother Benjamin, his own mother’s son, he asked, “Is this your youngest brother, the one you told me about?” And he said, “God be gracious to you, my son.”
01043030 Deeply moved at the sight of his brother, Joseph hurried out and looked for a place to weep. He went into his private room and wept there.
01043031 After he had washed his face, he came out and, controlling himself, said, “Serve the food.”
01043032 They served him by himself, the brothers by themselves, and the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves, because Egyptians could not eat with Hebrews, for that is detestable to Egyptians.
01043033 The men had been seated before him in the order of their ages, from the firstborn to the youngest; and they looked at each other in astonishment.
01043034 When portions were served to them from Joseph’s table, Benjamin’s portion was five times as much as anyone else’s. So they feasted and drank freely with him.
01044001 Now Joseph gave these instructions to the steward of his house: “Fill the men’s sacks with as much food as they can carry, and put each man’s silver in the mouth of his sack.
01044002 Then put my cup, the silver one, in the mouth of the youngest one’s sack, along with the silver for his grain.” And he did as Joseph said.
01044003 As morning dawned, the men were sent on their way with their donkeys.
01044004 They had not gone far from the city when Joseph said to his steward, “Go after those men at once, and when you catch up with them, say to them, ‘Why have you repaid good with evil?
01044005 Isn’t this the cup my master drinks from and also uses for divination? This is a wicked thing you have done.’ ”
01044006 When he caught up with them, he repeated these words to them.
01044007 But they said to him, “Why does my lord say such things? Far be it from your servants to do anything like that!
01044008 We even brought back to you from the land of Canaan the silver we found inside the mouths of our sacks. So why would we steal silver or gold from your master’s house?
01044009 If any of your servants is found to have it, he will die; and the rest of us will become my lord’s slaves.”
01044010 “Very well, then,” he said, “let it be as you say. Whoever is found to have it will become my slave; the rest of you will be free from blame.”
01044011 Each of them quickly lowered his sack to the ground and opened it.
01044012 Then the steward proceeded to search, beginning with the oldest and ending with the youngest. And the cup was found in Benjamin’s sack.
01044013 At this, they tore their clothes. Then they all loaded their donkeys and returned to the city.
01044014 Joseph was still in the house when Judah and his brothers came in, and they threw themselves to the ground before him.
01044015 Joseph said to them, “What is this you have done? Don’t you know that a man like me can find things out by divination?”
01044016 “What can we say to my lord?” Judah replied. “What can we say? How can we prove our innocence? God has uncovered your servants’ guilt. We are now my lord’s slaves—we ourselves and the one who was found to have the cup.”
01044017 But Joseph said, “Far be it from me to do such a thing! Only the man who was found to have the cup will become my slave. The rest of you, go back to your father in peace.”
01044018 Then Judah went up to him and said: “Pardon your servant, my lord, let me speak a word to my lord. Do not be angry with your servant, though you are equal to Pharaoh himself.
01044019 My lord asked his servants, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
01044020 And we answered, ‘We have an aged father, and there is a young son born to him in his old age. His brother is dead, and he is the only one of his mother’s sons left, and his father loves him.’
01044021 “Then you said to your servants, ‘Bring him down to me so I can see him for myself.’
01044022 And we said to my lord, ‘The boy cannot leave his father; if he leaves him, his father will die.’
01044023 But you told your servants, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will not see my face again.’
01044024 When we went back to your servant my father, we told him what my lord had said.
01044025 “Then our father said, ‘Go back and buy a little more food.’
01044026 But we said, ‘We cannot go down. Only if our youngest brother is with us will we go. We cannot see the man’s face unless our youngest brother is with us.’
01044027 “Your servant my father said to us, ‘You know that my wife bore me two sons.
01044028 One of them went away from me, and I said, “He has surely been torn to pieces.” And I have not seen him since.
01044029 If you take this one from me too and harm comes to him, you will bring my gray head down to the grave in misery.’
01044030 “So now, if the boy is not with us when I go back to your servant my father, and if my father, whose life is closely bound up with the boy’s life,
01044031 sees that the boy isn’t there, he will die. Your servants will bring the gray head of our father down to the grave in sorrow.
01044032 Your servant guaranteed the boy’s safety to my father. I said, ‘If I do not bring him back to you, I will bear the blame before you, my father, all my life!’
01044033 “Now then, please let your servant remain here as my lord’s slave in place of the boy, and let the boy return with his brothers.
01044034 How can I go back to my father if the boy is not with me? No! Do not let me see the misery that would come on my father.”
01045001 Then Joseph could no longer control himself before all his attendants, and he cried out, “Have everyone leave my presence!” So there was no one with Joseph when he made himself known to his brothers.
01045002 And he wept so loudly that the Egyptians heard him, and Pharaoh’s household heard about it.
01045003 Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still living?” But his brothers were not able to answer him, because they were terrified at his presence.
01045004 Then Joseph said to his brothers, “Come close to me.” When they had done so, he said, “I am your brother Joseph, the one you sold into Egypt!
01045005 And now, do not be distressed and do not be angry with yourselves for selling me here, because it was to save lives that God sent me ahead of you.
01045006 For two years now there has been famine in the land, and for the next five years there will be no plowing and reaping.
01045007 But God sent me ahead of you to preserve for you a remnant on earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance.
01045008 “So then, it was not you who sent me here, but God. He made me father to Pharaoh, lord of his entire household and ruler of all Egypt.
01045009 Now hurry back to my father and say to him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says: God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me; don’t delay.
01045010 You shall live in the region of Goshen and be near me—you, your children and grandchildren, your flocks and herds, and all you have.
01045011 I will provide for you there, because five years of famine are still to come. Otherwise you and your household and all who belong to you will become destitute.’
01045012 “You can see for yourselves, and so can my brother Benjamin, that it is really I who am speaking to you.
01045013 Tell my father about all the honor accorded me in Egypt and about everything you have seen. And bring my father down here quickly.”
01045014 Then he threw his arms around his brother Benjamin and wept, and Benjamin embraced him, weeping.
01045015 And he kissed all his brothers and wept over them. Afterward his brothers talked with him.
01045016 When the news reached Pharaoh’s palace that Joseph’s brothers had come, Pharaoh and all his officials were pleased.
01045017 Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers, ‘Do this: Load your animals and return to the land of Canaan,
01045018 and bring your father and your families back to me. I will give you the best of the land of Egypt and you can enjoy the fat of the land.’
01045019 “You are also directed to tell them, ‘Do this: Take some carts from Egypt for your children and your wives, and get your father and come.
01045020 Never mind about your belongings, because the best of all Egypt will be yours.’ ”
01045021 So the sons of Israel did this. Joseph gave them carts, as Pharaoh had commanded, and he also gave them provisions for their journey.
01045022 To each of them he gave new clothing, but to Benjamin he gave three hundred shekels of silver and five sets of clothes.
01045023 And this is what he sent to his father: ten donkeys loaded with the best things of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain and bread and other provisions for his journey.
01045024 Then he sent his brothers away, and as they were leaving he said to them, “Don’t quarrel on the way!”
01045025 So they went up out of Egypt and came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan.
01045026 They told him, “Joseph is still alive! In fact, he is ruler of all Egypt.” Jacob was stunned; he did not believe them.
01045027 But when they told him everything Joseph had said to them, and when he saw the carts Joseph had sent to carry him back, the spirit of their father Jacob revived.
01045028 And Israel said, “I’m convinced! My son Joseph is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”
01046001 So Israel set out with all that was his, and when he reached Beersheba, he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
01046002 And God spoke to Israel in a vision at night and said, “Jacob! Jacob!” “Here I am,” he replied.
01046003 “I am God, the God of your father,” he said. “Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you into a great nation there.
01046004 I will go down to Egypt with you, and I will surely bring you back again. And Joseph’s own hand will close your eyes.”
01046005 Then Jacob left Beersheba, and Israel’s sons took their father Jacob and their children and their wives in the carts that Pharaoh had sent to transport him.
01046006 So Jacob and all his offspring went to Egypt, taking with them their livestock and the possessions they had acquired in Canaan.
01046007 Jacob brought with him to Egypt his sons and grandsons and his daughters and granddaughters—all his offspring.
01046008 These are the names of the sons of Israel (Jacob and his descendants) who went to Egypt: Reuben the firstborn of Jacob.
01046009 The sons of Reuben: Hanok, Pallu, Hezron and Karmi.
01046010 The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman.
01046011 The sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath and Merari.
01046012 The sons of Judah: Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez and Zerah (but Er and Onan had died in the land of Canaan). The sons of Perez: Hezron and Hamul.
01046013 The sons of Issachar: Tola, Puah, Jashub and Shimron.
01046014 The sons of Zebulun: Sered, Elon and Jahleel.
01046015 These were the sons Leah bore to Jacob in Paddan Aram, besides his daughter Dinah. These sons and daughters of his were thirty-three in all.
01046016 The sons of Gad: Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi and Areli.
01046017 The sons of Asher: Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi and Beriah. Their sister was Serah. The sons of Beriah: Heber and Malkiel.
01046018 These were the children born to Jacob by Zilpah, whom Laban had given to his daughter Leah—sixteen in all.
01046019 The sons of Jacob’s wife Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
01046020 In Egypt, Manasseh and Ephraim were born to Joseph by Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.
01046021 The sons of Benjamin: Bela, Beker, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim and Ard.
01046022 These were the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob—fourteen in all.
01046023 The son of Dan: Hushim.
01046024 The sons of Naphtali: Jahziel, Guni, Jezer and Shillem.
01046025 These were the sons born to Jacob by Bilhah, whom Laban had given to his daughter Rachel—seven in all.
01046026 All those who went to Egypt with Jacob—those who were his direct descendants, not counting his sons’ wives—numbered sixty-six persons.
01046027 With the two sons who had been born to Joseph in Egypt, the members of Jacob’s family, which went to Egypt, were seventy in all.
01046028 Now Jacob sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to get directions to Goshen. When they arrived in the region of Goshen,
01046029 Joseph had his chariot made ready and went to Goshen to meet his father Israel. As soon as Joseph appeared before him, he threw his arms around his father and wept for a long time.
01046030 Israel said to Joseph, “Now I am ready to die, since I have seen for myself that you are still alive.”
01046031 Then Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s household, “I will go up and speak to Pharaoh and will say to him, ‘My brothers and my father’s household, who were living in the land of Canaan, have come to me.
01046032 The men are shepherds; they tend livestock, and they have brought along their flocks and herds and everything they own.’
01046033 When Pharaoh calls you in and asks, ‘What is your occupation?’
01046034 you should answer, ‘Your servants have tended livestock from our boyhood on, just as our fathers did.’ Then you will be allowed to settle in the region of Goshen, for all shepherds are detestable to the Egyptians.”
01047001 Joseph went and told Pharaoh, “My father and brothers, with their flocks and herds and everything they own, have come from the land of Canaan and are now in Goshen.”
01047002 He chose five of his brothers and presented them before Pharaoh.
01047003 Pharaoh asked the brothers, “What is your occupation?” “Your servants are shepherds,” they replied to Pharaoh, “just as our fathers were.”
01047004 They also said to him, “We have come to live here for a while, because the famine is severe in Canaan and your servants’ flocks have no pasture. So now, please let your servants settle in Goshen.”
01047005 Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Your father and your brothers have come to you,
01047006 and the land of Egypt is before you; settle your father and your brothers in the best part of the land. Let them live in Goshen. And if you know of any among them with special ability, put them in charge of my own livestock.”
01047007 Then Joseph brought his father Jacob in and presented him before Pharaoh. After Jacob blessed Pharaoh,
01047008 Pharaoh asked him, “How old are you?”
01047009 And Jacob said to Pharaoh, “The years of my pilgrimage are a hundred and thirty. My years have been few and difficult, and they do not equal the years of the pilgrimage of my fathers.”
01047010 Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from his presence.
01047011 So Joseph settled his father and his brothers in Egypt and gave them property in the best part of the land, the district of Rameses, as Pharaoh directed.
01047012 Joseph also provided his father and his brothers and all his father’s household with food, according to the number of their children.
01047013 There was no food, however, in the whole region because the famine was severe; both Egypt and Canaan wasted away because of the famine.
01047014 Joseph collected all the money that was to be found in Egypt and Canaan in payment for the grain they were buying, and he brought it to Pharaoh’s palace.
01047015 When the money of the people of Egypt and Canaan was gone, all Egypt came to Joseph and said, “Give us food. Why should we die before your eyes? Our money is all gone.”
01047016 “Then bring your livestock,” said Joseph. “I will sell you food in exchange for your livestock, since your money is gone.”
01047017 So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and he gave them food in exchange for their horses, their sheep and goats, their cattle and donkeys. And he brought them through that year with food in exchange for all their livestock.
01047018 When that year was over, they came to him the following year and said, “We cannot hide from our lord the fact that since our money is gone and our livestock belongs to you, there is nothing left for our lord except our bodies and our land.
01047019 Why should we perish before your eyes—we and our land as well? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we with our land will be in bondage to Pharaoh. Give us seed so that we may live and not die, and that the land may not become desolate.”
01047020 So Joseph bought all the land in Egypt for Pharaoh. The Egyptians, one and all, sold their fields, because the famine was too severe for them. The land became Pharaoh’s,
01047021 and Joseph reduced the people to servitude, from one end of Egypt to the other.
01047022 However, he did not buy the land of the priests, because they received a regular allotment from Pharaoh and had food enough from the allotment Pharaoh gave them. That is why they did not sell their land.
01047023 Joseph said to the people, “Now that I have bought you and your land today for Pharaoh, here is seed for you so you can plant the ground.
01047024 But when the crop comes in, give a fifth of it to Pharaoh. The other four-fifths you may keep as seed for the fields and as food for yourselves and your households and your children.”
01047025 “You have saved our lives,” they said. “May we find favor in the eyes of our lord; we will be in bondage to Pharaoh.”
01047026 So Joseph established it as a law concerning land in Egypt—still in force today—that a fifth of the produce belongs to Pharaoh. It was only the land of the priests that did not become Pharaoh’s.
01047027 Now the Israelites settled in Egypt in the region of Goshen. They acquired property there and were fruitful and increased greatly in number.
01047028 Jacob lived in Egypt seventeen years, and the years of his life were a hundred and forty-seven.
01047029 When the time drew near for Israel to die, he called for his son Joseph and said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, put your hand under my thigh and promise that you will show me kindness and faithfulness. Do not bury me in Egypt,
01047030 but when I rest with my fathers, carry me out of Egypt and bury me where they are buried.” “I will do as you say,” he said.
01047031 “Swear to me,” he said. Then Joseph swore to him, and Israel worshiped as he leaned on the top of his staff.
01048001 Some time later Joseph was told, “Your father is ill.” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim along with him.
01048002 When Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph has come to you,” Israel rallied his strength and sat up on the bed.
01048003 Jacob said to Joseph, “God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and there he blessed me
01048004 and said to me, ‘I am going to make you fruitful and increase your numbers. I will make you a community of peoples, and I will give this land as an everlasting possession to your descendants after you.’
01048005 “Now then, your two sons born to you in Egypt before I came to you here will be reckoned as mine; Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine, just as Reuben and Simeon are mine.
01048006 Any children born to you after them will be yours; in the territory they inherit they will be reckoned under the names of their brothers.
01048007 As I was returning from Paddan, to my sorrow Rachel died in the land of Canaan while we were still on the way, a little distance from Ephrath. So I buried her there beside the road to Ephrath” (that is, Bethlehem).
01048008 When Israel saw the sons of Joseph, he asked, “Who are these?”
01048009 “They are the sons God has given me here,” Joseph said to his father. Then Israel said, “Bring them to me so I may bless them.”
01048010 Now Israel’s eyes were failing because of old age, and he could hardly see. So Joseph brought his sons close to him, and his father kissed them and embraced them.
01048011 Israel said to Joseph, “I never expected to see your face again, and now God has allowed me to see your children too.”
01048012 Then Joseph removed them from Israel’s knees and bowed down with his face to the ground.
01048013 And Joseph took both of them, Ephraim on his right toward Israel’s left hand and Manasseh on his left toward Israel’s right hand, and brought them close to him.
01048014 But Israel reached out his right hand and put it on Ephraim’s head, though he was the younger, and crossing his arms, he put his left hand on Manasseh’s head, even though Manasseh was the firstborn.
01048015 Then he blessed Joseph and said, “May the God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked faithfully, the God who has been my shepherd all my life to this day,
01048016 the Angel who has delivered me from all harm —may he bless these boys. May they be called by my name and the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac, and may they increase greatly on the earth.”
01048017 When Joseph saw his father placing his right hand on Ephraim’s head he was displeased; so he took hold of his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
01048018 Joseph said to him, “No, my father, this one is the firstborn; put your right hand on his head.”
01048019 But his father refused and said, “I know, my son, I know. He too will become a people, and he too will become great. Nevertheless, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his descendants will become a group of nations.”
01048020 He blessed them that day and said, “In your name will Israel pronounce this blessing: ‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.’ ” So he put Ephraim ahead of Manasseh.
01048021 Then Israel said to Joseph, “I am about to die, but God will be with you and take you back to the land of your fathers.
01048022 And to you I give one more ridge of land than to your brothers, the ridge I took from the Amorites with my sword and my bow.”
01049001 Then Jacob called for his sons and said: “Gather around so I can tell you what will happen to you in days to come.
01049002 “Assemble and listen, sons of Jacob; listen to your father Israel.
01049003 “Reuben, you are my firstborn, my might, the first sign of my strength, excelling in honor, excelling in power.
01049004 Turbulent as the waters, you will no longer excel, for you went up onto your father’s bed, onto my couch and defiled it.
01049005 “Simeon and Levi are brothers— their swords are weapons of violence.
01049006 Let me not enter their council, let me not join their assembly, for they have killed men in their anger and hamstrung oxen as they pleased.
01049007 Cursed be their anger, so fierce, and their fury, so cruel! I will scatter them in Jacob and disperse them in Israel.
01049008 “Judah, your brothers will praise you; your hand will be on the neck of your enemies; your father’s sons will bow down to you.
01049009 You are a lion’s cub, Judah; you return from the prey, my son. Like a lion he crouches and lies down, like a lioness—who dares to rouse him?
01049010 The scepter will not depart from Judah, nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet, until he to whom it belongs shall come and the obedience of the nations shall be his.
01049011 He will tether his donkey to a vine, his colt to the choicest branch; he will wash his garments in wine, his robes in the blood of grapes.
01049012 His eyes will be darker than wine, his teeth whiter than milk.
01049013 “Zebulun will live by the seashore and become a haven for ships; his border will extend toward Sidon.
01049014 “Issachar is a rawboned donkey lying down among the sheep pens.
01049015 When he sees how good is his resting place and how pleasant is his land, he will bend his shoulder to the burden and submit to forced labor.
01049016 “Dan will provide justice for his people as one of the tribes of Israel.
01049017 Dan will be a snake by the roadside, a viper along the path, that bites the horse’s heels so that its rider tumbles backward.
01049018 “I look for your deliverance, Lord.
01049019 “Gad will be attacked by a band of raiders, but he will attack them at their heels.
01049020 “Asher’s food will be rich; he will provide delicacies fit for a king.
01049021 “Naphtali is a doe set free that bears beautiful fawns.
01049022 “Joseph is a fruitful vine, a fruitful vine near a spring, whose branches climb over a wall.
01049023 With bitterness archers attacked him; they shot at him with hostility.
01049024 But his bow remained steady, his strong arms stayed limber, because of the hand of the Mighty One of Jacob, because of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,
01049025 because of your father’s God, who helps you, because of the Almighty, who blesses you with blessings of the skies above, blessings of the deep springs below, blessings of the breast and womb.
01049026 Your father’s blessings are greater than the blessings of the ancient mountains, than the bounty of the age-old hills. Let all these rest on the head of Joseph, on the brow of the prince among his brothers.
01049027 “Benjamin is a ravenous wolf; in the morning he devours the prey, in the evening he divides the plunder.”
01049028 All these are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said to them when he blessed them, giving each the blessing appropriate to him.
01049029 Then he gave them these instructions: “I am about to be gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
01049030 the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre in Canaan, which Abraham bought along with the field as a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.
01049031 There Abraham and his wife Sarah were buried, there Isaac and his wife Rebekah were buried, and there I buried Leah.
01049032 The field and the cave in it were bought from the Hittites. ”
01049033 When Jacob had finished giving instructions to his sons, he drew his feet up into the bed, breathed his last and was gathered to his people.
01050001 Joseph threw himself on his father and wept over him and kissed him.
01050002 Then Joseph directed the physicians in his service to embalm his father Israel. So the physicians embalmed him,
01050003 taking a full forty days, for that was the time required for embalming. And the Egyptians mourned for him seventy days.
01050004 When the days of mourning had passed, Joseph said to Pharaoh’s court, “If I have found favor in your eyes, speak to Pharaoh for me. Tell him,
01050005 ‘My father made me swear an oath and said, “I am about to die; bury me in the tomb I dug for myself in the land of Canaan.” Now let me go up and bury my father; then I will return.’ ”
01050006 Pharaoh said, “Go up and bury your father, as he made you swear to do.”
01050007 So Joseph went up to bury his father. All Pharaoh’s officials accompanied him—the dignitaries of his court and all the dignitaries of Egypt—
01050008 besides all the members of Joseph’s household and his brothers and those belonging to his father’s household. Only their children and their flocks and herds were left in Goshen.
01050009 Chariots and horsemen also went up with him. It was a very large company.
01050010 When they reached the threshing floor of Atad, near the Jordan, they lamented loudly and bitterly; and there Joseph observed a seven-day period of mourning for his father.
01050011 When the Canaanites who lived there saw the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “The Egyptians are holding a solemn ceremony of mourning.” That is why that place near the Jordan is called Abel Mizraim.
01050012 So Jacob’s sons did as he had commanded them:
01050013 They carried him to the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre, which Abraham had bought along with the field as a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.
01050014 After burying his father, Joseph returned to Egypt, together with his brothers and all the others who had gone with him to bury his father.
01050015 When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “What if Joseph holds a grudge against us and pays us back for all the wrongs we did to him?”
01050016 So they sent word to Joseph, saying, “Your father left these instructions before he died:
01050017 ‘This is what you are to say to Joseph: I ask you to forgive your brothers the sins and the wrongs they committed in treating you so badly.’ Now please forgive the sins of the servants of the God of your father.” When their message came to him, Joseph wept.
01050018 His brothers then came and threw themselves down before him. “We are your slaves,” they said.
01050019 But Joseph said to them, “Don’t be afraid. Am I in the place of God?
01050020 You intended to harm me, but God intended it for good to accomplish what is now being done, the saving of many lives.
01050021 So then, don’t be afraid. I will provide for you and your children.” And he reassured them and spoke kindly to them.
01050022 Joseph stayed in Egypt, along with all his father’s family. He lived a hundred and ten years
01050023 and saw the third generation of Ephraim’s children. Also the children of Makir son of Manasseh were placed at birth on Joseph’s knees.
01050024 Then Joseph said to his brothers, “I am about to die. But God will surely come to your aid and take you up out of this land to the land he promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.”
01050025 And Joseph made the Israelites swear an oath and said, “God will surely come to your aid, and then you must carry my bones up from this place.”
01050026 So Joseph died at the age of a hundred and ten. And after they embalmed him, he was placed in a coffin in Egypt.
02001001 These are the names of the sons of Israel who went to Egypt with Jacob, each with his family:
02001002 Reuben, Simeon, Levi and Judah;
02001003 Issachar, Zebulun and Benjamin;
02001004 Dan and Naphtali; Gad and Asher.
02001005 The descendants of Jacob numbered seventy in all; Joseph was already in Egypt.
02001006 Now Joseph and all his brothers and all that generation died,
02001007 but the Israelites were exceedingly fruitful; they multiplied greatly, increased in numbers and became so numerous that the land was filled with them.
02001008 Then a new king, to whom Joseph meant nothing, came to power in Egypt.
02001009 “Look,” he said to his people, “the Israelites have become far too numerous for us.
02001010 Come, we must deal shrewdly with them or they will become even more numerous and, if war breaks out, will join our enemies, fight against us and leave the country.”
02001011 So they put slave masters over them to oppress them with forced labor, and they built Pithom and Rameses as store cities for Pharaoh.
02001012 But the more they were oppressed, the more they multiplied and spread; so the Egyptians came to dread the Israelites
02001013 and worked them ruthlessly.
02001014 They made their lives bitter with harsh labor in brick and mortar and with all kinds of work in the fields; in all their harsh labor the Egyptians worked them ruthlessly.
02001015 The king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, whose names were Shiphrah and Puah,
02001016 “When you are helping the Hebrew women during childbirth on the delivery stool, if you see that the baby is a boy, kill him; but if it is a girl, let her live.”
02001017 The midwives, however, feared God and did not do what the king of Egypt had told them to do; they let the boys live.
02001018 Then the king of Egypt summoned the midwives and asked them, “Why have you done this? Why have you let the boys live?”
02001019 The midwives answered Pharaoh, “Hebrew women are not like Egyptian women; they are vigorous and give birth before the midwives arrive.”
02001020 So God was kind to the midwives and the people increased and became even more numerous.
02001021 And because the midwives feared God, he gave them families of their own.
02001022 Then Pharaoh gave this order to all his people: “Every Hebrew boy that is born you must throw into the Nile, but let every girl live.”
02002001 Now a man of the tribe of Levi married a Levite woman,
02002002 and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. When she saw that he was a fine child, she hid him for three months.
02002003 But when she could hide him no longer, she got a papyrus basket for him and coated it with tar and pitch. Then she placed the child in it and put it among the reeds along the bank of the Nile.
02002004 His sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
02002005 Then Pharaoh’s daughter went down to the Nile to bathe, and her attendants were walking along the riverbank. She saw the basket among the reeds and sent her female slave to get it.
02002006 She opened it and saw the baby. He was crying, and she felt sorry for him. “This is one of the Hebrew babies,” she said.
02002007 Then his sister asked Pharaoh’s daughter, “Shall I go and get one of the Hebrew women to nurse the baby for you?”
02002008 “Yes, go,” she answered. So the girl went and got the baby’s mother.
02002009 Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this baby and nurse him for me, and I will pay you.” So the woman took the baby and nursed him.
02002010 When the child grew older, she took him to Pharaoh’s daughter and he became her son. She named him Moses, saying, “I drew him out of the water.”
02002011 One day, after Moses had grown up, he went out to where his own people were and watched them at their hard labor. He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his own people.
02002012 Looking this way and that and seeing no one, he killed the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
02002013 The next day he went out and saw two Hebrews fighting. He asked the one in the wrong, “Why are you hitting your fellow Hebrew?”
02002014 The man said, “Who made you ruler and judge over us? Are you thinking of killing me as you killed the Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid and thought, “What I did must have become known.”
02002015 When Pharaoh heard of this, he tried to kill Moses, but Moses fled from Pharaoh and went to live in Midian, where he sat down by a well.
02002016 Now a priest of Midian had seven daughters, and they came to draw water and fill the troughs to water their father’s flock.
02002017 Some shepherds came along and drove them away, but Moses got up and came to their rescue and watered their flock.
02002018 When the girls returned to Reuel their father, he asked them, “Why have you returned so early today?”
02002019 They answered, “An Egyptian rescued us from the shepherds. He even drew water for us and watered the flock.”
02002020 “And where is he?” Reuel asked his daughters. “Why did you leave him? Invite him to have something to eat.”
02002021 Moses agreed to stay with the man, who gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses in marriage.
02002022 Zipporah gave birth to a son, and Moses named him Gershom, saying, “I have become a foreigner in a foreign land.”
02002023 During that long period, the king of Egypt died. The Israelites groaned in their slavery and cried out, and their cry for help because of their slavery went up to God.
02002024 God heard their groaning and he remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac and with Jacob.
02002025 So God looked on the Israelites and was concerned about them.
02003001 Now Moses was tending the flock of Jethro his father-in-law, the priest of Midian, and he led the flock to the far side of the wilderness and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
02003002 There the angel of the Lord appeared to him in flames of fire from within a bush. Moses saw that though the bush was on fire it did not burn up.
02003003 So Moses thought, “I will go over and see this strange sight—why the bush does not burn up.”
02003004 When the Lord saw that he had gone over to look, God called to him from within the bush, “Moses! Moses!” And Moses said, “Here I am.”
02003005 “Do not come any closer,” God said. “Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.”
02003006 Then he said, “I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.” At this, Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at God.
02003007 The Lord said, “I have indeed seen the misery of my people in Egypt. I have heard them crying out because of their slave drivers, and I am concerned about their suffering.
02003008 So I have come down to rescue them from the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land into a good and spacious land, a land flowing with milk and honey—the home of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.
02003009 And now the cry of the Israelites has reached me, and I have seen the way the Egyptians are oppressing them.
02003010 So now, go. I am sending you to Pharaoh to bring my people the Israelites out of Egypt.”
02003011 But Moses said to God, “Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and bring the Israelites out of Egypt?”
02003012 And God said, “I will be with you. And this will be the sign to you that it is I who have sent you: When you have brought the people out of Egypt, you will worship God on this mountain.”
02003013 Moses said to God, “Suppose I go to the Israelites and say to them, ‘The God of your fathers has sent me to you,’ and they ask me, ‘What is his name?’ Then what shall I tell them?”
02003014 God said to Moses, “I am who I am. This is what you are to say to the Israelites: ‘I am has sent me to you.’ ”
02003015 God also said to Moses, “Say to the Israelites, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob—has sent me to you.’ “This is my name forever, the name you shall call me from generation to generation.
02003016 “Go, assemble the elders of Israel and say to them, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob—appeared to me and said: I have watched over you and have seen what has been done to you in Egypt.
02003017 And I have promised to bring you up out of your misery in Egypt into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites—a land flowing with milk and honey.’
02003018 “The elders of Israel will listen to you. Then you and the elders are to go to the king of Egypt and say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. Let us take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God.’
02003019 But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go unless a mighty hand compels him.
02003020 So I will stretch out my hand and strike the Egyptians with all the wonders that I will perform among them. After that, he will let you go.
02003021 “And I will make the Egyptians favorably disposed toward this people, so that when you leave you will not go empty-handed.
02003022 Every woman is to ask her neighbor and any woman living in her house for articles of silver and gold and for clothing, which you will put on your sons and daughters. And so you will plunder the Egyptians.”
02004001 Moses answered, “What if they do not believe me or listen to me and say, ‘The Lord did not appear to you’?”
02004002 Then the Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” “A staff,” he replied.
02004003 The Lord said, “Throw it on the ground.” Moses threw it on the ground and it became a snake, and he ran from it.
02004004 Then the Lord said to him, “Reach out your hand and take it by the tail.” So Moses reached out and took hold of the snake and it turned back into a staff in his hand.
02004005 “This,” said the Lord, “is so that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob—has appeared to you.”
02004006 Then the Lord said, “Put your hand inside your cloak.” So Moses put his hand into his cloak, and when he took it out, the skin was leprous —it had become as white as snow.
02004007 “Now put it back into your cloak,” he said. So Moses put his hand back into his cloak, and when he took it out, it was restored, like the rest of his flesh.
02004008 Then the Lord said, “If they do not believe you or pay attention to the first sign, they may believe the second.
02004009 But if they do not believe these two signs or listen to you, take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground. The water you take from the river will become blood on the ground.”
02004010 Moses said to the Lord, “Pardon your servant, Lord. I have never been eloquent, neither in the past nor since you have spoken to your servant. I am slow of speech and tongue.”
02004011 The Lord said to him, “Who gave human beings their mouths? Who makes them deaf or mute? Who gives them sight or makes them blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
02004012 Now go; I will help you speak and will teach you what to say.”
02004013 But Moses said, “Pardon your servant, Lord. Please send someone else.”
02004014 Then the Lord’s anger burned against Moses and he said, “What about your brother, Aaron the Levite? I know he can speak well. He is already on his way to meet you, and he will be glad to see you.
02004015 You shall speak to him and put words in his mouth; I will help both of you speak and will teach you what to do.
02004016 He will speak to the people for you, and it will be as if he were your mouth and as if you were God to him.
02004017 But take this staff in your hand so you can perform the signs with it.”
02004018 Then Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him, “Let me return to my own people in Egypt to see if any of them are still alive.” Jethro said, “Go, and I wish you well.”
02004019 Now the Lord had said to Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, for all those who wanted to kill you are dead.”
02004020 So Moses took his wife and sons, put them on a donkey and started back to Egypt. And he took the staff of God in his hand.
02004021 The Lord said to Moses, “When you return to Egypt, see that you perform before Pharaoh all the wonders I have given you the power to do. But I will harden his heart so that he will not let the people go.
02004022 Then say to Pharaoh, ‘This is what the Lord says: Israel is my firstborn son,
02004023 and I told you, “Let my son go, so he may worship me.” But you refused to let him go; so I will kill your firstborn son.’ ”
02004024 At a lodging place on the way, the Lord met Moses and was about to kill him.
02004025 But Zipporah took a flint knife, cut off her son’s foreskin and touched Moses’ feet with it. “Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me,” she said.
02004026 So the Lord let him alone. (At that time she said “bridegroom of blood,” referring to circumcision.)
02004027 The Lord said to Aaron, “Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.” So he met Moses at the mountain of God and kissed him.
02004028 Then Moses told Aaron everything the Lord had sent him to say, and also about all the signs he had commanded him to perform.
02004029 Moses and Aaron brought together all the elders of the Israelites,
02004030 and Aaron told them everything the Lord had said to Moses. He also performed the signs before the people,
02004031 and they believed. And when they heard that the Lord was concerned about them and had seen their misery, they bowed down and worshiped.
02005001 Afterward Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: ‘Let my people go, so that they may hold a festival to me in the wilderness.’ ”
02005002 Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord, that I should obey him and let Israel go? I do not know the Lord and I will not let Israel go.”
02005003 Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Now let us take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God, or he may strike us with plagues or with the sword.”
02005004 But the king of Egypt said, “Moses and Aaron, why are you taking the people away from their labor? Get back to your work!”
02005005 Then Pharaoh said, “Look, the people of the land are now numerous, and you are stopping them from working.”
02005006 That same day Pharaoh gave this order to the slave drivers and overseers in charge of the people:
02005007 “You are no longer to supply the people with straw for making bricks; let them go and gather their own straw.
02005008 But require them to make the same number of bricks as before; don’t reduce the quota. They are lazy; that is why they are crying out, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to our God.’
02005009 Make the work harder for the people so that they keep working and pay no attention to lies.”
02005010 Then the slave drivers and the overseers went out and said to the people, “This is what Pharaoh says: ‘I will not give you any more straw.
02005011 Go and get your own straw wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced at all.’ ”
02005012 So the people scattered all over Egypt to gather stubble to use for straw.
02005013 The slave drivers kept pressing them, saying, “Complete the work required of you for each day, just as when you had straw.”
02005014 And Pharaoh’s slave drivers beat the Israelite overseers they had appointed, demanding, “Why haven’t you met your quota of bricks yesterday or today, as before?”
02005015 Then the Israelite overseers went and appealed to Pharaoh: “Why have you treated your servants this way?
02005016 Your servants are given no straw, yet we are told, ‘Make bricks!’ Your servants are being beaten, but the fault is with your own people.”
02005017 Pharaoh said, “Lazy, that’s what you are—lazy! That is why you keep saying, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to the Lord.’
02005018 Now get to work. You will not be given any straw, yet you must produce your full quota of bricks.”
02005019 The Israelite overseers realized they were in trouble when they were told, “You are not to reduce the number of bricks required of you for each day.”
02005020 When they left Pharaoh, they found Moses and Aaron waiting to meet them,
02005021 and they said, “May the Lord look on you and judge you! You have made us obnoxious to Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword in their hand to kill us.”
02005022 Moses returned to the Lord and said, “Why, Lord, why have you brought trouble on this people? Is this why you sent me?
02005023 Ever since I went to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has brought trouble on this people, and you have not rescued your people at all.”
02006001 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh: Because of my mighty hand he will let them go; because of my mighty hand he will drive them out of his country.”
02006002 God also said to Moses, “I am the Lord.
02006003 I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac and to Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name the Lord I did not make myself fully known to them.
02006004 I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, where they resided as foreigners.
02006005 Moreover, I have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I have remembered my covenant.
02006006 “Therefore, say to the Israelites: ‘I am the Lord, and I will bring you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians. I will free you from being slaves to them, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with mighty acts of judgment.
02006007 I will take you as my own people, and I will be your God. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians.
02006008 And I will bring you to the land I swore with uplifted hand to give to Abraham, to Isaac and to Jacob. I will give it to you as a possession. I am the Lord.’ ”
02006009 Moses reported this to the Israelites, but they did not listen to him because of their discouragement and harsh labor.
02006010 Then the Lord said to Moses,
02006011 “Go, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the Israelites go out of his country.”
02006012 But Moses said to the Lord, “If the Israelites will not listen to me, why would Pharaoh listen to me, since I speak with faltering lips ?”
02006013 Now the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron about the Israelites and Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he commanded them to bring the Israelites out of Egypt.
02006014 These were the heads of their families : The sons of Reuben the firstborn son of Israel were Hanok and Pallu, Hezron and Karmi. These were the clans of Reuben.
02006015 The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman. These were the clans of Simeon.
02006016 These were the names of the sons of Levi according to their records: Gershon, Kohath and Merari. Levi lived 137 years.
02006017 The sons of Gershon, by clans, were Libni and Shimei.
02006018 The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.
02006019 The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These were the clans of Levi according to their records.
02006020 Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed, who bore him Aaron and Moses. Amram lived 137 years.
02006021 The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg and Zikri.
02006022 The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan and Sithri.
02006023 Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
02006024 The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah and Abiasaph. These were the Korahite clans.
02006025 Eleazar son of Aaron married one of the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas. These were the heads of the Levite families, clan by clan.
02006026 It was this Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring the Israelites out of Egypt by their divisions.”
02006027 They were the ones who spoke to Pharaoh king of Egypt about bringing the Israelites out of Egypt—this same Moses and Aaron.
02006028 Now when the Lord spoke to Moses in Egypt,
02006029 he said to him, “I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh king of Egypt everything I tell you.”
02006030 But Moses said to the Lord, “Since I speak with faltering lips, why would Pharaoh listen to me?”
02007001 Then the Lord said to Moses, “See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet.
02007002 You are to say everything I command you, and your brother Aaron is to tell Pharaoh to let the Israelites go out of his country.
02007003 But I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and though I multiply my signs and wonders in Egypt,
02007004 he will not listen to you. Then I will lay my hand on Egypt and with mighty acts of judgment I will bring out my divisions, my people the Israelites.
02007005 And the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring the Israelites out of it.”
02007006 Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord commanded them.
02007007 Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three when they spoke to Pharaoh.
02007008 The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
02007009 “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Perform a miracle,’ then say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh,’ and it will become a snake.”
02007010 So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did just as the Lord commanded. Aaron threw his staff down in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a snake.
02007011 Pharaoh then summoned wise men and sorcerers, and the Egyptian magicians also did the same things by their secret arts:
02007012 Each one threw down his staff and it became a snake. But Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
02007013 Yet Pharaoh’s heart became hard and he would not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
02007014 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is unyielding; he refuses to let the people go.
02007015 Go to Pharaoh in the morning as he goes out to the river. Confront him on the bank of the Nile, and take in your hand the staff that was changed into a snake.
02007016 Then say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to say to you: Let my people go, so that they may worship me in the wilderness. But until now you have not listened.
02007017 This is what the Lord says: By this you will know that I am the Lord: With the staff that is in my hand I will strike the water of the Nile, and it will be changed into blood.
02007018 The fish in the Nile will die, and the river will stink; the Egyptians will not be able to drink its water.’ ”
02007019 The Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—over the streams and canals, over the ponds and all the reservoirs—and they will turn to blood.’ Blood will be everywhere in Egypt, even in vessels of wood and stone.”
02007020 Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord had commanded. He raised his staff in the presence of Pharaoh and his officials and struck the water of the Nile, and all the water was changed into blood.
02007021 The fish in the Nile died, and the river smelled so bad that the Egyptians could not drink its water. Blood was everywhere in Egypt.
02007022 But the Egyptian magicians did the same things by their secret arts, and Pharaoh’s heart became hard; he would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said.
02007023 Instead, he turned and went into his palace, and did not take even this to heart.
02007024 And all the Egyptians dug along the Nile to get drinking water, because they could not drink the water of the river.
02007025 Seven days passed after the Lord struck the Nile.
02008001 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: Let my people go, so that they may worship me.
02008002 If you refuse to let them go, I will send a plague of frogs on your whole country.
02008003 The Nile will teem with frogs. They will come up into your palace and your bedroom and onto your bed, into the houses of your officials and on your people, and into your ovens and kneading troughs.
02008004 The frogs will come up on you and your people and all your officials.’ ”
02008005 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the streams and canals and ponds, and make frogs come up on the land of Egypt.’ ”
02008006 So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came up and covered the land.
02008007 But the magicians did the same things by their secret arts; they also made frogs come up on the land of Egypt.
02008008 Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Pray to the Lord to take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will let your people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
02008009 Moses said to Pharaoh, “I leave to you the honor of setting the time for me to pray for you and your officials and your people that you and your houses may be rid of the frogs, except for those that remain in the Nile.”
02008010 “Tomorrow,” Pharaoh said. Moses replied, “It will be as you say, so that you may know there is no one like the Lord our God.
02008011 The frogs will leave you and your houses, your officials and your people; they will remain only in the Nile.”
02008012 After Moses and Aaron left Pharaoh, Moses cried out to the Lord about the frogs he had brought on Pharaoh.
02008013 And the Lord did what Moses asked. The frogs died in the houses, in the courtyards and in the fields.
02008014 They were piled into heaps, and the land reeked of them.
02008015 But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said.
02008016 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Stretch out your staff and strike the dust of the ground,’ and throughout the land of Egypt the dust will become gnats.”
02008017 They did this, and when Aaron stretched out his hand with the staff and struck the dust of the ground, gnats came on people and animals. All the dust throughout the land of Egypt became gnats.
02008018 But when the magicians tried to produce gnats by their secret arts, they could not. Since the gnats were on people and animals everywhere,
02008019 the magicians said to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh’s heart was hard and he would not listen, just as the Lord had said.
02008020 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning and confront Pharaoh as he goes to the river and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: Let my people go, so that they may worship me.
02008021 If you do not let my people go, I will send swarms of flies on you and your officials, on your people and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies; even the ground will be covered with them.
02008022 “ ‘But on that day I will deal differently with the land of Goshen, where my people live; no swarms of flies will be there, so that you will know that I, the Lord, am in this land.
02008023 I will make a distinction between my people and your people. This sign will occur tomorrow.’ ”
02008024 And the Lord did this. Dense swarms of flies poured into Pharaoh’s palace and into the houses of his officials; throughout Egypt the land was ruined by the flies.
02008025 Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, sacrifice to your God here in the land.”
02008026 But Moses said, “That would not be right. The sacrifices we offer the Lord our God would be detestable to the Egyptians. And if we offer sacrifices that are detestable in their eyes, will they not stone us?
02008027 We must take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the Lord our God, as he commands us.”
02008028 Pharaoh said, “I will let you go to offer sacrifices to the Lord your God in the wilderness, but you must not go very far. Now pray for me.”
02008029 Moses answered, “As soon as I leave you, I will pray to the Lord, and tomorrow the flies will leave Pharaoh and his officials and his people. Only let Pharaoh be sure that he does not act deceitfully again by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
02008030 Then Moses left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord,
02008031 and the Lord did what Moses asked. The flies left Pharaoh and his officials and his people; not a fly remained.
02008032 But this time also Pharaoh hardened his heart and would not let the people go.
02009001 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: “Let my people go, so that they may worship me.”
02009002 If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them back,
02009003 the hand of the Lord will bring a terrible plague on your livestock in the field—on your horses, donkeys and camels and on your cattle, sheep and goats.
02009004 But the Lord will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and that of Egypt, so that no animal belonging to the Israelites will die.’ ”
02009005 The Lord set a time and said, “Tomorrow the Lord will do this in the land.”
02009006 And the next day the Lord did it: All the livestock of the Egyptians died, but not one animal belonging to the Israelites died.
02009007 Pharaoh investigated and found that not even one of the animals of the Israelites had died. Yet his heart was unyielding and he would not let the people go.
02009008 Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from a furnace and have Moses toss it into the air in the presence of Pharaoh.
02009009 It will become fine dust over the whole land of Egypt, and festering boils will break out on people and animals throughout the land.”
02009010 So they took soot from a furnace and stood before Pharaoh. Moses tossed it into the air, and festering boils broke out on people and animals.
02009011 The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils that were on them and on all the Egyptians.
02009012 But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart and he would not listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had said to Moses.
02009013 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning, confront Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go, so that they may worship me,
02009014 or this time I will send the full force of my plagues against you and against your officials and your people, so you may know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
02009015 For by now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with a plague that would have wiped you off the earth.
02009016 But I have raised you up for this very purpose, that I might show you my power and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth.
02009017 You still set yourself against my people and will not let them go.
02009018 Therefore, at this time tomorrow I will send the worst hailstorm that has ever fallen on Egypt, from the day it was founded till now.
02009019 Give an order now to bring your livestock and everything you have in the field to a place of shelter, because the hail will fall on every person and animal that has not been brought in and is still out in the field, and they will die.’ ”
02009020 Those officials of Pharaoh who feared the word of the Lord hurried to bring their slaves and their livestock inside.
02009021 But those who ignored the word of the Lord left their slaves and livestock in the field.
02009022 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward the sky so that hail will fall all over Egypt—on people and animals and on everything growing in the fields of Egypt.”
02009023 When Moses stretched out his staff toward the sky, the Lord sent thunder and hail, and lightning flashed down to the ground. So the Lord rained hail on the land of Egypt;
02009024 hail fell and lightning flashed back and forth. It was the worst storm in all the land of Egypt since it had become a nation.
02009025 Throughout Egypt hail struck everything in the fields—both people and animals; it beat down everything growing in the fields and stripped every tree.
02009026 The only place it did not hail was the land of Goshen, where the Israelites were.
02009027 Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron. “This time I have sinned,” he said to them. “The Lord is in the right, and I and my people are in the wrong.
02009028 Pray to the Lord, for we have had enough thunder and hail. I will let you go; you don’t have to stay any longer.”
02009029 Moses replied, “When I have gone out of the city, I will spread out my hands in prayer to the Lord. The thunder will stop and there will be no more hail, so you may know that the earth is the Lord’s.
02009030 But I know that you and your officials still do not fear the Lord God.”
02009031 (The flax and barley were destroyed, since the barley had headed and the flax was in bloom.
02009032 The wheat and spelt, however, were not destroyed, because they ripen later.)
02009033 Then Moses left Pharaoh and went out of the city. He spread out his hands toward the Lord; the thunder and hail stopped, and the rain no longer poured down on the land.
02009034 When Pharaoh saw that the rain and hail and thunder had stopped, he sinned again: He and his officials hardened their hearts.
02009035 So Pharaoh’s heart was hard and he would not let the Israelites go, just as the Lord had said through Moses.
02010001 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the hearts of his officials so that I may perform these signs of mine among them
02010002 that you may tell your children and grandchildren how I dealt harshly with the Egyptians and how I performed my signs among them, and that you may know that I am the Lord.”
02010003 So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said to him, “This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: ‘How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go, so that they may worship me.
02010004 If you refuse to let them go, I will bring locusts into your country tomorrow.
02010005 They will cover the face of the ground so that it cannot be seen. They will devour what little you have left after the hail, including every tree that is growing in your fields.
02010006 They will fill your houses and those of all your officials and all the Egyptians—something neither your parents nor your ancestors have ever seen from the day they settled in this land till now.’ ” Then Moses turned and left Pharaoh.
02010007 Pharaoh’s officials said to him, “How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the people go, so that they may worship the Lord their God. Do you not yet realize that Egypt is ruined?”
02010008 Then Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh. “Go, worship the Lord your God,” he said. “But tell me who will be going.”
02010009 Moses answered, “We will go with our young and our old, with our sons and our daughters, and with our flocks and herds, because we are to celebrate a festival to the Lord.”
02010010 Pharaoh said, “The Lord be with you—if I let you go, along with your women and children! Clearly you are bent on evil.
02010011 No! Have only the men go and worship the Lord, since that’s what you have been asking for.” Then Moses and Aaron were driven out of Pharaoh’s presence.
02010012 And the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over Egypt so that locusts swarm over the land and devour everything growing in the fields, everything left by the hail.”
02010013 So Moses stretched out his staff over Egypt, and the Lord made an east wind blow across the land all that day and all that night. By morning the wind had brought the locusts;
02010014 they invaded all Egypt and settled down in every area of the country in great numbers. Never before had there been such a plague of locusts, nor will there ever be again.
02010015 They covered all the ground until it was black. They devoured all that was left after the hail—everything growing in the fields and the fruit on the trees. Nothing green remained on tree or plant in all the land of Egypt.
02010016 Pharaoh quickly summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you.
02010017 Now forgive my sin once more and pray to the Lord your God to take this deadly plague away from me.”
02010018 Moses then left Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord.
02010019 And the Lord changed the wind to a very strong west wind, which caught up the locusts and carried them into the Red Sea. Not a locust was left anywhere in Egypt.
02010020 But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he would not let the Israelites go.
02010021 Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward the sky so that darkness spreads over Egypt—darkness that can be felt.”
02010022 So Moses stretched out his hand toward the sky, and total darkness covered all Egypt for three days.
02010023 No one could see anyone else or move about for three days. Yet all the Israelites had light in the places where they lived.
02010024 Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and said, “Go, worship the Lord. Even your women and children may go with you; only leave your flocks and herds behind.”
02010025 But Moses said, “You must allow us to have sacrifices and burnt offerings to present to the Lord our God.
02010026 Our livestock too must go with us; not a hoof is to be left behind. We have to use some of them in worshiping the Lord our God, and until we get there we will not know what we are to use to worship the Lord.”
02010027 But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he was not willing to let them go.
02010028 Pharaoh said to Moses, “Get out of my sight! Make sure you do not appear before me again! The day you see my face you will die.”
02010029 “Just as you say,” Moses replied. “I will never appear before you again.”
02011001 Now the Lord had said to Moses, “I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and on Egypt. After that, he will let you go from here, and when he does, he will drive you out completely.
02011002 Tell the people that men and women alike are to ask their neighbors for articles of silver and gold.”
02011003 (The Lord made the Egyptians favorably disposed toward the people, and Moses himself was highly regarded in Egypt by Pharaoh’s officials and by the people.)
02011004 So Moses said, “This is what the Lord says: ‘About midnight I will go throughout Egypt.
02011005 Every firstborn son in Egypt will die, from the firstborn son of Pharaoh, who sits on the throne, to the firstborn son of the female slave, who is at her hand mill, and all the firstborn of the cattle as well.
02011006 There will be loud wailing throughout Egypt—worse than there has ever been or ever will be again.
02011007 But among the Israelites not a dog will bark at any person or animal.’ Then you will know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.
02011008 All these officials of yours will come to me, bowing down before me and saying, ‘Go, you and all the people who follow you!’ After that I will leave.” Then Moses, hot with anger, left Pharaoh.
02011009 The Lord had said to Moses, “Pharaoh will refuse to listen to you—so that my wonders may be multiplied in Egypt.”
02011010 Moses and Aaron performed all these wonders before Pharaoh, but the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he would not let the Israelites go out of his country.
02012001 The Lord said to Moses and Aaron in Egypt,
02012002 “This month is to be for you the first month, the first month of your year.
02012003 Tell the whole community of Israel that on the tenth day of this month each man is to take a lamb for his family, one for each household.
02012004 If any household is too small for a whole lamb, they must share one with their nearest neighbor, having taken into account the number of people there are. You are to determine the amount of lamb needed in accordance with what each person will eat.
02012005 The animals you choose must be year-old males without defect, and you may take them from the sheep or the goats.
02012006 Take care of them until the fourteenth day of the month, when all the members of the community of Israel must slaughter them at twilight.
02012007 Then they are to take some of the blood and put it on the sides and tops of the doorframes of the houses where they eat the lambs.
02012008 That same night they are to eat the meat roasted over the fire, along with bitter herbs, and bread made without yeast.
02012009 Do not eat the meat raw or boiled in water, but roast it over a fire—with the head, legs and internal organs.
02012010 Do not leave any of it till morning; if some is left till morning, you must burn it.
02012011 This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt, your sandals on your feet and your staff in your hand. Eat it in haste; it is the Lord’s Passover.
02012012 “On that same night I will pass through Egypt and strike down every firstborn of both people and animals, and I will bring judgment on all the gods of Egypt. I am the Lord.
02012013 The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are, and when I see the blood, I will pass over you. No destructive plague will touch you when I strike Egypt.
02012014 “This is a day you are to commemorate; for the generations to come you shall celebrate it as a festival to the Lord—a lasting ordinance.
02012015 For seven days you are to eat bread made without yeast. On the first day remove the yeast from your houses, for whoever eats anything with yeast in it from the first day through the seventh must be cut off from Israel.
02012016 On the first day hold a sacred assembly, and another one on the seventh day. Do no work at all on these days, except to prepare food for everyone to eat; that is all you may do.
02012017 “Celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread, because it was on this very day that I brought your divisions out of Egypt. Celebrate this day as a lasting ordinance for the generations to come.
