07003024 After he had gone, the servants came and found the doors of the upper room locked. They said, “He must be relieving himself in the inner room of the palace.”
07003025 They waited to the point of embarrassment, but when he did not open the doors of the room, they took a key and unlocked them. There they saw their lord fallen to the floor, dead.
07003026 While they waited, Ehud got away. He passed by the stone images and escaped to Seirah.
07003027 When he arrived there, he blew a trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down with him from the hills, with him leading them.
07003028 “Follow me,” he ordered, “for the Lord has given Moab, your enemy, into your hands.” So they followed him down and took possession of the fords of the Jordan that led to Moab; they allowed no one to cross over.
07003029 At that time they struck down about ten thousand Moabites, all vigorous and strong; not one escaped.
07003030 That day Moab was made subject to Israel, and the land had peace for eighty years.
07003031 After Ehud came Shamgar son of Anath, who struck down six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad. He too saved Israel.
07004001 Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, now that Ehud was dead.
07004002 So the Lord sold them into the hands of Jabin king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. Sisera, the commander of his army, was based in Harosheth Haggoyim.
07004003 Because he had nine hundred chariots fitted with iron and had cruelly oppressed the Israelites for twenty years, they cried to the Lord for help.
07004004 Now Deborah, a prophet, the wife of Lappidoth, was leading Israel at that time.
07004005 She held court under the Palm of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went up to her to have their disputes decided.
07004006 She sent for Barak son of Abinoam from Kedesh in Naphtali and said to him, “The Lord, the God of Israel, commands you: ‘Go, take with you ten thousand men of Naphtali and Zebulun and lead them up to Mount Tabor.
07004007 I will lead Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and his troops to the Kishon River and give him into your hands.’ ”
07004008 Barak said to her, “If you go with me, I will go; but if you don’t go with me, I won’t go.”
07004009 “Certainly I will go with you,” said Deborah. “But because of the course you are taking, the honor will not be yours, for the Lord will deliver Sisera into the hands of a woman.” So Deborah went with Barak to Kedesh.
07004010 There Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali, and ten thousand men went up under his command. Deborah also went up with him.
07004011 Now Heber the Kenite had left the other Kenites, the descendants of Hobab, Moses’ brother-in-law, and pitched his tent by the great tree in Zaanannim near Kedesh.
07004012 When they told Sisera that Barak son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor,
07004013 Sisera summoned from Harosheth Haggoyim to the Kishon River all his men and his nine hundred chariots fitted with iron.
07004014 Then Deborah said to Barak, “Go! This is the day the Lord has given Sisera into your hands. Has not the Lord gone ahead of you?” So Barak went down Mount Tabor, with ten thousand men following him.
07004015 At Barak’s advance, the Lord routed Sisera and all his chariots and army by the sword, and Sisera got down from his chariot and fled on foot.
07004016 Barak pursued the chariots and army as far as Harosheth Haggoyim, and all Sisera’s troops fell by the sword; not a man was left.
07004017 Sisera, meanwhile, fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, because there was an alliance between Jabin king of Hazor and the family of Heber the Kenite.
07004018 Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, “Come, my lord, come right in. Don’t be afraid.” So he entered her tent, and she covered him with a blanket.
07004019 “I’m thirsty,” he said. “Please give me some water.” She opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him up.
07004020 “Stand in the doorway of the tent,” he told her. “If someone comes by and asks you, ‘Is anyone in there?’ say ‘No.’ ”
07004021 But Jael, Heber’s wife, picked up a tent peg and a hammer and went quietly to him while he lay fast asleep, exhausted. She drove the peg through his temple into the ground, and he died.
07004022 Just then Barak came by in pursuit of Sisera, and Jael went out to meet him. “Come,” she said, “I will show you the man you’re looking for.” So he went in with her, and there lay Sisera with the tent peg through his temple—dead.
07004023 On that day God subdued Jabin king of Canaan before the Israelites.
07004024 And the hand of the Israelites pressed harder and harder against Jabin king of Canaan until they destroyed him.
07005001 On that day Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang this song:
07005002 “When the princes in Israel take the lead, when the people willingly offer themselves— praise the Lord!
07005003 “Hear this, you kings! Listen, you rulers! I, even I, will sing to the Lord; I will praise the Lord, the God of Israel, in song.
07005004 “When you, Lord, went out from Seir, when you marched from the land of Edom, the earth shook, the heavens poured, the clouds poured down water.
07005005 The mountains quaked before the Lord, the One of Sinai, before the Lord, the God of Israel.
07005006 “In the days of Shamgar son of Anath, in the days of Jael, the highways were abandoned; travelers took to winding paths.
07005007 Villagers in Israel would not fight; they held back until I, Deborah, arose, until I arose, a mother in Israel.
07005008 God chose new leaders when war came to the city gates, but not a shield or spear was seen among forty thousand in Israel.
07005009 My heart is with Israel’s princes, with the willing volunteers among the people. Praise the Lord!
07005010 “You who ride on white donkeys, sitting on your saddle blankets, and you who walk along the road, consider
07005011 the voice of the singers at the watering places. They recite the victories of the Lord, the victories of his villagers in Israel. “Then the people of the Lord went down to the city gates.
07005012 ‘Wake up, wake up, Deborah! Wake up, wake up, break out in song! Arise, Barak! Take captive your captives, son of Abinoam.’
07005013 “The remnant of the nobles came down; the people of the Lord came down to me against the mighty.
07005014 Some came from Ephraim, whose roots were in Amalek; Benjamin was with the people who followed you. From Makir captains came down, from Zebulun those who bear a commander’s staff.
07005015 The princes of Issachar were with Deborah; yes, Issachar was with Barak, sent under his command into the valley. In the districts of Reuben there was much searching of heart.
07005016 Why did you stay among the sheep pens to hear the whistling for the flocks? In the districts of Reuben there was much searching of heart.
07005017 Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan. And Dan, why did he linger by the ships? Asher remained on the coast and stayed in his coves.
07005018 The people of Zebulun risked their very lives; so did Naphtali on the terraced fields.
07005019 “Kings came, they fought, the kings of Canaan fought. At Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo, they took no plunder of silver.
07005020 From the heavens the stars fought, from their courses they fought against Sisera.
07005021 The river Kishon swept them away, the age-old river, the river Kishon. March on, my soul; be strong!
07005022 Then thundered the horses’ hooves— galloping, galloping go his mighty steeds.
07005023 ‘Curse Meroz,’ said the angel of the Lord. ‘Curse its people bitterly, because they did not come to help the Lord, to help the Lord against the mighty.’
07005024 “Most blessed of women be Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, most blessed of tent-dwelling women.
07005025 He asked for water, and she gave him milk; in a bowl fit for nobles she brought him curdled milk.
07005026 Her hand reached for the tent peg, her right hand for the workman’s hammer. She struck Sisera, she crushed his head, she shattered and pierced his temple.
07005027 At her feet he sank, he fell; there he lay. At her feet he sank, he fell; where he sank, there he fell—dead.
07005028 “Through the window peered Sisera’s mother; behind the lattice she cried out, ‘Why is his chariot so long in coming? Why is the clatter of his chariots delayed?’
07005029 The wisest of her ladies answer her; indeed, she keeps saying to herself,
07005030 ‘Are they not finding and dividing the spoils: a woman or two for each man, colorful garments as plunder for Sisera, colorful garments embroidered, highly embroidered garments for my neck— all this as plunder?’
07005031 “So may all your enemies perish, Lord! But may all who love you be like the sun when it rises in its strength.” Then the land had peace forty years.
07006001 The Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, and for seven years he gave them into the hands of the Midianites.
07006002 Because the power of Midian was so oppressive, the Israelites prepared shelters for themselves in mountain clefts, caves and strongholds.
07006003 Whenever the Israelites planted their crops, the Midianites, Amalekites and other eastern peoples invaded the country.
07006004 They camped on the land and ruined the crops all the way to Gaza and did not spare a living thing for Israel, neither sheep nor cattle nor donkeys.
07006005 They came up with their livestock and their tents like swarms of locusts. It was impossible to count them or their camels; they invaded the land to ravage it.
07006006 Midian so impoverished the Israelites that they cried out to the Lord for help.
07006007 When the Israelites cried out to the Lord because of Midian,
07006008 he sent them a prophet, who said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I brought you up out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.
07006009 I rescued you from the hand of the Egyptians. And I delivered you from the hand of all your oppressors; I drove them out before you and gave you their land.
07006010 I said to you, ‘I am the Lord your God; do not worship the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you live.’ But you have not listened to me.”
07006011 The angel of the Lord came and sat down under the oak in Ophrah that belonged to Joash the Abiezrite, where his son Gideon was threshing wheat in a winepress to keep it from the Midianites.
07006012 When the angel of the Lord appeared to Gideon, he said, “The Lord is with you, mighty warrior.”
07006013 “Pardon me, my lord,” Gideon replied, “but if the Lord is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonders that our ancestors told us about when they said, ‘Did not the Lord bring us up out of Egypt?’ But now the Lord has abandoned us and given us into the hand of Midian.”
07006014 The Lord turned to him and said, “Go in the strength you have and save Israel out of Midian’s hand. Am I not sending you?”
07006015 “Pardon me, my lord,” Gideon replied, “but how can I save Israel? My clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my family.”
07006016 The Lord answered, “I will be with you, and you will strike down all the Midianites, leaving none alive.”
07006017 Gideon replied, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, give me a sign that it is really you talking to me.
07006018 Please do not go away until I come back and bring my offering and set it before you.” And the Lord said, “I will wait until you return.”
07006019 Gideon went inside, prepared a young goat, and from an ephah of flour he made bread without yeast. Putting the meat in a basket and its broth in a pot, he brought them out and offered them to him under the oak.
07006020 The angel of God said to him, “Take the meat and the unleavened bread, place them on this rock, and pour out the broth.” And Gideon did so.
07006021 Then the angel of the Lord touched the meat and the unleavened bread with the tip of the staff that was in his hand. Fire flared from the rock, consuming the meat and the bread. And the angel of the Lord disappeared.
07006022 When Gideon realized that it was the angel of the Lord, he exclaimed, “Alas, Sovereign Lord! I have seen the angel of the Lord face to face!”
07006023 But the Lord said to him, “Peace! Do not be afraid. You are not going to die.”
07006024 So Gideon built an altar to the Lord there and called it The Lord Is Peace. To this day it stands in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
07006025 That same night the Lord said to him, “Take the second bull from your father’s herd, the one seven years old. Tear down your father’s altar to Baal and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.
07006026 Then build a proper kind of altar to the Lord your God on the top of this height. Using the wood of the Asherah pole that you cut down, offer the second bull as a burnt offering.”
07006027 So Gideon took ten of his servants and did as the Lord told him. But because he was afraid of his family and the townspeople, he did it at night rather than in the daytime.
07006028 In the morning when the people of the town got up, there was Baal’s altar, demolished, with the Asherah pole beside it cut down and the second bull sacrificed on the newly built altar!
07006029 They asked each other, “Who did this?” When they carefully investigated, they were told, “Gideon son of Joash did it.”
07006030 The people of the town demanded of Joash, “Bring out your son. He must die, because he has broken down Baal’s altar and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.”
07006031 But Joash replied to the hostile crowd around him, “Are you going to plead Baal’s cause? Are you trying to save him? Whoever fights for him shall be put to death by morning! If Baal really is a god, he can defend himself when someone breaks down his altar.”
07006032 So because Gideon broke down Baal’s altar, they gave him the name Jerub-Baal that day, saying, “Let Baal contend with him.”
07006033 Now all the Midianites, Amalekites and other eastern peoples joined forces and crossed over the Jordan and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
07006034 Then the Spirit of the Lord came on Gideon, and he blew a trumpet, summoning the Abiezrites to follow him.
07006035 He sent messengers throughout Manasseh, calling them to arms, and also into Asher, Zebulun and Naphtali, so that they too went up to meet them.
07006036 Gideon said to God, “If you will save Israel by my hand as you have promised—
07006037 look, I will place a wool fleece on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece and all the ground is dry, then I will know that you will save Israel by my hand, as you said.”
07006038 And that is what happened. Gideon rose early the next day; he squeezed the fleece and wrung out the dew—a bowlful of water.
07006039 Then Gideon said to God, “Do not be angry with me. Let me make just one more request. Allow me one more test with the fleece, but this time make the fleece dry and let the ground be covered with dew.”
07006040 That night God did so. Only the fleece was dry; all the ground was covered with dew.
07007001 Early in the morning, Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) and all his men camped at the spring of Harod. The camp of Midian was north of them in the valley near the hill of Moreh.
07007002 The Lord said to Gideon, “You have too many men. I cannot deliver Midian into their hands, or Israel would boast against me, ‘My own strength has saved me.’
07007003 Now announce to the army, ‘Anyone who trembles with fear may turn back and leave Mount Gilead.’ ” So twenty-two thousand men left, while ten thousand remained.
07007004 But the Lord said to Gideon, “There are still too many men. Take them down to the water, and I will thin them out for you there. If I say, ‘This one shall go with you,’ he shall go; but if I say, ‘This one shall not go with you,’ he shall not go.”
07007005 So Gideon took the men down to the water. There the Lord told him, “Separate those who lap the water with their tongues as a dog laps from those who kneel down to drink.”
07007006 Three hundred of them drank from cupped hands, lapping like dogs. All the rest got down on their knees to drink.
07007007 The Lord said to Gideon, “With the three hundred men that lapped I will save you and give the Midianites into your hands. Let all the others go home.”
07007008 So Gideon sent the rest of the Israelites home but kept the three hundred, who took over the provisions and trumpets of the others. Now the camp of Midian lay below him in the valley.
07007009 During that night the Lord said to Gideon, “Get up, go down against the camp, because I am going to give it into your hands.
07007010 If you are afraid to attack, go down to the camp with your servant Purah
07007011 and listen to what they are saying. Afterward, you will be encouraged to attack the camp.” So he and Purah his servant went down to the outposts of the camp.
07007012 The Midianites, the Amalekites and all the other eastern peoples had settled in the valley, thick as locusts. Their camels could no more be counted than the sand on the seashore.
07007013 Gideon arrived just as a man was telling a friend his dream. “I had a dream,” he was saying. “A round loaf of barley bread came tumbling into the Midianite camp. It struck the tent with such force that the tent overturned and collapsed.”
07007014 His friend responded, “This can be nothing other than the sword of Gideon son of Joash, the Israelite. God has given the Midianites and the whole camp into his hands.”
07007015 When Gideon heard the dream and its interpretation, he bowed down and worshiped. He returned to the camp of Israel and called out, “Get up! The Lord has given the Midianite camp into your hands.”
07007016 Dividing the three hundred men into three companies, he placed trumpets and empty jars in the hands of all of them, with torches inside.
07007017 “Watch me,” he told them. “Follow my lead. When I get to the edge of the camp, do exactly as I do.
07007018 When I and all who are with me blow our trumpets, then from all around the camp blow yours and shout, ‘For the Lord and for Gideon.’ ”
07007019 Gideon and the hundred men with him reached the edge of the camp at the beginning of the middle watch, just after they had changed the guard. They blew their trumpets and broke the jars that were in their hands.
07007020 The three companies blew the trumpets and smashed the jars. Grasping the torches in their left hands and holding in their right hands the trumpets they were to blow, they shouted, “A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!”
07007021 While each man held his position around the camp, all the Midianites ran, crying out as they fled.
07007022 When the three hundred trumpets sounded, the Lord caused the men throughout the camp to turn on each other with their swords. The army fled to Beth Shittah toward Zererah as far as the border of Abel Meholah near Tabbath.
07007023 Israelites from Naphtali, Asher and all Manasseh were called out, and they pursued the Midianites.
07007024 Gideon sent messengers throughout the hill country of Ephraim, saying, “Come down against the Midianites and seize the waters of the Jordan ahead of them as far as Beth Barah.” So all the men of Ephraim were called out and they seized the waters of the Jordan as far as Beth Barah.
07007025 They also captured two of the Midianite leaders, Oreb and Zeeb. They killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb, and Zeeb at the winepress of Zeeb. They pursued the Midianites and brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon, who was by the Jordan.
07008001 Now the Ephraimites asked Gideon, “Why have you treated us like this? Why didn’t you call us when you went to fight Midian?” And they challenged him vigorously.
07008002 But he answered them, “What have I accomplished compared to you? Aren’t the gleanings of Ephraim’s grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?
07008003 God gave Oreb and Zeeb, the Midianite leaders, into your hands. What was I able to do compared to you?” At this, their resentment against him subsided.
07008004 Gideon and his three hundred men, exhausted yet keeping up the pursuit, came to the Jordan and crossed it.
07008005 He said to the men of Sukkoth, “Give my troops some bread; they are worn out, and I am still pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian.”
07008006 But the officials of Sukkoth said, “Do you already have the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna in your possession? Why should we give bread to your troops?”
07008007 Then Gideon replied, “Just for that, when the Lord has given Zebah and Zalmunna into my hand, I will tear your flesh with desert thorns and briers.”
07008008 From there he went up to Peniel and made the same request of them, but they answered as the men of Sukkoth had.
07008009 So he said to the men of Peniel, “When I return in triumph, I will tear down this tower.”
07008010 Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with a force of about fifteen thousand men, all that were left of the armies of the eastern peoples; a hundred and twenty thousand swordsmen had fallen.
07008011 Gideon went up by the route of the nomads east of Nobah and Jogbehah and attacked the unsuspecting army.
07008012 Zebah and Zalmunna, the two kings of Midian, fled, but he pursued them and captured them, routing their entire army.
07008013 Gideon son of Joash then returned from the battle by the Pass of Heres.
07008014 He caught a young man of Sukkoth and questioned him, and the young man wrote down for him the names of the seventy-seven officials of Sukkoth, the elders of the town.
07008015 Then Gideon came and said to the men of Sukkoth, “Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me by saying, ‘Do you already have the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna in your possession? Why should we give bread to your exhausted men?’ ”
07008016 He took the elders of the town and taught the men of Sukkoth a lesson by punishing them with desert thorns and briers.
07008017 He also pulled down the tower of Peniel and killed the men of the town.
07008018 Then he asked Zebah and Zalmunna, “What kind of men did you kill at Tabor?” “Men like you,” they answered, “each one with the bearing of a prince.”
07008019 Gideon replied, “Those were my brothers, the sons of my own mother. As surely as the Lord lives, if you had spared their lives, I would not kill you.”
07008020 Turning to Jether, his oldest son, he said, “Kill them!” But Jether did not draw his sword, because he was only a boy and was afraid.
07008021 Zebah and Zalmunna said, “Come, do it yourself. ‘As is the man, so is his strength.’ ” So Gideon stepped forward and killed them, and took the ornaments off their camels’ necks.
07008022 The Israelites said to Gideon, “Rule over us—you, your son and your grandson—because you have saved us from the hand of Midian.”
07008023 But Gideon told them, “I will not rule over you, nor will my son rule over you. The Lord will rule over you.”
07008024 And he said, “I do have one request, that each of you give me an earring from your share of the plunder.” (It was the custom of the Ishmaelites to wear gold earrings.)
07008025 They answered, “We’ll be glad to give them.” So they spread out a garment, and each of them threw a ring from his plunder onto it.
07008026 The weight of the gold rings he asked for came to seventeen hundred shekels, not counting the ornaments, the pendants and the purple garments worn by the kings of Midian or the chains that were on their camels’ necks.
07008027 Gideon made the gold into an ephod, which he placed in Ophrah, his town. All Israel prostituted themselves by worshiping it there, and it became a snare to Gideon and his family.
07008028 Thus Midian was subdued before the Israelites and did not raise its head again. During Gideon’s lifetime, the land had peace forty years.
07008029 Jerub-Baal son of Joash went back home to live.
07008030 He had seventy sons of his own, for he had many wives.
07008031 His concubine, who lived in Shechem, also bore him a son, whom he named Abimelek.
07008032 Gideon son of Joash died at a good old age and was buried in the tomb of his father Joash in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
07008033 No sooner had Gideon died than the Israelites again prostituted themselves to the Baals. They set up Baal-Berith as their god
07008034 and did not remember the Lord their God, who had rescued them from the hands of all their enemies on every side.
07008035 They also failed to show any loyalty to the family of Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) in spite of all the good things he had done for them.
07009001 Abimelek son of Jerub-Baal went to his mother’s brothers in Shechem and said to them and to all his mother’s clan,
07009002 “Ask all the citizens of Shechem, ‘Which is better for you: to have all seventy of Jerub-Baal’s sons rule over you, or just one man?’ Remember, I am your flesh and blood.”
07009003 When the brothers repeated all this to the citizens of Shechem, they were inclined to follow Abimelek, for they said, “He is related to us.”
07009004 They gave him seventy shekels of silver from the temple of Baal-Berith, and Abimelek used it to hire reckless scoundrels, who became his followers.
07009005 He went to his father’s home in Ophrah and on one stone murdered his seventy brothers, the sons of Jerub-Baal. But Jotham, the youngest son of Jerub-Baal, escaped by hiding.
07009006 Then all the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo gathered beside the great tree at the pillar in Shechem to crown Abimelek king.
07009007 When Jotham was told about this, he climbed up on the top of Mount Gerizim and shouted to them, “Listen to me, citizens of Shechem, so that God may listen to you.
07009008 One day the trees went out to anoint a king for themselves. They said to the olive tree, ‘Be our king.’
07009009 “But the olive tree answered, ‘Should I give up my oil, by which both gods and humans are honored, to hold sway over the trees?’
07009010 “Next, the trees said to the fig tree, ‘Come and be our king.’
07009011 “But the fig tree replied, ‘Should I give up my fruit, so good and sweet, to hold sway over the trees?’
07009012 “Then the trees said to the vine, ‘Come and be our king.’
07009013 “But the vine answered, ‘Should I give up my wine, which cheers both gods and humans, to hold sway over the trees?’
07009014 “Finally all the trees said to the thornbush, ‘Come and be our king.’
07009015 “The thornbush said to the trees, ‘If you really want to anoint me king over you, come and take refuge in my shade; but if not, then let fire come out of the thornbush and consume the cedars of Lebanon!’
07009016 “Have you acted honorably and in good faith by making Abimelek king? Have you been fair to Jerub-Baal and his family? Have you treated him as he deserves?
07009017 Remember that my father fought for you and risked his life to rescue you from the hand of Midian.
07009018 But today you have revolted against my father’s family. You have murdered his seventy sons on a single stone and have made Abimelek, the son of his female slave, king over the citizens of Shechem because he is related to you.
07009019 So have you acted honorably and in good faith toward Jerub-Baal and his family today? If you have, may Abimelek be your joy, and may you be his, too!
07009020 But if you have not, let fire come out from Abimelek and consume you, the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo, and let fire come out from you, the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo, and consume Abimelek!”
07009021 Then Jotham fled, escaping to Beer, and he lived there because he was afraid of his brother Abimelek.
07009022 After Abimelek had governed Israel three years,
07009023 God stirred up animosity between Abimelek and the citizens of Shechem so that they acted treacherously against Abimelek.
07009024 God did this in order that the crime against Jerub-Baal’s seventy sons, the shedding of their blood, might be avenged on their brother Abimelek and on the citizens of Shechem, who had helped him murder his brothers.
07009025 In opposition to him these citizens of Shechem set men on the hilltops to ambush and rob everyone who passed by, and this was reported to Abimelek.
07009026 Now Gaal son of Ebed moved with his clan into Shechem, and its citizens put their confidence in him.
07009027 After they had gone out into the fields and gathered the grapes and trodden them, they held a festival in the temple of their god. While they were eating and drinking, they cursed Abimelek.
07009028 Then Gaal son of Ebed said, “Who is Abimelek, and why should we Shechemites be subject to him? Isn’t he Jerub-Baal’s son, and isn’t Zebul his deputy? Serve the family of Hamor, Shechem’s father! Why should we serve Abimelek?
07009029 If only this people were under my command! Then I would get rid of him. I would say to Abimelek, ‘Call out your whole army!’ ”
07009030 When Zebul the governor of the city heard what Gaal son of Ebed said, he was very angry.
07009031 Under cover he sent messengers to Abimelek, saying, “Gaal son of Ebed and his clan have come to Shechem and are stirring up the city against you.
07009032 Now then, during the night you and your men should come and lie in wait in the fields.
07009033 In the morning at sunrise, advance against the city. When Gaal and his men come out against you, seize the opportunity to attack them.”
07009034 So Abimelek and all his troops set out by night and took up concealed positions near Shechem in four companies.
07009035 Now Gaal son of Ebed had gone out and was standing at the entrance of the city gate just as Abimelek and his troops came out from their hiding place.
07009036 When Gaal saw them, he said to Zebul, “Look, people are coming down from the tops of the mountains!” Zebul replied, “You mistake the shadows of the mountains for men.”
07009037 But Gaal spoke up again: “Look, people are coming down from the central hill, and a company is coming from the direction of the diviners’ tree.”
07009038 Then Zebul said to him, “Where is your big talk now, you who said, ‘Who is Abimelek that we should be subject to him?’ Aren’t these the men you ridiculed? Go out and fight them!”
07009039 So Gaal led out the citizens of Shechem and fought Abimelek.
07009040 Abimelek chased him all the way to the entrance of the gate, and many were killed as they fled.
07009041 Then Abimelek stayed in Arumah, and Zebul drove Gaal and his clan out of Shechem.
07009042 The next day the people of Shechem went out to the fields, and this was reported to Abimelek.
07009043 So he took his men, divided them into three companies and set an ambush in the fields. When he saw the people coming out of the city, he rose to attack them.
07009044 Abimelek and the companies with him rushed forward to a position at the entrance of the city gate. Then two companies attacked those in the fields and struck them down.
07009045 All that day Abimelek pressed his attack against the city until he had captured it and killed its people. Then he destroyed the city and scattered salt over it.
07009046 On hearing this, the citizens in the tower of Shechem went into the stronghold of the temple of El-Berith.
07009047 When Abimelek heard that they had assembled there,
07009048 he and all his men went up Mount Zalmon. He took an ax and cut off some branches, which he lifted to his shoulders. He ordered the men with him, “Quick! Do what you have seen me do!”
07009049 So all the men cut branches and followed Abimelek. They piled them against the stronghold and set it on fire with the people still inside. So all the people in the tower of Shechem, about a thousand men and women, also died.
07009050 Next Abimelek went to Thebez and besieged it and captured it.
07009051 Inside the city, however, was a strong tower, to which all the men and women—all the people of the city—had fled. They had locked themselves in and climbed up on the tower roof.
07009052 Abimelek went to the tower and attacked it. But as he approached the entrance to the tower to set it on fire,
07009053 a woman dropped an upper millstone on his head and cracked his skull.
07009054 Hurriedly he called to his armor-bearer, “Draw your sword and kill me, so that they can’t say, ‘A woman killed him.’ ” So his servant ran him through, and he died.
07009055 When the Israelites saw that Abimelek was dead, they went home.
07009056 Thus God repaid the wickedness that Abimelek had done to his father by murdering his seventy brothers.
07009057 God also made the people of Shechem pay for all their wickedness. The curse of Jotham son of Jerub-Baal came on them.
07010001 After the time of Abimelek, a man of Issachar named Tola son of Puah, the son of Dodo, rose to save Israel. He lived in Shamir, in the hill country of Ephraim.
07010002 He led Israel twenty-three years; then he died, and was buried in Shamir.
07010003 He was followed by Jair of Gilead, who led Israel twenty-two years.
07010004 He had thirty sons, who rode thirty donkeys. They controlled thirty towns in Gilead, which to this day are called Havvoth Jair.
07010005 When Jair died, he was buried in Kamon.
07010006 Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord. They served the Baals and the Ashtoreths, and the gods of Aram, the gods of Sidon, the gods of Moab, the gods of the Ammonites and the gods of the Philistines. And because the Israelites forsook the Lord and no longer served him,
07010007 he became angry with them. He sold them into the hands of the Philistines and the Ammonites,
07010008 who that year shattered and crushed them. For eighteen years they oppressed all the Israelites on the east side of the Jordan in Gilead, the land of the Amorites.
07010009 The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin and Ephraim; Israel was in great distress.
07010010 Then the Israelites cried out to the Lord, “We have sinned against you, forsaking our God and serving the Baals.”
07010011 The Lord replied, “When the Egyptians, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,
07010012 the Sidonians, the Amalekites and the Maonites oppressed you and you cried to me for help, did I not save you from their hands?
07010013 But you have forsaken me and served other gods, so I will no longer save you.
07010014 Go and cry out to the gods you have chosen. Let them save you when you are in trouble!”
07010015 But the Israelites said to the Lord, “We have sinned. Do with us whatever you think best, but please rescue us now.”
07010016 Then they got rid of the foreign gods among them and served the Lord. And he could bear Israel’s misery no longer.
07010017 When the Ammonites were called to arms and camped in Gilead, the Israelites assembled and camped at Mizpah.
07010018 The leaders of the people of Gilead said to each other, “Whoever will take the lead in attacking the Ammonites will be head over all who live in Gilead.”
07011001 Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty warrior. His father was Gilead; his mother was a prostitute.
07011002 Gilead’s wife also bore him sons, and when they were grown up, they drove Jephthah away. “You are not going to get any inheritance in our family,” they said, “because you are the son of another woman.”
07011003 So Jephthah fled from his brothers and settled in the land of Tob, where a gang of scoundrels gathered around him and followed him.
07011004 Some time later, when the Ammonites were fighting against Israel,
07011005 the elders of Gilead went to get Jephthah from the land of Tob.
07011006 “Come,” they said, “be our commander, so we can fight the Ammonites.”
07011007 Jephthah said to them, “Didn’t you hate me and drive me from my father’s house? Why do you come to me now, when you’re in trouble?”
07011008 The elders of Gilead said to him, “Nevertheless, we are turning to you now; come with us to fight the Ammonites, and you will be head over all of us who live in Gilead.”
07011009 Jephthah answered, “Suppose you take me back to fight the Ammonites and the Lord gives them to me—will I really be your head?”
07011010 The elders of Gilead replied, “The Lord is our witness; we will certainly do as you say.”
07011011 So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him head and commander over them. And he repeated all his words before the Lord in Mizpah.
07011012 Then Jephthah sent messengers to the Ammonite king with the question: “What do you have against me that you have attacked my country?”
07011013 The king of the Ammonites answered Jephthah’s messengers, “When Israel came up out of Egypt, they took away my land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, all the way to the Jordan. Now give it back peaceably.”
07011014 Jephthah sent back messengers to the Ammonite king,
07011015 saying: “This is what Jephthah says: Israel did not take the land of Moab or the land of the Ammonites.
07011016 But when they came up out of Egypt, Israel went through the wilderness to the Red Sea and on to Kadesh.
07011017 Then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, ‘Give us permission to go through your country,’ but the king of Edom would not listen. They sent also to the king of Moab, and he refused. So Israel stayed at Kadesh.
07011018 “Next they traveled through the wilderness, skirted the lands of Edom and Moab, passed along the eastern side of the country of Moab, and camped on the other side of the Arnon. They did not enter the territory of Moab, for the Arnon was its border.
07011019 “Then Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon, and said to him, ‘Let us pass through your country to our own place.’
07011020 Sihon, however, did not trust Israel to pass through his territory. He mustered all his troops and encamped at Jahaz and fought with Israel.
07011021 “Then the Lord, the God of Israel, gave Sihon and his whole army into Israel’s hands, and they defeated them. Israel took over all the land of the Amorites who lived in that country,
07011022 capturing all of it from the Arnon to the Jabbok and from the desert to the Jordan.
07011023 “Now since the Lord, the God of Israel, has driven the Amorites out before his people Israel, what right have you to take it over?
07011024 Will you not take what your god Chemosh gives you? Likewise, whatever the Lord our God has given us, we will possess.
07011025 Are you any better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever quarrel with Israel or fight with them?
07011026 For three hundred years Israel occupied Heshbon, Aroer, the surrounding settlements and all the towns along the Arnon. Why didn’t you retake them during that time?
07011027 I have not wronged you, but you are doing me wrong by waging war against me. Let the Lord, the Judge, decide the dispute this day between the Israelites and the Ammonites.”
07011028 The king of Ammon, however, paid no attention to the message Jephthah sent him.
07011029 Then the Spirit of the Lord came on Jephthah. He crossed Gilead and Manasseh, passed through Mizpah of Gilead, and from there he advanced against the Ammonites.
07011030 And Jephthah made a vow to the Lord: “If you give the Ammonites into my hands,
07011031 whatever comes out of the door of my house to meet me when I return in triumph from the Ammonites will be the Lord’s, and I will sacrifice it as a burnt offering.”
07011032 Then Jephthah went over to fight the Ammonites, and the Lord gave them into his hands.
07011033 He devastated twenty towns from Aroer to the vicinity of Minnith, as far as Abel Keramim. Thus Israel subdued Ammon.
07011034 When Jephthah returned to his home in Mizpah, who should come out to meet him but his daughter, dancing to the sound of timbrels! She was an only child. Except for her he had neither son nor daughter.
07011035 When he saw her, he tore his clothes and cried, “Oh no, my daughter! You have brought me down and I am devastated. I have made a vow to the Lord that I cannot break.”
07011036 “My father,” she replied, “you have given your word to the Lord. Do to me just as you promised, now that the Lord has avenged you of your enemies, the Ammonites.
07011037 But grant me this one request,” she said. “Give me two months to roam the hills and weep with my friends, because I will never marry.”
07011038 “You may go,” he said. And he let her go for two months. She and her friends went into the hills and wept because she would never marry.
07011039 After the two months, she returned to her father, and he did to her as he had vowed. And she was a virgin. From this comes the Israelite tradition
07011040 that each year the young women of Israel go out for four days to commemorate the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite.
07012001 The Ephraimite forces were called out, and they crossed over to Zaphon. They said to Jephthah, “Why did you go to fight the Ammonites without calling us to go with you? We’re going to burn down your house over your head.”
07012002 Jephthah answered, “I and my people were engaged in a great struggle with the Ammonites, and although I called, you didn’t save me out of their hands.
07012003 When I saw that you wouldn’t help, I took my life in my hands and crossed over to fight the Ammonites, and the Lord gave me the victory over them. Now why have you come up today to fight me?”
07012004 Jephthah then called together the men of Gilead and fought against Ephraim. The Gileadites struck them down because the Ephraimites had said, “You Gileadites are renegades from Ephraim and Manasseh.”
07012005 The Gileadites captured the fords of the Jordan leading to Ephraim, and whenever a survivor of Ephraim said, “Let me cross over,” the men of Gilead asked him, “Are you an Ephraimite?” If he replied, “No,”
07012006 they said, “All right, say ‘Shibboleth.’ ” If he said, “Sibboleth,” because he could not pronounce the word correctly, they seized him and killed him at the fords of the Jordan. Forty-two thousand Ephraimites were killed at that time.
07012007 Jephthah led Israel six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died and was buried in a town in Gilead.
07012008 After him, Ibzan of Bethlehem led Israel.
07012009 He had thirty sons and thirty daughters. He gave his daughters away in marriage to those outside his clan, and for his sons he brought in thirty young women as wives from outside his clan. Ibzan led Israel seven years.
07012010 Then Ibzan died and was buried in Bethlehem.
07012011 After him, Elon the Zebulunite led Israel ten years.
07012012 Then Elon died and was buried in Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
07012013 After him, Abdon son of Hillel, from Pirathon, led Israel.
07012014 He had forty sons and thirty grandsons, who rode on seventy donkeys. He led Israel eight years.
07012015 Then Abdon son of Hillel died and was buried at Pirathon in Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.
07013001 Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, so the Lord delivered them into the hands of the Philistines for forty years.
07013002 A certain man of Zorah, named Manoah, from the clan of the Danites, had a wife who was childless, unable to give birth.
07013003 The angel of the Lord appeared to her and said, “You are barren and childless, but you are going to become pregnant and give birth to a son.
07013004 Now see to it that you drink no wine or other fermented drink and that you do not eat anything unclean.
07013005 You will become pregnant and have a son whose head is never to be touched by a razor because the boy is to be a Nazirite, dedicated to God from the womb. He will take the lead in delivering Israel from the hands of the Philistines.”
07013006 Then the woman went to her husband and told him, “A man of God came to me. He looked like an angel of God, very awesome. I didn’t ask him where he came from, and he didn’t tell me his name.
07013007 But he said to me, ‘You will become pregnant and have a son. Now then, drink no wine or other fermented drink and do not eat anything unclean, because the boy will be a Nazirite of God from the womb until the day of his death.’ ”
07013008 Then Manoah prayed to the Lord: “Pardon your servant, Lord. I beg you to let the man of God you sent to us come again to teach us how to bring up the boy who is to be born.”
07013009 God heard Manoah, and the angel of God came again to the woman while she was out in the field; but her husband Manoah was not with her.
07013010 The woman hurried to tell her husband, “He’s here! The man who appeared to me the other day!”
07013011 Manoah got up and followed his wife. When he came to the man, he said, “Are you the man who talked to my wife?” “I am,” he said.
07013012 So Manoah asked him, “When your words are fulfilled, what is to be the rule that governs the boy’s life and work?”
07013013 The angel of the Lord answered, “Your wife must do all that I have told her.
07013014 She must not eat anything that comes from the grapevine, nor drink any wine or other fermented drink nor eat anything unclean. She must do everything I have commanded her.”
07013015 Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “We would like you to stay until we prepare a young goat for you.”
07013016 The angel of the Lord replied, “Even though you detain me, I will not eat any of your food. But if you prepare a burnt offering, offer it to the Lord.” (Manoah did not realize that it was the angel of the Lord.)
07013017 Then Manoah inquired of the angel of the Lord, “What is your name, so that we may honor you when your word comes true?”
07013018 He replied, “Why do you ask my name? It is beyond understanding. ”
07013019 Then Manoah took a young goat, together with the grain offering, and sacrificed it on a rock to the Lord. And the Lord did an amazing thing while Manoah and his wife watched:
07013020 As the flame blazed up from the altar toward heaven, the angel of the Lord ascended in the flame. Seeing this, Manoah and his wife fell with their faces to the ground.
07013021 When the angel of the Lord did not show himself again to Manoah and his wife, Manoah realized that it was the angel of the Lord.
07013022 “We are doomed to die!” he said to his wife. “We have seen God!”
07013023 But his wife answered, “If the Lord had meant to kill us, he would not have accepted a burnt offering and grain offering from our hands, nor shown us all these things or now told us this.”
07013024 The woman gave birth to a boy and named him Samson. He grew and the Lord blessed him,
07013025 and the Spirit of the Lord began to stir him while he was in Mahaneh Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
07014001 Samson went down to Timnah and saw there a young Philistine woman.
07014002 When he returned, he said to his father and mother, “I have seen a Philistine woman in Timnah; now get her for me as my wife.”
07014003 His father and mother replied, “Isn’t there an acceptable woman among your relatives or among all our people? Must you go to the uncircumcised Philistines to get a wife?” But Samson said to his father, “Get her for me. She’s the right one for me.”
07014004 (His parents did not know that this was from the Lord, who was seeking an occasion to confront the Philistines; for at that time they were ruling over Israel.)
07014005 Samson went down to Timnah together with his father and mother. As they approached the vineyards of Timnah, suddenly a young lion came roaring toward him.
07014006 The Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him so that he tore the lion apart with his bare hands as he might have torn a young goat. But he told neither his father nor his mother what he had done.
07014007 Then he went down and talked with the woman, and he liked her.
07014008 Some time later, when he went back to marry her, he turned aside to look at the lion’s carcass, and in it he saw a swarm of bees and some honey.
07014009 He scooped out the honey with his hands and ate as he went along. When he rejoined his parents, he gave them some, and they too ate it. But he did not tell them that he had taken the honey from the lion’s carcass.
07014010 Now his father went down to see the woman. And there Samson held a feast, as was customary for young men.
07014011 When the people saw him, they chose thirty men to be his companions.
07014012 “Let me tell you a riddle,” Samson said to them. “If you can give me the answer within the seven days of the feast, I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes.
07014013 If you can’t tell me the answer, you must give me thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes.” “Tell us your riddle,” they said. “Let’s hear it.”
07014014 He replied, “Out of the eater, something to eat; out of the strong, something sweet.” For three days they could not give the answer.
07014015 On the fourth day, they said to Samson’s wife, “Coax your husband into explaining the riddle for us, or we will burn you and your father’s household to death. Did you invite us here to steal our property?”
07014016 Then Samson’s wife threw herself on him, sobbing, “You hate me! You don’t really love me. You’ve given my people a riddle, but you haven’t told me the answer.” “I haven’t even explained it to my father or mother,” he replied, “so why should I explain it to you?”
07014017 She cried the whole seven days of the feast. So on the seventh day he finally told her, because she continued to press him. She in turn explained the riddle to her people.
07014018 Before sunset on the seventh day the men of the town said to him, “What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?” Samson said to them, “If you had not plowed with my heifer, you would not have solved my riddle.”
07014019 Then the Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him. He went down to Ashkelon, struck down thirty of their men, stripped them of everything and gave their clothes to those who had explained the riddle. Burning with anger, he returned to his father’s home.
07014020 And Samson’s wife was given to one of his companions who had attended him at the feast.
07015001 Later on, at the time of wheat harvest, Samson took a young goat and went to visit his wife. He said, “I’m going to my wife’s room.” But her father would not let him go in.
07015002 “I was so sure you hated her,” he said, “that I gave her to your companion. Isn’t her younger sister more attractive? Take her instead.”
07015003 Samson said to them, “This time I have a right to get even with the Philistines; I will really harm them.”
07015004 So he went out and caught three hundred foxes and tied them tail to tail in pairs. He then fastened a torch to every pair of tails,
07015005 lit the torches and let the foxes loose in the standing grain of the Philistines. He burned up the shocks and standing grain, together with the vineyards and olive groves.
07015006 When the Philistines asked, “Who did this?” they were told, “Samson, the Timnite’s son-in-law, because his wife was given to his companion.” So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father to death.
07015007 Samson said to them, “Since you’ve acted like this, I swear that I won’t stop until I get my revenge on you.”
07015008 He attacked them viciously and slaughtered many of them. Then he went down and stayed in a cave in the rock of Etam.
07015009 The Philistines went up and camped in Judah, spreading out near Lehi.
07015010 The people of Judah asked, “Why have you come to fight us?” “We have come to take Samson prisoner,” they answered, “to do to him as he did to us.”
07015011 Then three thousand men from Judah went down to the cave in the rock of Etam and said to Samson, “Don’t you realize that the Philistines are rulers over us? What have you done to us?” He answered, “I merely did to them what they did to me.”
07015012 They said to him, “We’ve come to tie you up and hand you over to the Philistines.” Samson said, “Swear to me that you won’t kill me yourselves.”
07015013 “Agreed,” they answered. “We will only tie you up and hand you over to them. We will not kill you.” So they bound him with two new ropes and led him up from the rock.
07015014 As he approached Lehi, the Philistines came toward him shouting. The Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him. The ropes on his arms became like charred flax, and the bindings dropped from his hands.
07015015 Finding a fresh jawbone of a donkey, he grabbed it and struck down a thousand men.
07015016 Then Samson said, “With a donkey’s jawbone I have made donkeys of them. With a donkey’s jawbone I have killed a thousand men.”
07015017 When he finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone; and the place was called Ramath Lehi.
07015018 Because he was very thirsty, he cried out to the Lord, “You have given your servant this great victory. Must I now die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?”
07015019 Then God opened up the hollow place in Lehi, and water came out of it. When Samson drank, his strength returned and he revived. So the spring was called En Hakkore, and it is still there in Lehi.
07015020 Samson led Israel for twenty years in the days of the Philistines.
07016001 One day Samson went to Gaza, where he saw a prostitute. He went in to spend the night with her.
07016002 The people of Gaza were told, “Samson is here!” So they surrounded the place and lay in wait for him all night at the city gate. They made no move during the night, saying, “At dawn we’ll kill him.”
07016003 But Samson lay there only until the middle of the night. Then he got up and took hold of the doors of the city gate, together with the two posts, and tore them loose, bar and all. He lifted them to his shoulders and carried them to the top of the hill that faces Hebron.
07016004 Some time later, he fell in love with a woman in the Valley of Sorek whose name was Delilah.
07016005 The rulers of the Philistines went to her and said, “See if you can lure him into showing you the secret of his great strength and how we can overpower him so we may tie him up and subdue him. Each one of us will give you eleven hundred shekels of silver.”
07016006 So Delilah said to Samson, “Tell me the secret of your great strength and how you can be tied up and subdued.”
07016007 Samson answered her, “If anyone ties me with seven fresh bowstrings that have not been dried, I’ll become as weak as any other man.”
07016008 Then the rulers of the Philistines brought her seven fresh bowstrings that had not been dried, and she tied him with them.
07016009 With men hidden in the room, she called to him, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” But he snapped the bowstrings as easily as a piece of string snaps when it comes close to a flame. So the secret of his strength was not discovered.
07016010 Then Delilah said to Samson, “You have made a fool of me; you lied to me. Come now, tell me how you can be tied.”
07016011 He said, “If anyone ties me securely with new ropes that have never been used, I’ll become as weak as any other man.”
07016012 So Delilah took new ropes and tied him with them. Then, with men hidden in the room, she called to him, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” But he snapped the ropes off his arms as if they were threads.
07016013 Delilah then said to Samson, “All this time you have been making a fool of me and lying to me. Tell me how you can be tied.” He replied, “If you weave the seven braids of my head into the fabric on the loom and tighten it with the pin, I’ll become as weak as any other man.” So while he was sleeping, Delilah took the seven braids of his head, wove them into the fabric
07016014 and tightened it with the pin. Again she called to him, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” He awoke from his sleep and pulled up the pin and the loom, with the fabric.
07016015 Then she said to him, “How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when you won’t confide in me? This is the third time you have made a fool of me and haven’t told me the secret of your great strength.”
07016016 With such nagging she prodded him day after day until he was sick to death of it.
07016017 So he told her everything. “No razor has ever been used on my head,” he said, “because I have been a Nazirite dedicated to God from my mother’s womb. If my head were shaved, my strength would leave me, and I would become as weak as any other man.”
07016018 When Delilah saw that he had told her everything, she sent word to the rulers of the Philistines, “Come back once more; he has told me everything.” So the rulers of the Philistines returned with the silver in their hands.
07016019 After putting him to sleep on her lap, she called for someone to shave off the seven braids of his hair, and so began to subdue him. And his strength left him.
07016020 Then she called, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” He awoke from his sleep and thought, “I’ll go out as before and shake myself free.” But he did not know that the Lord had left him.
07016021 Then the Philistines seized him, gouged out his eyes and took him down to Gaza. Binding him with bronze shackles, they set him to grinding grain in the prison.
07016022 But the hair on his head began to grow again after it had been shaved.
07016023 Now the rulers of the Philistines assembled to offer a great sacrifice to Dagon their god and to celebrate, saying, “Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands.”
07016024 When the people saw him, they praised their god, saying, “Our god has delivered our enemy into our hands, the one who laid waste our land and multiplied our slain.”
07016025 While they were in high spirits, they shouted, “Bring out Samson to entertain us.” So they called Samson out of the prison, and he performed for them. When they stood him among the pillars,
07016026 Samson said to the servant who held his hand, “Put me where I can feel the pillars that support the temple, so that I may lean against them.”
07016027 Now the temple was crowded with men and women; all the rulers of the Philistines were there, and on the roof were about three thousand men and women watching Samson perform.
07016028 Then Samson prayed to the Lord, “Sovereign Lord, remember me. Please, God, strengthen me just once more, and let me with one blow get revenge on the Philistines for my two eyes.”
07016029 Then Samson reached toward the two central pillars on which the temple stood. Bracing himself against them, his right hand on the one and his left hand on the other,
07016030 Samson said, “Let me die with the Philistines!” Then he pushed with all his might, and down came the temple on the rulers and all the people in it. Thus he killed many more when he died than while he lived.
07016031 Then his brothers and his father’s whole family went down to get him. They brought him back and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of Manoah his father. He had led Israel twenty years.
07017001 Now a man named Micah from the hill country of Ephraim
07017002 said to his mother, “The eleven hundred shekels of silver that were taken from you and about which I heard you utter a curse—I have that silver with me; I took it.” Then his mother said, “The Lord bless you, my son!”
07017003 When he returned the eleven hundred shekels of silver to his mother, she said, “I solemnly consecrate my silver to the Lord for my son to make an image overlaid with silver. I will give it back to you.”
07017004 So after he returned the silver to his mother, she took two hundred shekels of silver and gave them to a silversmith, who used them to make the idol. And it was put in Micah’s house.
07017005 Now this man Micah had a shrine, and he made an ephod and some household gods and installed one of his sons as his priest.
07017006 In those days Israel had no king; everyone did as they saw fit.
07017007 A young Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, who had been living within the clan of Judah,
07017008 left that town in search of some other place to stay. On his way he came to Micah’s house in the hill country of Ephraim.
07017009 Micah asked him, “Where are you from?” “I’m a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah,” he said, “and I’m looking for a place to stay.”
07017010 Then Micah said to him, “Live with me and be my father and priest, and I’ll give you ten shekels of silver a year, your clothes and your food.”
07017011 So the Levite agreed to live with him, and the young man became like one of his sons to him.
07017012 Then Micah installed the Levite, and the young man became his priest and lived in his house.
07017013 And Micah said, “Now I know that the Lord will be good to me, since this Levite has become my priest.”
07018001 In those days Israel had no king. And in those days the tribe of the Danites was seeking a place of their own where they might settle, because they had not yet come into an inheritance among the tribes of Israel.
07018002 So the Danites sent five of their leading men from Zorah and Eshtaol to spy out the land and explore it. These men represented all the Danites. They told them, “Go, explore the land.” So they entered the hill country of Ephraim and came to the house of Micah, where they spent the night.
07018003 When they were near Micah’s house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite; so they turned in there and asked him, “Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place? Why are you here?”
07018004 He told them what Micah had done for him, and said, “He has hired me and I am his priest.”
07018005 Then they said to him, “Please inquire of God to learn whether our journey will be successful.”
07018006 The priest answered them, “Go in peace. Your journey has the Lord’s approval.”
07018007 So the five men left and came to Laish, where they saw that the people were living in safety, like the Sidonians, at peace and secure. And since their land lacked nothing, they were prosperous. Also, they lived a long way from the Sidonians and had no relationship with anyone else.
07018008 When they returned to Zorah and Eshtaol, their fellow Danites asked them, “How did you find things?”
07018009 They answered, “Come on, let’s attack them! We have seen the land, and it is very good. Aren’t you going to do something? Don’t hesitate to go there and take it over.
07018010 When you get there, you will find an unsuspecting people and a spacious land that God has put into your hands, a land that lacks nothing whatever.”
07018011 Then six hundred men of the Danites, armed for battle, set out from Zorah and Eshtaol.
07018012 On their way they set up camp near Kiriath Jearim in Judah. This is why the place west of Kiriath Jearim is called Mahaneh Dan to this day.
07018013 From there they went on to the hill country of Ephraim and came to Micah’s house.
07018014 Then the five men who had spied out the land of Laish said to their fellow Danites, “Do you know that one of these houses has an ephod, some household gods and an image overlaid with silver? Now you know what to do.”
07018015 So they turned in there and went to the house of the young Levite at Micah’s place and greeted him.
07018016 The six hundred Danites, armed for battle, stood at the entrance of the gate.
07018017 The five men who had spied out the land went inside and took the idol, the ephod and the household gods while the priest and the six hundred armed men stood at the entrance of the gate.
07018018 When the five men went into Micah’s house and took the idol, the ephod and the household gods, the priest said to them, “What are you doing?”
07018019 They answered him, “Be quiet! Don’t say a word. Come with us, and be our father and priest. Isn’t it better that you serve a tribe and clan in Israel as priest rather than just one man’s household?”
07018020 The priest was very pleased. He took the ephod, the household gods and the idol and went along with the people.
07018021 Putting their little children, their livestock and their possessions in front of them, they turned away and left.
07018022 When they had gone some distance from Micah’s house, the men who lived near Micah were called together and overtook the Danites.
07018023 As they shouted after them, the Danites turned and said to Micah, “What’s the matter with you that you called out your men to fight?”
07018024 He replied, “You took the gods I made, and my priest, and went away. What else do I have? How can you ask, ‘What’s the matter with you?’ ”
07018025 The Danites answered, “Don’t argue with us, or some of the men may get angry and attack you, and you and your family will lose your lives.”
07018026 So the Danites went their way, and Micah, seeing that they were too strong for him, turned around and went back home.
07018027 Then they took what Micah had made, and his priest, and went on to Laish, against a people at peace and secure. They attacked them with the sword and burned down their city.
07018028 There was no one to rescue them because they lived a long way from Sidon and had no relationship with anyone else. The city was in a valley near Beth Rehob. The Danites rebuilt the city and settled there.
07018029 They named it Dan after their ancestor Dan, who was born to Israel—though the city used to be called Laish.
07018030 There the Danites set up for themselves the idol, and Jonathan son of Gershom, the son of Moses, and his sons were priests for the tribe of Dan until the time of the captivity of the land.
07018031 They continued to use the idol Micah had made, all the time the house of God was in Shiloh.
07019001 In those days Israel had no king. Now a Levite who lived in a remote area in the hill country of Ephraim took a concubine from Bethlehem in Judah.
07019002 But she was unfaithful to him. She left him and went back to her parents’ home in Bethlehem, Judah. After she had been there four months,
07019003 her husband went to her to persuade her to return. He had with him his servant and two donkeys. She took him into her parents’ home, and when her father saw him, he gladly welcomed him.
07019004 His father-in-law, the woman’s father, prevailed on him to stay; so he remained with him three days, eating and drinking, and sleeping there.
07019005 On the fourth day they got up early and he prepared to leave, but the woman’s father said to his son-in-law, “Refresh yourself with something to eat; then you can go.”
07019006 So the two of them sat down to eat and drink together. Afterward the woman’s father said, “Please stay tonight and enjoy yourself.”
07019007 And when the man got up to go, his father-in-law persuaded him, so he stayed there that night.
07019008 On the morning of the fifth day, when he rose to go, the woman’s father said, “Refresh yourself. Wait till afternoon!” So the two of them ate together.
07019009 Then when the man, with his concubine and his servant, got up to leave, his father-in-law, the woman’s father, said, “Now look, it’s almost evening. Spend the night here; the day is nearly over. Stay and enjoy yourself. Early tomorrow morning you can get up and be on your way home.”
07019010 But, unwilling to stay another night, the man left and went toward Jebus (that is, Jerusalem), with his two saddled donkeys and his concubine.
07019011 When they were near Jebus and the day was almost gone, the servant said to his master, “Come, let’s stop at this city of the Jebusites and spend the night.”
07019012 His master replied, “No. We won’t go into any city whose people are not Israelites. We will go on to Gibeah.”
07019013 He added, “Come, let’s try to reach Gibeah or Ramah and spend the night in one of those places.”
07019014 So they went on, and the sun set as they neared Gibeah in Benjamin.
07019015 There they stopped to spend the night. They went and sat in the city square, but no one took them in for the night.
07019016 That evening an old man from the hill country of Ephraim, who was living in Gibeah (the inhabitants of the place were Benjamites), came in from his work in the fields.
07019017 When he looked and saw the traveler in the city square, the old man asked, “Where are you going? Where did you come from?”
07019018 He answered, “We are on our way from Bethlehem in Judah to a remote area in the hill country of Ephraim where I live. I have been to Bethlehem in Judah and now I am going to the house of the Lord. No one has taken me in for the night.
07019019 We have both straw and fodder for our donkeys and bread and wine for ourselves your servants—me, the woman and the young man with us. We don’t need anything.”
07019020 “You are welcome at my house,” the old man said. “Let me supply whatever you need. Only don’t spend the night in the square.”
07019021 So he took him into his house and fed his donkeys. After they had washed their feet, they had something to eat and drink.
07019022 While they were enjoying themselves, some of the wicked men of the city surrounded the house. Pounding on the door, they shouted to the old man who owned the house, “Bring out the man who came to your house so we can have sex with him.”
07019023 The owner of the house went outside and said to them, “No, my friends, don’t be so vile. Since this man is my guest, don’t do this outrageous thing.
07019024 Look, here is my virgin daughter, and his concubine. I will bring them out to you now, and you can use them and do to them whatever you wish. But as for this man, don’t do such an outrageous thing.”
07019025 But the men would not listen to him. So the man took his concubine and sent her outside to them, and they raped her and abused her throughout the night, and at dawn they let her go.
07019026 At daybreak the woman went back to the house where her master was staying, fell down at the door and lay there until daylight.
07019027 When her master got up in the morning and opened the door of the house and stepped out to continue on his way, there lay his concubine, fallen in the doorway of the house, with her hands on the threshold.
07019028 He said to her, “Get up; let’s go.” But there was no answer. Then the man put her on his donkey and set out for home.
07019029 When he reached home, he took a knife and cut up his concubine, limb by limb, into twelve parts and sent them into all the areas of Israel.
07019030 Everyone who saw it was saying to one another, “Such a thing has never been seen or done, not since the day the Israelites came up out of Egypt. Just imagine! We must do something! So speak up!”
07020001 Then all Israel from Dan to Beersheba and from the land of Gilead came together as one and assembled before the Lord in Mizpah.
07020002 The leaders of all the people of the tribes of Israel took their places in the assembly of God’s people, four hundred thousand men armed with swords.
07020003 (The Benjamites heard that the Israelites had gone up to Mizpah.) Then the Israelites said, “Tell us how this awful thing happened.”
07020004 So the Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, said, “I and my concubine came to Gibeah in Benjamin to spend the night.
07020005 During the night the men of Gibeah came after me and surrounded the house, intending to kill me. They raped my concubine, and she died.
07020006 I took my concubine, cut her into pieces and sent one piece to each region of Israel’s inheritance, because they committed this lewd and outrageous act in Israel.
07020007 Now, all you Israelites, speak up and tell me what you have decided to do.”
07020008 All the men rose up together as one, saying, “None of us will go home. No, not one of us will return to his house.
07020009 But now this is what we’ll do to Gibeah: We’ll go up against it in the order decided by casting lots.
07020010 We’ll take ten men out of every hundred from all the tribes of Israel, and a hundred from a thousand, and a thousand from ten thousand, to get provisions for the army. Then, when the army arrives at Gibeah in Benjamin, it can give them what they deserve for this outrageous act done in Israel.”
07020011 So all the Israelites got together and united as one against the city.
07020012 The tribes of Israel sent messengers throughout the tribe of Benjamin, saying, “What about this awful crime that was committed among you?
07020013 Now turn those wicked men of Gibeah over to us so that we may put them to death and purge the evil from Israel.” But the Benjamites would not listen to their fellow Israelites.
07020014 From their towns they came together at Gibeah to fight against the Israelites.
07020015 At once the Benjamites mobilized twenty-six thousand swordsmen from their towns, in addition to seven hundred able young men from those living in Gibeah.
07020016 Among all these soldiers there were seven hundred select troops who were left-handed, each of whom could sling a stone at a hair and not miss.
07020017 Israel, apart from Benjamin, mustered four hundred thousand swordsmen, all of them fit for battle.
07020018 The Israelites went up to Bethel and inquired of God. They said, “Who of us is to go up first to fight against the Benjamites?” The Lord replied, “Judah shall go first.”
07020019 The next morning the Israelites got up and pitched camp near Gibeah.
07020020 The Israelites went out to fight the Benjamites and took up battle positions against them at Gibeah.
07020021 The Benjamites came out of Gibeah and cut down twenty-two thousand Israelites on the battlefield that day.
07020022 But the Israelites encouraged one another and again took up their positions where they had stationed themselves the first day.
07020023 The Israelites went up and wept before the Lord until evening, and they inquired of the Lord. They said, “Shall we go up again to fight against the Benjamites, our fellow Israelites?” The Lord answered, “Go up against them.”
07020024 Then the Israelites drew near to Benjamin the second day.
07020025 This time, when the Benjamites came out from Gibeah to oppose them, they cut down another eighteen thousand Israelites, all of them armed with swords.
07020026 Then all the Israelites, the whole army, went up to Bethel, and there they sat weeping before the Lord. They fasted that day until evening and presented burnt offerings and fellowship offerings to the Lord.
07020027 And the Israelites inquired of the Lord. (In those days the ark of the covenant of God was there,
07020028 with Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, ministering before it.) They asked, “Shall we go up again to fight against the Benjamites, our fellow Israelites, or not?” The Lord responded, “Go, for tomorrow I will give them into your hands.”
07020029 Then Israel set an ambush around Gibeah.
07020030 They went up against the Benjamites on the third day and took up positions against Gibeah as they had done before.
07020031 The Benjamites came out to meet them and were drawn away from the city. They began to inflict casualties on the Israelites as before, so that about thirty men fell in the open field and on the roads—the one leading to Bethel and the other to Gibeah.
07020032 While the Benjamites were saying, “We are defeating them as before,” the Israelites were saying, “Let’s retreat and draw them away from the city to the roads.”
07020033 All the men of Israel moved from their places and took up positions at Baal Tamar, and the Israelite ambush charged out of its place on the west of Gibeah.
07020034 Then ten thousand of Israel’s able young men made a frontal attack on Gibeah. The fighting was so heavy that the Benjamites did not realize how near disaster was.
07020035 The Lord defeated Benjamin before Israel, and on that day the Israelites struck down 25,100 Benjamites, all armed with swords.
07020036 Then the Benjamites saw that they were beaten. Now the men of Israel had given way before Benjamin, because they relied on the ambush they had set near Gibeah.
07020037 Those who had been in ambush made a sudden dash into Gibeah, spread out and put the whole city to the sword.
07020038 The Israelites had arranged with the ambush that they should send up a great cloud of smoke from the city,
07020039 and then the Israelites would counterattack. The Benjamites had begun to inflict casualties on the Israelites (about thirty), and they said, “We are defeating them as in the first battle.”
07020040 But when the column of smoke began to rise from the city, the Benjamites turned and saw the whole city going up in smoke.
07020041 Then the Israelites counterattacked, and the Benjamites were terrified, because they realized that disaster had come on them.
07020042 So they fled before the Israelites in the direction of the wilderness, but they could not escape the battle. And the Israelites who came out of the towns cut them down there.
07020043 They surrounded the Benjamites, chased them and easily overran them in the vicinity of Gibeah on the east.
07020044 Eighteen thousand Benjamites fell, all of them valiant fighters.
07020045 As they turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, the Israelites cut down five thousand men along the roads. They kept pressing after the Benjamites as far as Gidom and struck down two thousand more.
07020046 On that day twenty-five thousand Benjamite swordsmen fell, all of them valiant fighters.
07020047 But six hundred of them turned and fled into the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, where they stayed four months.
07020048 The men of Israel went back to Benjamin and put all the towns to the sword, including the animals and everything else they found. All the towns they came across they set on fire.
07021001 The men of Israel had taken an oath at Mizpah: “Not one of us will give his daughter in marriage to a Benjamite.”
07021002 The people went to Bethel, where they sat before God until evening, raising their voices and weeping bitterly.
07021003 “Lord, God of Israel,” they cried, “why has this happened to Israel? Why should one tribe be missing from Israel today?”
07021004 Early the next day the people built an altar and presented burnt offerings and fellowship offerings.
07021005 Then the Israelites asked, “Who from all the tribes of Israel has failed to assemble before the Lord?” For they had taken a solemn oath that anyone who failed to assemble before the Lord at Mizpah was to be put to death.
07021006 Now the Israelites grieved for the tribe of Benjamin, their fellow Israelites. “Today one tribe is cut off from Israel,” they said.
07021007 “How can we provide wives for those who are left, since we have taken an oath by the Lord not to give them any of our daughters in marriage?”
07021008 Then they asked, “Which one of the tribes of Israel failed to assemble before the Lord at Mizpah?” They discovered that no one from Jabesh Gilead had come to the camp for the assembly.
07021009 For when they counted the people, they found that none of the people of Jabesh Gilead were there.
07021010 So the assembly sent twelve thousand fighting men with instructions to go to Jabesh Gilead and put to the sword those living there, including the women and children.
07021011 “This is what you are to do,” they said. “Kill every male and every woman who is not a virgin.”
07021012 They found among the people living in Jabesh Gilead four hundred young women who had never slept with a man, and they took them to the camp at Shiloh in Canaan.
07021013 Then the whole assembly sent an offer of peace to the Benjamites at the rock of Rimmon.
07021014 So the Benjamites returned at that time and were given the women of Jabesh Gilead who had been spared. But there were not enough for all of them.
07021015 The people grieved for Benjamin, because the Lord had made a gap in the tribes of Israel.
07021016 And the elders of the assembly said, “With the women of Benjamin destroyed, how shall we provide wives for the men who are left?
07021017 The Benjamite survivors must have heirs,” they said, “so that a tribe of Israel will not be wiped out.
07021018 We can’t give them our daughters as wives, since we Israelites have taken this oath: ‘Cursed be anyone who gives a wife to a Benjamite.’
07021019 But look, there is the annual festival of the Lord in Shiloh, which lies north of Bethel, east of the road that goes from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah.”
07021020 So they instructed the Benjamites, saying, “Go and hide in the vineyards
07021021 and watch. When the young women of Shiloh come out to join in the dancing, rush from the vineyards and each of you seize one of them to be your wife. Then return to the land of Benjamin.
