10006020 When David returned home to bless his household, Michal daughter of Saul came out to meet him and said, “How the king of Israel has distinguished himself today, going around half-naked in full view of the slave girls of his servants as any vulgar fellow would!”
10006021 David said to Michal, “It was before the Lord, who chose me rather than your father or anyone from his house when he appointed me ruler over the Lord’s people Israel—I will celebrate before the Lord.
10006022 I will become even more undignified than this, and I will be humiliated in my own eyes. But by these slave girls you spoke of, I will be held in honor.”
10006023 And Michal daughter of Saul had no children to the day of her death.
10007001 After the king was settled in his palace and the Lord had given him rest from all his enemies around him,
10007002 he said to Nathan the prophet, “Here I am, living in a house of cedar, while the ark of God remains in a tent.”
10007003 Nathan replied to the king, “Whatever you have in mind, go ahead and do it, for the Lord is with you.”
10007004 But that night the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:
10007005 “Go and tell my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord says: Are you the one to build me a house to dwell in?
10007006 I have not dwelt in a house from the day I brought the Israelites up out of Egypt to this day. I have been moving from place to place with a tent as my dwelling.
10007007 Wherever I have moved with all the Israelites, did I ever say to any of their rulers whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, “Why have you not built me a house of cedar?” ’
10007008 “Now then, tell my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord Almighty says: I took you from the pasture, from tending the flock, and appointed you ruler over my people Israel.
10007009 I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. Now I will make your name great, like the names of the greatest men on earth.
10007010 And I will provide a place for my people Israel and will plant them so that they can have a home of their own and no longer be disturbed. Wicked people will not oppress them anymore, as they did at the beginning
10007011 and have done ever since the time I appointed leaders over my people Israel. I will also give you rest from all your enemies. “ ‘The Lord declares to you that the Lord himself will establish a house for you:
10007012 When your days are over and you rest with your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring to succeed you, your own flesh and blood, and I will establish his kingdom.
10007013 He is the one who will build a house for my Name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
10007014 I will be his father, and he will be my son. When he does wrong, I will punish him with a rod wielded by men, with floggings inflicted by human hands.
10007015 But my love will never be taken away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I removed from before you.
10007016 Your house and your kingdom will endure forever before me ; your throne will be established forever.’ ”
10007017 Nathan reported to David all the words of this entire revelation.
10007018 Then King David went in and sat before the Lord, and he said: “Who am I, Sovereign Lord, and what is my family, that you have brought me this far?
10007019 And as if this were not enough in your sight, Sovereign Lord, you have also spoken about the future of the house of your servant—and this decree, Sovereign Lord, is for a mere human!
10007020 “What more can David say to you? For you know your servant, Sovereign Lord.
10007021 For the sake of your word and according to your will, you have done this great thing and made it known to your servant.
10007022 “How great you are, Sovereign Lord! There is no one like you, and there is no God but you, as we have heard with our own ears.
10007023 And who is like your people Israel—the one nation on earth that God went out to redeem as a people for himself, and to make a name for himself, and to perform great and awesome wonders by driving out nations and their gods from before your people, whom you redeemed from Egypt?
10007024 You have established your people Israel as your very own forever, and you, Lord, have become their God.
10007025 “And now, Lord God, keep forever the promise you have made concerning your servant and his house. Do as you promised,
10007026 so that your name will be great forever. Then people will say, ‘The Lord Almighty is God over Israel!’ And the house of your servant David will be established in your sight.
10007027 “Lord Almighty, God of Israel, you have revealed this to your servant, saying, ‘I will build a house for you.’ So your servant has found courage to pray this prayer to you.
10007028 Sovereign Lord, you are God! Your covenant is trustworthy, and you have promised these good things to your servant.
10007029 Now be pleased to bless the house of your servant, that it may continue forever in your sight; for you, Sovereign Lord, have spoken, and with your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed forever.”
10008001 In the course of time, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, and he took Metheg Ammah from the control of the Philistines.
10008002 David also defeated the Moabites. He made them lie down on the ground and measured them off with a length of cord. Every two lengths of them were put to death, and the third length was allowed to live. So the Moabites became subject to David and brought him tribute.
10008003 Moreover, David defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to restore his monument at the Euphrates River.
10008004 David captured a thousand of his chariots, seven thousand charioteers and twenty thousand foot soldiers. He hamstrung all but a hundred of the chariot horses.
10008005 When the Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand of them.
10008006 He put garrisons in the Aramean kingdom of Damascus, and the Arameans became subject to him and brought tribute. The Lord gave David victory wherever he went.
10008007 David took the gold shields that belonged to the officers of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
10008008 From Tebah and Berothai, towns that belonged to Hadadezer, King David took a great quantity of bronze.
10008009 When Tou king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,
10008010 he sent his son Joram to King David to greet him and congratulate him on his victory in battle over Hadadezer, who had been at war with Tou. Joram brought with him articles of silver, of gold and of bronze.
10008011 King David dedicated these articles to the Lord, as he had done with the silver and gold from all the nations he had subdued:
10008012 Edom and Moab, the Ammonites and the Philistines, and Amalek. He also dedicated the plunder taken from Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
10008013 And David became famous after he returned from striking down eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
10008014 He put garrisons throughout Edom, and all the Edomites became subject to David. The Lord gave David victory wherever he went.
10008015 David reigned over all Israel, doing what was just and right for all his people.
10008016 Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
10008017 Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelek son of Abiathar were priests; Seraiah was secretary;
10008018 Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites; and David’s sons were priests.
10009001 David asked, “Is there anyone still left of the house of Saul to whom I can show kindness for Jonathan’s sake?”
10009002 Now there was a servant of Saul’s household named Ziba. They summoned him to appear before David, and the king said to him, “Are you Ziba?” “At your service,” he replied.
10009003 The king asked, “Is there no one still alive from the house of Saul to whom I can show God’s kindness?” Ziba answered the king, “There is still a son of Jonathan; he is lame in both feet.”
10009004 “Where is he?” the king asked. Ziba answered, “He is at the house of Makir son of Ammiel in Lo Debar.”
10009005 So King David had him brought from Lo Debar, from the house of Makir son of Ammiel.
10009006 When Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David, he bowed down to pay him honor. David said, “Mephibosheth!” “At your service,” he replied.
10009007 “Don’t be afraid,” David said to him, “for I will surely show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan. I will restore to you all the land that belonged to your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.”
10009008 Mephibosheth bowed down and said, “What is your servant, that you should notice a dead dog like me?”
10009009 Then the king summoned Ziba, Saul’s steward, and said to him, “I have given your master’s grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family.
10009010 You and your sons and your servants are to farm the land for him and bring in the crops, so that your master’s grandson may be provided for. And Mephibosheth, grandson of your master, will always eat at my table.” (Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.)
10009011 Then Ziba said to the king, “Your servant will do whatever my lord the king commands his servant to do.” So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table like one of the king’s sons.
10009012 Mephibosheth had a young son named Mika, and all the members of Ziba’s household were servants of Mephibosheth.
10009013 And Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king’s table; he was lame in both feet.
10010001 In the course of time, the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun succeeded him as king.
10010002 David thought, “I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent a delegation to express his sympathy to Hanun concerning his father. When David’s men came to the land of the Ammonites,
10010003 the Ammonite commanders said to Hanun their lord, “Do you think David is honoring your father by sending envoys to you to express sympathy? Hasn’t David sent them to you only to explore the city and spy it out and overthrow it?”
10010004 So Hanun seized David’s envoys, shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their garments at the buttocks, and sent them away.
10010005 When David was told about this, he sent messengers to meet the men, for they were greatly humiliated. The king said, “Stay at Jericho till your beards have grown, and then come back.”
10010006 When the Ammonites realized that they had become obnoxious to David, they hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth Rehob and Zobah, as well as the king of Maakah with a thousand men, and also twelve thousand men from Tob.
10010007 On hearing this, David sent Joab out with the entire army of fighting men.
10010008 The Ammonites came out and drew up in battle formation at the entrance of their city gate, while the Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maakah were by themselves in the open country.
10010009 Joab saw that there were battle lines in front of him and behind him; so he selected some of the best troops in Israel and deployed them against the Arameans.
10010010 He put the rest of the men under the command of Abishai his brother and deployed them against the Ammonites.
10010011 Joab said, “If the Arameans are too strong for me, then you are to come to my rescue; but if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come to rescue you.
10010012 Be strong, and let us fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. The Lord will do what is good in his sight.”
10010013 Then Joab and the troops with him advanced to fight the Arameans, and they fled before him.
10010014 When the Ammonites realized that the Arameans were fleeing, they fled before Abishai and went inside the city. So Joab returned from fighting the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
10010015 After the Arameans saw that they had been routed by Israel, they regrouped.
10010016 Hadadezer had Arameans brought from beyond the Euphrates River; they went to Helam, with Shobak the commander of Hadadezer’s army leading them.
10010017 When David was told of this, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan and went to Helam. The Arameans formed their battle lines to meet David and fought against him.
10010018 But they fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred of their charioteers and forty thousand of their foot soldiers. He also struck down Shobak the commander of their army, and he died there.
10010019 When all the kings who were vassals of Hadadezer saw that they had been routed by Israel, they made peace with the Israelites and became subject to them. So the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites anymore.
10011001 In the spring, at the time when kings go off to war, David sent Joab out with the king’s men and the whole Israelite army. They destroyed the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah. But David remained in Jerusalem.
10011002 One evening David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of the palace. From the roof he saw a woman bathing. The woman was very beautiful,
10011003 and David sent someone to find out about her. The man said, “She is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”
10011004 Then David sent messengers to get her. She came to him, and he slept with her. (Now she was purifying herself from her monthly uncleanness.) Then she went back home.
10011005 The woman conceived and sent word to David, saying, “I am pregnant.”
10011006 So David sent this word to Joab: “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” And Joab sent him to David.
10011007 When Uriah came to him, David asked him how Joab was, how the soldiers were and how the war was going.
10011008 Then David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house and wash your feet.” So Uriah left the palace, and a gift from the king was sent after him.
10011009 But Uriah slept at the entrance to the palace with all his master’s servants and did not go down to his house.
10011010 David was told, “Uriah did not go home.” So he asked Uriah, “Haven’t you just come from a military campaign? Why didn’t you go home?”
10011011 Uriah said to David, “The ark and Israel and Judah are staying in tents, and my commander Joab and my lord’s men are camped in the open country. How could I go to my house to eat and drink and make love to my wife? As surely as you live, I will not do such a thing!”
10011012 Then David said to him, “Stay here one more day, and tomorrow I will send you back.” So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the next.
10011013 At David’s invitation, he ate and drank with him, and David made him drunk. But in the evening Uriah went out to sleep on his mat among his master’s servants; he did not go home.
10011014 In the morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.
10011015 In it he wrote, “Put Uriah out in front where the fighting is fiercest. Then withdraw from him so he will be struck down and die.”
10011016 So while Joab had the city under siege, he put Uriah at a place where he knew the strongest defenders were.
10011017 When the men of the city came out and fought against Joab, some of the men in David’s army fell; moreover, Uriah the Hittite died.
10011018 Joab sent David a full account of the battle.
10011019 He instructed the messenger: “When you have finished giving the king this account of the battle,
10011020 the king’s anger may flare up, and he may ask you, ‘Why did you get so close to the city to fight? Didn’t you know they would shoot arrows from the wall?
10011021 Who killed Abimelek son of Jerub-Besheth ? Didn’t a woman drop an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you get so close to the wall?’ If he asks you this, then say to him, ‘Moreover, your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead.’ ”
10011022 The messenger set out, and when he arrived he told David everything Joab had sent him to say.
10011023 The messenger said to David, “The men overpowered us and came out against us in the open, but we drove them back to the entrance of the city gate.
10011024 Then the archers shot arrows at your servants from the wall, and some of the king’s men died. Moreover, your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead.”
10011025 David told the messenger, “Say this to Joab: ‘Don’t let this upset you; the sword devours one as well as another. Press the attack against the city and destroy it.’ Say this to encourage Joab.”
10011026 When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for him.
10011027 After the time of mourning was over, David had her brought to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing David had done displeased the Lord.
10012001 The Lord sent Nathan to David. When he came to him, he said, “There were two men in a certain town, one rich and the other poor.
10012002 The rich man had a very large number of sheep and cattle,
10012003 but the poor man had nothing except one little ewe lamb he had bought. He raised it, and it grew up with him and his children. It shared his food, drank from his cup and even slept in his arms. It was like a daughter to him.
10012004 “Now a traveler came to the rich man, but the rich man refrained from taking one of his own sheep or cattle to prepare a meal for the traveler who had come to him. Instead, he took the ewe lamb that belonged to the poor man and prepared it for the one who had come to him.”
10012005 David burned with anger against the man and said to Nathan, “As surely as the Lord lives, the man who did this must die!
10012006 He must pay for that lamb four times over, because he did such a thing and had no pity.”
10012007 Then Nathan said to David, “You are the man! This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
10012008 I gave your master’s house to you, and your master’s wives into your arms. I gave you all Israel and Judah. And if all this had been too little, I would have given you even more.
10012009 Why did you despise the word of the Lord by doing what is evil in his eyes? You struck down Uriah the Hittite with the sword and took his wife to be your own. You killed him with the sword of the Ammonites.
10012010 Now, therefore, the sword will never depart from your house, because you despised me and took the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own.’
10012011 “This is what the Lord says: ‘Out of your own household I am going to bring calamity on you. Before your very eyes I will take your wives and give them to one who is close to you, and he will sleep with your wives in broad daylight.
10012012 You did it in secret, but I will do this thing in broad daylight before all Israel.’ ”
10012013 Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.” Nathan replied, “The Lord has taken away your sin. You are not going to die.
10012014 But because by doing this you have shown utter contempt for the Lord, the son born to you will die.”
10012015 After Nathan had gone home, the Lord struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne to David, and he became ill.
10012016 David pleaded with God for the child. He fasted and spent the nights lying in sackcloth on the ground.
10012017 The elders of his household stood beside him to get him up from the ground, but he refused, and he would not eat any food with them.
10012018 On the seventh day the child died. David’s attendants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they thought, “While the child was still living, he wouldn’t listen to us when we spoke to him. How can we now tell him the child is dead? He may do something desperate.”
10012019 David noticed that his attendants were whispering among themselves, and he realized the child was dead. “Is the child dead?” he asked. “Yes,” they replied, “he is dead.”
10012020 Then David got up from the ground. After he had washed, put on lotions and changed his clothes, he went into the house of the Lord and worshiped. Then he went to his own house, and at his request they served him food, and he ate.
10012021 His attendants asked him, “Why are you acting this way? While the child was alive, you fasted and wept, but now that the child is dead, you get up and eat!”
10012022 He answered, “While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept. I thought, ‘Who knows? The Lord may be gracious to me and let the child live.’
10012023 But now that he is dead, why should I go on fasting? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.”
10012024 Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba, and he went to her and made love to her. She gave birth to a son, and they named him Solomon. The Lord loved him;
10012025 and because the Lord loved him, he sent word through Nathan the prophet to name him Jedidiah.
10012026 Meanwhile Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal citadel.
10012027 Joab then sent messengers to David, saying, “I have fought against Rabbah and taken its water supply.
10012028 Now muster the rest of the troops and besiege the city and capture it. Otherwise I will take the city, and it will be named after me.”
10012029 So David mustered the entire army and went to Rabbah, and attacked and captured it.
10012030 David took the crown from their king’s head, and it was placed on his own head. It weighed a talent of gold, and it was set with precious stones. David took a great quantity of plunder from the city
10012031 and brought out the people who were there, consigning them to labor with saws and with iron picks and axes, and he made them work at brickmaking. David did this to all the Ammonite towns. Then he and his entire army returned to Jerusalem.
10013001 In the course of time, Amnon son of David fell in love with Tamar, the beautiful sister of Absalom son of David.
10013002 Amnon became so obsessed with his sister Tamar that he made himself ill. She was a virgin, and it seemed impossible for him to do anything to her.
10013003 Now Amnon had an adviser named Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother. Jonadab was a very shrewd man.
10013004 He asked Amnon, “Why do you, the king’s son, look so haggard morning after morning? Won’t you tell me?” Amnon said to him, “I’m in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.”
10013005 “Go to bed and pretend to be ill,” Jonadab said. “When your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘I would like my sister Tamar to come and give me something to eat. Let her prepare the food in my sight so I may watch her and then eat it from her hand.’ ”
10013006 So Amnon lay down and pretended to be ill. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to him, “I would like my sister Tamar to come and make some special bread in my sight, so I may eat from her hand.”
10013007 David sent word to Tamar at the palace: “Go to the house of your brother Amnon and prepare some food for him.”
10013008 So Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was lying down. She took some dough, kneaded it, made the bread in his sight and baked it.
10013009 Then she took the pan and served him the bread, but he refused to eat. “Send everyone out of here,” Amnon said. So everyone left him.
10013010 Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food here into my bedroom so I may eat from your hand.” And Tamar took the bread she had prepared and brought it to her brother Amnon in his bedroom.
10013011 But when she took it to him to eat, he grabbed her and said, “Come to bed with me, my sister.”
10013012 “No, my brother!” she said to him. “Don’t force me! Such a thing should not be done in Israel! Don’t do this wicked thing.
10013013 What about me? Where could I get rid of my disgrace? And what about you? You would be like one of the wicked fools in Israel. Please speak to the king; he will not keep me from being married to you.”
10013014 But he refused to listen to her, and since he was stronger than she, he raped her.
10013015 Then Amnon hated her with intense hatred. In fact, he hated her more than he had loved her. Amnon said to her, “Get up and get out!”
10013016 “No!” she said to him. “Sending me away would be a greater wrong than what you have already done to me.” But he refused to listen to her.
10013017 He called his personal servant and said, “Get this woman out of my sight and bolt the door after her.”
10013018 So his servant put her out and bolted the door after her. She was wearing an ornate robe, for this was the kind of garment the virgin daughters of the king wore.
10013019 Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the ornate robe she was wearing. She put her hands on her head and went away, weeping aloud as she went.
10013020 Her brother Absalom said to her, “Has that Amnon, your brother, been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister; he is your brother. Don’t take this thing to heart.” And Tamar lived in her brother Absalom’s house, a desolate woman.
10013021 When King David heard all this, he was furious.
10013022 And Absalom never said a word to Amnon, either good or bad; he hated Amnon because he had disgraced his sister Tamar.
10013023 Two years later, when Absalom’s sheepshearers were at Baal Hazor near the border of Ephraim, he invited all the king’s sons to come there.
10013024 Absalom went to the king and said, “Your servant has had shearers come. Will the king and his attendants please join me?”
10013025 “No, my son,” the king replied. “All of us should not go; we would only be a burden to you.” Although Absalom urged him, he still refused to go but gave him his blessing.
10013026 Then Absalom said, “If not, please let my brother Amnon come with us.” The king asked him, “Why should he go with you?”
10013027 But Absalom urged him, so he sent with him Amnon and the rest of the king’s sons.
10013028 Absalom ordered his men, “Listen! When Amnon is in high spirits from drinking wine and I say to you, ‘Strike Amnon down,’ then kill him. Don’t be afraid. Haven’t I given you this order? Be strong and brave.”
10013029 So Absalom’s men did to Amnon what Absalom had ordered. Then all the king’s sons got up, mounted their mules and fled.
10013030 While they were on their way, the report came to David: “Absalom has struck down all the king’s sons; not one of them is left.”
10013031 The king stood up, tore his clothes and lay down on the ground; and all his attendants stood by with their clothes torn.
10013032 But Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother, said, “My lord should not think that they killed all the princes; only Amnon is dead. This has been Absalom’s express intention ever since the day Amnon raped his sister Tamar.
10013033 My lord the king should not be concerned about the report that all the king’s sons are dead. Only Amnon is dead.”
10013034 Meanwhile, Absalom had fled. Now the man standing watch looked up and saw many people on the road west of him, coming down the side of the hill. The watchman went and told the king, “I see men in the direction of Horonaim, on the side of the hill.”
10013035 Jonadab said to the king, “See, the king’s sons have come; it has happened just as your servant said.”
10013036 As he finished speaking, the king’s sons came in, wailing loudly. The king, too, and all his attendants wept very bitterly.
10013037 Absalom fled and went to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. But King David mourned many days for his son.
10013038 After Absalom fled and went to Geshur, he stayed there three years.
10013039 And King David longed to go to Absalom, for he was consoled concerning Amnon’s death.
10014001 Joab son of Zeruiah knew that the king’s heart longed for Absalom.
10014002 So Joab sent someone to Tekoa and had a wise woman brought from there. He said to her, “Pretend you are in mourning. Dress in mourning clothes, and don’t use any cosmetic lotions. Act like a woman who has spent many days grieving for the dead.
10014003 Then go to the king and speak these words to him.” And Joab put the words in her mouth.
10014004 When the woman from Tekoa went to the king, she fell with her face to the ground to pay him honor, and she said, “Help me, Your Majesty!”
10014005 The king asked her, “What is troubling you?” She said, “I am a widow; my husband is dead.
10014006 I your servant had two sons. They got into a fight with each other in the field, and no one was there to separate them. One struck the other and killed him.
10014007 Now the whole clan has risen up against your servant; they say, ‘Hand over the one who struck his brother down, so that we may put him to death for the life of his brother whom he killed; then we will get rid of the heir as well.’ They would put out the only burning coal I have left, leaving my husband neither name nor descendant on the face of the earth.”
10014008 The king said to the woman, “Go home, and I will issue an order in your behalf.”
10014009 But the woman from Tekoa said to him, “Let my lord the king pardon me and my family, and let the king and his throne be without guilt.”
10014010 The king replied, “If anyone says anything to you, bring them to me, and they will not bother you again.”
10014011 She said, “Then let the king invoke the Lord his God to prevent the avenger of blood from adding to the destruction, so that my son will not be destroyed.” “As surely as the Lord lives,” he said, “not one hair of your son’s head will fall to the ground.”
10014012 Then the woman said, “Let your servant speak a word to my lord the king.” “Speak,” he replied.
10014013 The woman said, “Why then have you devised a thing like this against the people of God? When the king says this, does he not convict himself, for the king has not brought back his banished son?
10014014 Like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be recovered, so we must die. But that is not what God desires; rather, he devises ways so that a banished person does not remain banished from him.
10014015 “And now I have come to say this to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. Your servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king; perhaps he will grant his servant’s request.
10014016 Perhaps the king will agree to deliver his servant from the hand of the man who is trying to cut off both me and my son from God’s inheritance.’
10014017 “And now your servant says, ‘May the word of my lord the king secure my inheritance, for my lord the king is like an angel of God in discerning good and evil. May the Lord your God be with you.’ ”
10014018 Then the king said to the woman, “Don’t keep from me the answer to what I am going to ask you.” “Let my lord the king speak,” the woman said.
10014019 The king asked, “Isn’t the hand of Joab with you in all this?” The woman answered, “As surely as you live, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or to the left from anything my lord the king says. Yes, it was your servant Joab who instructed me to do this and who put all these words into the mouth of your servant.
10014020 Your servant Joab did this to change the present situation. My lord has wisdom like that of an angel of God—he knows everything that happens in the land.”
10014021 The king said to Joab, “Very well, I will do it. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.”
10014022 Joab fell with his face to the ground to pay him honor, and he blessed the king. Joab said, “Today your servant knows that he has found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, because the king has granted his servant’s request.”
10014023 Then Joab went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
10014024 But the king said, “He must go to his own house; he must not see my face.” So Absalom went to his own house and did not see the face of the king.
10014025 In all Israel there was not a man so highly praised for his handsome appearance as Absalom. From the top of his head to the sole of his foot there was no blemish in him.
10014026 Whenever he cut the hair of his head—he used to cut his hair once a year because it became too heavy for him—he would weigh it, and its weight was two hundred shekels by the royal standard.
10014027 Three sons and a daughter were born to Absalom. His daughter’s name was Tamar, and she became a beautiful woman.
10014028 Absalom lived two years in Jerusalem without seeing the king’s face.
10014029 Then Absalom sent for Joab in order to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. So he sent a second time, but he refused to come.
10014030 Then he said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
10014031 Then Joab did go to Absalom’s house, and he said to him, “Why have your servants set my field on fire?”
10014032 Absalom said to Joab, “Look, I sent word to you and said, ‘Come here so I can send you to the king to ask, “Why have I come from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there!” ’ Now then, I want to see the king’s face, and if I am guilty of anything, let him put me to death.”
10014033 So Joab went to the king and told him this. Then the king summoned Absalom, and he came in and bowed down with his face to the ground before the king. And the king kissed Absalom.
10015001 In the course of time, Absalom provided himself with a chariot and horses and with fifty men to run ahead of him.
10015002 He would get up early and stand by the side of the road leading to the city gate. Whenever anyone came with a complaint to be placed before the king for a decision, Absalom would call out to him, “What town are you from?” He would answer, “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel.”
10015003 Then Absalom would say to him, “Look, your claims are valid and proper, but there is no representative of the king to hear you.”
10015004 And Absalom would add, “If only I were appointed judge in the land! Then everyone who has a complaint or case could come to me and I would see that they receive justice.”
10015005 Also, whenever anyone approached him to bow down before him, Absalom would reach out his hand, take hold of him and kiss him.
10015006 Absalom behaved in this way toward all the Israelites who came to the king asking for justice, and so he stole the hearts of the people of Israel.
10015007 At the end of four years, Absalom said to the king, “Let me go to Hebron and fulfill a vow I made to the Lord.
10015008 While your servant was living at Geshur in Aram, I made this vow: ‘If the Lord takes me back to Jerusalem, I will worship the Lord in Hebron. ’ ”
10015009 The king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he went to Hebron.
10015010 Then Absalom sent secret messengers throughout the tribes of Israel to say, “As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpets, then say, ‘Absalom is king in Hebron.’ ”
10015011 Two hundred men from Jerusalem had accompanied Absalom. They had been invited as guests and went quite innocently, knowing nothing about the matter.
10015012 While Absalom was offering sacrifices, he also sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, to come from Giloh, his hometown. And so the conspiracy gained strength, and Absalom’s following kept on increasing.
10015013 A messenger came and told David, “The hearts of the people of Israel are with Absalom.”
10015014 Then David said to all his officials who were with him in Jerusalem, “Come! We must flee, or none of us will escape from Absalom. We must leave immediately, or he will move quickly to overtake us and bring ruin on us and put the city to the sword.”
10015015 The king’s officials answered him, “Your servants are ready to do whatever our lord the king chooses.”
10015016 The king set out, with his entire household following him; but he left ten concubines to take care of the palace.
10015017 So the king set out, with all the people following him, and they halted at the edge of the city.
10015018 All his men marched past him, along with all the Kerethites and Pelethites; and all the six hundred Gittites who had accompanied him from Gath marched before the king.
10015019 The king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why should you come along with us? Go back and stay with King Absalom. You are a foreigner, an exile from your homeland.
10015020 You came only yesterday. And today shall I make you wander about with us, when I do not know where I am going? Go back, and take your people with you. May the Lord show you kindness and faithfulness.”
10015021 But Ittai replied to the king, “As surely as the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means life or death, there will your servant be.”
10015022 David said to Ittai, “Go ahead, march on.” So Ittai the Gittite marched on with all his men and the families that were with him.
10015023 The whole countryside wept aloud as all the people passed by. The king also crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people moved on toward the wilderness.
10015024 Zadok was there, too, and all the Levites who were with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had finished leaving the city.
10015025 Then the king said to Zadok, “Take the ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the Lord’s eyes, he will bring me back and let me see it and his dwelling place again.
10015026 But if he says, ‘I am not pleased with you,’ then I am ready; let him do to me whatever seems good to him.”
10015027 The king also said to Zadok the priest, “Do you understand? Go back to the city with my blessing. Take your son Ahimaaz with you, and also Abiathar’s son Jonathan. You and Abiathar return with your two sons.
10015028 I will wait at the fords in the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.”
10015029 So Zadok and Abiathar took the ark of God back to Jerusalem and stayed there.
10015030 But David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went; his head was covered and he was barefoot. All the people with him covered their heads too and were weeping as they went up.
10015031 Now David had been told, “Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.” So David prayed, “Lord, turn Ahithophel’s counsel into foolishness.”
10015032 When David arrived at the summit, where people used to worship God, Hushai the Arkite was there to meet him, his robe torn and dust on his head.
10015033 David said to him, “If you go with me, you will be a burden to me.
10015034 But if you return to the city and say to Absalom, ‘Your Majesty, I will be your servant; I was your father’s servant in the past, but now I will be your servant,’ then you can help me by frustrating Ahithophel’s advice.
10015035 Won’t the priests Zadok and Abiathar be there with you? Tell them anything you hear in the king’s palace.
10015036 Their two sons, Ahimaaz son of Zadok and Jonathan son of Abiathar, are there with them. Send them to me with anything you hear.”
10015037 So Hushai, David’s confidant, arrived at Jerusalem as Absalom was entering the city.
10016001 When David had gone a short distance beyond the summit, there was Ziba, the steward of Mephibosheth, waiting to meet him. He had a string of donkeys saddled and loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred cakes of raisins, a hundred cakes of figs and a skin of wine.
10016002 The king asked Ziba, “Why have you brought these?” Ziba answered, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride on, the bread and fruit are for the men to eat, and the wine is to refresh those who become exhausted in the wilderness.”
10016003 The king then asked, “Where is your master’s grandson?” Ziba said to him, “He is staying in Jerusalem, because he thinks, ‘Today the Israelites will restore to me my grandfather’s kingdom.’ ”
10016004 Then the king said to Ziba, “All that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.” “I humbly bow,” Ziba said. “May I find favor in your eyes, my lord the king.”
10016005 As King David approached Bahurim, a man from the same clan as Saul’s family came out from there. His name was Shimei son of Gera, and he cursed as he came out.
10016006 He pelted David and all the king’s officials with stones, though all the troops and the special guard were on David’s right and left.
10016007 As he cursed, Shimei said, “Get out, get out, you murderer, you scoundrel!
10016008 The Lord has repaid you for all the blood you shed in the household of Saul, in whose place you have reigned. The Lord has given the kingdom into the hands of your son Absalom. You have come to ruin because you are a murderer!”
10016009 Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head.”
10016010 But the king said, “What does this have to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the Lord said to him, ‘Curse David,’ who can ask, ‘Why do you do this?’ ”
10016011 David then said to Abishai and all his officials, “My son, my own flesh and blood, is trying to kill me. How much more, then, this Benjamite! Leave him alone; let him curse, for the Lord has told him to.
10016012 It may be that the Lord will look upon my misery and restore to me his covenant blessing instead of his curse today.”
10016013 So David and his men continued along the road while Shimei was going along the hillside opposite him, cursing as he went and throwing stones at him and showering him with dirt.
10016014 The king and all the people with him arrived at their destination exhausted. And there he refreshed himself.
10016015 Meanwhile, Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
10016016 Then Hushai the Arkite, David’s confidant, went to Absalom and said to him, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
10016017 Absalom said to Hushai, “So this is the love you show your friend? If he’s your friend, why didn’t you go with him?”
10016018 Hushai said to Absalom, “No, the one chosen by the Lord, by these people, and by all the men of Israel—his I will be, and I will remain with him.
10016019 Furthermore, whom should I serve? Should I not serve the son? Just as I served your father, so I will serve you.”
10016020 Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give us your advice. What should we do?”
10016021 Ahithophel answered, “Sleep with your father’s concubines whom he left to take care of the palace. Then all Israel will hear that you have made yourself obnoxious to your father, and the hands of everyone with you will be more resolute.”
10016022 So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he slept with his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
10016023 Now in those days the advice Ahithophel gave was like that of one who inquires of God. That was how both David and Absalom regarded all of Ahithophel’s advice.
10017001 Ahithophel said to Absalom, “I would choose twelve thousand men and set out tonight in pursuit of David.
10017002 I would attack him while he is weary and weak. I would strike him with terror, and then all the people with him will flee. I would strike down only the king
10017003 and bring all the people back to you. The death of the man you seek will mean the return of all; all the people will be unharmed.”
10017004 This plan seemed good to Absalom and to all the elders of Israel.
10017005 But Absalom said, “Summon also Hushai the Arkite, so we can hear what he has to say as well.”
10017006 When Hushai came to him, Absalom said, “Ahithophel has given this advice. Should we do what he says? If not, give us your opinion.”
10017007 Hushai replied to Absalom, “The advice Ahithophel has given is not good this time.
10017008 You know your father and his men; they are fighters, and as fierce as a wild bear robbed of her cubs. Besides, your father is an experienced fighter; he will not spend the night with the troops.
10017009 Even now, he is hidden in a cave or some other place. If he should attack your troops first, whoever hears about it will say, ‘There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.’
10017010 Then even the bravest soldier, whose heart is like the heart of a lion, will melt with fear, for all Israel knows that your father is a fighter and that those with him are brave.
10017011 “So I advise you: Let all Israel, from Dan to Beersheba—as numerous as the sand on the seashore—be gathered to you, with you yourself leading them into battle.
10017012 Then we will attack him wherever he may be found, and we will fall on him as dew settles on the ground. Neither he nor any of his men will be left alive.
10017013 If he withdraws into a city, then all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it down to the valley until not so much as a pebble is left.”
10017014 Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than that of Ahithophel.” For the Lord had determined to frustrate the good advice of Ahithophel in order to bring disaster on Absalom.
10017015 Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, “Ahithophel has advised Absalom and the elders of Israel to do such and such, but I have advised them to do so and so.
10017016 Now send a message at once and tell David, ‘Do not spend the night at the fords in the wilderness; cross over without fail, or the king and all the people with him will be swallowed up.’ ”
10017017 Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En Rogel. A female servant was to go and inform them, and they were to go and tell King David, for they could not risk being seen entering the city.
10017018 But a young man saw them and told Absalom. So the two of them left at once and went to the house of a man in Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they climbed down into it.
10017019 His wife took a covering and spread it out over the opening of the well and scattered grain over it. No one knew anything about it.
10017020 When Absalom’s men came to the woman at the house, they asked, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” The woman answered them, “They crossed over the brook.” The men searched but found no one, so they returned to Jerusalem.
10017021 After they had gone, the two climbed out of the well and went to inform King David. They said to him, “Set out and cross the river at once; Ahithophel has advised such and such against you.”
10017022 So David and all the people with him set out and crossed the Jordan. By daybreak, no one was left who had not crossed the Jordan.
10017023 When Ahithophel saw that his advice had not been followed, he saddled his donkey and set out for his house in his hometown. He put his house in order and then hanged himself. So he died and was buried in his father’s tomb.
10017024 David went to Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed the Jordan with all the men of Israel.
10017025 Absalom had appointed Amasa over the army in place of Joab. Amasa was the son of Jether, an Ishmaelite who had married Abigail , the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah the mother of Joab.
10017026 The Israelites and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
10017027 When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, and Makir son of Ammiel from Lo Debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
10017028 brought bedding and bowls and articles of pottery. They also brought wheat and barley, flour and roasted grain, beans and lentils,
10017029 honey and curds, sheep, and cheese from cows’ milk for David and his people to eat. For they said, “The people have become exhausted and hungry and thirsty in the wilderness.”
10018001 David mustered the men who were with him and appointed over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.
10018002 David sent out his troops, a third under the command of Joab, a third under Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah, and a third under Ittai the Gittite. The king told the troops, “I myself will surely march out with you.”
10018003 But the men said, “You must not go out; if we are forced to flee, they won’t care about us. Even if half of us die, they won’t care; but you are worth ten thousand of us. It would be better now for you to give us support from the city.”
10018004 The king answered, “I will do whatever seems best to you.” So the king stood beside the gate while all his men marched out in units of hundreds and of thousands.
10018005 The king commanded Joab, Abishai and Ittai, “Be gentle with the young man Absalom for my sake.” And all the troops heard the king giving orders concerning Absalom to each of the commanders.
10018006 David’s army marched out of the city to fight Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
10018007 There Israel’s troops were routed by David’s men, and the casualties that day were great—twenty thousand men.
10018008 The battle spread out over the whole countryside, and the forest swallowed up more men that day than the sword.
10018009 Now Absalom happened to meet David’s men. He was riding his mule, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a large oak, Absalom’s hair got caught in the tree. He was left hanging in midair, while the mule he was riding kept on going.
10018010 When one of the men saw what had happened, he told Joab, “I just saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree.”
10018011 Joab said to the man who had told him this, “What! You saw him? Why didn’t you strike him to the ground right there? Then I would have had to give you ten shekels of silver and a warrior’s belt.”
10018012 But the man replied, “Even if a thousand shekels were weighed out into my hands, I would not lay a hand on the king’s son. In our hearing the king commanded you and Abishai and Ittai, ‘Protect the young man Absalom for my sake. ’
10018013 And if I had put my life in jeopardy —and nothing is hidden from the king—you would have kept your distance from me.”
10018014 Joab said, “I’m not going to wait like this for you.” So he took three javelins in his hand and plunged them into Absalom’s heart while Absalom was still alive in the oak tree.
10018015 And ten of Joab’s armor-bearers surrounded Absalom, struck him and killed him.
10018016 Then Joab sounded the trumpet, and the troops stopped pursuing Israel, for Joab halted them.
10018017 They took Absalom, threw him into a big pit in the forest and piled up a large heap of rocks over him. Meanwhile, all the Israelites fled to their homes.
10018018 During his lifetime Absalom had taken a pillar and erected it in the King’s Valley as a monument to himself, for he thought, “I have no son to carry on the memory of my name.” He named the pillar after himself, and it is called Absalom’s Monument to this day.
10018019 Now Ahimaaz son of Zadok said, “Let me run and take the news to the king that the Lord has vindicated him by delivering him from the hand of his enemies.”
10018020 “You are not the one to take the news today,” Joab told him. “You may take the news another time, but you must not do so today, because the king’s son is dead.”
10018021 Then Joab said to a Cushite, “Go, tell the king what you have seen.” The Cushite bowed down before Joab and ran off.
10018022 Ahimaaz son of Zadok again said to Joab, “Come what may, please let me run behind the Cushite.” But Joab replied, “My son, why do you want to go? You don’t have any news that will bring you a reward.”
10018023 He said, “Come what may, I want to run.” So Joab said, “Run!” Then Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and outran the Cushite.
10018024 While David was sitting between the inner and outer gates, the watchman went up to the roof of the gateway by the wall. As he looked out, he saw a man running alone.
10018025 The watchman called out to the king and reported it. The king said, “If he is alone, he must have good news.” And the runner came closer and closer.
10018026 Then the watchman saw another runner, and he called down to the gatekeeper, “Look, another man running alone!” The king said, “He must be bringing good news, too.”
10018027 The watchman said, “It seems to me that the first one runs like Ahimaaz son of Zadok.” “He’s a good man,” the king said. “He comes with good news.”
10018028 Then Ahimaaz called out to the king, “All is well!” He bowed down before the king with his face to the ground and said, “Praise be to the Lord your God! He has delivered up those who lifted their hands against my lord the king.”
10018029 The king asked, “Is the young man Absalom safe?” Ahimaaz answered, “I saw great confusion just as Joab was about to send the king’s servant and me, your servant, but I don’t know what it was.”
10018030 The king said, “Stand aside and wait here.” So he stepped aside and stood there.
10018031 Then the Cushite arrived and said, “My lord the king, hear the good news! The Lord has vindicated you today by delivering you from the hand of all who rose up against you.”
10018032 The king asked the Cushite, “Is the young man Absalom safe?” The Cushite replied, “May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise up to harm you be like that young man.”
10018033 The king was shaken. He went up to the room over the gateway and wept. As he went, he said: “O my son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you—O Absalom, my son, my son!”
10019001 Joab was told, “The king is weeping and mourning for Absalom.”
10019002 And for the whole army the victory that day was turned into mourning, because on that day the troops heard it said, “The king is grieving for his son.”
10019003 The men stole into the city that day as men steal in who are ashamed when they flee from battle.
10019004 The king covered his face and cried aloud, “O my son Absalom! O Absalom, my son, my son!”
10019005 Then Joab went into the house to the king and said, “Today you have humiliated all your men, who have just saved your life and the lives of your sons and daughters and the lives of your wives and concubines.
10019006 You love those who hate you and hate those who love you. You have made it clear today that the commanders and their men mean nothing to you. I see that you would be pleased if Absalom were alive today and all of us were dead.
10019007 Now go out and encourage your men. I swear by the Lord that if you don’t go out, not a man will be left with you by nightfall. This will be worse for you than all the calamities that have come on you from your youth till now.”
10019008 So the king got up and took his seat in the gateway. When the men were told, “The king is sitting in the gateway,” they all came before him. Meanwhile, the Israelites had fled to their homes.
10019009 Throughout the tribes of Israel, all the people were arguing among themselves, saying, “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies; he is the one who rescued us from the hand of the Philistines. But now he has fled the country to escape from Absalom;
10019010 and Absalom, whom we anointed to rule over us, has died in battle. So why do you say nothing about bringing the king back?”
10019011 King David sent this message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: “Ask the elders of Judah, ‘Why should you be the last to bring the king back to his palace, since what is being said throughout Israel has reached the king at his quarters?
10019012 You are my relatives, my own flesh and blood. So why should you be the last to bring back the king?’
10019013 And say to Amasa, ‘Are you not my own flesh and blood? May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if you are not the commander of my army for life in place of Joab.’ ”
10019014 He won over the hearts of the men of Judah so that they were all of one mind. They sent word to the king, “Return, you and all your men.”
10019015 Then the king returned and went as far as the Jordan. Now the men of Judah had come to Gilgal to go out and meet the king and bring him across the Jordan.
10019016 Shimei son of Gera, the Benjamite from Bahurim, hurried down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
10019017 With him were a thousand Benjamites, along with Ziba, the steward of Saul’s household, and his fifteen sons and twenty servants. They rushed to the Jordan, where the king was.
10019018 They crossed at the ford to take the king’s household over and to do whatever he wished. When Shimei son of Gera crossed the Jordan, he fell prostrate before the king
10019019 and said to him, “May my lord not hold me guilty. Do not remember how your servant did wrong on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem. May the king put it out of his mind.
10019020 For I your servant know that I have sinned, but today I have come here as the first from the tribes of Joseph to come down and meet my lord the king.”
10019021 Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said, “Shouldn’t Shimei be put to death for this? He cursed the Lord’s anointed.”
10019022 David replied, “What does this have to do with you, you sons of Zeruiah? What right do you have to interfere? Should anyone be put to death in Israel today? Don’t I know that today I am king over Israel?”
10019023 So the king said to Shimei, “You shall not die.” And the king promised him on oath.
10019024 Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson, also went down to meet the king. He had not taken care of his feet or trimmed his mustache or washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he returned safely.
10019025 When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, “Why didn’t you go with me, Mephibosheth?”
10019026 He said, “My lord the king, since I your servant am lame, I said, ‘I will have my donkey saddled and will ride on it, so I can go with the king.’ But Ziba my servant betrayed me.
10019027 And he has slandered your servant to my lord the king. My lord the king is like an angel of God; so do whatever you wish.
10019028 All my grandfather’s descendants deserved nothing but death from my lord the king, but you gave your servant a place among those who eat at your table. So what right do I have to make any more appeals to the king?”
10019029 The king said to him, “Why say more? I order you and Ziba to divide the land.”
10019030 Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him take everything, now that my lord the king has returned home safely.”
10019031 Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim to cross the Jordan with the king and to send him on his way from there.
10019032 Now Barzillai was very old, eighty years of age. He had provided for the king during his stay in Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.
10019033 The king said to Barzillai, “Cross over with me and stay with me in Jerusalem, and I will provide for you.”
10019034 But Barzillai answered the king, “How many more years will I live, that I should go up to Jerusalem with the king?
10019035 I am now eighty years old. Can I tell the difference between what is enjoyable and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats and drinks? Can I still hear the voices of male and female singers? Why should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?
10019036 Your servant will cross over the Jordan with the king for a short distance, but why should the king reward me in this way?
10019037 Let your servant return, that I may die in my own town near the tomb of my father and mother. But here is your servant Kimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king. Do for him whatever you wish.”
10019038 The king said, “Kimham shall cross over with me, and I will do for him whatever you wish. And anything you desire from me I will do for you.”
10019039 So all the people crossed the Jordan, and then the king crossed over. The king kissed Barzillai and bid him farewell, and Barzillai returned to his home.
10019040 When the king crossed over to Gilgal, Kimham crossed with him. All the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel had taken the king over.
10019041 Soon all the men of Israel were coming to the king and saying to him, “Why did our brothers, the men of Judah, steal the king away and bring him and his household across the Jordan, together with all his men?”
10019042 All the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, “We did this because the king is closely related to us. Why are you angry about it? Have we eaten any of the king’s provisions? Have we taken anything for ourselves?”
10019043 Then the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, “We have ten shares in the king; so we have a greater claim on David than you have. Why then do you treat us with contempt? Weren’t we the first to speak of bringing back our king?” But the men of Judah pressed their claims even more forcefully than the men of Israel.
10020001 Now a troublemaker named Sheba son of Bikri, a Benjamite, happened to be there. He sounded the trumpet and shouted, “We have no share in David, no part in Jesse’s son! Every man to his tent, Israel!”
10020002 So all the men of Israel deserted David to follow Sheba son of Bikri. But the men of Judah stayed by their king all the way from the Jordan to Jerusalem.
10020003 When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to take care of the palace and put them in a house under guard. He provided for them but had no sexual relations with them. They were kept in confinement till the day of their death, living as widows.
10020004 Then the king said to Amasa, “Summon the men of Judah to come to me within three days, and be here yourself.”
10020005 But when Amasa went to summon Judah, he took longer than the time the king had set for him.
10020006 David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba son of Bikri will do us more harm than Absalom did. Take your master’s men and pursue him, or he will find fortified cities and escape from us.”
10020007 So Joab’s men and the Kerethites and Pelethites and all the mighty warriors went out under the command of Abishai. They marched out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba son of Bikri.
10020008 While they were at the great rock in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Joab was wearing his military tunic, and strapped over it at his waist was a belt with a dagger in its sheath. As he stepped forward, it dropped out of its sheath.
10020009 Joab said to Amasa, “How are you, my brother?” Then Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him.
10020010 Amasa was not on his guard against the dagger in Joab’s hand, and Joab plunged it into his belly, and his intestines spilled out on the ground. Without being stabbed again, Amasa died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai pursued Sheba son of Bikri.
10020011 One of Joab’s men stood beside Amasa and said, “Whoever favors Joab, and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab!”
10020012 Amasa lay wallowing in his blood in the middle of the road, and the man saw that all the troops came to a halt there. When he realized that everyone who came up to Amasa stopped, he dragged him from the road into a field and threw a garment over him.
10020013 After Amasa had been removed from the road, everyone went on with Joab to pursue Sheba son of Bikri.
10020014 Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel Beth Maakah and through the entire region of the Bikrites, who gathered together and followed him.
10020015 All the troops with Joab came and besieged Sheba in Abel Beth Maakah. They built a siege ramp up to the city, and it stood against the outer fortifications. While they were battering the wall to bring it down,
10020016 a wise woman called from the city, “Listen! Listen! Tell Joab to come here so I can speak to him.”
10020017 He went toward her, and she asked, “Are you Joab?” “I am,” he answered. She said, “Listen to what your servant has to say.” “I’m listening,” he said.
10020018 She continued, “Long ago they used to say, ‘Get your answer at Abel,’ and that settled it.
10020019 We are the peaceful and faithful in Israel. You are trying to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why do you want to swallow up the Lord’s inheritance?”
10020020 “Far be it from me!” Joab replied, “Far be it from me to swallow up or destroy!
10020021 That is not the case. A man named Sheba son of Bikri, from the hill country of Ephraim, has lifted up his hand against the king, against David. Hand over this one man, and I’ll withdraw from the city.” The woman said to Joab, “His head will be thrown to you from the wall.”
10020022 Then the woman went to all the people with her wise advice, and they cut off the head of Sheba son of Bikri and threw it to Joab. So he sounded the trumpet, and his men dispersed from the city, each returning to his home. And Joab went back to the king in Jerusalem.
10020023 Joab was over Israel’s entire army; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites;
10020024 Adoniram was in charge of forced labor; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
10020025 Sheva was secretary; Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
10020026 and Ira the Jairite was David’s priest.
10021001 During the reign of David, there was a famine for three successive years; so David sought the face of the Lord. The Lord said, “It is on account of Saul and his blood-stained house; it is because he put the Gibeonites to death.”
10021002 The king summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not a part of Israel but were survivors of the Amorites; the Israelites had sworn to spare them, but Saul in his zeal for Israel and Judah had tried to annihilate them.)
10021003 David asked the Gibeonites, “What shall I do for you? How shall I make atonement so that you will bless the Lord’s inheritance?”
10021004 The Gibeonites answered him, “We have no right to demand silver or gold from Saul or his family, nor do we have the right to put anyone in Israel to death.” “What do you want me to do for you?” David asked.
10021005 They answered the king, “As for the man who destroyed us and plotted against us so that we have been decimated and have no place anywhere in Israel,
10021006 let seven of his male descendants be given to us to be killed and their bodies exposed before the Lord at Gibeah of Saul—the Lord’s chosen one.” So the king said, “I will give them to you.”
10021007 The king spared Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the oath before the Lord between David and Jonathan son of Saul.
10021008 But the king took Armoni and Mephibosheth, the two sons of Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, whom she had borne to Saul, together with the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab, whom she had borne to Adriel son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
10021009 He handed them over to the Gibeonites, who killed them and exposed their bodies on a hill before the Lord. All seven of them fell together; they were put to death during the first days of the harvest, just as the barley harvest was beginning.
10021010 Rizpah daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it out for herself on a rock. From the beginning of the harvest till the rain poured down from the heavens on the bodies, she did not let the birds touch them by day or the wild animals by night.
10021011 When David was told what Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, Saul’s concubine, had done,
10021012 he went and took the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from the citizens of Jabesh Gilead. (They had stolen their bodies from the public square at Beth Shan, where the Philistines had hung them after they struck Saul down on Gilboa.)
10021013 David brought the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from there, and the bones of those who had been killed and exposed were gathered up.
10021014 They buried the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in the tomb of Saul’s father Kish, at Zela in Benjamin, and did everything the king commanded. After that, God answered prayer in behalf of the land.
10021015 Once again there was a battle between the Philistines and Israel. David went down with his men to fight against the Philistines, and he became exhausted.
10021016 And Ishbi-Benob, one of the descendants of Rapha, whose bronze spearhead weighed three hundred shekels and who was armed with a new sword, said he would kill David.
10021017 But Abishai son of Zeruiah came to David’s rescue; he struck the Philistine down and killed him. Then David’s men swore to him, saying, “Never again will you go out with us to battle, so that the lamp of Israel will not be extinguished.”
10021018 In the course of time, there was another battle with the Philistines, at Gob. At that time Sibbekai the Hushathite killed Saph, one of the descendants of Rapha.
10021019 In another battle with the Philistines at Gob, Elhanan son of Jair the Bethlehemite killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, who had a spear with a shaft like a weaver’s rod.
10021020 In still another battle, which took place at Gath, there was a huge man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four in all. He also was descended from Rapha.
10021021 When he taunted Israel, Jonathan son of Shimeah, David’s brother, killed him.
10021022 These four were descendants of Rapha in Gath, and they fell at the hands of David and his men.
10022001 David sang to the Lord the words of this song when the Lord delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
10022002 He said: “The Lord is my rock, my fortress and my deliverer;
10022003 my God is my rock, in whom I take refuge, my shield and the horn of my salvation. He is my stronghold, my refuge and my savior— from violent people you save me.
10022004 “I called to the Lord, who is worthy of praise, and have been saved from my enemies.
10022005 The waves of death swirled about me; the torrents of destruction overwhelmed me.
10022006 The cords of the grave coiled around me; the snares of death confronted me.
10022007 “In my distress I called to the Lord; I called out to my God. From his temple he heard my voice; my cry came to his ears.
10022008 The earth trembled and quaked, the foundations of the heavens shook; they trembled because he was angry.
10022009 Smoke rose from his nostrils; consuming fire came from his mouth, burning coals blazed out of it.
10022010 He parted the heavens and came down; dark clouds were under his feet.
10022011 He mounted the cherubim and flew; he soared on the wings of the wind.
10022012 He made darkness his canopy around him— the dark rain clouds of the sky.
10022013 Out of the brightness of his presence bolts of lightning blazed forth.
10022014 The Lord thundered from heaven; the voice of the Most High resounded.
10022015 He shot his arrows and scattered the enemy, with great bolts of lightning he routed them.
10022016 The valleys of the sea were exposed and the foundations of the earth laid bare at the rebuke of the Lord, at the blast of breath from his nostrils.
10022017 “He reached down from on high and took hold of me; he drew me out of deep waters.
10022018 He rescued me from my powerful enemy, from my foes, who were too strong for me.
10022019 They confronted me in the day of my disaster, but the Lord was my support.
10022020 He brought me out into a spacious place; he rescued me because he delighted in me.
10022021 “The Lord has dealt with me according to my righteousness; according to the cleanness of my hands he has rewarded me.
10022022 For I have kept the ways of the Lord; I am not guilty of turning from my God.
10022023 All his laws are before me; I have not turned away from his decrees.
10022024 I have been blameless before him and have kept myself from sin.
10022025 The Lord has rewarded me according to my righteousness, according to my cleanness in his sight.
10022026 “To the faithful you show yourself faithful, to the blameless you show yourself blameless,
10022027 to the pure you show yourself pure, but to the devious you show yourself shrewd.
10022028 You save the humble, but your eyes are on the haughty to bring them low.
10022029 You, Lord, are my lamp; the Lord turns my darkness into light.
10022030 With your help I can advance against a troop ; with my God I can scale a wall.
10022031 “As for God, his way is perfect: The Lord’s word is flawless; he shields all who take refuge in him.
10022032 For who is God besides the Lord? And who is the Rock except our God?
10022033 It is God who arms me with strength and keeps my way secure.
10022034 He makes my feet like the feet of a deer; he causes me to stand on the heights.
10022035 He trains my hands for battle; my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
10022036 You make your saving help my shield; your help has made me great.
10022037 You provide a broad path for my feet, so that my ankles do not give way.
10022038 “I pursued my enemies and crushed them; I did not turn back till they were destroyed.
10022039 I crushed them completely, and they could not rise; they fell beneath my feet.
10022040 You armed me with strength for battle; you humbled my adversaries before me.
10022041 You made my enemies turn their backs in flight, and I destroyed my foes.
10022042 They cried for help, but there was no one to save them— to the Lord, but he did not answer.
10022043 I beat them as fine as the dust of the earth; I pounded and trampled them like mud in the streets.
10022044 “You have delivered me from the attacks of the peoples; you have preserved me as the head of nations. People I did not know now serve me,
10022045 foreigners cower before me; as soon as they hear of me, they obey me.
10022046 They all lose heart; they come trembling from their strongholds.
10022047 “The Lord lives! Praise be to my Rock! Exalted be my God, the Rock, my Savior!
10022048 He is the God who avenges me, who puts the nations under me,
10022049 who sets me free from my enemies. You exalted me above my foes; from a violent man you rescued me.
10022050 Therefore I will praise you, Lord, among the nations; I will sing the praises of your name.
10022051 “He gives his king great victories; he shows unfailing kindness to his anointed, to David and his descendants forever.”
10023001 These are the last words of David: “The inspired utterance of David son of Jesse, the utterance of the man exalted by the Most High, the man anointed by the God of Jacob, the hero of Israel’s songs:
10023002 “The Spirit of the Lord spoke through me; his word was on my tongue.
10023003 The God of Israel spoke, the Rock of Israel said to me: ‘When one rules over people in righteousness, when he rules in the fear of God,
10023004 he is like the light of morning at sunrise on a cloudless morning, like the brightness after rain that brings grass from the earth.’
10023005 “If my house were not right with God, surely he would not have made with me an everlasting covenant, arranged and secured in every part; surely he would not bring to fruition my salvation and grant me my every desire.
10023006 But evil men are all to be cast aside like thorns, which are not gathered with the hand.
10023007 Whoever touches thorns uses a tool of iron or the shaft of a spear; they are burned up where they lie.”
10023008 These are the names of David’s mighty warriors: Josheb-Basshebeth, a Tahkemonite, was chief of the Three; he raised his spear against eight hundred men, whom he killed in one encounter.
10023009 Next to him was Eleazar son of Dodai the Ahohite. As one of the three mighty warriors, he was with David when they taunted the Philistines gathered at Pas Dammim for battle. Then the Israelites retreated,
10023010 but Eleazar stood his ground and struck down the Philistines till his hand grew tired and froze to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day. The troops returned to Eleazar, but only to strip the dead.
10023011 Next to him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines banded together at a place where there was a field full of lentils, Israel’s troops fled from them.
10023012 But Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field. He defended it and struck the Philistines down, and the Lord brought about a great victory.
10023013 During harvest time, three of the thirty chief warriors came down to David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.
10023014 At that time David was in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
10023015 David longed for water and said, “Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!”
10023016 So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out before the Lord.
10023017 “Far be it from me, Lord, to do this!” he said. “Is it not the blood of men who went at the risk of their lives?” And David would not drink it. Such were the exploits of the three mighty warriors.
10023018 Abishai the brother of Joab son of Zeruiah was chief of the Three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed, and so he became as famous as the Three.
10023019 Was he not held in greater honor than the Three? He became their commander, even though he was not included among them.
10023020 Benaiah son of Jehoiada, a valiant fighter from Kabzeel, performed great exploits. He struck down Moab’s two mightiest warriors. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.
10023021 And he struck down a huge Egyptian. Although the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, Benaiah went against him with a club. He snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
10023022 Such were the exploits of Benaiah son of Jehoiada; he too was as famous as the three mighty warriors.
10023023 He was held in greater honor than any of the Thirty, but he was not included among the Three. And David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
10023024 Among the Thirty were: Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
10023025 Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
10023026 Helez the Paltite, Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa,
10023027 Abiezer from Anathoth, Sibbekai the Hushathite,
10023028 Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
10023029 Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin,
10023030 Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash,
10023031 Abi-Albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
10023032 Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, Jonathan
10023033 son of Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam son of Sharar the Hararite,
10023034 Eliphelet son of Ahasbai the Maakathite, Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
10023035 Hezro the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
10023036 Igal son of Nathan from Zobah, the son of Hagri,
10023037 Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
10023038 Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite
10023039 and Uriah the Hittite. There were thirty-seven in all.
10024001 Again the anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.”
10024002 So the king said to Joab and the army commanders with him, “Go throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and enroll the fighting men, so that I may know how many there are.”
10024003 But Joab replied to the king, “May the Lord your God multiply the troops a hundred times over, and may the eyes of my lord the king see it. But why does my lord the king want to do such a thing?”
10024004 The king’s word, however, overruled Joab and the army commanders; so they left the presence of the king to enroll the fighting men of Israel.
10024005 After crossing the Jordan, they camped near Aroer, south of the town in the gorge, and then went through Gad and on to Jazer.
10024006 They went to Gilead and the region of Tahtim Hodshi, and on to Dan Jaan and around toward Sidon.
10024007 Then they went toward the fortress of Tyre and all the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went on to Beersheba in the Negev of Judah.
10024008 After they had gone through the entire land, they came back to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
10024009 Joab reported the number of the fighting men to the king: In Israel there were eight hundred thousand able-bodied men who could handle a sword, and in Judah five hundred thousand.
10024010 David was conscience-stricken after he had counted the fighting men, and he said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done. Now, Lord, I beg you, take away the guilt of your servant. I have done a very foolish thing.”
