16009026 “But they were disobedient and rebelled against you; they turned their backs on your law. They killed your prophets, who had warned them in order to turn them back to you; they committed awful blasphemies.
16009027 So you delivered them into the hands of their enemies, who oppressed them. But when they were oppressed they cried out to you. From heaven you heard them, and in your great compassion you gave them deliverers, who rescued them from the hand of their enemies.
16009028 “But as soon as they were at rest, they again did what was evil in your sight. Then you abandoned them to the hand of their enemies so that they ruled over them. And when they cried out to you again, you heard from heaven, and in your compassion you delivered them time after time.
16009029 “You warned them in order to turn them back to your law, but they became arrogant and disobeyed your commands. They sinned against your ordinances, of which you said, ‘The person who obeys them will live by them.’ Stubbornly they turned their backs on you, became stiff-necked and refused to listen.
16009030 For many years you were patient with them. By your Spirit you warned them through your prophets. Yet they paid no attention, so you gave them into the hands of the neighboring peoples.
16009031 But in your great mercy you did not put an end to them or abandon them, for you are a gracious and merciful God.
16009032 “Now therefore, our God, the great God, mighty and awesome, who keeps his covenant of love, do not let all this hardship seem trifling in your eyes—the hardship that has come on us, on our kings and leaders, on our priests and prophets, on our ancestors and all your people, from the days of the kings of Assyria until today.
16009033 In all that has happened to us, you have remained righteous; you have acted faithfully, while we acted wickedly.
16009034 Our kings, our leaders, our priests and our ancestors did not follow your law; they did not pay attention to your commands or the statutes you warned them to keep.
16009035 Even while they were in their kingdom, enjoying your great goodness to them in the spacious and fertile land you gave them, they did not serve you or turn from their evil ways.
16009036 “But see, we are slaves today, slaves in the land you gave our ancestors so they could eat its fruit and the other good things it produces.
16009037 Because of our sins, its abundant harvest goes to the kings you have placed over us. They rule over our bodies and our cattle as they please. We are in great distress.
16009038 “In view of all this, we are making a binding agreement, putting it in writing, and our leaders, our Levites and our priests are affixing their seals to it.”
16010001 Those who sealed it were: Nehemiah the governor, the son of Hakaliah. Zedekiah,
16010002 Seraiah, Azariah, Jeremiah,
16010003 Pashhur, Amariah, Malkijah,
16010004 Hattush, Shebaniah, Malluk,
16010005 Harim, Meremoth, Obadiah,
16010006 Daniel, Ginnethon, Baruch,
16010007 Meshullam, Abijah, Mijamin,
16010008 Maaziah, Bilgai and Shemaiah. These were the priests.
16010009 The Levites: Jeshua son of Azaniah, Binnui of the sons of Henadad, Kadmiel,
16010010 and their associates: Shebaniah, Hodiah, Kelita, Pelaiah, Hanan,
16010011 Mika, Rehob, Hashabiah,
16010012 Zakkur, Sherebiah, Shebaniah,
16010013 Hodiah, Bani and Beninu.
16010014 The leaders of the people: Parosh, Pahath-Moab, Elam, Zattu, Bani,
16010015 Bunni, Azgad, Bebai,
16010016 Adonijah, Bigvai, Adin,
16010017 Ater, Hezekiah, Azzur,
16010018 Hodiah, Hashum, Bezai,
16010019 Hariph, Anathoth, Nebai,
16010020 Magpiash, Meshullam, Hezir,
16010021 Meshezabel, Zadok, Jaddua,
16010022 Pelatiah, Hanan, Anaiah,
16010023 Hoshea, Hananiah, Hasshub,
16010024 Hallohesh, Pilha, Shobek,
16010025 Rehum, Hashabnah, Maaseiah,
16010026 Ahiah, Hanan, Anan,
16010027 Malluk, Harim and Baanah.
16010028 “The rest of the people—priests, Levites, gatekeepers, musicians, temple servants and all who separated themselves from the neighboring peoples for the sake of the Law of God, together with their wives and all their sons and daughters who are able to understand—
16010029 all these now join their fellow Israelites the nobles, and bind themselves with a curse and an oath to follow the Law of God given through Moses the servant of God and to obey carefully all the commands, regulations and decrees of the Lord our Lord.
16010030 “We promise not to give our daughters in marriage to the peoples around us or take their daughters for our sons.
16010031 “When the neighboring peoples bring merchandise or grain to sell on the Sabbath, we will not buy from them on the Sabbath or on any holy day. Every seventh year we will forgo working the land and will cancel all debts.
16010032 “We assume the responsibility for carrying out the commands to give a third of a shekel each year for the service of the house of our God:
16010033 for the bread set out on the table; for the regular grain offerings and burnt offerings; for the offerings on the Sabbaths, at the New Moon feasts and at the appointed festivals; for the holy offerings; for sin offerings to make atonement for Israel; and for all the duties of the house of our God.
16010034 “We—the priests, the Levites and the people—have cast lots to determine when each of our families is to bring to the house of our God at set times each year a contribution of wood to burn on the altar of the Lord our God, as it is written in the Law.
16010035 “We also assume responsibility for bringing to the house of the Lord each year the firstfruits of our crops and of every fruit tree.
16010036 “As it is also written in the Law, we will bring the firstborn of our sons and of our cattle, of our herds and of our flocks to the house of our God, to the priests ministering there.
16010037 “Moreover, we will bring to the storerooms of the house of our God, to the priests, the first of our ground meal, of our grain offerings, of the fruit of all our trees and of our new wine and olive oil. And we will bring a tithe of our crops to the Levites, for it is the Levites who collect the tithes in all the towns where we work.
16010038 A priest descended from Aaron is to accompany the Levites when they receive the tithes, and the Levites are to bring a tenth of the tithes up to the house of our God, to the storerooms of the treasury.
16010039 The people of Israel, including the Levites, are to bring their contributions of grain, new wine and olive oil to the storerooms, where the articles for the sanctuary and for the ministering priests, the gatekeepers and the musicians are also kept. “We will not neglect the house of our God.”
16011001 Now the leaders of the people settled in Jerusalem. The rest of the people cast lots to bring one out of every ten of them to live in Jerusalem, the holy city, while the remaining nine were to stay in their own towns.
16011002 The people commended all who volunteered to live in Jerusalem.
16011003 These are the provincial leaders who settled in Jerusalem (now some Israelites, priests, Levites, temple servants and descendants of Solomon’s servants lived in the towns of Judah, each on their own property in the various towns,
16011004 while other people from both Judah and Benjamin lived in Jerusalem): From the descendants of Judah: Athaiah son of Uzziah, the son of Zechariah, the son of Amariah, the son of Shephatiah, the son of Mahalalel, a descendant of Perez;
16011005 and Maaseiah son of Baruch, the son of Kol-Hozeh, the son of Hazaiah, the son of Adaiah, the son of Joiarib, the son of Zechariah, a descendant of Shelah.
16011006 The descendants of Perez who lived in Jerusalem totaled 468 men of standing.
16011007 From the descendants of Benjamin: Sallu son of Meshullam, the son of Joed, the son of Pedaiah, the son of Kolaiah, the son of Maaseiah, the son of Ithiel, the son of Jeshaiah,
16011008 and his followers, Gabbai and Sallai—928 men.
16011009 Joel son of Zikri was their chief officer, and Judah son of Hassenuah was over the New Quarter of the city.
16011010 From the priests: Jedaiah; the son of Joiarib; Jakin;
16011011 Seraiah son of Hilkiah, the son of Meshullam, the son of Zadok, the son of Meraioth, the son of Ahitub, the official in charge of the house of God,
16011012 and their associates, who carried on work for the temple—822 men; Adaiah son of Jeroham, the son of Pelaliah, the son of Amzi, the son of Zechariah, the son of Pashhur, the son of Malkijah,
16011013 and his associates, who were heads of families—242 men; Amashsai son of Azarel, the son of Ahzai, the son of Meshillemoth, the son of Immer,
16011014 and his associates, who were men of standing—128. Their chief officer was Zabdiel son of Haggedolim.
16011015 From the Levites: Shemaiah son of Hasshub, the son of Azrikam, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Bunni;
16011016 Shabbethai and Jozabad, two of the heads of the Levites, who had charge of the outside work of the house of God;
16011017 Mattaniah son of Mika, the son of Zabdi, the son of Asaph, the director who led in thanksgiving and prayer; Bakbukiah, second among his associates; and Abda son of Shammua, the son of Galal, the son of Jeduthun.
16011018 The Levites in the holy city totaled 284.
16011019 The gatekeepers: Akkub, Talmon and their associates, who kept watch at the gates—172 men.
16011020 The rest of the Israelites, with the priests and Levites, were in all the towns of Judah, each on their ancestral property.
16011021 The temple servants lived on the hill of Ophel, and Ziha and Gishpa were in charge of them.
16011022 The chief officer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi son of Bani, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Mika. Uzzi was one of Asaph’s descendants, who were the musicians responsible for the service of the house of God.
16011023 The musicians were under the king’s orders, which regulated their daily activity.
16011024 Pethahiah son of Meshezabel, one of the descendants of Zerah son of Judah, was the king’s agent in all affairs relating to the people.
16011025 As for the villages with their fields, some of the people of Judah lived in Kiriath Arba and its surrounding settlements, in Dibon and its settlements, in Jekabzeel and its villages,
16011026 in Jeshua, in Moladah, in Beth Pelet,
16011027 in Hazar Shual, in Beersheba and its settlements,
16011028 in Ziklag, in Mekonah and its settlements,
16011029 in En Rimmon, in Zorah, in Jarmuth,
16011030 Zanoah, Adullam and their villages, in Lachish and its fields, and in Azekah and its settlements. So they were living all the way from Beersheba to the Valley of Hinnom.
16011031 The descendants of the Benjamites from Geba lived in Mikmash, Aija, Bethel and its settlements,
16011032 in Anathoth, Nob and Ananiah,
16011033 in Hazor, Ramah and Gittaim,
16011034 in Hadid, Zeboim and Neballat,
16011035 in Lod and Ono, and in Ge Harashim.
16011036 Some of the divisions of the Levites of Judah settled in Benjamin.
16012001 These were the priests and Levites who returned with Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel and with Joshua: Seraiah, Jeremiah, Ezra,
16012002 Amariah, Malluk, Hattush,
16012003 Shekaniah, Rehum, Meremoth,
16012004 Iddo, Ginnethon, Abijah,
16012005 Mijamin, Moadiah, Bilgah,
16012006 Shemaiah, Joiarib, Jedaiah,
16012007 Sallu, Amok, Hilkiah and Jedaiah. These were the leaders of the priests and their associates in the days of Joshua.
16012008 The Levites were Jeshua, Binnui, Kadmiel, Sherebiah, Judah, and also Mattaniah, who, together with his associates, was in charge of the songs of thanksgiving.
16012009 Bakbukiah and Unni, their associates, stood opposite them in the services.
16012010 Joshua was the father of Joiakim, Joiakim the father of Eliashib, Eliashib the father of Joiada,
16012011 Joiada the father of Jonathan, and Jonathan the father of Jaddua.
16012012 In the days of Joiakim, these were the heads of the priestly families: of Seraiah’s family, Meraiah; of Jeremiah’s, Hananiah;
16012013 of Ezra’s, Meshullam; of Amariah’s, Jehohanan;
16012014 of Malluk’s, Jonathan; of Shekaniah’s, Joseph;
16012015 of Harim’s, Adna; of Meremoth’s, Helkai;
16012016 of Iddo’s, Zechariah; of Ginnethon’s, Meshullam;
16012017 of Abijah’s, Zikri; of Miniamin’s and of Moadiah’s, Piltai;
16012018 of Bilgah’s, Shammua; of Shemaiah’s, Jehonathan;
16012019 of Joiarib’s, Mattenai; of Jedaiah’s, Uzzi;
16012020 of Sallu’s, Kallai; of Amok’s, Eber;
16012021 of Hilkiah’s, Hashabiah; of Jedaiah’s, Nethanel.
16012022 The family heads of the Levites in the days of Eliashib, Joiada, Johanan and Jaddua, as well as those of the priests, were recorded in the reign of Darius the Persian.
16012023 The family heads among the descendants of Levi up to the time of Johanan son of Eliashib were recorded in the book of the annals.
16012024 And the leaders of the Levites were Hashabiah, Sherebiah, Jeshua son of Kadmiel, and their associates, who stood opposite them to give praise and thanksgiving, one section responding to the other, as prescribed by David the man of God.
16012025 Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon and Akkub were gatekeepers who guarded the storerooms at the gates.
16012026 They served in the days of Joiakim son of Joshua, the son of Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor and of Ezra the priest, the teacher of the Law.
16012027 At the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, the Levites were sought out from where they lived and were brought to Jerusalem to celebrate joyfully the dedication with songs of thanksgiving and with the music of cymbals, harps and lyres.
16012028 The musicians also were brought together from the region around Jerusalem—from the villages of the Netophathites,
16012029 from Beth Gilgal, and from the area of Geba and Azmaveth, for the musicians had built villages for themselves around Jerusalem.
16012030 When the priests and Levites had purified themselves ceremonially, they purified the people, the gates and the wall.
16012031 I had the leaders of Judah go up on top of the wall. I also assigned two large choirs to give thanks. One was to proceed on top of the wall to the right, toward the Dung Gate.
16012032 Hoshaiah and half the leaders of Judah followed them,
16012033 along with Azariah, Ezra, Meshullam,
16012034 Judah, Benjamin, Shemaiah, Jeremiah,
16012035 as well as some priests with trumpets, and also Zechariah son of Jonathan, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Micaiah, the son of Zakkur, the son of Asaph,
16012036 and his associates—Shemaiah, Azarel, Milalai, Gilalai, Maai, Nethanel, Judah and Hanani—with musical instruments prescribed by David the man of God. Ezra the teacher of the Law led the procession.
16012037 At the Fountain Gate they continued directly up the steps of the City of David on the ascent to the wall and passed above the site of David’s palace to the Water Gate on the east.
16012038 The second choir proceeded in the opposite direction. I followed them on top of the wall, together with half the people—past the Tower of the Ovens to the Broad Wall,
16012039 over the Gate of Ephraim, the Jeshanah Gate, the Fish Gate, the Tower of Hananel and the Tower of the Hundred, as far as the Sheep Gate. At the Gate of the Guard they stopped.
16012040 The two choirs that gave thanks then took their places in the house of God; so did I, together with half the officials,
16012041 as well as the priests—Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Micaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah and Hananiah with their trumpets—
16012042 and also Maaseiah, Shemaiah, Eleazar, Uzzi, Jehohanan, Malkijah, Elam and Ezer. The choirs sang under the direction of Jezrahiah.
16012043 And on that day they offered great sacrifices, rejoicing because God had given them great joy. The women and children also rejoiced. The sound of rejoicing in Jerusalem could be heard far away.
16012044 At that time men were appointed to be in charge of the storerooms for the contributions, firstfruits and tithes. From the fields around the towns they were to bring into the storerooms the portions required by the Law for the priests and the Levites, for Judah was pleased with the ministering priests and Levites.
16012045 They performed the service of their God and the service of purification, as did also the musicians and gatekeepers, according to the commands of David and his son Solomon.
16012046 For long ago, in the days of David and Asaph, there had been directors for the musicians and for the songs of praise and thanksgiving to God.
16012047 So in the days of Zerubbabel and of Nehemiah, all Israel contributed the daily portions for the musicians and the gatekeepers. They also set aside the portion for the other Levites, and the Levites set aside the portion for the descendants of Aaron.
16013001 On that day the Book of Moses was read aloud in the hearing of the people and there it was found written that no Ammonite or Moabite should ever be admitted into the assembly of God,
16013002 because they had not met the Israelites with food and water but had hired Balaam to call a curse down on them. (Our God, however, turned the curse into a blessing.)
16013003 When the people heard this law, they excluded from Israel all who were of foreign descent.
16013004 Before this, Eliashib the priest had been put in charge of the storerooms of the house of our God. He was closely associated with Tobiah,
16013005 and he had provided him with a large room formerly used to store the grain offerings and incense and temple articles, and also the tithes of grain, new wine and olive oil prescribed for the Levites, musicians and gatekeepers, as well as the contributions for the priests.
16013006 But while all this was going on, I was not in Jerusalem, for in the thirty-second year of Artaxerxes king of Babylon I had returned to the king. Some time later I asked his permission
16013007 and came back to Jerusalem. Here I learned about the evil thing Eliashib had done in providing Tobiah a room in the courts of the house of God.
16013008 I was greatly displeased and threw all Tobiah’s household goods out of the room.
16013009 I gave orders to purify the rooms, and then I put back into them the equipment of the house of God, with the grain offerings and the incense.
16013010 I also learned that the portions assigned to the Levites had not been given to them, and that all the Levites and musicians responsible for the service had gone back to their own fields.
16013011 So I rebuked the officials and asked them, “Why is the house of God neglected?” Then I called them together and stationed them at their posts.
16013012 All Judah brought the tithes of grain, new wine and olive oil into the storerooms.
16013013 I put Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and a Levite named Pedaiah in charge of the storerooms and made Hanan son of Zakkur, the son of Mattaniah, their assistant, because they were considered trustworthy. They were made responsible for distributing the supplies to their fellow Levites.
16013014 Remember me for this, my God, and do not blot out what I have so faithfully done for the house of my God and its services.
16013015 In those days I saw people in Judah treading winepresses on the Sabbath and bringing in grain and loading it on donkeys, together with wine, grapes, figs and all other kinds of loads. And they were bringing all this into Jerusalem on the Sabbath. Therefore I warned them against selling food on that day.
16013016 People from Tyre who lived in Jerusalem were bringing in fish and all kinds of merchandise and selling them in Jerusalem on the Sabbath to the people of Judah.
16013017 I rebuked the nobles of Judah and said to them, “What is this wicked thing you are doing—desecrating the Sabbath day?
16013018 Didn’t your ancestors do the same things, so that our God brought all this calamity on us and on this city? Now you are stirring up more wrath against Israel by desecrating the Sabbath.”
16013019 When evening shadows fell on the gates of Jerusalem before the Sabbath, I ordered the doors to be shut and not opened until the Sabbath was over. I stationed some of my own men at the gates so that no load could be brought in on the Sabbath day.
16013020 Once or twice the merchants and sellers of all kinds of goods spent the night outside Jerusalem.
16013021 But I warned them and said, “Why do you spend the night by the wall? If you do this again, I will arrest you.” From that time on they no longer came on the Sabbath.
16013022 Then I commanded the Levites to purify themselves and go and guard the gates in order to keep the Sabbath day holy. Remember me for this also, my God, and show mercy to me according to your great love.
16013023 Moreover, in those days I saw men of Judah who had married women from Ashdod, Ammon and Moab.
16013024 Half of their children spoke the language of Ashdod or the language of one of the other peoples, and did not know how to speak the language of Judah.
16013025 I rebuked them and called curses down on them. I beat some of the men and pulled out their hair. I made them take an oath in God’s name and said: “You are not to give your daughters in marriage to their sons, nor are you to take their daughters in marriage for your sons or for yourselves.
16013026 Was it not because of marriages like these that Solomon king of Israel sinned? Among the many nations there was no king like him. He was loved by his God, and God made him king over all Israel, but even he was led into sin by foreign women.
16013027 Must we hear now that you too are doing all this terrible wickedness and are being unfaithful to our God by marrying foreign women?”
16013028 One of the sons of Joiada son of Eliashib the high priest was son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite. And I drove him away from me.
16013029 Remember them, my God, because they defiled the priestly office and the covenant of the priesthood and of the Levites.
16013030 So I purified the priests and the Levites of everything foreign, and assigned them duties, each to his own task.
16013031 I also made provision for contributions of wood at designated times, and for the firstfruits. Remember me with favor, my God.
17001001 This is what happened during the time of Xerxes, the Xerxes who ruled over 127 provinces stretching from India to Cush :
17001002 At that time King Xerxes reigned from his royal throne in the citadel of Susa,
17001003 and in the third year of his reign he gave a banquet for all his nobles and officials. The military leaders of Persia and Media, the princes, and the nobles of the provinces were present.
17001004 For a full 180 days he displayed the vast wealth of his kingdom and the splendor and glory of his majesty.
17001005 When these days were over, the king gave a banquet, lasting seven days, in the enclosed garden of the king’s palace, for all the people from the least to the greatest who were in the citadel of Susa.
17001006 The garden had hangings of white and blue linen, fastened with cords of white linen and purple material to silver rings on marble pillars. There were couches of gold and silver on a mosaic pavement of porphyry, marble, mother-of-pearl and other costly stones.
17001007 Wine was served in goblets of gold, each one different from the other, and the royal wine was abundant, in keeping with the king’s liberality.
17001008 By the king’s command each guest was allowed to drink with no restrictions, for the king instructed all the wine stewards to serve each man what he wished.
17001009 Queen Vashti also gave a banquet for the women in the royal palace of King Xerxes.
17001010 On the seventh day, when King Xerxes was in high spirits from wine, he commanded the seven eunuchs who served him—Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, Abagtha, Zethar and Karkas—
17001011 to bring before him Queen Vashti, wearing her royal crown, in order to display her beauty to the people and nobles, for she was lovely to look at.
17001012 But when the attendants delivered the king’s command, Queen Vashti refused to come. Then the king became furious and burned with anger.
17001013 Since it was customary for the king to consult experts in matters of law and justice, he spoke with the wise men who understood the times
17001014 and were closest to the king—Karshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena and Memukan, the seven nobles of Persia and Media who had special access to the king and were highest in the kingdom.
17001015 “According to law, what must be done to Queen Vashti?” he asked. “She has not obeyed the command of King Xerxes that the eunuchs have taken to her.”
17001016 Then Memukan replied in the presence of the king and the nobles, “Queen Vashti has done wrong, not only against the king but also against all the nobles and the peoples of all the provinces of King Xerxes.
17001017 For the queen’s conduct will become known to all the women, and so they will despise their husbands and say, ‘King Xerxes commanded Queen Vashti to be brought before him, but she would not come.’
17001018 This very day the Persian and Median women of the nobility who have heard about the queen’s conduct will respond to all the king’s nobles in the same way. There will be no end of disrespect and discord.
17001019 “Therefore, if it pleases the king, let him issue a royal decree and let it be written in the laws of Persia and Media, which cannot be repealed, that Vashti is never again to enter the presence of King Xerxes. Also let the king give her royal position to someone else who is better than she.
17001020 Then when the king’s edict is proclaimed throughout all his vast realm, all the women will respect their husbands, from the least to the greatest.”
17001021 The king and his nobles were pleased with this advice, so the king did as Memukan proposed.
17001022 He sent dispatches to all parts of the kingdom, to each province in its own script and to each people in their own language, proclaiming that every man should be ruler over his own household, using his native tongue.
17002001 Later when King Xerxes’ fury had subsided, he remembered Vashti and what she had done and what he had decreed about her.
17002002 Then the king’s personal attendants proposed, “Let a search be made for beautiful young virgins for the king.
17002003 Let the king appoint commissioners in every province of his realm to bring all these beautiful young women into the harem at the citadel of Susa. Let them be placed under the care of Hegai, the king’s eunuch, who is in charge of the women; and let beauty treatments be given to them.
17002004 Then let the young woman who pleases the king be queen instead of Vashti.” This advice appealed to the king, and he followed it.
17002005 Now there was in the citadel of Susa a Jew of the tribe of Benjamin, named Mordecai son of Jair, the son of Shimei, the son of Kish,
17002006 who had been carried into exile from Jerusalem by Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, among those taken captive with Jehoiachin king of Judah.
17002007 Mordecai had a cousin named Hadassah, whom he had brought up because she had neither father nor mother. This young woman, who was also known as Esther, had a lovely figure and was beautiful. Mordecai had taken her as his own daughter when her father and mother died.
17002008 When the king’s order and edict had been proclaimed, many young women were brought to the citadel of Susa and put under the care of Hegai. Esther also was taken to the king’s palace and entrusted to Hegai, who had charge of the harem.
17002009 She pleased him and won his favor. Immediately he provided her with her beauty treatments and special food. He assigned to her seven female attendants selected from the king’s palace and moved her and her attendants into the best place in the harem.
17002010 Esther had not revealed her nationality and family background, because Mordecai had forbidden her to do so.
17002011 Every day he walked back and forth near the courtyard of the harem to find out how Esther was and what was happening to her.
17002012 Before a young woman’s turn came to go in to King Xerxes, she had to complete twelve months of beauty treatments prescribed for the women, six months with oil of myrrh and six with perfumes and cosmetics.
17002013 And this is how she would go to the king: Anything she wanted was given her to take with her from the harem to the king’s palace.
17002014 In the evening she would go there and in the morning return to another part of the harem to the care of Shaashgaz, the king’s eunuch who was in charge of the concubines. She would not return to the king unless he was pleased with her and summoned her by name.
17002015 When the turn came for Esther (the young woman Mordecai had adopted, the daughter of his uncle Abihail) to go to the king, she asked for nothing other than what Hegai, the king’s eunuch who was in charge of the harem, suggested. And Esther won the favor of everyone who saw her.
17002016 She was taken to King Xerxes in the royal residence in the tenth month, the month of Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.
17002017 Now the king was attracted to Esther more than to any of the other women, and she won his favor and approval more than any of the other virgins. So he set a royal crown on her head and made her queen instead of Vashti.
17002018 And the king gave a great banquet, Esther’s banquet, for all his nobles and officials. He proclaimed a holiday throughout the provinces and distributed gifts with royal liberality.
17002019 When the virgins were assembled a second time, Mordecai was sitting at the king’s gate.
17002020 But Esther had kept secret her family background and nationality just as Mordecai had told her to do, for she continued to follow Mordecai’s instructions as she had done when he was bringing her up.
17002021 During the time Mordecai was sitting at the king’s gate, Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king’s officers who guarded the doorway, became angry and conspired to assassinate King Xerxes.
17002022 But Mordecai found out about the plot and told Queen Esther, who in turn reported it to the king, giving credit to Mordecai.
17002023 And when the report was investigated and found to be true, the two officials were impaled on poles. All this was recorded in the book of the annals in the presence of the king.
17003001 After these events, King Xerxes honored Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, elevating him and giving him a seat of honor higher than that of all the other nobles.
17003002 All the royal officials at the king’s gate knelt down and paid honor to Haman, for the king had commanded this concerning him. But Mordecai would not kneel down or pay him honor.
17003003 Then the royal officials at the king’s gate asked Mordecai, “Why do you disobey the king’s command?”
17003004 Day after day they spoke to him but he refused to comply. Therefore they told Haman about it to see whether Mordecai’s behavior would be tolerated, for he had told them he was a Jew.
17003005 When Haman saw that Mordecai would not kneel down or pay him honor, he was enraged.
17003006 Yet having learned who Mordecai’s people were, he scorned the idea of killing only Mordecai. Instead Haman looked for a way to destroy all Mordecai’s people, the Jews, throughout the whole kingdom of Xerxes.
17003007 In the twelfth year of King Xerxes, in the first month, the month of Nisan, the pur (that is, the lot) was cast in the presence of Haman to select a day and month. And the lot fell on the twelfth month, the month of Adar.
17003008 Then Haman said to King Xerxes, “There is a certain people dispersed among the peoples in all the provinces of your kingdom who keep themselves separate. Their customs are different from those of all other people, and they do not obey the king’s laws; it is not in the king’s best interest to tolerate them.
17003009 If it pleases the king, let a decree be issued to destroy them, and I will give ten thousand talents of silver to the king’s administrators for the royal treasury.”
17003010 So the king took his signet ring from his finger and gave it to Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of the Jews.
17003011 “Keep the money,” the king said to Haman, “and do with the people as you please.”
17003012 Then on the thirteenth day of the first month the royal secretaries were summoned. They wrote out in the script of each province and in the language of each people all Haman’s orders to the king’s satraps, the governors of the various provinces and the nobles of the various peoples. These were written in the name of King Xerxes himself and sealed with his own ring.
17003013 Dispatches were sent by couriers to all the king’s provinces with the order to destroy, kill and annihilate all the Jews—young and old, women and children—on a single day, the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar, and to plunder their goods.
17003014 A copy of the text of the edict was to be issued as law in every province and made known to the people of every nationality so they would be ready for that day.
17003015 The couriers went out, spurred on by the king’s command, and the edict was issued in the citadel of Susa. The king and Haman sat down to drink, but the city of Susa was bewildered.
17004001 When Mordecai learned of all that had been done, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and went out into the city, wailing loudly and bitterly.
17004002 But he went only as far as the king’s gate, because no one clothed in sackcloth was allowed to enter it.
17004003 In every province to which the edict and order of the king came, there was great mourning among the Jews, with fasting, weeping and wailing. Many lay in sackcloth and ashes.
17004004 When Esther’s eunuchs and female attendants came and told her about Mordecai, she was in great distress. She sent clothes for him to put on instead of his sackcloth, but he would not accept them.
17004005 Then Esther summoned Hathak, one of the king’s eunuchs assigned to attend her, and ordered him to find out what was troubling Mordecai and why.
17004006 So Hathak went out to Mordecai in the open square of the city in front of the king’s gate.
17004007 Mordecai told him everything that had happened to him, including the exact amount of money Haman had promised to pay into the royal treasury for the destruction of the Jews.
17004008 He also gave him a copy of the text of the edict for their annihilation, which had been published in Susa, to show to Esther and explain it to her, and he told him to instruct her to go into the king’s presence to beg for mercy and plead with him for her people.
17004009 Hathak went back and reported to Esther what Mordecai had said.
17004010 Then she instructed him to say to Mordecai,
17004011 “All the king’s officials and the people of the royal provinces know that for any man or woman who approaches the king in the inner court without being summoned the king has but one law: that they be put to death unless the king extends the gold scepter to them and spares their lives. But thirty days have passed since I was called to go to the king.”
17004012 When Esther’s words were reported to Mordecai,
17004013 he sent back this answer: “Do not think that because you are in the king’s house you alone of all the Jews will escape.
17004014 For if you remain silent at this time, relief and deliverance for the Jews will arise from another place, but you and your father’s family will perish. And who knows but that you have come to your royal position for such a time as this?”
17004015 Then Esther sent this reply to Mordecai:
17004016 “Go, gather together all the Jews who are in Susa, and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day. I and my attendants will fast as you do. When this is done, I will go to the king, even though it is against the law. And if I perish, I perish.”
17004017 So Mordecai went away and carried out all of Esther’s instructions.
17005001 On the third day Esther put on her royal robes and stood in the inner court of the palace, in front of the king’s hall. The king was sitting on his royal throne in the hall, facing the entrance.
17005002 When he saw Queen Esther standing in the court, he was pleased with her and held out to her the gold scepter that was in his hand. So Esther approached and touched the tip of the scepter.
17005003 Then the king asked, “What is it, Queen Esther? What is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be given you.”
17005004 “If it pleases the king,” replied Esther, “let the king, together with Haman, come today to a banquet I have prepared for him.”
17005005 “Bring Haman at once,” the king said, “so that we may do what Esther asks.” So the king and Haman went to the banquet Esther had prepared.
17005006 As they were drinking wine, the king again asked Esther, “Now what is your petition? It will be given you. And what is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be granted.”
17005007 Esther replied, “My petition and my request is this:
17005008 If the king regards me with favor and if it pleases the king to grant my petition and fulfill my request, let the king and Haman come tomorrow to the banquet I will prepare for them. Then I will answer the king’s question.”
17005009 Haman went out that day happy and in high spirits. But when he saw Mordecai at the king’s gate and observed that he neither rose nor showed fear in his presence, he was filled with rage against Mordecai.
17005010 Nevertheless, Haman restrained himself and went home. Calling together his friends and Zeresh, his wife,
17005011 Haman boasted to them about his vast wealth, his many sons, and all the ways the king had honored him and how he had elevated him above the other nobles and officials.
17005012 “And that’s not all,” Haman added. “I’m the only person Queen Esther invited to accompany the king to the banquet she gave. And she has invited me along with the king tomorrow.
17005013 But all this gives me no satisfaction as long as I see that Jew Mordecai sitting at the king’s gate.”
17005014 His wife Zeresh and all his friends said to him, “Have a pole set up, reaching to a height of fifty cubits, and ask the king in the morning to have Mordecai impaled on it. Then go with the king to the banquet and enjoy yourself.” This suggestion delighted Haman, and he had the pole set up.
17006001 That night the king could not sleep; so he ordered the book of the chronicles, the record of his reign, to be brought in and read to him.
17006002 It was found recorded there that Mordecai had exposed Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king’s officers who guarded the doorway, who had conspired to assassinate King Xerxes.
17006003 “What honor and recognition has Mordecai received for this?” the king asked. “Nothing has been done for him,” his attendants answered.
17006004 The king said, “Who is in the court?” Now Haman had just entered the outer court of the palace to speak to the king about impaling Mordecai on the pole he had set up for him.
17006005 His attendants answered, “Haman is standing in the court.” “Bring him in,” the king ordered.
17006006 When Haman entered, the king asked him, “What should be done for the man the king delights to honor?” Now Haman thought to himself, “Who is there that the king would rather honor than me?”
17006007 So he answered the king, “For the man the king delights to honor,
17006008 have them bring a royal robe the king has worn and a horse the king has ridden, one with a royal crest placed on its head.
17006009 Then let the robe and horse be entrusted to one of the king’s most noble princes. Let them robe the man the king delights to honor, and lead him on the horse through the city streets, proclaiming before him, ‘This is what is done for the man the king delights to honor!’ ”
17006010 “Go at once,” the king commanded Haman. “Get the robe and the horse and do just as you have suggested for Mordecai the Jew, who sits at the king’s gate. Do not neglect anything you have recommended.”
17006011 So Haman got the robe and the horse. He robed Mordecai, and led him on horseback through the city streets, proclaiming before him, “This is what is done for the man the king delights to honor!”
17006012 Afterward Mordecai returned to the king’s gate. But Haman rushed home, with his head covered in grief,
17006013 and told Zeresh his wife and all his friends everything that had happened to him. His advisers and his wife Zeresh said to him, “Since Mordecai, before whom your downfall has started, is of Jewish origin, you cannot stand against him—you will surely come to ruin!”
17006014 While they were still talking with him, the king’s eunuchs arrived and hurried Haman away to the banquet Esther had prepared.
17007001 So the king and Haman went to Queen Esther’s banquet,
17007002 and as they were drinking wine on the second day, the king again asked, “Queen Esther, what is your petition? It will be given you. What is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be granted.”
17007003 Then Queen Esther answered, “If I have found favor with you, Your Majesty, and if it pleases you, grant me my life—this is my petition. And spare my people—this is my request.
17007004 For I and my people have been sold to be destroyed, killed and annihilated. If we had merely been sold as male and female slaves, I would have kept quiet, because no such distress would justify disturbing the king. ”
17007005 King Xerxes asked Queen Esther, “Who is he? Where is he—the man who has dared to do such a thing?”
17007006 Esther said, “An adversary and enemy! This vile Haman!” Then Haman was terrified before the king and queen.
17007007 The king got up in a rage, left his wine and went out into the palace garden. But Haman, realizing that the king had already decided his fate, stayed behind to beg Queen Esther for his life.
17007008 Just as the king returned from the palace garden to the banquet hall, Haman was falling on the couch where Esther was reclining. The king exclaimed, “Will he even molest the queen while she is with me in the house?” As soon as the word left the king’s mouth, they covered Haman’s face.
17007009 Then Harbona, one of the eunuchs attending the king, said, “A pole reaching to a height of fifty cubits stands by Haman’s house. He had it set up for Mordecai, who spoke up to help the king.” The king said, “Impale him on it!”
17007010 So they impaled Haman on the pole he had set up for Mordecai. Then the king’s fury subsided.
17008001 That same day King Xerxes gave Queen Esther the estate of Haman, the enemy of the Jews. And Mordecai came into the presence of the king, for Esther had told how he was related to her.
17008002 The king took off his signet ring, which he had reclaimed from Haman, and presented it to Mordecai. And Esther appointed him over Haman’s estate.
17008003 Esther again pleaded with the king, falling at his feet and weeping. She begged him to put an end to the evil plan of Haman the Agagite, which he had devised against the Jews.
17008004 Then the king extended the gold scepter to Esther and she arose and stood before him.
17008005 “If it pleases the king,” she said, “and if he regards me with favor and thinks it the right thing to do, and if he is pleased with me, let an order be written overruling the dispatches that Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, devised and wrote to destroy the Jews in all the king’s provinces.
17008006 For how can I bear to see disaster fall on my people? How can I bear to see the destruction of my family?”
17008007 King Xerxes replied to Queen Esther and to Mordecai the Jew, “Because Haman attacked the Jews, I have given his estate to Esther, and they have impaled him on the pole he set up.
17008008 Now write another decree in the king’s name in behalf of the Jews as seems best to you, and seal it with the king’s signet ring—for no document written in the king’s name and sealed with his ring can be revoked.”
17008009 At once the royal secretaries were summoned—on the twenty-third day of the third month, the month of Sivan. They wrote out all Mordecai’s orders to the Jews, and to the satraps, governors and nobles of the 127 provinces stretching from India to Cush. These orders were written in the script of each province and the language of each people and also to the Jews in their own script and language.
17008010 Mordecai wrote in the name of King Xerxes, sealed the dispatches with the king’s signet ring, and sent them by mounted couriers, who rode fast horses especially bred for the king.
17008011 The king’s edict granted the Jews in every city the right to assemble and protect themselves; to destroy, kill and annihilate the armed men of any nationality or province who might attack them and their women and children, and to plunder the property of their enemies.
17008012 The day appointed for the Jews to do this in all the provinces of King Xerxes was the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar.
17008013 A copy of the text of the edict was to be issued as law in every province and made known to the people of every nationality so that the Jews would be ready on that day to avenge themselves on their enemies.
17008014 The couriers, riding the royal horses, went out, spurred on by the king’s command, and the edict was issued in the citadel of Susa.
17008015 When Mordecai left the king’s presence, he was wearing royal garments of blue and white, a large crown of gold and a purple robe of fine linen. And the city of Susa held a joyous celebration.
17008016 For the Jews it was a time of happiness and joy, gladness and honor.
17008017 In every province and in every city to which the edict of the king came, there was joy and gladness among the Jews, with feasting and celebrating. And many people of other nationalities became Jews because fear of the Jews had seized them.
17009001 On the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar, the edict commanded by the king was to be carried out. On this day the enemies of the Jews had hoped to overpower them, but now the tables were turned and the Jews got the upper hand over those who hated them.
17009002 The Jews assembled in their cities in all the provinces of King Xerxes to attack those determined to destroy them. No one could stand against them, because the people of all the other nationalities were afraid of them.
17009003 And all the nobles of the provinces, the satraps, the governors and the king’s administrators helped the Jews, because fear of Mordecai had seized them.
17009004 Mordecai was prominent in the palace; his reputation spread throughout the provinces, and he became more and more powerful.
17009005 The Jews struck down all their enemies with the sword, killing and destroying them, and they did what they pleased to those who hated them.
17009006 In the citadel of Susa, the Jews killed and destroyed five hundred men.
17009007 They also killed Parshandatha, Dalphon, Aspatha,
17009008 Poratha, Adalia, Aridatha,
17009009 Parmashta, Arisai, Aridai and Vaizatha,
17009010 the ten sons of Haman son of Hammedatha, the enemy of the Jews. But they did not lay their hands on the plunder.
17009011 The number of those killed in the citadel of Susa was reported to the king that same day.
17009012 The king said to Queen Esther, “The Jews have killed and destroyed five hundred men and the ten sons of Haman in the citadel of Susa. What have they done in the rest of the king’s provinces? Now what is your petition? It will be given you. What is your request? It will also be granted.”
17009013 “If it pleases the king,” Esther answered, “give the Jews in Susa permission to carry out this day’s edict tomorrow also, and let Haman’s ten sons be impaled on poles.”
17009014 So the king commanded that this be done. An edict was issued in Susa, and they impaled the ten sons of Haman.
17009015 The Jews in Susa came together on the fourteenth day of the month of Adar, and they put to death in Susa three hundred men, but they did not lay their hands on the plunder.
17009016 Meanwhile, the remainder of the Jews who were in the king’s provinces also assembled to protect themselves and get relief from their enemies. They killed seventy-five thousand of them but did not lay their hands on the plunder.
17009017 This happened on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar, and on the fourteenth they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy.
17009018 The Jews in Susa, however, had assembled on the thirteenth and fourteenth, and then on the fifteenth they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy.
17009019 That is why rural Jews—those living in villages—observe the fourteenth of the month of Adar as a day of joy and feasting, a day for giving presents to each other.
17009020 Mordecai recorded these events, and he sent letters to all the Jews throughout the provinces of King Xerxes, near and far,
17009021 to have them celebrate annually the fourteenth and fifteenth days of the month of Adar
17009022 as the time when the Jews got relief from their enemies, and as the month when their sorrow was turned into joy and their mourning into a day of celebration. He wrote them to observe the days as days of feasting and joy and giving presents of food to one another and gifts to the poor.
17009023 So the Jews agreed to continue the celebration they had begun, doing what Mordecai had written to them.
17009024 For Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had plotted against the Jews to destroy them and had cast the pur (that is, the lot) for their ruin and destruction.
17009025 But when the plot came to the king’s attention, he issued written orders that the evil scheme Haman had devised against the Jews should come back onto his own head, and that he and his sons should be impaled on poles.
17009026 (Therefore these days were called Purim, from the word pur.) Because of everything written in this letter and because of what they had seen and what had happened to them,
17009027 the Jews took it on themselves to establish the custom that they and their descendants and all who join them should without fail observe these two days every year, in the way prescribed and at the time appointed.
17009028 These days should be remembered and observed in every generation by every family, and in every province and in every city. And these days of Purim should never fail to be celebrated by the Jews—nor should the memory of these days die out among their descendants.
17009029 So Queen Esther, daughter of Abihail, along with Mordecai the Jew, wrote with full authority to confirm this second letter concerning Purim.
17009030 And Mordecai sent letters to all the Jews in the 127 provinces of Xerxes’ kingdom—words of goodwill and assurance—
17009031 to establish these days of Purim at their designated times, as Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther had decreed for them, and as they had established for themselves and their descendants in regard to their times of fasting and lamentation.
17009032 Esther’s decree confirmed these regulations about Purim, and it was written down in the records.
17010001 King Xerxes imposed tribute throughout the empire, to its distant shores.
17010002 And all his acts of power and might, together with a full account of the greatness of Mordecai, whom the king had promoted, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Media and Persia?
17010003 Mordecai the Jew was second in rank to King Xerxes, preeminent among the Jews, and held in high esteem by his many fellow Jews, because he worked for the good of his people and spoke up for the welfare of all the Jews.
18001001 In the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil.
18001002 He had seven sons and three daughters,
18001003 and he owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen and five hundred donkeys, and had a large number of servants. He was the greatest man among all the people of the East.
18001004 His sons used to hold feasts in their homes on their birthdays, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
18001005 When a period of feasting had run its course, Job would make arrangements for them to be purified. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them, thinking, “Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” This was Job’s regular custom.
18001006 One day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them.
18001007 The Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?” Satan answered the Lord, “From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it.”
18001008 Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil.”
18001009 “Does Job fear God for nothing?” Satan replied.
18001010 “Have you not put a hedge around him and his household and everything he has? You have blessed the work of his hands, so that his flocks and herds are spread throughout the land.
18001011 But now stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
18001012 The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, everything he has is in your power, but on the man himself do not lay a finger.” Then Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.
18001013 One day when Job’s sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,
18001014 a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,
18001015 and the Sabeans attacked and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
18001016 While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The fire of God fell from the heavens and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
18001017 While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and made off with them. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
18001018 While he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said, “Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother’s house,
18001019 when suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on them and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
18001020 At this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship
18001021 and said: “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked I will depart. The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away; may the name of the Lord be praised.”
18001022 In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.
18002001 On another day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them to present himself before him.
18002002 And the Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?” Satan answered the Lord, “From roaming throughout the earth, going back and forth on it.”
18002003 Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil. And he still maintains his integrity, though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason.”
18002004 “Skin for skin!” Satan replied. “A man will give all he has for his own life.
18002005 But now stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.”
18002006 The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, he is in your hands; but you must spare his life.”
18002007 So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the crown of his head.
18002008 Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes.
18002009 His wife said to him, “Are you still maintaining your integrity? Curse God and die!”
18002010 He replied, “You are talking like a foolish woman. Shall we accept good from God, and not trouble?” In all this, Job did not sin in what he said.
18002011 When Job’s three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.
18002012 When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads.
18002013 Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was.
18003001 After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
18003002 He said:
18003003 “May the day of my birth perish, and the night that said, ‘A boy is conceived!’
18003004 That day—may it turn to darkness; may God above not care about it; may no light shine on it.
18003005 May gloom and utter darkness claim it once more; may a cloud settle over it; may blackness overwhelm it.
18003006 That night—may thick darkness seize it; may it not be included among the days of the year nor be entered in any of the months.
18003007 May that night be barren; may no shout of joy be heard in it.
18003008 May those who curse days curse that day, those who are ready to rouse Leviathan.
18003009 May its morning stars become dark; may it wait for daylight in vain and not see the first rays of dawn,
18003010 for it did not shut the doors of the womb on me to hide trouble from my eyes.
18003011 “Why did I not perish at birth, and die as I came from the womb?
18003012 Why were there knees to receive me and breasts that I might be nursed?
18003013 For now I would be lying down in peace; I would be asleep and at rest
18003014 with kings and rulers of the earth, who built for themselves places now lying in ruins,
18003015 with princes who had gold, who filled their houses with silver.
18003016 Or why was I not hidden away in the ground like a stillborn child, like an infant who never saw the light of day?
18003017 There the wicked cease from turmoil, and there the weary are at rest.
18003018 Captives also enjoy their ease; they no longer hear the slave driver’s shout.
18003019 The small and the great are there, and the slaves are freed from their owners.
18003020 “Why is light given to those in misery, and life to the bitter of soul,
18003021 to those who long for death that does not come, who search for it more than for hidden treasure,
18003022 who are filled with gladness and rejoice when they reach the grave?
18003023 Why is life given to a man whose way is hidden, whom God has hedged in?
18003024 For sighing has become my daily food; my groans pour out like water.
18003025 What I feared has come upon me; what I dreaded has happened to me.
18003026 I have no peace, no quietness; I have no rest, but only turmoil.”
18004001 Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
18004002 “If someone ventures a word with you, will you be impatient? But who can keep from speaking?
18004003 Think how you have instructed many, how you have strengthened feeble hands.
18004004 Your words have supported those who stumbled; you have strengthened faltering knees.
18004005 But now trouble comes to you, and you are discouraged; it strikes you, and you are dismayed.
18004006 Should not your piety be your confidence and your blameless ways your hope?
18004007 “Consider now: Who, being innocent, has ever perished? Where were the upright ever destroyed?
18004008 As I have observed, those who plow evil and those who sow trouble reap it.
18004009 At the breath of God they perish; at the blast of his anger they are no more.
18004010 The lions may roar and growl, yet the teeth of the great lions are broken.
18004011 The lion perishes for lack of prey, and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
18004012 “A word was secretly brought to me, my ears caught a whisper of it.
18004013 Amid disquieting dreams in the night, when deep sleep falls on people,
18004014 fear and trembling seized me and made all my bones shake.
18004015 A spirit glided past my face, and the hair on my body stood on end.
18004016 It stopped, but I could not tell what it was. A form stood before my eyes, and I heard a hushed voice:
18004017 ‘Can a mortal be more righteous than God? Can even a strong man be more pure than his Maker?
18004018 If God places no trust in his servants, if he charges his angels with error,
18004019 how much more those who live in houses of clay, whose foundations are in the dust, who are crushed more readily than a moth!
18004020 Between dawn and dusk they are broken to pieces; unnoticed, they perish forever.
18004021 Are not the cords of their tent pulled up, so that they die without wisdom?’
18005001 “Call if you will, but who will answer you? To which of the holy ones will you turn?
18005002 Resentment kills a fool, and envy slays the simple.
18005003 I myself have seen a fool taking root, but suddenly his house was cursed.
18005004 His children are far from safety, crushed in court without a defender.
18005005 The hungry consume his harvest, taking it even from among thorns, and the thirsty pant after his wealth.
18005006 For hardship does not spring from the soil, nor does trouble sprout from the ground.
18005007 Yet man is born to trouble as surely as sparks fly upward.
18005008 “But if I were you, I would appeal to God; I would lay my cause before him.
18005009 He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted.
18005010 He provides rain for the earth; he sends water on the countryside.
18005011 The lowly he sets on high, and those who mourn are lifted to safety.
18005012 He thwarts the plans of the crafty, so that their hands achieve no success.
18005013 He catches the wise in their craftiness, and the schemes of the wily are swept away.
18005014 Darkness comes upon them in the daytime; at noon they grope as in the night.
18005015 He saves the needy from the sword in their mouth; he saves them from the clutches of the powerful.
18005016 So the poor have hope, and injustice shuts its mouth.
18005017 “Blessed is the one whom God corrects; so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
18005018 For he wounds, but he also binds up; he injures, but his hands also heal.
18005019 From six calamities he will rescue you; in seven no harm will touch you.
18005020 In famine he will deliver you from death, and in battle from the stroke of the sword.
18005021 You will be protected from the lash of the tongue, and need not fear when destruction comes.
18005022 You will laugh at destruction and famine, and need not fear the wild animals.
18005023 For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field, and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
18005024 You will know that your tent is secure; you will take stock of your property and find nothing missing.
18005025 You will know that your children will be many, and your descendants like the grass of the earth.
18005026 You will come to the grave in full vigor, like sheaves gathered in season.
18005027 “We have examined this, and it is true. So hear it and apply it to yourself.”
18006001 Then Job replied:
18006002 “If only my anguish could be weighed and all my misery be placed on the scales!
18006003 It would surely outweigh the sand of the seas— no wonder my words have been impetuous.
18006004 The arrows of the Almighty are in me, my spirit drinks in their poison; God’s terrors are marshaled against me.
18006005 Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass, or an ox bellow when it has fodder?
18006006 Is tasteless food eaten without salt, or is there flavor in the sap of the mallow ?
18006007 I refuse to touch it; such food makes me ill.
18006008 “Oh, that I might have my request, that God would grant what I hope for,
18006009 that God would be willing to crush me, to let loose his hand and cut off my life!
18006010 Then I would still have this consolation— my joy in unrelenting pain— that I had not denied the words of the Holy One.
18006011 “What strength do I have, that I should still hope? What prospects, that I should be patient?
18006012 Do I have the strength of stone? Is my flesh bronze?
18006013 Do I have any power to help myself, now that success has been driven from me?
18006014 “Anyone who withholds kindness from a friend forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
18006015 But my brothers are as undependable as intermittent streams, as the streams that overflow
18006016 when darkened by thawing ice and swollen with melting snow,
18006017 but that stop flowing in the dry season, and in the heat vanish from their channels.
18006018 Caravans turn aside from their routes; they go off into the wasteland and perish.
18006019 The caravans of Tema look for water, the traveling merchants of Sheba look in hope.
18006020 They are distressed, because they had been confident; they arrive there, only to be disappointed.
18006021 Now you too have proved to be of no help; you see something dreadful and are afraid.
18006022 Have I ever said, ‘Give something on my behalf, pay a ransom for me from your wealth,
18006023 deliver me from the hand of the enemy, rescue me from the clutches of the ruthless’?
18006024 “Teach me, and I will be quiet; show me where I have been wrong.
18006025 How painful are honest words! But what do your arguments prove?
18006026 Do you mean to correct what I say, and treat my desperate words as wind?
18006027 You would even cast lots for the fatherless and barter away your friend.
18006028 “But now be so kind as to look at me. Would I lie to your face?
18006029 Relent, do not be unjust; reconsider, for my integrity is at stake.
18006030 Is there any wickedness on my lips? Can my mouth not discern malice?
18007001 “Do not mortals have hard service on earth? Are not their days like those of hired laborers?
18007002 Like a slave longing for the evening shadows, or a hired laborer waiting to be paid,
18007003 so I have been allotted months of futility, and nights of misery have been assigned to me.
18007004 When I lie down I think, ‘How long before I get up?’ The night drags on, and I toss and turn until dawn.
18007005 My body is clothed with worms and scabs, my skin is broken and festering.
18007006 “My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, and they come to an end without hope.
18007007 Remember, O God, that my life is but a breath; my eyes will never see happiness again.
18007008 The eye that now sees me will see me no longer; you will look for me, but I will be no more.
18007009 As a cloud vanishes and is gone, so one who goes down to the grave does not return.
18007010 He will never come to his house again; his place will know him no more.
18007011 “Therefore I will not keep silent; I will speak out in the anguish of my spirit, I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
18007012 Am I the sea, or the monster of the deep, that you put me under guard?
18007013 When I think my bed will comfort me and my couch will ease my complaint,
18007014 even then you frighten me with dreams and terrify me with visions,
18007015 so that I prefer strangling and death, rather than this body of mine.
18007016 I despise my life; I would not live forever. Let me alone; my days have no meaning.
18007017 “What is mankind that you make so much of them, that you give them so much attention,
18007018 that you examine them every morning and test them every moment?
18007019 Will you never look away from me, or let me alone even for an instant?
18007020 If I have sinned, what have I done to you, you who see everything we do? Why have you made me your target? Have I become a burden to you?
18007021 Why do you not pardon my offenses and forgive my sins? For I will soon lie down in the dust; you will search for me, but I will be no more.”
18008001 Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
18008002 “How long will you say such things? Your words are a blustering wind.
18008003 Does God pervert justice? Does the Almighty pervert what is right?
18008004 When your children sinned against him, he gave them over to the penalty of their sin.
18008005 But if you will seek God earnestly and plead with the Almighty,
18008006 if you are pure and upright, even now he will rouse himself on your behalf and restore you to your prosperous state.
18008007 Your beginnings will seem humble, so prosperous will your future be.
18008008 “Ask the former generation and find out what their ancestors learned,
18008009 for we were born only yesterday and know nothing, and our days on earth are but a shadow.
18008010 Will they not instruct you and tell you? Will they not bring forth words from their understanding?
18008011 Can papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh? Can reeds thrive without water?
18008012 While still growing and uncut, they wither more quickly than grass.
18008013 Such is the destiny of all who forget God; so perishes the hope of the godless.
18008014 What they trust in is fragile ; what they rely on is a spider’s web.
18008015 They lean on the web, but it gives way; they cling to it, but it does not hold.
18008016 They are like a well-watered plant in the sunshine, spreading its shoots over the garden;
18008017 it entwines its roots around a pile of rocks and looks for a place among the stones.
18008018 But when it is torn from its spot, that place disowns it and says, ‘I never saw you.’
18008019 Surely its life withers away, and from the soil other plants grow.
18008020 “Surely God does not reject one who is blameless or strengthen the hands of evildoers.
18008021 He will yet fill your mouth with laughter and your lips with shouts of joy.
18008022 Your enemies will be clothed in shame, and the tents of the wicked will be no more.”
18009001 Then Job replied:
18009002 “Indeed, I know that this is true. But how can mere mortals prove their innocence before God?
18009003 Though they wished to dispute with him, they could not answer him one time out of a thousand.
18009004 His wisdom is profound, his power is vast. Who has resisted him and come out unscathed?
18009005 He moves mountains without their knowing it and overturns them in his anger.
18009006 He shakes the earth from its place and makes its pillars tremble.
18009007 He speaks to the sun and it does not shine; he seals off the light of the stars.
18009008 He alone stretches out the heavens and treads on the waves of the sea.
18009009 He is the Maker of the Bear and Orion, the Pleiades and the constellations of the south.
18009010 He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted.
18009011 When he passes me, I cannot see him; when he goes by, I cannot perceive him.
18009012 If he snatches away, who can stop him? Who can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
18009013 God does not restrain his anger; even the cohorts of Rahab cowered at his feet.
18009014 “How then can I dispute with him? How can I find words to argue with him?
18009015 Though I were innocent, I could not answer him; I could only plead with my Judge for mercy.
18009016 Even if I summoned him and he responded, I do not believe he would give me a hearing.
18009017 He would crush me with a storm and multiply my wounds for no reason.
18009018 He would not let me catch my breath but would overwhelm me with misery.
18009019 If it is a matter of strength, he is mighty! And if it is a matter of justice, who can challenge him ?
18009020 Even if I were innocent, my mouth would condemn me; if I were blameless, it would pronounce me guilty.
18009021 “Although I am blameless, I have no concern for myself; I despise my own life.
18009022 It is all the same; that is why I say, ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
18009023 When a scourge brings sudden death, he mocks the despair of the innocent.
18009024 When a land falls into the hands of the wicked, he blindfolds its judges. If it is not he, then who is it?
18009025 “My days are swifter than a runner; they fly away without a glimpse of joy.
18009026 They skim past like boats of papyrus, like eagles swooping down on their prey.
18009027 If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I will change my expression, and smile,’
18009028 I still dread all my sufferings, for I know you will not hold me innocent.
18009029 Since I am already found guilty, why should I struggle in vain?
18009030 Even if I washed myself with soap and my hands with cleansing powder,
18009031 you would plunge me into a slime pit so that even my clothes would detest me.
18009032 “He is not a mere mortal like me that I might answer him, that we might confront each other in court.
18009033 If only there were someone to mediate between us, someone to bring us together,
18009034 someone to remove God’s rod from me, so that his terror would frighten me no more.
18009035 Then I would speak up without fear of him, but as it now stands with me, I cannot.
18010001 “I loathe my very life; therefore I will give free rein to my complaint and speak out in the bitterness of my soul.
18010002 I say to God: Do not declare me guilty, but tell me what charges you have against me.
18010003 Does it please you to oppress me, to spurn the work of your hands, while you smile on the plans of the wicked?
18010004 Do you have eyes of flesh? Do you see as a mortal sees?
18010005 Are your days like those of a mortal or your years like those of a strong man,
18010006 that you must search out my faults and probe after my sin—
18010007 though you know that I am not guilty and that no one can rescue me from your hand?
18010008 “Your hands shaped me and made me. Will you now turn and destroy me?
18010009 Remember that you molded me like clay. Will you now turn me to dust again?
18010010 Did you not pour me out like milk and curdle me like cheese,
18010011 clothe me with skin and flesh and knit me together with bones and sinews?
18010012 You gave me life and showed me kindness, and in your providence watched over my spirit.
18010013 “But this is what you concealed in your heart, and I know that this was in your mind:
18010014 If I sinned, you would be watching me and would not let my offense go unpunished.
18010015 If I am guilty—woe to me! Even if I am innocent, I cannot lift my head, for I am full of shame and drowned in my affliction.
18010016 If I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion and again display your awesome power against me.
18010017 You bring new witnesses against me and increase your anger toward me; your forces come against me wave upon wave.
18010018 “Why then did you bring me out of the womb? I wish I had died before any eye saw me.
18010019 If only I had never come into being, or had been carried straight from the womb to the grave!
18010020 Are not my few days almost over? Turn away from me so I can have a moment’s joy
18010021 before I go to the place of no return, to the land of gloom and utter darkness,
18010022 to the land of deepest night, of utter darkness and disorder, where even the light is like darkness.”
18011001 Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:
18011002 “Are all these words to go unanswered? Is this talker to be vindicated?
18011003 Will your idle talk reduce others to silence? Will no one rebuke you when you mock?
18011004 You say to God, ‘My beliefs are flawless and I am pure in your sight.’
18011005 Oh, how I wish that God would speak, that he would open his lips against you
18011006 and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom, for true wisdom has two sides. Know this: God has even forgotten some of your sin.
18011007 “Can you fathom the mysteries of God? Can you probe the limits of the Almighty?
18011008 They are higher than the heavens above—what can you do? They are deeper than the depths below—what can you know?
18011009 Their measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea.
18011010 “If he comes along and confines you in prison and convenes a court, who can oppose him?
18011011 Surely he recognizes deceivers; and when he sees evil, does he not take note?
18011012 But the witless can no more become wise than a wild donkey’s colt can be born human.
18011013 “Yet if you devote your heart to him and stretch out your hands to him,
18011014 if you put away the sin that is in your hand and allow no evil to dwell in your tent,
18011015 then, free of fault, you will lift up your face; you will stand firm and without fear.
18011016 You will surely forget your trouble, recalling it only as waters gone by.
18011017 Life will be brighter than noonday, and darkness will become like morning.
18011018 You will be secure, because there is hope; you will look about you and take your rest in safety.
18011019 You will lie down, with no one to make you afraid, and many will court your favor.
18011020 But the eyes of the wicked will fail, and escape will elude them; their hope will become a dying gasp.”
18012001 Then Job replied:
18012002 “Doubtless you are the only people who matter, and wisdom will die with you!
18012003 But I have a mind as well as you; I am not inferior to you. Who does not know all these things?
18012004 “I have become a laughingstock to my friends, though I called on God and he answered— a mere laughingstock, though righteous and blameless!
18012005 Those who are at ease have contempt for misfortune as the fate of those whose feet are slipping.
18012006 The tents of marauders are undisturbed, and those who provoke God are secure— those God has in his hand.
18012007 “But ask the animals, and they will teach you, or the birds in the sky, and they will tell you;
18012008 or speak to the earth, and it will teach you, or let the fish in the sea inform you.
18012009 Which of all these does not know that the hand of the Lord has done this?
18012010 In his hand is the life of every creature and the breath of all mankind.
18012011 Does not the ear test words as the tongue tastes food?
18012012 Is not wisdom found among the aged? Does not long life bring understanding?
18012013 “To God belong wisdom and power; counsel and understanding are his.
18012014 What he tears down cannot be rebuilt; those he imprisons cannot be released.
18012015 If he holds back the waters, there is drought; if he lets them loose, they devastate the land.
18012016 To him belong strength and insight; both deceived and deceiver are his.
18012017 He leads rulers away stripped and makes fools of judges.
18012018 He takes off the shackles put on by kings and ties a loincloth around their waist.
18012019 He leads priests away stripped and overthrows officials long established.
18012020 He silences the lips of trusted advisers and takes away the discernment of elders.
18012021 He pours contempt on nobles and disarms the mighty.
18012022 He reveals the deep things of darkness and brings utter darkness into the light.
18012023 He makes nations great, and destroys them; he enlarges nations, and disperses them.
18012024 He deprives the leaders of the earth of their reason; he makes them wander in a trackless waste.
18012025 They grope in darkness with no light; he makes them stagger like drunkards.
18013001 “My eyes have seen all this, my ears have heard and understood it.
18013002 What you know, I also know; I am not inferior to you.
18013003 But I desire to speak to the Almighty and to argue my case with God.
18013004 You, however, smear me with lies; you are worthless physicians, all of you!
18013005 If only you would be altogether silent! For you, that would be wisdom.
18013006 Hear now my argument; listen to the pleas of my lips.
18013007 Will you speak wickedly on God’s behalf? Will you speak deceitfully for him?
18013008 Will you show him partiality? Will you argue the case for God?
18013009 Would it turn out well if he examined you? Could you deceive him as you might deceive a mortal?
18013010 He would surely call you to account if you secretly showed partiality.
