18013011 Would not his splendor terrify you? Would not the dread of him fall on you?
18013012 Your maxims are proverbs of ashes; your defenses are defenses of clay.
18013013 “Keep silent and let me speak; then let come to me what may.
18013014 Why do I put myself in jeopardy and take my life in my hands?
18013015 Though he slay me, yet will I hope in him; I will surely defend my ways to his face.
18013016 Indeed, this will turn out for my deliverance, for no godless person would dare come before him!
18013017 Listen carefully to what I say; let my words ring in your ears.
18013018 Now that I have prepared my case, I know I will be vindicated.
18013019 Can anyone bring charges against me? If so, I will be silent and die.
18013020 “Only grant me these two things, God, and then I will not hide from you:
18013021 Withdraw your hand far from me, and stop frightening me with your terrors.
18013022 Then summon me and I will answer, or let me speak, and you reply to me.
18013023 How many wrongs and sins have I committed? Show me my offense and my sin.
18013024 Why do you hide your face and consider me your enemy?
18013025 Will you torment a windblown leaf? Will you chase after dry chaff?
18013026 For you write down bitter things against me and make me reap the sins of my youth.
18013027 You fasten my feet in shackles; you keep close watch on all my paths by putting marks on the soles of my feet.
18013028 “So man wastes away like something rotten, like a garment eaten by moths.
18014001 “Mortals, born of woman, are of few days and full of trouble.
18014002 They spring up like flowers and wither away; like fleeting shadows, they do not endure.
18014003 Do you fix your eye on them? Will you bring them before you for judgment?
18014004 Who can bring what is pure from the impure? No one!
18014005 A person’s days are determined; you have decreed the number of his months and have set limits he cannot exceed.
18014006 So look away from him and let him alone, till he has put in his time like a hired laborer.
18014007 “At least there is hope for a tree: If it is cut down, it will sprout again, and its new shoots will not fail.
18014008 Its roots may grow old in the ground and its stump die in the soil,
18014009 yet at the scent of water it will bud and put forth shoots like a plant.
18014010 But a man dies and is laid low; he breathes his last and is no more.
18014011 As the water of a lake dries up or a riverbed becomes parched and dry,
18014012 so he lies down and does not rise; till the heavens are no more, people will not awake or be roused from their sleep.
18014013 “If only you would hide me in the grave and conceal me till your anger has passed! If only you would set me a time and then remember me!
18014014 If someone dies, will they live again? All the days of my hard service I will wait for my renewal to come.
18014015 You will call and I will answer you; you will long for the creature your hands have made.
18014016 Surely then you will count my steps but not keep track of my sin.
18014017 My offenses will be sealed up in a bag; you will cover over my sin.
18014018 “But as a mountain erodes and crumbles and as a rock is moved from its place,
18014019 as water wears away stones and torrents wash away the soil, so you destroy a person’s hope.
18014020 You overpower them once for all, and they are gone; you change their countenance and send them away.
18014021 If their children are honored, they do not know it; if their offspring are brought low, they do not see it.
18014022 They feel but the pain of their own bodies and mourn only for themselves.”
18015001 Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
18015002 “Would a wise person answer with empty notions or fill their belly with the hot east wind?
18015003 Would they argue with useless words, with speeches that have no value?
18015004 But you even undermine piety and hinder devotion to God.
18015005 Your sin prompts your mouth; you adopt the tongue of the crafty.
18015006 Your own mouth condemns you, not mine; your own lips testify against you.
18015007 “Are you the first man ever born? Were you brought forth before the hills?
18015008 Do you listen in on God’s council? Do you have a monopoly on wisdom?
18015009 What do you know that we do not know? What insights do you have that we do not have?
18015010 The gray-haired and the aged are on our side, men even older than your father.
18015011 Are God’s consolations not enough for you, words spoken gently to you?
18015012 Why has your heart carried you away, and why do your eyes flash,
18015013 so that you vent your rage against God and pour out such words from your mouth?
18015014 “What are mortals, that they could be pure, or those born of woman, that they could be righteous?
18015015 If God places no trust in his holy ones, if even the heavens are not pure in his eyes,
18015016 how much less mortals, who are vile and corrupt, who drink up evil like water!
18015017 “Listen to me and I will explain to you; let me tell you what I have seen,
18015018 what the wise have declared, hiding nothing received from their ancestors
18015019 (to whom alone the land was given when no foreigners moved among them):
18015020 All his days the wicked man suffers torment, the ruthless man through all the years stored up for him.
18015021 Terrifying sounds fill his ears; when all seems well, marauders attack him.
18015022 He despairs of escaping the realm of darkness; he is marked for the sword.
18015023 He wanders about for food like a vulture; he knows the day of darkness is at hand.
18015024 Distress and anguish fill him with terror; troubles overwhelm him, like a king poised to attack,
18015025 because he shakes his fist at God and vaunts himself against the Almighty,
18015026 defiantly charging against him with a thick, strong shield.
18015027 “Though his face is covered with fat and his waist bulges with flesh,
18015028 he will inhabit ruined towns and houses where no one lives, houses crumbling to rubble.
18015029 He will no longer be rich and his wealth will not endure, nor will his possessions spread over the land.
18015030 He will not escape the darkness; a flame will wither his shoots, and the breath of God’s mouth will carry him away.
18015031 Let him not deceive himself by trusting what is worthless, for he will get nothing in return.
18015032 Before his time he will wither, and his branches will not flourish.
18015033 He will be like a vine stripped of its unripe grapes, like an olive tree shedding its blossoms.
18015034 For the company of the godless will be barren, and fire will consume the tents of those who love bribes.
18015035 They conceive trouble and give birth to evil; their womb fashions deceit.”
18016001 Then Job replied:
18016002 “I have heard many things like these; you are miserable comforters, all of you!
18016003 Will your long-winded speeches never end? What ails you that you keep on arguing?
18016004 I also could speak like you, if you were in my place; I could make fine speeches against you and shake my head at you.
18016005 But my mouth would encourage you; comfort from my lips would bring you relief.
18016006 “Yet if I speak, my pain is not relieved; and if I refrain, it does not go away.
18016007 Surely, God, you have worn me out; you have devastated my entire household.
18016008 You have shriveled me up—and it has become a witness; my gauntness rises up and testifies against me.
18016009 God assails me and tears me in his anger and gnashes his teeth at me; my opponent fastens on me his piercing eyes.
18016010 People open their mouths to jeer at me; they strike my cheek in scorn and unite together against me.
18016011 God has turned me over to the ungodly and thrown me into the clutches of the wicked.
18016012 All was well with me, but he shattered me; he seized me by the neck and crushed me. He has made me his target;
18016013 his archers surround me. Without pity, he pierces my kidneys and spills my gall on the ground.
18016014 Again and again he bursts upon me; he rushes at me like a warrior.
18016015 “I have sewed sackcloth over my skin and buried my brow in the dust.
18016016 My face is red with weeping, dark shadows ring my eyes;
18016017 yet my hands have been free of violence and my prayer is pure.
18016018 “Earth, do not cover my blood; may my cry never be laid to rest!
18016019 Even now my witness is in heaven; my advocate is on high.
18016020 My intercessor is my friend as my eyes pour out tears to God;
18016021 on behalf of a man he pleads with God as one pleads for a friend.
18016022 “Only a few years will pass before I take the path of no return.
18017001 My spirit is broken, my days are cut short, the grave awaits me.
18017002 Surely mockers surround me; my eyes must dwell on their hostility.
18017003 “Give me, O God, the pledge you demand. Who else will put up security for me?
18017004 You have closed their minds to understanding; therefore you will not let them triumph.
18017005 If anyone denounces their friends for reward, the eyes of their children will fail.
18017006 “God has made me a byword to everyone, a man in whose face people spit.
18017007 My eyes have grown dim with grief; my whole frame is but a shadow.
18017008 The upright are appalled at this; the innocent are aroused against the ungodly.
18017009 Nevertheless, the righteous will hold to their ways, and those with clean hands will grow stronger.
18017010 “But come on, all of you, try again! I will not find a wise man among you.
18017011 My days have passed, my plans are shattered. Yet the desires of my heart
18017012 turn night into day; in the face of the darkness light is near.
18017013 If the only home I hope for is the grave, if I spread out my bed in the realm of darkness,
18017014 if I say to corruption, ‘You are my father,’ and to the worm, ‘My mother’ or ‘My sister,’
18017015 where then is my hope— who can see any hope for me?
18017016 Will it go down to the gates of death? Will we descend together into the dust?”
18018001 Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
18018002 “When will you end these speeches? Be sensible, and then we can talk.
18018003 Why are we regarded as cattle and considered stupid in your sight?
18018004 You who tear yourself to pieces in your anger, is the earth to be abandoned for your sake? Or must the rocks be moved from their place?
18018005 “The lamp of a wicked man is snuffed out; the flame of his fire stops burning.
18018006 The light in his tent becomes dark; the lamp beside him goes out.
18018007 The vigor of his step is weakened; his own schemes throw him down.
18018008 His feet thrust him into a net; he wanders into its mesh.
18018009 A trap seizes him by the heel; a snare holds him fast.
18018010 A noose is hidden for him on the ground; a trap lies in his path.
18018011 Terrors startle him on every side and dog his every step.
18018012 Calamity is hungry for him; disaster is ready for him when he falls.
18018013 It eats away parts of his skin; death’s firstborn devours his limbs.
18018014 He is torn from the security of his tent and marched off to the king of terrors.
18018015 Fire resides in his tent; burning sulfur is scattered over his dwelling.
18018016 His roots dry up below and his branches wither above.
18018017 The memory of him perishes from the earth; he has no name in the land.
18018018 He is driven from light into the realm of darkness and is banished from the world.
18018019 He has no offspring or descendants among his people, no survivor where once he lived.
18018020 People of the west are appalled at his fate; those of the east are seized with horror.
18018021 Surely such is the dwelling of an evil man; such is the place of one who does not know God.”
18019001 Then Job replied:
18019002 “How long will you torment me and crush me with words?
18019003 Ten times now you have reproached me; shamelessly you attack me.
18019004 If it is true that I have gone astray, my error remains my concern alone.
18019005 If indeed you would exalt yourselves above me and use my humiliation against me,
18019006 then know that God has wronged me and drawn his net around me.
18019007 “Though I cry, ‘Violence!’ I get no response; though I call for help, there is no justice.
18019008 He has blocked my way so I cannot pass; he has shrouded my paths in darkness.
18019009 He has stripped me of my honor and removed the crown from my head.
18019010 He tears me down on every side till I am gone; he uproots my hope like a tree.
18019011 His anger burns against me; he counts me among his enemies.
18019012 His troops advance in force; they build a siege ramp against me and encamp around my tent.
18019013 “He has alienated my family from me; my acquaintances are completely estranged from me.
18019014 My relatives have gone away; my closest friends have forgotten me.
18019015 My guests and my female servants count me a foreigner; they look on me as on a stranger.
18019016 I summon my servant, but he does not answer, though I beg him with my own mouth.
18019017 My breath is offensive to my wife; I am loathsome to my own family.
18019018 Even the little boys scorn me; when I appear, they ridicule me.
18019019 All my intimate friends detest me; those I love have turned against me.
18019020 I am nothing but skin and bones; I have escaped only by the skin of my teeth.
18019021 “Have pity on me, my friends, have pity, for the hand of God has struck me.
18019022 Why do you pursue me as God does? Will you never get enough of my flesh?
18019023 “Oh, that my words were recorded, that they were written on a scroll,
18019024 that they were inscribed with an iron tool on lead, or engraved in rock forever!
18019025 I know that my redeemer lives, and that in the end he will stand on the earth.
18019026 And after my skin has been destroyed, yet in my flesh I will see God;
18019027 I myself will see him with my own eyes—I, and not another. How my heart yearns within me!
18019028 “If you say, ‘How we will hound him, since the root of the trouble lies in him, ’
18019029 you should fear the sword yourselves; for wrath will bring punishment by the sword, and then you will know that there is judgment. ”
18020001 Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:
18020002 “My troubled thoughts prompt me to answer because I am greatly disturbed.
18020003 I hear a rebuke that dishonors me, and my understanding inspires me to reply.
18020004 “Surely you know how it has been from of old, ever since mankind was placed on the earth,
18020005 that the mirth of the wicked is brief, the joy of the godless lasts but a moment.
18020006 Though the pride of the godless person reaches to the heavens and his head touches the clouds,
18020007 he will perish forever, like his own dung; those who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
18020008 Like a dream he flies away, no more to be found, banished like a vision of the night.
18020009 The eye that saw him will not see him again; his place will look on him no more.
18020010 His children must make amends to the poor; his own hands must give back his wealth.
18020011 The youthful vigor that fills his bones will lie with him in the dust.
18020012 “Though evil is sweet in his mouth and he hides it under his tongue,
18020013 though he cannot bear to let it go and lets it linger in his mouth,
18020014 yet his food will turn sour in his stomach; it will become the venom of serpents within him.
18020015 He will spit out the riches he swallowed; God will make his stomach vomit them up.
18020016 He will suck the poison of serpents; the fangs of an adder will kill him.
18020017 He will not enjoy the streams, the rivers flowing with honey and cream.
18020018 What he toiled for he must give back uneaten; he will not enjoy the profit from his trading.
18020019 For he has oppressed the poor and left them destitute; he has seized houses he did not build.
18020020 “Surely he will have no respite from his craving; he cannot save himself by his treasure.
18020021 Nothing is left for him to devour; his prosperity will not endure.
18020022 In the midst of his plenty, distress will overtake him; the full force of misery will come upon him.
18020023 When he has filled his belly, God will vent his burning anger against him and rain down his blows on him.
18020024 Though he flees from an iron weapon, a bronze-tipped arrow pierces him.
18020025 He pulls it out of his back, the gleaming point out of his liver. Terrors will come over him;
18020026 total darkness lies in wait for his treasures. A fire unfanned will consume him and devour what is left in his tent.
18020027 The heavens will expose his guilt; the earth will rise up against him.
18020028 A flood will carry off his house, rushing waters on the day of God’s wrath.
18020029 Such is the fate God allots the wicked, the heritage appointed for them by God.”
18021001 Then Job replied:
18021002 “Listen carefully to my words; let this be the consolation you give me.
18021003 Bear with me while I speak, and after I have spoken, mock on.
18021004 “Is my complaint directed to a human being? Why should I not be impatient?
18021005 Look at me and be appalled; clap your hand over your mouth.
18021006 When I think about this, I am terrified; trembling seizes my body.
18021007 Why do the wicked live on, growing old and increasing in power?
18021008 They see their children established around them, their offspring before their eyes.
18021009 Their homes are safe and free from fear; the rod of God is not on them.
18021010 Their bulls never fail to breed; their cows calve and do not miscarry.
18021011 They send forth their children as a flock; their little ones dance about.
18021012 They sing to the music of timbrel and lyre; they make merry to the sound of the pipe.
18021013 They spend their years in prosperity and go down to the grave in peace.
18021014 Yet they say to God, ‘Leave us alone! We have no desire to know your ways.
18021015 Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him? What would we gain by praying to him?’
18021016 But their prosperity is not in their own hands, so I stand aloof from the plans of the wicked.
18021017 “Yet how often is the lamp of the wicked snuffed out? How often does calamity come upon them, the fate God allots in his anger?
18021018 How often are they like straw before the wind, like chaff swept away by a gale?
18021019 It is said, ‘God stores up the punishment of the wicked for their children.’ Let him repay the wicked, so that they themselves will experience it!
18021020 Let their own eyes see their destruction; let them drink the cup of the wrath of the Almighty.
18021021 For what do they care about the families they leave behind when their allotted months come to an end?
18021022 “Can anyone teach knowledge to God, since he judges even the highest?
18021023 One person dies in full vigor, completely secure and at ease,
18021024 well nourished in body, bones rich with marrow.
18021025 Another dies in bitterness of soul, never having enjoyed anything good.
18021026 Side by side they lie in the dust, and worms cover them both.
18021027 “I know full well what you are thinking, the schemes by which you would wrong me.
18021028 You say, ‘Where now is the house of the great, the tents where the wicked lived?’
18021029 Have you never questioned those who travel? Have you paid no regard to their accounts—
18021030 that the wicked are spared from the day of calamity, that they are delivered from the day of wrath?
18021031 Who denounces their conduct to their face? Who repays them for what they have done?
18021032 They are carried to the grave, and watch is kept over their tombs.
18021033 The soil in the valley is sweet to them; everyone follows after them, and a countless throng goes before them.
18021034 “So how can you console me with your nonsense? Nothing is left of your answers but falsehood!”
18022001 Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
18022002 “Can a man be of benefit to God? Can even a wise person benefit him?
18022003 What pleasure would it give the Almighty if you were righteous? What would he gain if your ways were blameless?
18022004 “Is it for your piety that he rebukes you and brings charges against you?
18022005 Is not your wickedness great? Are not your sins endless?
18022006 You demanded security from your relatives for no reason; you stripped people of their clothing, leaving them naked.
18022007 You gave no water to the weary and you withheld food from the hungry,
18022008 though you were a powerful man, owning land— an honored man, living on it.
18022009 And you sent widows away empty-handed and broke the strength of the fatherless.
18022010 That is why snares are all around you, why sudden peril terrifies you,
18022011 why it is so dark you cannot see, and why a flood of water covers you.
18022012 “Is not God in the heights of heaven? And see how lofty are the highest stars!
18022013 Yet you say, ‘What does God know? Does he judge through such darkness?
18022014 Thick clouds veil him, so he does not see us as he goes about in the vaulted heavens.’
18022015 Will you keep to the old path that the wicked have trod?
18022016 They were carried off before their time, their foundations washed away by a flood.
18022017 They said to God, ‘Leave us alone! What can the Almighty do to us?’
18022018 Yet it was he who filled their houses with good things, so I stand aloof from the plans of the wicked.
18022019 The righteous see their ruin and rejoice; the innocent mock them, saying,
18022020 ‘Surely our foes are destroyed, and fire devours their wealth.’
18022021 “Submit to God and be at peace with him; in this way prosperity will come to you.
18022022 Accept instruction from his mouth and lay up his words in your heart.
18022023 If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored: If you remove wickedness far from your tent
18022024 and assign your nuggets to the dust, your gold of Ophir to the rocks in the ravines,
18022025 then the Almighty will be your gold, the choicest silver for you.
18022026 Surely then you will find delight in the Almighty and will lift up your face to God.
18022027 You will pray to him, and he will hear you, and you will fulfill your vows.
18022028 What you decide on will be done, and light will shine on your ways.
18022029 When people are brought low and you say, ‘Lift them up!’ then he will save the downcast.
18022030 He will deliver even one who is not innocent, who will be delivered through the cleanness of your hands.”
18023001 Then Job replied:
18023002 “Even today my complaint is bitter; his hand is heavy in spite of my groaning.
18023003 If only I knew where to find him; if only I could go to his dwelling!
18023004 I would state my case before him and fill my mouth with arguments.
18023005 I would find out what he would answer me, and consider what he would say to me.
18023006 Would he vigorously oppose me? No, he would not press charges against me.
18023007 There the upright can establish their innocence before him, and there I would be delivered forever from my judge.
18023008 “But if I go to the east, he is not there; if I go to the west, I do not find him.
18023009 When he is at work in the north, I do not see him; when he turns to the south, I catch no glimpse of him.
18023010 But he knows the way that I take; when he has tested me, I will come forth as gold.
18023011 My feet have closely followed his steps; I have kept to his way without turning aside.
18023012 I have not departed from the commands of his lips; I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread.
18023013 “But he stands alone, and who can oppose him? He does whatever he pleases.
18023014 He carries out his decree against me, and many such plans he still has in store.
18023015 That is why I am terrified before him; when I think of all this, I fear him.
18023016 God has made my heart faint; the Almighty has terrified me.
18023017 Yet I am not silenced by the darkness, by the thick darkness that covers my face.
18024001 “Why does the Almighty not set times for judgment? Why must those who know him look in vain for such days?
18024002 There are those who move boundary stones; they pasture flocks they have stolen.
18024003 They drive away the orphan’s donkey and take the widow’s ox in pledge.
18024004 They thrust the needy from the path and force all the poor of the land into hiding.
18024005 Like wild donkeys in the desert, the poor go about their labor of foraging food; the wasteland provides food for their children.
18024006 They gather fodder in the fields and glean in the vineyards of the wicked.
18024007 Lacking clothes, they spend the night naked; they have nothing to cover themselves in the cold.
18024008 They are drenched by mountain rains and hug the rocks for lack of shelter.
18024009 The fatherless child is snatched from the breast; the infant of the poor is seized for a debt.
18024010 Lacking clothes, they go about naked; they carry the sheaves, but still go hungry.
18024011 They crush olives among the terraces ; they tread the winepresses, yet suffer thirst.
18024012 The groans of the dying rise from the city, and the souls of the wounded cry out for help. But God charges no one with wrongdoing.
18024013 “There are those who rebel against the light, who do not know its ways or stay in its paths.
18024014 When daylight is gone, the murderer rises up, kills the poor and needy, and in the night steals forth like a thief.
18024015 The eye of the adulterer watches for dusk; he thinks, ‘No eye will see me,’ and he keeps his face concealed.
18024016 In the dark, thieves break into houses, but by day they shut themselves in; they want nothing to do with the light.
18024017 For all of them, midnight is their morning; they make friends with the terrors of darkness.
18024018 “Yet they are foam on the surface of the water; their portion of the land is cursed, so that no one goes to the vineyards.
18024019 As heat and drought snatch away the melted snow, so the grave snatches away those who have sinned.
18024020 The womb forgets them, the worm feasts on them; the wicked are no longer remembered but are broken like a tree.
18024021 They prey on the barren and childless woman, and to the widow they show no kindness.
18024022 But God drags away the mighty by his power; though they become established, they have no assurance of life.
18024023 He may let them rest in a feeling of security, but his eyes are on their ways.
18024024 For a little while they are exalted, and then they are gone; they are brought low and gathered up like all others; they are cut off like heads of grain.
18024025 “If this is not so, who can prove me false and reduce my words to nothing?”
18025001 Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
18025002 “Dominion and awe belong to God; he establishes order in the heights of heaven.
18025003 Can his forces be numbered? On whom does his light not rise?
18025004 How then can a mortal be righteous before God? How can one born of woman be pure?
18025005 If even the moon is not bright and the stars are not pure in his eyes,
18025006 how much less a mortal, who is but a maggot— a human being, who is only a worm!”
18026001 Then Job replied:
18026002 “How you have helped the powerless! How you have saved the arm that is feeble!
18026003 What advice you have offered to one without wisdom! And what great insight you have displayed!
18026004 Who has helped you utter these words? And whose spirit spoke from your mouth?
18026005 “The dead are in deep anguish, those beneath the waters and all that live in them.
18026006 The realm of the dead is naked before God; Destruction lies uncovered.
18026007 He spreads out the northern skies over empty space; he suspends the earth over nothing.
18026008 He wraps up the waters in his clouds, yet the clouds do not burst under their weight.
18026009 He covers the face of the full moon, spreading his clouds over it.
18026010 He marks out the horizon on the face of the waters for a boundary between light and darkness.
18026011 The pillars of the heavens quake, aghast at his rebuke.
18026012 By his power he churned up the sea; by his wisdom he cut Rahab to pieces.
18026013 By his breath the skies became fair; his hand pierced the gliding serpent.
18026014 And these are but the outer fringe of his works; how faint the whisper we hear of him! Who then can understand the thunder of his power?”
18027001 And Job continued his discourse:
18027002 “As surely as God lives, who has denied me justice, the Almighty, who has made my life bitter,
18027003 as long as I have life within me, the breath of God in my nostrils,
18027004 my lips will not say anything wicked, and my tongue will not utter lies.
18027005 I will never admit you are in the right; till I die, I will not deny my integrity.
18027006 I will maintain my innocence and never let go of it; my conscience will not reproach me as long as I live.
18027007 “May my enemy be like the wicked, my adversary like the unjust!
18027008 For what hope have the godless when they are cut off, when God takes away their life?
18027009 Does God listen to their cry when distress comes upon them?
18027010 Will they find delight in the Almighty? Will they call on God at all times?
18027011 “I will teach you about the power of God; the ways of the Almighty I will not conceal.
18027012 You have all seen this yourselves. Why then this meaningless talk?
18027013 “Here is the fate God allots to the wicked, the heritage a ruthless man receives from the Almighty:
18027014 However many his children, their fate is the sword; his offspring will never have enough to eat.
18027015 The plague will bury those who survive him, and their widows will not weep for them.
18027016 Though he heaps up silver like dust and clothes like piles of clay,
18027017 what he lays up the righteous will wear, and the innocent will divide his silver.
18027018 The house he builds is like a moth’s cocoon, like a hut made by a watchman.
18027019 He lies down wealthy, but will do so no more; when he opens his eyes, all is gone.
18027020 Terrors overtake him like a flood; a tempest snatches him away in the night.
18027021 The east wind carries him off, and he is gone; it sweeps him out of his place.
18027022 It hurls itself against him without mercy as he flees headlong from its power.
18027023 It claps its hands in derision and hisses him out of his place.”
18028001 There is a mine for silver and a place where gold is refined.
18028002 Iron is taken from the earth, and copper is smelted from ore.
18028003 Mortals put an end to the darkness; they search out the farthest recesses for ore in the blackest darkness.
18028004 Far from human dwellings they cut a shaft, in places untouched by human feet; far from other people they dangle and sway.
18028005 The earth, from which food comes, is transformed below as by fire;
18028006 lapis lazuli comes from its rocks, and its dust contains nuggets of gold.
18028007 No bird of prey knows that hidden path, no falcon’s eye has seen it.
18028008 Proud beasts do not set foot on it, and no lion prowls there.
18028009 People assault the flinty rock with their hands and lay bare the roots of the mountains.
18028010 They tunnel through the rock; their eyes see all its treasures.
18028011 They search the sources of the rivers and bring hidden things to light.
18028012 But where can wisdom be found? Where does understanding dwell?
18028013 No mortal comprehends its worth; it cannot be found in the land of the living.
18028014 The deep says, “It is not in me”; the sea says, “It is not with me.”
18028015 It cannot be bought with the finest gold, nor can its price be weighed out in silver.
18028016 It cannot be bought with the gold of Ophir, with precious onyx or lapis lazuli.
18028017 Neither gold nor crystal can compare with it, nor can it be had for jewels of gold.
18028018 Coral and jasper are not worthy of mention; the price of wisdom is beyond rubies.
18028019 The topaz of Cush cannot compare with it; it cannot be bought with pure gold.
18028020 Where then does wisdom come from? Where does understanding dwell?
18028021 It is hidden from the eyes of every living thing, concealed even from the birds in the sky.
18028022 Destruction and Death say, “Only a rumor of it has reached our ears.”
18028023 God understands the way to it and he alone knows where it dwells,
18028024 for he views the ends of the earth and sees everything under the heavens.
18028025 When he established the force of the wind and measured out the waters,
18028026 when he made a decree for the rain and a path for the thunderstorm,
18028027 then he looked at wisdom and appraised it; he confirmed it and tested it.
18028028 And he said to the human race, “The fear of the Lord—that is wisdom, and to shun evil is understanding.”
18029001 Job continued his discourse:
18029002 “How I long for the months gone by, for the days when God watched over me,
18029003 when his lamp shone on my head and by his light I walked through darkness!
18029004 Oh, for the days when I was in my prime, when God’s intimate friendship blessed my house,
18029005 when the Almighty was still with me and my children were around me,
18029006 when my path was drenched with cream and the rock poured out for me streams of olive oil.
18029007 “When I went to the gate of the city and took my seat in the public square,
18029008 the young men saw me and stepped aside and the old men rose to their feet;
18029009 the chief men refrained from speaking and covered their mouths with their hands;
18029010 the voices of the nobles were hushed, and their tongues stuck to the roof of their mouths.
18029011 Whoever heard me spoke well of me, and those who saw me commended me,
18029012 because I rescued the poor who cried for help, and the fatherless who had none to assist them.
18029013 The one who was dying blessed me; I made the widow’s heart sing.
18029014 I put on righteousness as my clothing; justice was my robe and my turban.
18029015 I was eyes to the blind and feet to the lame.
18029016 I was a father to the needy; I took up the case of the stranger.
18029017 I broke the fangs of the wicked and snatched the victims from their teeth.
18029018 “I thought, ‘I will die in my own house, my days as numerous as the grains of sand.
18029019 My roots will reach to the water, and the dew will lie all night on my branches.
18029020 My glory will not fade; the bow will be ever new in my hand.’
18029021 “People listened to me expectantly, waiting in silence for my counsel.
18029022 After I had spoken, they spoke no more; my words fell gently on their ears.
18029023 They waited for me as for showers and drank in my words as the spring rain.
18029024 When I smiled at them, they scarcely believed it; the light of my face was precious to them.
18029025 I chose the way for them and sat as their chief; I dwelt as a king among his troops; I was like one who comforts mourners.
18030001 “But now they mock me, men younger than I, whose fathers I would have disdained to put with my sheep dogs.
18030002 Of what use was the strength of their hands to me, since their vigor had gone from them?
18030003 Haggard from want and hunger, they roamed the parched land in desolate wastelands at night.
18030004 In the brush they gathered salt herbs, and their food was the root of the broom bush.
18030005 They were banished from human society, shouted at as if they were thieves.
18030006 They were forced to live in the dry stream beds, among the rocks and in holes in the ground.
18030007 They brayed among the bushes and huddled in the undergrowth.
18030008 A base and nameless brood, they were driven out of the land.
18030009 “And now those young men mock me in song; I have become a byword among them.
18030010 They detest me and keep their distance; they do not hesitate to spit in my face.
18030011 Now that God has unstrung my bow and afflicted me, they throw off restraint in my presence.
18030012 On my right the tribe attacks; they lay snares for my feet, they build their siege ramps against me.
18030013 They break up my road; they succeed in destroying me. ‘No one can help him,’ they say.
18030014 They advance as through a gaping breach; amid the ruins they come rolling in.
18030015 Terrors overwhelm me; my dignity is driven away as by the wind, my safety vanishes like a cloud.
18030016 “And now my life ebbs away; days of suffering grip me.
18030017 Night pierces my bones; my gnawing pains never rest.
18030018 In his great power God becomes like clothing to me ; he binds me like the neck of my garment.
18030019 He throws me into the mud, and I am reduced to dust and ashes.
18030020 “I cry out to you, God, but you do not answer; I stand up, but you merely look at me.
18030021 You turn on me ruthlessly; with the might of your hand you attack me.
18030022 You snatch me up and drive me before the wind; you toss me about in the storm.
18030023 I know you will bring me down to death, to the place appointed for all the living.
18030024 “Surely no one lays a hand on a broken man when he cries for help in his distress.
18030025 Have I not wept for those in trouble? Has not my soul grieved for the poor?
18030026 Yet when I hoped for good, evil came; when I looked for light, then came darkness.
18030027 The churning inside me never stops; days of suffering confront me.
18030028 I go about blackened, but not by the sun; I stand up in the assembly and cry for help.
18030029 I have become a brother of jackals, a companion of owls.
18030030 My skin grows black and peels; my body burns with fever.
18030031 My lyre is tuned to mourning, and my pipe to the sound of wailing.
18031001 “I made a covenant with my eyes not to look lustfully at a young woman.
18031002 For what is our lot from God above, our heritage from the Almighty on high?
18031003 Is it not ruin for the wicked, disaster for those who do wrong?
18031004 Does he not see my ways and count my every step?
18031005 “If I have walked with falsehood or my foot has hurried after deceit—
18031006 let God weigh me in honest scales and he will know that I am blameless—
18031007 if my steps have turned from the path, if my heart has been led by my eyes, or if my hands have been defiled,
18031008 then may others eat what I have sown, and may my crops be uprooted.
18031009 “If my heart has been enticed by a woman, or if I have lurked at my neighbor’s door,
18031010 then may my wife grind another man’s grain, and may other men sleep with her.
18031011 For that would have been wicked, a sin to be judged.
18031012 It is a fire that burns to Destruction ; it would have uprooted my harvest.
18031013 “If I have denied justice to any of my servants, whether male or female, when they had a grievance against me,
18031014 what will I do when God confronts me? What will I answer when called to account?
18031015 Did not he who made me in the womb make them? Did not the same one form us both within our mothers?
18031016 “If I have denied the desires of the poor or let the eyes of the widow grow weary,
18031017 if I have kept my bread to myself, not sharing it with the fatherless—
18031018 but from my youth I reared them as a father would, and from my birth I guided the widow—
18031019 if I have seen anyone perishing for lack of clothing, or the needy without garments,
18031020 and their hearts did not bless me for warming them with the fleece from my sheep,
18031021 if I have raised my hand against the fatherless, knowing that I had influence in court,
18031022 then let my arm fall from the shoulder, let it be broken off at the joint.
18031023 For I dreaded destruction from God, and for fear of his splendor I could not do such things.
18031024 “If I have put my trust in gold or said to pure gold, ‘You are my security,’
18031025 if I have rejoiced over my great wealth, the fortune my hands had gained,
18031026 if I have regarded the sun in its radiance or the moon moving in splendor,
18031027 so that my heart was secretly enticed and my hand offered them a kiss of homage,
18031028 then these also would be sins to be judged, for I would have been unfaithful to God on high.
18031029 “If I have rejoiced at my enemy’s misfortune or gloated over the trouble that came to him—
18031030 I have not allowed my mouth to sin by invoking a curse against their life—
18031031 if those of my household have never said, ‘Who has not been filled with Job’s meat?’—
18031032 but no stranger had to spend the night in the street, for my door was always open to the traveler—
18031033 if I have concealed my sin as people do, by hiding my guilt in my heart
18031034 because I so feared the crowd and so dreaded the contempt of the clans that I kept silent and would not go outside—
18031035 (“Oh, that I had someone to hear me! I sign now my defense—let the Almighty answer me; let my accuser put his indictment in writing.
18031036 Surely I would wear it on my shoulder, I would put it on like a crown.
18031037 I would give him an account of my every step; I would present it to him as to a ruler.)—
18031038 “if my land cries out against me and all its furrows are wet with tears,
18031039 if I have devoured its yield without payment or broken the spirit of its tenants,
18031040 then let briers come up instead of wheat and stinkweed instead of barley.” The words of Job are ended.
18032001 So these three men stopped answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
18032002 But Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job for justifying himself rather than God.
18032003 He was also angry with the three friends, because they had found no way to refute Job, and yet had condemned him.
18032004 Now Elihu had waited before speaking to Job because they were older than he.
18032005 But when he saw that the three men had nothing more to say, his anger was aroused.
18032006 So Elihu son of Barakel the Buzite said: “I am young in years, and you are old; that is why I was fearful, not daring to tell you what I know.
18032007 I thought, ‘Age should speak; advanced years should teach wisdom.’
18032008 But it is the spirit in a person, the breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.
18032009 It is not only the old who are wise, not only the aged who understand what is right.
18032010 “Therefore I say: Listen to me; I too will tell you what I know.
18032011 I waited while you spoke, I listened to your reasoning; while you were searching for words,
18032012 I gave you my full attention. But not one of you has proved Job wrong; none of you has answered his arguments.
18032013 Do not say, ‘We have found wisdom; let God, not a man, refute him.’
18032014 But Job has not marshaled his words against me, and I will not answer him with your arguments.
18032015 “They are dismayed and have no more to say; words have failed them.
18032016 Must I wait, now that they are silent, now that they stand there with no reply?
18032017 I too will have my say; I too will tell what I know.
18032018 For I am full of words, and the spirit within me compels me;
18032019 inside I am like bottled-up wine, like new wineskins ready to burst.
18032020 I must speak and find relief; I must open my lips and reply.
18032021 I will show no partiality, nor will I flatter anyone;
18032022 for if I were skilled in flattery, my Maker would soon take me away.
18033001 “But now, Job, listen to my words; pay attention to everything I say.
18033002 I am about to open my mouth; my words are on the tip of my tongue.
18033003 My words come from an upright heart; my lips sincerely speak what I know.
18033004 The Spirit of God has made me; the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
18033005 Answer me then, if you can; stand up and argue your case before me.
18033006 I am the same as you in God’s sight; I too am a piece of clay.
18033007 No fear of me should alarm you, nor should my hand be heavy on you.
18033008 “But you have said in my hearing— I heard the very words—
18033009 ‘I am pure, I have done no wrong; I am clean and free from sin.
18033010 Yet God has found fault with me; he considers me his enemy.
18033011 He fastens my feet in shackles; he keeps close watch on all my paths.’
18033012 “But I tell you, in this you are not right, for God is greater than any mortal.
18033013 Why do you complain to him that he responds to no one’s words ?
18033014 For God does speak—now one way, now another— though no one perceives it.
18033015 In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falls on people as they slumber in their beds,
18033016 he may speak in their ears and terrify them with warnings,
18033017 to turn them from wrongdoing and keep them from pride,
18033018 to preserve them from the pit, their lives from perishing by the sword.
18033019 “Or someone may be chastened on a bed of pain with constant distress in their bones,
18033020 so that their body finds food repulsive and their soul loathes the choicest meal.
18033021 Their flesh wastes away to nothing, and their bones, once hidden, now stick out.
18033022 They draw near to the pit, and their life to the messengers of death.
18033023 Yet if there is an angel at their side, a messenger, one out of a thousand, sent to tell them how to be upright,
18033024 and he is gracious to that person and says to God, ‘Spare them from going down to the pit; I have found a ransom for them—
18033025 let their flesh be renewed like a child’s; let them be restored as in the days of their youth’—
18033026 then that person can pray to God and find favor with him, they will see God’s face and shout for joy; he will restore them to full well-being.
18033027 And they will go to others and say, ‘I have sinned, I have perverted what is right, but I did not get what I deserved.
18033028 God has delivered me from going down to the pit, and I shall live to enjoy the light of life.’
18033029 “God does all these things to a person— twice, even three times—
18033030 to turn them back from the pit, that the light of life may shine on them.
18033031 “Pay attention, Job, and listen to me; be silent, and I will speak.
18033032 If you have anything to say, answer me; speak up, for I want to vindicate you.
18033033 But if not, then listen to me; be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.”
18034001 Then Elihu said:
18034002 “Hear my words, you wise men; listen to me, you men of learning.
18034003 For the ear tests words as the tongue tastes food.
18034004 Let us discern for ourselves what is right; let us learn together what is good.
18034005 “Job says, ‘I am innocent, but God denies me justice.
18034006 Although I am right, I am considered a liar; although I am guiltless, his arrow inflicts an incurable wound.’
18034007 Is there anyone like Job, who drinks scorn like water?
18034008 He keeps company with evildoers; he associates with the wicked.
18034009 For he says, ‘There is no profit in trying to please God.’
18034010 “So listen to me, you men of understanding. Far be it from God to do evil, from the Almighty to do wrong.
18034011 He repays everyone for what they have done; he brings on them what their conduct deserves.
18034012 It is unthinkable that God would do wrong, that the Almighty would pervert justice.
18034013 Who appointed him over the earth? Who put him in charge of the whole world?
18034014 If it were his intention and he withdrew his spirit and breath,
18034015 all humanity would perish together and mankind would return to the dust.
18034016 “If you have understanding, hear this; listen to what I say.
18034017 Can someone who hates justice govern? Will you condemn the just and mighty One?
18034018 Is he not the One who says to kings, ‘You are worthless,’ and to nobles, ‘You are wicked,’
18034019 who shows no partiality to princes and does not favor the rich over the poor, for they are all the work of his hands?
18034020 They die in an instant, in the middle of the night; the people are shaken and they pass away; the mighty are removed without human hand.
18034021 “His eyes are on the ways of mortals; he sees their every step.
18034022 There is no deep shadow, no utter darkness, where evildoers can hide.
18034023 God has no need to examine people further, that they should come before him for judgment.
18034024 Without inquiry he shatters the mighty and sets up others in their place.
18034025 Because he takes note of their deeds, he overthrows them in the night and they are crushed.
18034026 He punishes them for their wickedness where everyone can see them,
18034027 because they turned from following him and had no regard for any of his ways.
18034028 They caused the cry of the poor to come before him, so that he heard the cry of the needy.
18034029 But if he remains silent, who can condemn him? If he hides his face, who can see him? Yet he is over individual and nation alike,
18034030 to keep the godless from ruling, from laying snares for the people.
18034031 “Suppose someone says to God, ‘I am guilty but will offend no more.
18034032 Teach me what I cannot see; if I have done wrong, I will not do so again.’
18034033 Should God then reward you on your terms, when you refuse to repent? You must decide, not I; so tell me what you know.
18034034 “Men of understanding declare, wise men who hear me say to me,
18034035 ‘Job speaks without knowledge; his words lack insight.’
18034036 Oh, that Job might be tested to the utmost for answering like a wicked man!
18034037 To his sin he adds rebellion; scornfully he claps his hands among us and multiplies his words against God.”
18035001 Then Elihu said:
18035002 “Do you think this is just? You say, ‘I am in the right, not God.’
18035003 Yet you ask him, ‘What profit is it to me, and what do I gain by not sinning?’
18035004 “I would like to reply to you and to your friends with you.
18035005 Look up at the heavens and see; gaze at the clouds so high above you.
18035006 If you sin, how does that affect him? If your sins are many, what does that do to him?
18035007 If you are righteous, what do you give to him, or what does he receive from your hand?
18035008 Your wickedness only affects humans like yourself, and your righteousness only other people.
18035009 “People cry out under a load of oppression; they plead for relief from the arm of the powerful.
18035010 But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker, who gives songs in the night,
18035011 who teaches us more than he teaches the beasts of the earth and makes us wiser than the birds in the sky?’
18035012 He does not answer when people cry out because of the arrogance of the wicked.
18035013 Indeed, God does not listen to their empty plea; the Almighty pays no attention to it.
18035014 How much less, then, will he listen when you say that you do not see him, that your case is before him and you must wait for him,
18035015 and further, that his anger never punishes and he does not take the least notice of wickedness.
18035016 So Job opens his mouth with empty talk; without knowledge he multiplies words.”
18036001 Elihu continued:
18036002 “Bear with me a little longer and I will show you that there is more to be said in God’s behalf.
18036003 I get my knowledge from afar; I will ascribe justice to my Maker.
18036004 Be assured that my words are not false; one who has perfect knowledge is with you.
18036005 “God is mighty, but despises no one; he is mighty, and firm in his purpose.
18036006 He does not keep the wicked alive but gives the afflicted their rights.
18036007 He does not take his eyes off the righteous; he enthrones them with kings and exalts them forever.
18036008 But if people are bound in chains, held fast by cords of affliction,
18036009 he tells them what they have done— that they have sinned arrogantly.
18036010 He makes them listen to correction and commands them to repent of their evil.
18036011 If they obey and serve him, they will spend the rest of their days in prosperity and their years in contentment.
18036012 But if they do not listen, they will perish by the sword and die without knowledge.
18036013 “The godless in heart harbor resentment; even when he fetters them, they do not cry for help.
18036014 They die in their youth, among male prostitutes of the shrines.
18036015 But those who suffer he delivers in their suffering; he speaks to them in their affliction.
18036016 “He is wooing you from the jaws of distress to a spacious place free from restriction, to the comfort of your table laden with choice food.
18036017 But now you are laden with the judgment due the wicked; judgment and justice have taken hold of you.
18036018 Be careful that no one entices you by riches; do not let a large bribe turn you aside.
18036019 Would your wealth or even all your mighty efforts sustain you so you would not be in distress?
18036020 Do not long for the night, to drag people away from their homes.
18036021 Beware of turning to evil, which you seem to prefer to affliction.
18036022 “God is exalted in his power. Who is a teacher like him?
18036023 Who has prescribed his ways for him, or said to him, ‘You have done wrong’?
18036024 Remember to extol his work, which people have praised in song.
18036025 All humanity has seen it; mortals gaze on it from afar.
18036026 How great is God—beyond our understanding! The number of his years is past finding out.
18036027 “He draws up the drops of water, which distill as rain to the streams ;
18036028 the clouds pour down their moisture and abundant showers fall on mankind.
18036029 Who can understand how he spreads out the clouds, how he thunders from his pavilion?
18036030 See how he scatters his lightning about him, bathing the depths of the sea.
18036031 This is the way he governs the nations and provides food in abundance.
18036032 He fills his hands with lightning and commands it to strike its mark.
18036033 His thunder announces the coming storm; even the cattle make known its approach.
18037001 “At this my heart pounds and leaps from its place.
18037002 Listen! Listen to the roar of his voice, to the rumbling that comes from his mouth.
18037003 He unleashes his lightning beneath the whole heaven and sends it to the ends of the earth.
18037004 After that comes the sound of his roar; he thunders with his majestic voice. When his voice resounds, he holds nothing back.
18037005 God’s voice thunders in marvelous ways; he does great things beyond our understanding.
18037006 He says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth,’ and to the rain shower, ‘Be a mighty downpour.’
18037007 So that everyone he has made may know his work, he stops all people from their labor.
18037008 The animals take cover; they remain in their dens.
18037009 The tempest comes out from its chamber, the cold from the driving winds.
18037010 The breath of God produces ice, and the broad waters become frozen.
18037011 He loads the clouds with moisture; he scatters his lightning through them.
18037012 At his direction they swirl around over the face of the whole earth to do whatever he commands them.
18037013 He brings the clouds to punish people, or to water his earth and show his love.
18037014 “Listen to this, Job; stop and consider God’s wonders.
18037015 Do you know how God controls the clouds and makes his lightning flash?
18037016 Do you know how the clouds hang poised, those wonders of him who has perfect knowledge?
18037017 You who swelter in your clothes when the land lies hushed under the south wind,
18037018 can you join him in spreading out the skies, hard as a mirror of cast bronze?
18037019 “Tell us what we should say to him; we cannot draw up our case because of our darkness.
18037020 Should he be told that I want to speak? Would anyone ask to be swallowed up?
18037021 Now no one can look at the sun, bright as it is in the skies after the wind has swept them clean.
18037022 Out of the north he comes in golden splendor; God comes in awesome majesty.
18037023 The Almighty is beyond our reach and exalted in power; in his justice and great righteousness, he does not oppress.
18037024 Therefore, people revere him, for does he not have regard for all the wise in heart? ”
18038001 Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm. He said:
18038002 “Who is this that obscures my plans with words without knowledge?
18038003 Brace yourself like a man; I will question you, and you shall answer me.
18038004 “Where were you when I laid the earth’s foundation? Tell me, if you understand.
18038005 Who marked off its dimensions? Surely you know! Who stretched a measuring line across it?
18038006 On what were its footings set, or who laid its cornerstone—
18038007 while the morning stars sang together and all the angels shouted for joy?
18038008 “Who shut up the sea behind doors when it burst forth from the womb,
18038009 when I made the clouds its garment and wrapped it in thick darkness,
18038010 when I fixed limits for it and set its doors and bars in place,
18038011 when I said, ‘This far you may come and no farther; here is where your proud waves halt’?
18038012 “Have you ever given orders to the morning, or shown the dawn its place,
18038013 that it might take the earth by the edges and shake the wicked out of it?
18038014 The earth takes shape like clay under a seal; its features stand out like those of a garment.
18038015 The wicked are denied their light, and their upraised arm is broken.
18038016 “Have you journeyed to the springs of the sea or walked in the recesses of the deep?
18038017 Have the gates of death been shown to you? Have you seen the gates of the deepest darkness?
18038018 Have you comprehended the vast expanses of the earth? Tell me, if you know all this.
18038019 “What is the way to the abode of light? And where does darkness reside?
18038020 Can you take them to their places? Do you know the paths to their dwellings?
18038021 Surely you know, for you were already born! You have lived so many years!
18038022 “Have you entered the storehouses of the snow or seen the storehouses of the hail,
18038023 which I reserve for times of trouble, for days of war and battle?
18038024 What is the way to the place where the lightning is dispersed, or the place where the east winds are scattered over the earth?
18038025 Who cuts a channel for the torrents of rain, and a path for the thunderstorm,
18038026 to water a land where no one lives, an uninhabited desert,
18038027 to satisfy a desolate wasteland and make it sprout with grass?
18038028 Does the rain have a father? Who fathers the drops of dew?
18038029 From whose womb comes the ice? Who gives birth to the frost from the heavens
18038030 when the waters become hard as stone, when the surface of the deep is frozen?
18038031 “Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades? Can you loosen Orion’s belt?
18038032 Can you bring forth the constellations in their seasons or lead out the Bear with its cubs?
18038033 Do you know the laws of the heavens? Can you set up God’s dominion over the earth?
18038034 “Can you raise your voice to the clouds and cover yourself with a flood of water?
18038035 Do you send the lightning bolts on their way? Do they report to you, ‘Here we are’?
18038036 Who gives the ibis wisdom or gives the rooster understanding?
18038037 Who has the wisdom to count the clouds? Who can tip over the water jars of the heavens
18038038 when the dust becomes hard and the clods of earth stick together?
18038039 “Do you hunt the prey for the lioness and satisfy the hunger of the lions
18038040 when they crouch in their dens or lie in wait in a thicket?
18038041 Who provides food for the raven when its young cry out to God and wander about for lack of food?
18039001 “Do you know when the mountain goats give birth? Do you watch when the doe bears her fawn?
18039002 Do you count the months till they bear? Do you know the time they give birth?
18039003 They crouch down and bring forth their young; their labor pains are ended.
18039004 Their young thrive and grow strong in the wilds; they leave and do not return.
18039005 “Who let the wild donkey go free? Who untied its ropes?
18039006 I gave it the wasteland as its home, the salt flats as its habitat.
18039007 It laughs at the commotion in the town; it does not hear a driver’s shout.
18039008 It ranges the hills for its pasture and searches for any green thing.
18039009 “Will the wild ox consent to serve you? Will it stay by your manger at night?
18039010 Can you hold it to the furrow with a harness? Will it till the valleys behind you?
18039011 Will you rely on it for its great strength? Will you leave your heavy work to it?
18039012 Can you trust it to haul in your grain and bring it to your threshing floor?
18039013 “The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully, though they cannot compare with the wings and feathers of the stork.
18039014 She lays her eggs on the ground and lets them warm in the sand,
18039015 unmindful that a foot may crush them, that some wild animal may trample them.
18039016 She treats her young harshly, as if they were not hers; she cares not that her labor was in vain,
18039017 for God did not endow her with wisdom or give her a share of good sense.
18039018 Yet when she spreads her feathers to run, she laughs at horse and rider.
18039019 “Do you give the horse its strength or clothe its neck with a flowing mane?
18039020 Do you make it leap like a locust, striking terror with its proud snorting?
18039021 It paws fiercely, rejoicing in its strength, and charges into the fray.
18039022 It laughs at fear, afraid of nothing; it does not shy away from the sword.
18039023 The quiver rattles against its side, along with the flashing spear and lance.
18039024 In frenzied excitement it eats up the ground; it cannot stand still when the trumpet sounds.
18039025 At the blast of the trumpet it snorts, ‘Aha!’ It catches the scent of battle from afar, the shout of commanders and the battle cry.
18039026 “Does the hawk take flight by your wisdom and spread its wings toward the south?
18039027 Does the eagle soar at your command and build its nest on high?
18039028 It dwells on a cliff and stays there at night; a rocky crag is its stronghold.
18039029 From there it looks for food; its eyes detect it from afar.
18039030 Its young ones feast on blood, and where the slain are, there it is.”
18040001 The Lord said to Job:
18040002 “Will the one who contends with the Almighty correct him? Let him who accuses God answer him!”
18040003 Then Job answered the Lord:
18040004 “I am unworthy—how can I reply to you? I put my hand over my mouth.
18040005 I spoke once, but I have no answer— twice, but I will say no more.”
18040006 Then the Lord spoke to Job out of the storm:
18040007 “Brace yourself like a man; I will question you, and you shall answer me.
18040008 “Would you discredit my justice? Would you condemn me to justify yourself?
18040009 Do you have an arm like God’s, and can your voice thunder like his?
18040010 Then adorn yourself with glory and splendor, and clothe yourself in honor and majesty.
18040011 Unleash the fury of your wrath, look at all who are proud and bring them low,
18040012 look at all who are proud and humble them, crush the wicked where they stand.
18040013 Bury them all in the dust together; shroud their faces in the grave.
18040014 Then I myself will admit to you that your own right hand can save you.
18040015 “Look at Behemoth, which I made along with you and which feeds on grass like an ox.
18040016 What strength it has in its loins, what power in the muscles of its belly!
18040017 Its tail sways like a cedar; the sinews of its thighs are close-knit.
18040018 Its bones are tubes of bronze, its limbs like rods of iron.
18040019 It ranks first among the works of God, yet its Maker can approach it with his sword.
18040020 The hills bring it their produce, and all the wild animals play nearby.
18040021 Under the lotus plants it lies, hidden among the reeds in the marsh.
18040022 The lotuses conceal it in their shadow; the poplars by the stream surround it.
18040023 A raging river does not alarm it; it is secure, though the Jordan should surge against its mouth.
18040024 Can anyone capture it by the eyes, or trap it and pierce its nose?
18041001 “Can you pull in Leviathan with a fishhook or tie down its tongue with a rope?
18041002 Can you put a cord through its nose or pierce its jaw with a hook?
18041003 Will it keep begging you for mercy? Will it speak to you with gentle words?
18041004 Will it make an agreement with you for you to take it as your slave for life?
18041005 Can you make a pet of it like a bird or put it on a leash for the young women in your house?
18041006 Will traders barter for it? Will they divide it up among the merchants?
18041007 Can you fill its hide with harpoons or its head with fishing spears?
18041008 If you lay a hand on it, you will remember the struggle and never do it again!
18041009 Any hope of subduing it is false; the mere sight of it is overpowering.
18041010 No one is fierce enough to rouse it. Who then is able to stand against me?
18041011 Who has a claim against me that I must pay? Everything under heaven belongs to me.
18041012 “I will not fail to speak of Leviathan’s limbs, its strength and its graceful form.
18041013 Who can strip off its outer coat? Who can penetrate its double coat of armor ?
18041014 Who dares open the doors of its mouth, ringed about with fearsome teeth?
18041015 Its back has rows of shields tightly sealed together;
18041016 each is so close to the next that no air can pass between.
18041017 They are joined fast to one another; they cling together and cannot be parted.
18041018 Its snorting throws out flashes of light; its eyes are like the rays of dawn.
18041019 Flames stream from its mouth; sparks of fire shoot out.
18041020 Smoke pours from its nostrils as from a boiling pot over burning reeds.
18041021 Its breath sets coals ablaze, and flames dart from its mouth.
18041022 Strength resides in its neck; dismay goes before it.
18041023 The folds of its flesh are tightly joined; they are firm and immovable.
18041024 Its chest is hard as rock, hard as a lower millstone.
18041025 When it rises up, the mighty are terrified; they retreat before its thrashing.
18041026 The sword that reaches it has no effect, nor does the spear or the dart or the javelin.
18041027 Iron it treats like straw and bronze like rotten wood.
18041028 Arrows do not make it flee; slingstones are like chaff to it.
18041029 A club seems to it but a piece of straw; it laughs at the rattling of the lance.
18041030 Its undersides are jagged potsherds, leaving a trail in the mud like a threshing sledge.
18041031 It makes the depths churn like a boiling caldron and stirs up the sea like a pot of ointment.
18041032 It leaves a glistening wake behind it; one would think the deep had white hair.
18041033 Nothing on earth is its equal— a creature without fear.
18041034 It looks down on all that are haughty; it is king over all that are proud.”
18042001 Then Job replied to the Lord:
18042002 “I know that you can do all things; no purpose of yours can be thwarted.
18042003 You asked, ‘Who is this that obscures my plans without knowledge?’ Surely I spoke of things I did not understand, things too wonderful for me to know.
18042004 “You said, ‘Listen now, and I will speak; I will question you, and you shall answer me.’
18042005 My ears had heard of you but now my eyes have seen you.
18042006 Therefore I despise myself and repent in dust and ashes.”
18042007 After the Lord had said these things to Job, he said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “I am angry with you and your two friends, because you have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.
18042008 So now take seven bulls and seven rams and go to my servant Job and sacrifice a burnt offering for yourselves. My servant Job will pray for you, and I will accept his prayer and not deal with you according to your folly. You have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.”
18042009 So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite did what the Lord told them; and the Lord accepted Job’s prayer.
18042010 After Job had prayed for his friends, the Lord restored his fortunes and gave him twice as much as he had before.
18042011 All his brothers and sisters and everyone who had known him before came and ate with him in his house. They comforted and consoled him over all the trouble the Lord had brought on him, and each one gave him a piece of silver and a gold ring.
18042012 The Lord blessed the latter part of Job’s life more than the former part. He had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, a thousand yoke of oxen and a thousand donkeys.
18042013 And he also had seven sons and three daughters.
18042014 The first daughter he named Jemimah, the second Keziah and the third Keren-Happuch.
18042015 Nowhere in all the land were there found women as beautiful as Job’s daughters, and their father granted them an inheritance along with their brothers.
18042016 After this, Job lived a hundred and forty years; he saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.
18042017 And so Job died, an old man and full of years.
19001001 Blessed is the one who does not walk in step with the wicked or stand in the way that sinners take or sit in the company of mockers,
19001002 but whose delight is in the law of the Lord, and who meditates on his law day and night.
19001003 That person is like a tree planted by streams of water, which yields its fruit in season and whose leaf does not wither— whatever they do prospers.
19001004 Not so the wicked! They are like chaff that the wind blows away.
19001005 Therefore the wicked will not stand in the judgment, nor sinners in the assembly of the righteous.
19001006 For the Lord watches over the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked leads to destruction.
19002001 Why do the nations conspire and the peoples plot in vain?
19002002 The kings of the earth rise up and the rulers band together against the Lord and against his anointed, saying,
19002003 “Let us break their chains and throw off their shackles.”
19002004 The One enthroned in heaven laughs; the Lord scoffs at them.
19002005 He rebukes them in his anger and terrifies them in his wrath, saying,
19002006 “I have installed my king on Zion, my holy mountain.”
19002007 I will proclaim the Lord’s decree: He said to me, “You are my son; today I have become your father.
19002008 Ask me, and I will make the nations your inheritance, the ends of the earth your possession.
19002009 You will break them with a rod of iron ; you will dash them to pieces like pottery.”
19002010 Therefore, you kings, be wise; be warned, you rulers of the earth.
19002011 Serve the Lord with fear and celebrate his rule with trembling.
19002012 Kiss his son, or he will be angry and your way will lead to your destruction, for his wrath can flare up in a moment. Blessed are all who take refuge in him.

19017000 A prayer of David.

19019010 They are more precious than gold, than much pure gold; they are sweeter than honey, than honey from the honeycomb.

19022001 My God, my God, why have you forsaken me? Why are you so far from saving me, so far from my cries of anguish?

19022028 for dominion belongs to the Lord and he rules over the nations.

19038002 Your arrows have pierced me, and your hand has come down on me.
19038003 Because of your wrath there is no health in my body; there is no soundness in my bones because of my sin.
19038004 My guilt has overwhelmed me like a burden too heavy to bear.
19038005 My wounds fester and are loathsome because of my sinful folly.
19038006 I am bowed down and brought very low; all day long I go about mourning.
19038007 My back is filled with searing pain; there is no health in my body.
19038008 I am feeble and utterly crushed; I groan in anguish of heart.
19038009 All my longings lie open before you, Lord; my sighing is not hidden from you.
19038010 My heart pounds, my strength fails me; even the light has gone from my eyes.
19038011 My friends and companions avoid me because of my wounds; my neighbors stay far away.
19038012 Those who want to kill me set their traps, those who would harm me talk of my ruin; all day long they scheme and lie.
19038013 I am like the deaf, who cannot hear, like the mute, who cannot speak;
19038014 I have become like one who does not hear, whose mouth can offer no reply.
19038015 Lord, I wait for you; you will answer, Lord my God.
19038016 For I said, “Do not let them gloat or exalt themselves over me when my feet slip.”
19038017 For I am about to fall, and my pain is ever with me.
19038018 I confess my iniquity; I am troubled by my sin.
19038019 Many have become my enemies without cause ; those who hate me without reason are numerous.
19038020 Those who repay my good with evil lodge accusations against me, though I seek only to do what is good.
19038021 Lord, do not forsake me; do not be far from me, my God.
19038022 Come quickly to help me, my Lord and my Savior.
19039000 For the director of music. For Jeduthun. A psalm of David.
19039001 I said, “I will watch my ways and keep my tongue from sin; I will put a muzzle on my mouth while in the presence of the wicked.”
19039002 So I remained utterly silent, not even saying anything good. But my anguish increased;
19039003 my heart grew hot within me. While I meditated, the fire burned; then I spoke with my tongue:
19039004 “Show me, Lord, my life’s end and the number of my days; let me know how fleeting my life is.
19039005 You have made my days a mere handbreadth; the span of my years is as nothing before you. Everyone is but a breath, even those who seem secure.
19039006 “Surely everyone goes around like a mere phantom; in vain they rush about, heaping up wealth without knowing whose it will finally be.
19039007 “But now, Lord, what do I look for? My hope is in you.
19039008 Save me from all my transgressions; do not make me the scorn of fools.
19039009 I was silent; I would not open my mouth, for you are the one who has done this.
19039010 Remove your scourge from me; I am overcome by the blow of your hand.
19039011 When you rebuke and discipline anyone for their sin, you consume their wealth like a moth— surely everyone is but a breath.
19039012 “Hear my prayer, Lord, listen to my cry for help; do not be deaf to my weeping. I dwell with you as a foreigner, a stranger, as all my ancestors were.
19039013 Look away from me, that I may enjoy life again before I depart and am no more.”

19040002 He lifted me out of the slimy pit, out of the mud and mire; he set my feet on a rock and gave me a firm place to stand.
19040003 He put a new song in my mouth, a hymn of praise to our God. Many will see and fear the Lord and put their trust in him.
19040004 Blessed is the one who trusts in the Lord, who does not look to the proud, to those who turn aside to false gods.
19040005 Many, Lord my God, are the wonders you have done, the things you planned for us. None can compare with you; were I to speak and tell of your deeds, they would be too many to declare.
19040006 Sacrifice and offering you did not desire— but my ears you have opened — burnt offerings and sin offerings you did not require.

19040009 I proclaim your saving acts in the great assembly; I do not seal my lips, Lord, as you know.
19040010 I do not hide your righteousness in my heart; I speak of your faithfulness and your saving help. I do not conceal your love and your faithfulness from the great assembly.
19040011 Do not withhold your mercy from me, Lord; may your love and faithfulness always protect me.
19040012 For troubles without number surround me; my sins have overtaken me, and I cannot see. They are more than the hairs of my head, and my heart fails within me.
19040013 Be pleased to save me, Lord; come quickly, Lord, to help me.
19040014 May all who want to take my life be put to shame and confusion; may all who desire my ruin be turned back in disgrace.
19040015 May those who say to me, “Aha! Aha!” be appalled at their own shame.
19040016 But may all who seek you rejoice and be glad in you; may those who long for your saving help always say, “The Lord is great!”
19040017 But as for me, I am poor and needy; may the Lord think of me. You are my help and my deliverer; you are my God, do not delay.

19044000 For the director of music. Of the Sons of Korah. A maskil.
19044001 We have heard it with our ears, O God; our ancestors have told us what you did in their days, in days long ago.
19044002 With your hand you drove out the nations and planted our ancestors; you crushed the peoples and made our ancestors flourish.
19044003 It was not by their sword that they won the land, nor did their arm bring them victory; it was your right hand, your arm, and the light of your face, for you loved them.
19044004 You are my King and my God, who decrees victories for Jacob.
19044005 Through you we push back our enemies; through your name we trample our foes.
19044006 I put no trust in my bow, my sword does not bring me victory;
19044007 but you give us victory over our enemies, you put our adversaries to shame.
19044008 In God we make our boast all day long, and we will praise your name forever.
19044009 But now you have rejected and humbled us; you no longer go out with our armies.
19044010 You made us retreat before the enemy, and our adversaries have plundered us.
19044011 You gave us up to be devoured like sheep and have scattered us among the nations.
19044012 You sold your people for a pittance, gaining nothing from their sale.
19044013 You have made us a reproach to our neighbors, the scorn and derision of those around us.
19044014 You have made us a byword among the nations; the peoples shake their heads at us.
19044015 I live in disgrace all day long, and my face is covered with shame
19044016 at the taunts of those who reproach and revile me, because of the enemy, who is bent on revenge.
19044017 All this came upon us, though we had not forgotten you; we had not been false to your covenant.
19044018 Our hearts had not turned back; our feet had not strayed from your path.
19044019 But you crushed us and made us a haunt for jackals; you covered us over with deep darkness.
19044020 If we had forgotten the name of our God or spread out our hands to a foreign god,
19044021 would not God have discovered it, since he knows the secrets of the heart?
19044022 Yet for your sake we face death all day long; we are considered as sheep to be slaughtered.
19044023 Awake, Lord! Why do you sleep? Rouse yourself! Do not reject us forever.
19044024 Why do you hide your face and forget our misery and oppression?
19044025 We are brought down to the dust; our bodies cling to the ground.
19044026 Rise up and help us; rescue us because of your unfailing love.
