19120000 A song of ascents.
19120001 I call on the Lord in my distress, and he answers me.
19120002 Save me, Lord, from lying lips and from deceitful tongues.
19120003 What will he do to you, and what more besides, you deceitful tongue?
19120004 He will punish you with a warrior’s sharp arrows, with burning coals of the broom bush.
19120005 Woe to me that I dwell in Meshek, that I live among the tents of Kedar!
19120006 Too long have I lived among those who hate peace.
19120007 I am for peace; but when I speak, they are for war.
19121000 A song of ascents.
19121001 I lift up my eyes to the mountains— where does my help come from?
19121002 My help comes from the Lord, the Maker of heaven and earth.
19121003 He will not let your foot slip— he who watches over you will not slumber;
19121004 indeed, he who watches over Israel will neither slumber nor sleep.
19121005 The Lord watches over you— the Lord is your shade at your right hand;
19121006 the sun will not harm you by day, nor the moon by night.
19121007 The Lord will keep you from all harm— he will watch over your life;
19121008 the Lord will watch over your coming and going both now and forevermore.
19122000 A song of ascents. Of David.
19122001 I rejoiced with those who said to me, “Let us go to the house of the Lord.”
19122002 Our feet are standing in your gates, Jerusalem.
19122003 Jerusalem is built like a city that is closely compacted together.
19122004 That is where the tribes go up— the tribes of the Lord— to praise the name of the Lord according to the statute given to Israel.
19122005 There stand the thrones for judgment, the thrones of the house of David.
19122006 Pray for the peace of Jerusalem: “May those who love you be secure.
19122007 May there be peace within your walls and security within your citadels.”
19122008 For the sake of my family and friends, I will say, “Peace be within you.”
19122009 For the sake of the house of the Lord our God, I will seek your prosperity.
19123000 A song of ascents.
19123001 I lift up my eyes to you, to you who sit enthroned in heaven.
19123002 As the eyes of slaves look to the hand of their master, as the eyes of a female slave look to the hand of her mistress, so our eyes look to the Lord our God, till he shows us his mercy.
19123003 Have mercy on us, Lord, have mercy on us, for we have endured no end of contempt.
19123004 We have endured no end of ridicule from the arrogant, of contempt from the proud.
19124000 A song of ascents. Of David.
19124001 If the Lord had not been on our side— let Israel say—
19124002 if the Lord had not been on our side when people attacked us,
19124003 they would have swallowed us alive when their anger flared against us;
19124004 the flood would have engulfed us, the torrent would have swept over us,
19124005 the raging waters would have swept us away.
19124006 Praise be to the Lord, who has not let us be torn by their teeth.
19124007 We have escaped like a bird from the fowler’s snare; the snare has been broken, and we have escaped.
19124008 Our help is in the name of the Lord, the Maker of heaven and earth.
19125000 A song of ascents.
19125001 Those who trust in the Lord are like Mount Zion, which cannot be shaken but endures forever.
19125002 As the mountains surround Jerusalem, so the Lord surrounds his people both now and forevermore.
19125003 The scepter of the wicked will not remain over the land allotted to the righteous, for then the righteous might use their hands to do evil.
19125004 Lord, do good to those who are good, to those who are upright in heart.
19125005 But those who turn to crooked ways the Lord will banish with the evildoers. Peace be on Israel.
19126000 A song of ascents.
19126001 When the Lord restored the fortunes of Zion, we were like those who dreamed.
19126002 Our mouths were filled with laughter, our tongues with songs of joy. Then it was said among the nations, “The Lord has done great things for them.”
19126003 The Lord has done great things for us, and we are filled with joy.
19126004 Restore our fortunes, Lord, like streams in the Negev.
19126005 Those who sow with tears will reap with songs of joy.
19126006 Those who go out weeping, carrying seed to sow, will return with songs of joy, carrying sheaves with them.
19127000 A song of ascents. Of Solomon.
19127001 Unless the Lord builds the house, the builders labor in vain. Unless the Lord watches over the city, the guards stand watch in vain.
19127002 In vain you rise early and stay up late, toiling for food to eat— for he grants sleep to those he loves.
19127003 Children are a heritage from the Lord, offspring a reward from him.
19127004 Like arrows in the hands of a warrior are children born in one’s youth.
19127005 Blessed is the man whose quiver is full of them. They will not be put to shame when they contend with their opponents in court.
19128000 A song of ascents.
19128001 Blessed are all who fear the Lord, who walk in obedience to him.
19128002 You will eat the fruit of your labor; blessings and prosperity will be yours.
19128003 Your wife will be like a fruitful vine within your house; your children will be like olive shoots around your table.
19128004 Yes, this will be the blessing for the man who fears the Lord.
19128005 May the Lord bless you from Zion; may you see the prosperity of Jerusalem all the days of your life.
19128006 May you live to see your children’s children— peace be on Israel.
19129000 A song of ascents.
19129001 “They have greatly oppressed me from my youth,” let Israel say;
19129002 “they have greatly oppressed me from my youth, but they have not gained the victory over me.
19129003 Plowmen have plowed my back and made their furrows long.
19129004 But the Lord is righteous; he has cut me free from the cords of the wicked.”
19129005 May all who hate Zion be turned back in shame.
19129006 May they be like grass on the roof, which withers before it can grow;
19129007 a reaper cannot fill his hands with it, nor one who gathers fill his arms.
19129008 May those who pass by not say to them, “The blessing of the Lord be on you; we bless you in the name of the Lord.”
19130000 A song of ascents.
19130001 Out of the depths I cry to you, Lord;
19130002 Lord, hear my voice. Let your ears be attentive to my cry for mercy.
19130003 If you, Lord, kept a record of sins, Lord, who could stand?
19130004 But with you there is forgiveness, so that we can, with reverence, serve you.
19130005 I wait for the Lord, my whole being waits, and in his word I put my hope.
19130006 I wait for the Lord more than watchmen wait for the morning, more than watchmen wait for the morning.
19130007 Israel, put your hope in the Lord, for with the Lord is unfailing love and with him is full redemption.
19130008 He himself will redeem Israel from all their sins.
19131000 A song of ascents. Of David.
19131001 My heart is not proud, Lord, my eyes are not haughty; I do not concern myself with great matters or things too wonderful for me.
19131002 But I have calmed and quieted myself, I am like a weaned child with its mother; like a weaned child I am content.
19131003 Israel, put your hope in the Lord both now and forevermore.
19132000 A song of ascents.
19132001 Lord, remember David and all his self-denial.
19132002 He swore an oath to the Lord, he made a vow to the Mighty One of Jacob:
19132003 “I will not enter my house or go to my bed,
19132004 I will allow no sleep to my eyes or slumber to my eyelids,
19132005 till I find a place for the Lord, a dwelling for the Mighty One of Jacob.”
19132006 We heard it in Ephrathah, we came upon it in the fields of Jaar:
19132007 “Let us go to his dwelling place, let us worship at his footstool, saying,
19132008 ‘Arise, Lord, and come to your resting place, you and the ark of your might.
19132009 May your priests be clothed with your righteousness; may your faithful people sing for joy.’ ”
19132010 For the sake of your servant David, do not reject your anointed one.
19132011 The Lord swore an oath to David, a sure oath he will not revoke: “One of your own descendants I will place on your throne.
19132012 If your sons keep my covenant and the statutes I teach them, then their sons will sit on your throne for ever and ever.”
19132013 For the Lord has chosen Zion, he has desired it for his dwelling, saying,
19132014 “This is my resting place for ever and ever; here I will sit enthroned, for I have desired it.
19132015 I will bless her with abundant provisions; her poor I will satisfy with food.
19132016 I will clothe her priests with salvation, and her faithful people will ever sing for joy.
19132017 “Here I will make a horn grow for David and set up a lamp for my anointed one.
19132018 I will clothe his enemies with shame, but his head will be adorned with a radiant crown.”
19133000 A song of ascents. Of David.
19133001 How good and pleasant it is when God’s people live together in unity!
19133002 It is like precious oil poured on the head, running down on the beard, running down on Aaron’s beard, down on the collar of his robe.
19133003 It is as if the dew of Hermon were falling on Mount Zion. For there the Lord bestows his blessing, even life forevermore.

19134001 Praise the Lord, all you servants of the Lord who minister by night in the house of the Lord.
19134002 Lift up your hands in the sanctuary and praise the Lord.
19134003 May the Lord bless you from Zion, he who is the Maker of heaven and earth.

19135003 Praise the Lord, for the Lord is good; sing praise to his name, for that is pleasant.
19135004 For the Lord has chosen Jacob to be his own, Israel to be his treasured possession.
19135005 I know that the Lord is great, that our Lord is greater than all gods.
19135006 The Lord does whatever pleases him, in the heavens and on the earth, in the seas and all their depths.
19135007 He makes clouds rise from the ends of the earth; he sends lightning with the rain and brings out the wind from his storehouses.
19135008 He struck down the firstborn of Egypt, the firstborn of people and animals.
19135009 He sent his signs and wonders into your midst, Egypt, against Pharaoh and all his servants.

19135013 Your name, Lord, endures forever, your renown, Lord, through all generations.
19135014 For the Lord will vindicate his people and have compassion on his servants.
19135015 The idols of the nations are silver and gold, made by human hands.

19135021 Praise be to the Lord from Zion, to him who dwells in Jerusalem. Praise the Lord.

19137001 By the rivers of Babylon we sat and wept when we remembered Zion.
19137002 There on the poplars we hung our harps,
19137003 for there our captors asked us for songs, our tormentors demanded songs of joy; they said, “Sing us one of the songs of Zion!”
19137004 How can we sing the songs of the Lord while in a foreign land?
19137005 If I forget you, Jerusalem, may my right hand forget its skill.
19137006 May my tongue cling to the roof of my mouth if I do not remember you, if I do not consider Jerusalem my highest joy.
19137007 Remember, Lord, what the Edomites did on the day Jerusalem fell. “Tear it down,” they cried, “tear it down to its foundations!”
19137008 Daughter Babylon, doomed to destruction, happy is the one who repays you according to what you have done to us.
19137009 Happy is the one who seizes your infants and dashes them against the rocks.
19138000 Of David.
19138001 I will praise you, Lord, with all my heart; before the “gods” I will sing your praise.
19138002 I will bow down toward your holy temple and will praise your name for your unfailing love and your faithfulness, for you have so exalted your solemn decree that it surpasses your fame.
19138003 When I called, you answered me; you greatly emboldened me.
19138004 May all the kings of the earth praise you, Lord, when they hear what you have decreed.
19138005 May they sing of the ways of the Lord, for the glory of the Lord is great.
19138006 Though the Lord is exalted, he looks kindly on the lowly; though lofty, he sees them from afar.
19138007 Though I walk in the midst of trouble, you preserve my life. You stretch out your hand against the anger of my foes; with your right hand you save me.
19138008 The Lord will vindicate me; your love, Lord, endures forever— do not abandon the works of your hands.
19139000 For the director of music. Of David. A psalm.
19139001 You have searched me, Lord, and you know me.
19139002 You know when I sit and when I rise; you perceive my thoughts from afar.
19139003 You discern my going out and my lying down; you are familiar with all my ways.
19139004 Before a word is on my tongue you, Lord, know it completely.
19139005 You hem me in behind and before, and you lay your hand upon me.
19139006 Such knowledge is too wonderful for me, too lofty for me to attain.
19139007 Where can I go from your Spirit? Where can I flee from your presence?
19139008 If I go up to the heavens, you are there; if I make my bed in the depths, you are there.
19139009 If I rise on the wings of the dawn, if I settle on the far side of the sea,
19139010 even there your hand will guide me, your right hand will hold me fast.
19139011 If I say, “Surely the darkness will hide me and the light become night around me,”
19139012 even the darkness will not be dark to you; the night will shine like the day, for darkness is as light to you.
19139013 For you created my inmost being; you knit me together in my mother’s womb.
19139014 I praise you because I am fearfully and wonderfully made; your works are wonderful, I know that full well.
19139015 My frame was not hidden from you when I was made in the secret place, when I was woven together in the depths of the earth.
19139016 Your eyes saw my unformed body; all the days ordained for me were written in your book before one of them came to be.
19139017 How precious to me are your thoughts, God! How vast is the sum of them!
19139018 Were I to count them, they would outnumber the grains of sand— when I awake, I am still with you.
19139019 If only you, God, would slay the wicked! Away from me, you who are bloodthirsty!
19139020 They speak of you with evil intent; your adversaries misuse your name.
19139021 Do I not hate those who hate you, Lord, and abhor those who are in rebellion against you?
19139022 I have nothing but hatred for them; I count them my enemies.
19139023 Search me, God, and know my heart; test me and know my anxious thoughts.
19139024 See if there is any offensive way in me, and lead me in the way everlasting.
19140000 For the director of music. A psalm of David.
19140001 Rescue me, Lord, from evildoers; protect me from the violent,
19140002 who devise evil plans in their hearts and stir up war every day.
19140003 They make their tongues as sharp as a serpent’s; the poison of vipers is on their lips.
19140004 Keep me safe, Lord, from the hands of the wicked; protect me from the violent, who devise ways to trip my feet.
19140005 The arrogant have hidden a snare for me; they have spread out the cords of their net and have set traps for me along my path.
19140006 I say to the Lord, “You are my God.” Hear, Lord, my cry for mercy.
19140007 Sovereign Lord, my strong deliverer, you shield my head in the day of battle.
19140008 Do not grant the wicked their desires, Lord; do not let their plans succeed.
19140009 Those who surround me proudly rear their heads; may the mischief of their lips engulf them.
19140010 May burning coals fall on them; may they be thrown into the fire, into miry pits, never to rise.
19140011 May slanderers not be established in the land; may disaster hunt down the violent.
19140012 I know that the Lord secures justice for the poor and upholds the cause of the needy.
19140013 Surely the righteous will praise your name, and the upright will live in your presence.
19141000 A psalm of David.
19141001 I call to you, Lord, come quickly to me; hear me when I call to you.
19141002 May my prayer be set before you like incense; may the lifting up of my hands be like the evening sacrifice.
19141003 Set a guard over my mouth, Lord; keep watch over the door of my lips.
19141004 Do not let my heart be drawn to what is evil so that I take part in wicked deeds along with those who are evildoers; do not let me eat their delicacies.
19141005 Let a righteous man strike me—that is a kindness; let him rebuke me—that is oil on my head. My head will not refuse it, for my prayer will still be against the deeds of evildoers.
19141006 Their rulers will be thrown down from the cliffs, and the wicked will learn that my words were well spoken.
19141007 They will say, “As one plows and breaks up the earth, so our bones have been scattered at the mouth of the grave.”
19141008 But my eyes are fixed on you, Sovereign Lord; in you I take refuge—do not give me over to death.
19141009 Keep me safe from the traps set by evildoers, from the snares they have laid for me.
19141010 Let the wicked fall into their own nets, while I pass by in safety.
19142000 A maskil of David. When he was in the cave. A prayer.
19142001 I cry aloud to the Lord; I lift up my voice to the Lord for mercy.
19142002 I pour out before him my complaint; before him I tell my trouble.
19142003 When my spirit grows faint within me, it is you who watch over my way. In the path where I walk people have hidden a snare for me.
19142004 Look and see, there is no one at my right hand; no one is concerned for me. I have no refuge; no one cares for my life.
19142005 I cry to you, Lord; I say, “You are my refuge, my portion in the land of the living.”
19142006 Listen to my cry, for I am in desperate need; rescue me from those who pursue me, for they are too strong for me.
19142007 Set me free from my prison, that I may praise your name. Then the righteous will gather about me because of your goodness to me.
19143000 A psalm of David.
19143001 Lord, hear my prayer, listen to my cry for mercy; in your faithfulness and righteousness come to my relief.
19143002 Do not bring your servant into judgment, for no one living is righteous before you.
19143003 The enemy pursues me, he crushes me to the ground; he makes me dwell in the darkness like those long dead.
19143004 So my spirit grows faint within me; my heart within me is dismayed.
19143005 I remember the days of long ago; I meditate on all your works and consider what your hands have done.
19143006 I spread out my hands to you; I thirst for you like a parched land.
19143007 Answer me quickly, Lord; my spirit fails. Do not hide your face from me or I will be like those who go down to the pit.
19143008 Let the morning bring me word of your unfailing love, for I have put my trust in you. Show me the way I should go, for to you I entrust my life.
19143009 Rescue me from my enemies, Lord, for I hide myself in you.
19143010 Teach me to do your will, for you are my God; may your good Spirit lead me on level ground.
19143011 For your name’s sake, Lord, preserve my life; in your righteousness, bring me out of trouble.
19143012 In your unfailing love, silence my enemies; destroy all my foes, for I am your servant.

19150002 Praise him for his acts of power; praise him for his surpassing greatness.
19150003 Praise him with the sounding of the trumpet, praise him with the harp and lyre,
19150004 praise him with timbrel and dancing, praise him with the strings and pipe,
19150005 praise him with the clash of cymbals, praise him with resounding cymbals.
19150006 Let everything that has breath praise the Lord. Praise the Lord.
20001001 The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel:
20001002 for gaining wisdom and instruction; for understanding words of insight;
20001003 for receiving instruction in prudent behavior, doing what is right and just and fair;
20001004 for giving prudence to those who are simple, knowledge and discretion to the young—
20001005 let the wise listen and add to their learning, and let the discerning get guidance—
20001006 for understanding proverbs and parables, the sayings and riddles of the wise.
20001007 The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, but fools despise wisdom and instruction.
20001008 Listen, my son, to your father’s instruction and do not forsake your mother’s teaching.
20001009 They are a garland to grace your head and a chain to adorn your neck.
20001010 My son, if sinful men entice you, do not give in to them.
20001011 If they say, “Come along with us; let’s lie in wait for innocent blood, let’s ambush some harmless soul;
20001012 let’s swallow them alive, like the grave, and whole, like those who go down to the pit;
20001013 we will get all sorts of valuable things and fill our houses with plunder;
20001014 cast lots with us; we will all share the loot”—
20001015 my son, do not go along with them, do not set foot on their paths;
20001016 for their feet rush into evil, they are swift to shed blood.
20001017 How useless to spread a net where every bird can see it!
20001018 These men lie in wait for their own blood; they ambush only themselves!
20001019 Such are the paths of all who go after ill-gotten gain; it takes away the life of those who get it.
20001020 Out in the open wisdom calls aloud, she raises her voice in the public square;
20001021 on top of the wall she cries out, at the city gate she makes her speech:
20001022 “How long will you who are simple love your simple ways? How long will mockers delight in mockery and fools hate knowledge?
20001023 Repent at my rebuke! Then I will pour out my thoughts to you, I will make known to you my teachings.
20001024 But since you refuse to listen when I call and no one pays attention when I stretch out my hand,
20001025 since you disregard all my advice and do not accept my rebuke,
20001026 I in turn will laugh when disaster strikes you; I will mock when calamity overtakes you—
20001027 when calamity overtakes you like a storm, when disaster sweeps over you like a whirlwind, when distress and trouble overwhelm you.
20001028 “Then they will call to me but I will not answer; they will look for me but will not find me,
20001029 since they hated knowledge and did not choose to fear the Lord.
20001030 Since they would not accept my advice and spurned my rebuke,
20001031 they will eat the fruit of their ways and be filled with the fruit of their schemes.
20001032 For the waywardness of the simple will kill them, and the complacency of fools will destroy them;
20001033 but whoever listens to me will live in safety and be at ease, without fear of harm.”
20002001 My son, if you accept my words and store up my commands within you,
20002002 turning your ear to wisdom and applying your heart to understanding—
20002003 indeed, if you call out for insight and cry aloud for understanding,
20002004 and if you look for it as for silver and search for it as for hidden treasure,
20002005 then you will understand the fear of the Lord and find the knowledge of God.
20002006 For the Lord gives wisdom; from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.
20002007 He holds success in store for the upright, he is a shield to those whose walk is blameless,
20002008 for he guards the course of the just and protects the way of his faithful ones.
20002009 Then you will understand what is right and just and fair—every good path.
20002010 For wisdom will enter your heart, and knowledge will be pleasant to your soul.
20002011 Discretion will protect you, and understanding will guard you.
20002012 Wisdom will save you from the ways of wicked men, from men whose words are perverse,
20002013 who have left the straight paths to walk in dark ways,
20002014 who delight in doing wrong and rejoice in the perverseness of evil,
20002015 whose paths are crooked and who are devious in their ways.
20002016 Wisdom will save you also from the adulterous woman, from the wayward woman with her seductive words,
20002017 who has left the partner of her youth and ignored the covenant she made before God.
20002018 Surely her house leads down to death and her paths to the spirits of the dead.
20002019 None who go to her return or attain the paths of life.
20002020 Thus you will walk in the ways of the good and keep to the paths of the righteous.
20002021 For the upright will live in the land, and the blameless will remain in it;
20002022 but the wicked will be cut off from the land, and the unfaithful will be torn from it.
20003001 My son, do not forget my teaching, but keep my commands in your heart,
20003002 for they will prolong your life many years and bring you peace and prosperity.
20003003 Let love and faithfulness never leave you; bind them around your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart.
20003004 Then you will win favor and a good name in the sight of God and man.
20003005 Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding;
20003006 in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight.
20003007 Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the Lord and shun evil.
20003008 This will bring health to your body and nourishment to your bones.
20003009 Honor the Lord with your wealth, with the firstfruits of all your crops;
20003010 then your barns will be filled to overflowing, and your vats will brim over with new wine.
20003011 My son, do not despise the Lord’s discipline, and do not resent his rebuke,
20003012 because the Lord disciplines those he loves, as a father the son he delights in.
20003013 Blessed are those who find wisdom, those who gain understanding,
20003014 for she is more profitable than silver and yields better returns than gold.
20003015 She is more precious than rubies; nothing you desire can compare with her.
20003016 Long life is in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor.
20003017 Her ways are pleasant ways, and all her paths are peace.
20003018 She is a tree of life to those who take hold of her; those who hold her fast will be blessed.
20003019 By wisdom the Lord laid the earth’s foundations, by understanding he set the heavens in place;
20003020 by his knowledge the watery depths were divided, and the clouds let drop the dew.
20003021 My son, do not let wisdom and understanding out of your sight, preserve sound judgment and discretion;
20003022 they will be life for you, an ornament to grace your neck.
20003023 Then you will go on your way in safety, and your foot will not stumble.
20003024 When you lie down, you will not be afraid; when you lie down, your sleep will be sweet.
20003025 Have no fear of sudden disaster or of the ruin that overtakes the wicked,
20003026 for the Lord will be at your side and will keep your foot from being snared.
20003027 Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in your power to act.
20003028 Do not say to your neighbor, “Come back tomorrow and I’ll give it to you”— when you already have it with you.
20003029 Do not plot harm against your neighbor, who lives trustfully near you.
20003030 Do not accuse anyone for no reason— when they have done you no harm.
20003031 Do not envy the violent or choose any of their ways.
20003032 For the Lord detests the perverse but takes the upright into his confidence.
20003033 The Lord’s curse is on the house of the wicked, but he blesses the home of the righteous.
20003034 He mocks proud mockers but shows favor to the humble and oppressed.
20003035 The wise inherit honor, but fools get only shame.
20004001 Listen, my sons, to a father’s instruction; pay attention and gain understanding.
20004002 I give you sound learning, so do not forsake my teaching.
20004003 For I too was a son to my father, still tender, and cherished by my mother.
20004004 Then he taught me, and he said to me, “Take hold of my words with all your heart; keep my commands, and you will live.
20004005 Get wisdom, get understanding; do not forget my words or turn away from them.
20004006 Do not forsake wisdom, and she will protect you; love her, and she will watch over you.
20004007 The beginning of wisdom is this: Get wisdom. Though it cost all you have, get understanding.
20004008 Cherish her, and she will exalt you; embrace her, and she will honor you.
20004009 She will give you a garland to grace your head and present you with a glorious crown.”
20004010 Listen, my son, accept what I say, and the years of your life will be many.
20004011 I instruct you in the way of wisdom and lead you along straight paths.
20004012 When you walk, your steps will not be hampered; when you run, you will not stumble.
20004013 Hold on to instruction, do not let it go; guard it well, for it is your life.
20004014 Do not set foot on the path of the wicked or walk in the way of evildoers.
20004015 Avoid it, do not travel on it; turn from it and go on your way.
20004016 For they cannot rest until they do evil; they are robbed of sleep till they make someone stumble.
20004017 They eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.
20004018 The path of the righteous is like the morning sun, shining ever brighter till the full light of day.
20004019 But the way of the wicked is like deep darkness; they do not know what makes them stumble.
20004020 My son, pay attention to what I say; turn your ear to my words.
20004021 Do not let them out of your sight, keep them within your heart;
20004022 for they are life to those who find them and health to one’s whole body.
20004023 Above all else, guard your heart, for everything you do flows from it.
20004024 Keep your mouth free of perversity; keep corrupt talk far from your lips.
20004025 Let your eyes look straight ahead; fix your gaze directly before you.
20004026 Give careful thought to the paths for your feet and be steadfast in all your ways.
20004027 Do not turn to the right or the left; keep your foot from evil.
20005001 My son, pay attention to my wisdom, turn your ear to my words of insight,
20005002 that you may maintain discretion and your lips may preserve knowledge.
20005003 For the lips of the adulterous woman drip honey, and her speech is smoother than oil;
20005004 but in the end she is bitter as gall, sharp as a double-edged sword.
20005005 Her feet go down to death; her steps lead straight to the grave.
20005006 She gives no thought to the way of life; her paths wander aimlessly, but she does not know it.
20005007 Now then, my sons, listen to me; do not turn aside from what I say.
20005008 Keep to a path far from her, do not go near the door of her house,
20005009 lest you lose your honor to others and your dignity to one who is cruel,
20005010 lest strangers feast on your wealth and your toil enrich the house of another.
20005011 At the end of your life you will groan, when your flesh and body are spent.
20005012 You will say, “How I hated discipline! How my heart spurned correction!
20005013 I would not obey my teachers or turn my ear to my instructors.
20005014 And I was soon in serious trouble in the assembly of God’s people.”
20005015 Drink water from your own cistern, running water from your own well.
20005016 Should your springs overflow in the streets, your streams of water in the public squares?
20005017 Let them be yours alone, never to be shared with strangers.
20005018 May your fountain be blessed, and may you rejoice in the wife of your youth.
20005019 A loving doe, a graceful deer— may her breasts satisfy you always, may you ever be intoxicated with her love.
20005020 Why, my son, be intoxicated with another man’s wife? Why embrace the bosom of a wayward woman?
20005021 For your ways are in full view of the Lord, and he examines all your paths.
20005022 The evil deeds of the wicked ensnare them; the cords of their sins hold them fast.
20005023 For lack of discipline they will die, led astray by their own great folly.
20006001 My son, if you have put up security for your neighbor, if you have shaken hands in pledge for a stranger,
20006002 you have been trapped by what you said, ensnared by the words of your mouth.
20006003 So do this, my son, to free yourself, since you have fallen into your neighbor’s hands: Go—to the point of exhaustion— and give your neighbor no rest!
20006004 Allow no sleep to your eyes, no slumber to your eyelids.
20006005 Free yourself, like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter, like a bird from the snare of the fowler.
20006006 Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider its ways and be wise!
20006007 It has no commander, no overseer or ruler,
20006008 yet it stores its provisions in summer and gathers its food at harvest.
20006009 How long will you lie there, you sluggard? When will you get up from your sleep?
20006010 A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest—
20006011 and poverty will come on you like a thief and scarcity like an armed man.
20006012 A troublemaker and a villain, who goes about with a corrupt mouth,
20006013 who winks maliciously with his eye, signals with his feet and motions with his fingers,
20006014 who plots evil with deceit in his heart— he always stirs up conflict.
20006015 Therefore disaster will overtake him in an instant; he will suddenly be destroyed—without remedy.
20006016 There are six things the Lord hates, seven that are detestable to him:
20006017 haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood,
20006018 a heart that devises wicked schemes, feet that are quick to rush into evil,
20006019 a false witness who pours out lies and a person who stirs up conflict in the community.
20006020 My son, keep your father’s command and do not forsake your mother’s teaching.
20006021 Bind them always on your heart; fasten them around your neck.
20006022 When you walk, they will guide you; when you sleep, they will watch over you; when you awake, they will speak to you.
20006023 For this command is a lamp, this teaching is a light, and correction and instruction are the way to life,
20006024 keeping you from your neighbor’s wife, from the smooth talk of a wayward woman.
20006025 Do not lust in your heart after her beauty or let her captivate you with her eyes.
20006026 For a prostitute can be had for a loaf of bread, but another man’s wife preys on your very life.
20006027 Can a man scoop fire into his lap without his clothes being burned?
20006028 Can a man walk on hot coals without his feet being scorched?
20006029 So is he who sleeps with another man’s wife; no one who touches her will go unpunished.
20006030 People do not despise a thief if he steals to satisfy his hunger when he is starving.
20006031 Yet if he is caught, he must pay sevenfold, though it costs him all the wealth of his house.
20006032 But a man who commits adultery has no sense; whoever does so destroys himself.
20006033 Blows and disgrace are his lot, and his shame will never be wiped away.
20006034 For jealousy arouses a husband’s fury, and he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.
20006035 He will not accept any compensation; he will refuse a bribe, however great it is.
20007001 My son, keep my words and store up my commands within you.
20007002 Keep my commands and you will live; guard my teachings as the apple of your eye.
20007003 Bind them on your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart.
20007004 Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,” and to insight, “You are my relative.”
20007005 They will keep you from the adulterous woman, from the wayward woman with her seductive words.
20007006 At the window of my house I looked down through the lattice.
20007007 I saw among the simple, I noticed among the young men, a youth who had no sense.
20007008 He was going down the street near her corner, walking along in the direction of her house
20007009 at twilight, as the day was fading, as the dark of night set in.
20007010 Then out came a woman to meet him, dressed like a prostitute and with crafty intent.
20007011 (She is unruly and defiant, her feet never stay at home;
20007012 now in the street, now in the squares, at every corner she lurks.)
20007013 She took hold of him and kissed him and with a brazen face she said:
20007014 “Today I fulfilled my vows, and I have food from my fellowship offering at home.
20007015 So I came out to meet you; I looked for you and have found you!
20007016 I have covered my bed with colored linens from Egypt.
20007017 I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes and cinnamon.
20007018 Come, let’s drink deeply of love till morning; let’s enjoy ourselves with love!
20007019 My husband is not at home; he has gone on a long journey.
20007020 He took his purse filled with money and will not be home till full moon.”
20007021 With persuasive words she led him astray; she seduced him with her smooth talk.
20007022 All at once he followed her like an ox going to the slaughter, like a deer stepping into a noose
20007023 till an arrow pierces his liver, like a bird darting into a snare, little knowing it will cost him his life.
20007024 Now then, my sons, listen to me; pay attention to what I say.
20007025 Do not let your heart turn to her ways or stray into her paths.
20007026 Many are the victims she has brought down; her slain are a mighty throng.
20007027 Her house is a highway to the grave, leading down to the chambers of death.
20008001 Does not wisdom call out? Does not understanding raise her voice?
20008002 At the highest point along the way, where the paths meet, she takes her stand;
20008003 beside the gate leading into the city, at the entrance, she cries aloud:
20008004 “To you, O people, I call out; I raise my voice to all mankind.
20008005 You who are simple, gain prudence; you who are foolish, set your hearts on it.
20008006 Listen, for I have trustworthy things to say; I open my lips to speak what is right.
20008007 My mouth speaks what is true, for my lips detest wickedness.
20008008 All the words of my mouth are just; none of them is crooked or perverse.
20008009 To the discerning all of them are right; they are upright to those who have found knowledge.
20008010 Choose my instruction instead of silver, knowledge rather than choice gold,
20008011 for wisdom is more precious than rubies, and nothing you desire can compare with her.
20008012 “I, wisdom, dwell together with prudence; I possess knowledge and discretion.
20008013 To fear the Lord is to hate evil; I hate pride and arrogance, evil behavior and perverse speech.
20008014 Counsel and sound judgment are mine; I have insight, I have power.
20008015 By me kings reign and rulers issue decrees that are just;
20008016 by me princes govern, and nobles—all who rule on earth.
20008017 I love those who love me, and those who seek me find me.
20008018 With me are riches and honor, enduring wealth and prosperity.
20008019 My fruit is better than fine gold; what I yield surpasses choice silver.
20008020 I walk in the way of righteousness, along the paths of justice,
20008021 bestowing a rich inheritance on those who love me and making their treasuries full.
20008022 “The Lord brought me forth as the first of his works, before his deeds of old;
20008023 I was formed long ages ago, at the very beginning, when the world came to be.
20008024 When there were no watery depths, I was given birth, when there were no springs overflowing with water;
20008025 before the mountains were settled in place, before the hills, I was given birth,
20008026 before he made the world or its fields or any of the dust of the earth.
20008027 I was there when he set the heavens in place, when he marked out the horizon on the face of the deep,
20008028 when he established the clouds above and fixed securely the fountains of the deep,
20008029 when he gave the sea its boundary so the waters would not overstep his command, and when he marked out the foundations of the earth.
20008030 Then I was constantly at his side. I was filled with delight day after day, rejoicing always in his presence,
20008031 rejoicing in his whole world and delighting in mankind.
20008032 “Now then, my children, listen to me; blessed are those who keep my ways.
20008033 Listen to my instruction and be wise; do not disregard it.
20008034 Blessed are those who listen to me, watching daily at my doors, waiting at my doorway.
20008035 For those who find me find life and receive favor from the Lord.
20008036 But those who fail to find me harm themselves; all who hate me love death.”
20009001 Wisdom has built her house; she has set up its seven pillars.
20009002 She has prepared her meat and mixed her wine; she has also set her table.
20009003 She has sent out her servants, and she calls from the highest point of the city,
20009004 “Let all who are simple come to my house!” To those who have no sense she says,
20009005 “Come, eat my food and drink the wine I have mixed.
20009006 Leave your simple ways and you will live; walk in the way of insight.”
20009007 Whoever corrects a mocker invites insults; whoever rebukes the wicked incurs abuse.
20009008 Do not rebuke mockers or they will hate you; rebuke the wise and they will love you.
20009009 Instruct the wise and they will be wiser still; teach the righteous and they will add to their learning.
20009010 The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
20009011 For through wisdom your days will be many, and years will be added to your life.
20009012 If you are wise, your wisdom will reward you; if you are a mocker, you alone will suffer.
20009013 Folly is an unruly woman; she is simple and knows nothing.
20009014 She sits at the door of her house, on a seat at the highest point of the city,
20009015 calling out to those who pass by, who go straight on their way,
20009016 “Let all who are simple come to my house!” To those who have no sense she says,
20009017 “Stolen water is sweet; food eaten in secret is delicious!”
20009018 But little do they know that the dead are there, that her guests are deep in the realm of the dead.
20010001 The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son brings grief to his mother.
20010002 Ill-gotten treasures have no lasting value, but righteousness delivers from death.
20010003 The Lord does not let the righteous go hungry, but he thwarts the craving of the wicked.
20010004 Lazy hands make for poverty, but diligent hands bring wealth.
20010005 He who gathers crops in summer is a prudent son, but he who sleeps during harvest is a disgraceful son.
20010006 Blessings crown the head of the righteous, but violence overwhelms the mouth of the wicked.
20010007 The name of the righteous is used in blessings, but the name of the wicked will rot.
20010008 The wise in heart accept commands, but a chattering fool comes to ruin.
20010009 Whoever walks in integrity walks securely, but whoever takes crooked paths will be found out.
20010010 Whoever winks maliciously causes grief, and a chattering fool comes to ruin.
20010011 The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
20010012 Hatred stirs up conflict, but love covers over all wrongs.
20010013 Wisdom is found on the lips of the discerning, but a rod is for the back of one who has no sense.
20010014 The wise store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool invites ruin.
20010015 The wealth of the rich is their fortified city, but poverty is the ruin of the poor.
20010016 The wages of the righteous is life, but the earnings of the wicked are sin and death.
20010017 Whoever heeds discipline shows the way to life, but whoever ignores correction leads others astray.
20010018 Whoever conceals hatred with lying lips and spreads slander is a fool.
20010019 Sin is not ended by multiplying words, but the prudent hold their tongues.
20010020 The tongue of the righteous is choice silver, but the heart of the wicked is of little value.
20010021 The lips of the righteous nourish many, but fools die for lack of sense.
20010022 The blessing of the Lord brings wealth, without painful toil for it.
20010023 A fool finds pleasure in wicked schemes, but a person of understanding delights in wisdom.
20010024 What the wicked dread will overtake them; what the righteous desire will be granted.
20010025 When the storm has swept by, the wicked are gone, but the righteous stand firm forever.
20010026 As vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so are sluggards to those who send them.
20010027 The fear of the Lord adds length to life, but the years of the wicked are cut short.
20010028 The prospect of the righteous is joy, but the hopes of the wicked come to nothing.
20010029 The way of the Lord is a refuge for the blameless, but it is the ruin of those who do evil.
20010030 The righteous will never be uprooted, but the wicked will not remain in the land.
20010031 From the mouth of the righteous comes the fruit of wisdom, but a perverse tongue will be silenced.
20010032 The lips of the righteous know what finds favor, but the mouth of the wicked only what is perverse.
20011001 The Lord detests dishonest scales, but accurate weights find favor with him.
20011002 When pride comes, then comes disgrace, but with humility comes wisdom.
20011003 The integrity of the upright guides them, but the unfaithful are destroyed by their duplicity.
20011004 Wealth is worthless in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.
20011005 The righteousness of the blameless makes their paths straight, but the wicked are brought down by their own wickedness.
20011006 The righteousness of the upright delivers them, but the unfaithful are trapped by evil desires.
20011007 Hopes placed in mortals die with them; all the promise of their power comes to nothing.
20011008 The righteous person is rescued from trouble, and it falls on the wicked instead.
20011009 With their mouths the godless destroy their neighbors, but through knowledge the righteous escape.
20011010 When the righteous prosper, the city rejoices; when the wicked perish, there are shouts of joy.
20011011 Through the blessing of the upright a city is exalted, but by the mouth of the wicked it is destroyed.
20011012 Whoever derides their neighbor has no sense, but the one who has understanding holds their tongue.
20011013 A gossip betrays a confidence, but a trustworthy person keeps a secret.
20011014 For lack of guidance a nation falls, but victory is won through many advisers.
20011015 Whoever puts up security for a stranger will surely suffer, but whoever refuses to shake hands in pledge is safe.
20011016 A kindhearted woman gains honor, but ruthless men gain only wealth.
20011017 Those who are kind benefit themselves, but the cruel bring ruin on themselves.
20011018 A wicked person earns deceptive wages, but the one who sows righteousness reaps a sure reward.
20011019 Truly the righteous attain life, but whoever pursues evil finds death.
20011020 The Lord detests those whose hearts are perverse, but he delights in those whose ways are blameless.
20011021 Be sure of this: The wicked will not go unpunished, but those who are righteous will go free.
20011022 Like a gold ring in a pig’s snout is a beautiful woman who shows no discretion.
20011023 The desire of the righteous ends only in good, but the hope of the wicked only in wrath.
20011024 One person gives freely, yet gains even more; another withholds unduly, but comes to poverty.
20011025 A generous person will prosper; whoever refreshes others will be refreshed.
20011026 People curse the one who hoards grain, but they pray God’s blessing on the one who is willing to sell.
20011027 Whoever seeks good finds favor, but evil comes to one who searches for it.
20011028 Those who trust in their riches will fall, but the righteous will thrive like a green leaf.
20011029 Whoever brings ruin on their family will inherit only wind, and the fool will be servant to the wise.
20011030 The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and the one who is wise saves lives.
20011031 If the righteous receive their due on earth, how much more the ungodly and the sinner!
20012001 Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but whoever hates correction is stupid.
20012002 Good people obtain favor from the Lord, but he condemns those who devise wicked schemes.
20012003 No one can be established through wickedness, but the righteous cannot be uprooted.
20012004 A wife of noble character is her husband’s crown, but a disgraceful wife is like decay in his bones.
20012005 The plans of the righteous are just, but the advice of the wicked is deceitful.
20012006 The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood, but the speech of the upright rescues them.
20012007 The wicked are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the righteous stands firm.
20012008 A person is praised according to their prudence, and one with a warped mind is despised.
20012009 Better to be a nobody and yet have a servant than pretend to be somebody and have no food.
20012010 The righteous care for the needs of their animals, but the kindest acts of the wicked are cruel.
20012011 Those who work their land will have abundant food, but those who chase fantasies have no sense.
20012012 The wicked desire the stronghold of evildoers, but the root of the righteous endures.
20012013 Evildoers are trapped by their sinful talk, and so the innocent escape trouble.
20012014 From the fruit of their lips people are filled with good things, and the work of their hands brings them reward.
20012015 The way of fools seems right to them, but the wise listen to advice.
20012016 Fools show their annoyance at once, but the prudent overlook an insult.
20012017 An honest witness tells the truth, but a false witness tells lies.
20012018 The words of the reckless pierce like swords, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
20012019 Truthful lips endure forever, but a lying tongue lasts only a moment.
20012020 Deceit is in the hearts of those who plot evil, but those who promote peace have joy.
20012021 No harm overtakes the righteous, but the wicked have their fill of trouble.
20012022 The Lord detests lying lips, but he delights in people who are trustworthy.
20012023 The prudent keep their knowledge to themselves, but a fool’s heart blurts out folly.
20012024 Diligent hands will rule, but laziness ends in forced labor.
20012025 Anxiety weighs down the heart, but a kind word cheers it up.
20012026 The righteous choose their friends carefully, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
20012027 The lazy do not roast any game, but the diligent feed on the riches of the hunt.

20022021 teaching you to be honest and to speak the truth, so that you bring back truthful reports to those you serve?

20023001 When you sit to dine with a ruler, note well what is before you,
20023002 and put a knife to your throat if you are given to gluttony.
20023003 Do not crave his delicacies, for that food is deceptive.
20023004 Do not wear yourself out to get rich; do not trust your own cleverness.
20023005 Cast but a glance at riches, and they are gone, for they will surely sprout wings and fly off to the sky like an eagle.
20023006 Do not eat the food of a begrudging host, do not crave his delicacies;
20023007 for he is the kind of person who is always thinking about the cost. “Eat and drink,” he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
20023008 You will vomit up the little you have eaten and will have wasted your compliments.
20023009 Do not speak to fools, for they will scorn your prudent words.
20023010 Do not move an ancient boundary stone or encroach on the fields of the fatherless,
20023011 for their Defender is strong; he will take up their case against you.
20023012 Apply your heart to instruction and your ears to words of knowledge.
20023013 Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you punish them with the rod, they will not die.
20023014 Punish them with the rod and save them from death.
20023015 My son, if your heart is wise, then my heart will be glad indeed;
20023016 my inmost being will rejoice when your lips speak what is right.
20023017 Do not let your heart envy sinners, but always be zealous for the fear of the Lord.
20023018 There is surely a future hope for you, and your hope will not be cut off.
20023019 Listen, my son, and be wise, and set your heart on the right path:
20023020 Do not join those who drink too much wine or gorge themselves on meat,
20023021 for drunkards and gluttons become poor, and drowsiness clothes them in rags.
20023022 Listen to your father, who gave you life, and do not despise your mother when she is old.
20023023 Buy the truth and do not sell it— wisdom, instruction and insight as well.
20023024 The father of a righteous child has great joy; a man who fathers a wise son rejoices in him.
20023025 May your father and mother rejoice; may she who gave you birth be joyful!
20023026 My son, give me your heart and let your eyes delight in my ways,
20023027 for an adulterous woman is a deep pit, and a wayward wife is a narrow well.
20023028 Like a bandit she lies in wait and multiplies the unfaithful among men.
20023029 Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has strife? Who has complaints? Who has needless bruises? Who has bloodshot eyes?
20023030 Those who linger over wine, who go to sample bowls of mixed wine.
20023031 Do not gaze at wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup, when it goes down smoothly!
20023032 In the end it bites like a snake and poisons like a viper.
20023033 Your eyes will see strange sights, and your mind will imagine confusing things.
20023034 You will be like one sleeping on the high seas, lying on top of the rigging.
20023035 “They hit me,” you will say, “but I’m not hurt! They beat me, but I don’t feel it! When will I wake up so I can find another drink?”
20024001 Do not envy the wicked, do not desire their company;
20024002 for their hearts plot violence, and their lips talk about making trouble.
20024003 By wisdom a house is built, and through understanding it is established;
20024004 through knowledge its rooms are filled with rare and beautiful treasures.
20024005 The wise prevail through great power, and those who have knowledge muster their strength.
20024006 Surely you need guidance to wage war, and victory is won through many advisers.
20024007 Wisdom is too high for fools; in the assembly at the gate they must not open their mouths.
20024008 Whoever plots evil will be known as a schemer.
20024009 The schemes of folly are sin, and people detest a mocker.
20024010 If you falter in a time of trouble, how small is your strength!
20024011 Rescue those being led away to death; hold back those staggering toward slaughter.
20024012 If you say, “But we knew nothing about this,” does not he who weighs the heart perceive it? Does not he who guards your life know it? Will he not repay everyone according to what they have done?
20024013 Eat honey, my son, for it is good; honey from the comb is sweet to your taste.
20024014 Know also that wisdom is like honey for you: If you find it, there is a future hope for you, and your hope will not be cut off.
20024015 Do not lurk like a thief near the house of the righteous, do not plunder their dwelling place;
20024016 for though the righteous fall seven times, they rise again, but the wicked stumble when calamity strikes.
20024017 Do not gloat when your enemy falls; when they stumble, do not let your heart rejoice,
20024018 or the Lord will see and disapprove and turn his wrath away from them.
20024019 Do not fret because of evildoers or be envious of the wicked,
20024020 for the evildoer has no future hope, and the lamp of the wicked will be snuffed out.
20024021 Fear the Lord and the king, my son, and do not join with rebellious officials,
20024022 for those two will send sudden destruction on them, and who knows what calamities they can bring?
20024023 These also are sayings of the wise: To show partiality in judging is not good:
20024024 Whoever says to the guilty, “You are innocent,” will be cursed by peoples and denounced by nations.
20024025 But it will go well with those who convict the guilty, and rich blessing will come on them.
20024026 An honest answer is like a kiss on the lips.
20024027 Put your outdoor work in order and get your fields ready; after that, build your house.
20024028 Do not testify against your neighbor without cause— would you use your lips to mislead?
20024029 Do not say, “I’ll do to them as they have done to me; I’ll pay them back for what they did.”
20024030 I went past the field of a sluggard, past the vineyard of someone who has no sense;
20024031 thorns had come up everywhere, the ground was covered with weeds, and the stone wall was in ruins.
20024032 I applied my heart to what I observed and learned a lesson from what I saw:
20024033 A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest—
20024034 and poverty will come on you like a thief and scarcity like an armed man.
20025001 These are more proverbs of Solomon, compiled by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah:
20025002 It is the glory of God to conceal a matter; to search out a matter is the glory of kings.
20025003 As the heavens are high and the earth is deep, so the hearts of kings are unsearchable.
20025004 Remove the dross from the silver, and a silversmith can produce a vessel;
20025005 remove wicked officials from the king’s presence, and his throne will be established through righteousness.
20025006 Do not exalt yourself in the king’s presence, and do not claim a place among his great men;
20025007 it is better for him to say to you, “Come up here,” than for him to humiliate you before his nobles. What you have seen with your eyes
20025008 do not bring hastily to court, for what will you do in the end if your neighbor puts you to shame?
20025009 If you take your neighbor to court, do not betray another’s confidence,
20025010 or the one who hears it may shame you and the charge against you will stand.
20025011 Like apples of gold in settings of silver is a ruling rightly given.
20025012 Like an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold is the rebuke of a wise judge to a listening ear.
20025013 Like a snow-cooled drink at harvest time is a trustworthy messenger to the one who sends him; he refreshes the spirit of his master.
20025014 Like clouds and wind without rain is one who boasts of gifts never given.
20025015 Through patience a ruler can be persuaded, and a gentle tongue can break a bone.
20025016 If you find honey, eat just enough— too much of it, and you will vomit.
20025017 Seldom set foot in your neighbor’s house— too much of you, and they will hate you.
20025018 Like a club or a sword or a sharp arrow is one who gives false testimony against a neighbor.
20025019 Like a broken tooth or a lame foot is reliance on the unfaithful in a time of trouble.
20025020 Like one who takes away a garment on a cold day, or like vinegar poured on a wound, is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
20025021 If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat; if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
20025022 In doing this, you will heap burning coals on his head, and the Lord will reward you.
20025023 Like a north wind that brings unexpected rain is a sly tongue—which provokes a horrified look.
20025024 Better to live on a corner of the roof than share a house with a quarrelsome wife.
20025025 Like cold water to a weary soul is good news from a distant land.
20025026 Like a muddied spring or a polluted well are the righteous who give way to the wicked.
20025027 It is not good to eat too much honey, nor is it honorable to search out matters that are too deep.
20025028 Like a city whose walls are broken through is a person who lacks self-control.
20026001 Like snow in summer or rain in harvest, honor is not fitting for a fool.
20026002 Like a fluttering sparrow or a darting swallow, an undeserved curse does not come to rest.
20026003 A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the backs of fools!
20026004 Do not answer a fool according to his folly, or you yourself will be just like him.
20026005 Answer a fool according to his folly, or he will be wise in his own eyes.
20026006 Sending a message by the hands of a fool is like cutting off one’s feet or drinking poison.
20026007 Like the useless legs of one who is lame is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
20026008 Like tying a stone in a sling is the giving of honor to a fool.
20026009 Like a thornbush in a drunkard’s hand is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
20026010 Like an archer who wounds at random is one who hires a fool or any passer-by.
20026011 As a dog returns to its vomit, so fools repeat their folly.
20026012 Do you see a person wise in their own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for them.
20026013 A sluggard says, “There’s a lion in the road, a fierce lion roaming the streets!”
20026014 As a door turns on its hinges, so a sluggard turns on his bed.
20026015 A sluggard buries his hand in the dish; he is too lazy to bring it back to his mouth.
20026016 A sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than seven people who answer discreetly.
20026017 Like one who grabs a stray dog by the ears is someone who rushes into a quarrel not their own.
20026018 Like a maniac shooting flaming arrows of death
20026019 is one who deceives their neighbor and says, “I was only joking!”
20026020 Without wood a fire goes out; without a gossip a quarrel dies down.
20026021 As charcoal to embers and as wood to fire, so is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.
20026022 The words of a gossip are like choice morsels; they go down to the inmost parts.
20026023 Like a coating of silver dross on earthenware are fervent lips with an evil heart.
20026024 Enemies disguise themselves with their lips, but in their hearts they harbor deceit.
20026025 Though their speech is charming, do not believe them, for seven abominations fill their hearts.
20026026 Their malice may be concealed by deception, but their wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.
20026027 Whoever digs a pit will fall into it; if someone rolls a stone, it will roll back on them.
20026028 A lying tongue hates those it hurts, and a flattering mouth works ruin.
20027001 Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring.
20027002 Let someone else praise you, and not your own mouth; an outsider, and not your own lips.
20027003 Stone is heavy and sand a burden, but a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.
20027004 Anger is cruel and fury overwhelming, but who can stand before jealousy?
20027005 Better is open rebuke than hidden love.
20027006 Wounds from a friend can be trusted, but an enemy multiplies kisses.
20027007 One who is full loathes honey from the comb, but to the hungry even what is bitter tastes sweet.
20027008 Like a bird that flees its nest is anyone who flees from home.
20027009 Perfume and incense bring joy to the heart, and the pleasantness of a friend springs from their heartfelt advice.
20027010 Do not forsake your friend or a friend of your family, and do not go to your relative’s house when disaster strikes you— better a neighbor nearby than a relative far away.
20027011 Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart; then I can answer anyone who treats me with contempt.
20027012 The prudent see danger and take refuge, but the simple keep going and pay the penalty.
20027013 Take the garment of one who puts up security for a stranger; hold it in pledge if it is done for an outsider.
20027014 If anyone loudly blesses their neighbor early in the morning, it will be taken as a curse.
20027015 A quarrelsome wife is like the dripping of a leaky roof in a rainstorm;
20027016 restraining her is like restraining the wind or grasping oil with the hand.
20027017 As iron sharpens iron, so one person sharpens another.
20027018 The one who guards a fig tree will eat its fruit, and whoever protects their master will be honored.
20027019 As water reflects the face, so one’s life reflects the heart.
20027020 Death and Destruction are never satisfied, and neither are human eyes.
20027021 The crucible for silver and the furnace for gold, but people are tested by their praise.
20027022 Though you grind a fool in a mortar, grinding them like grain with a pestle, you will not remove their folly from them.
20027023 Be sure you know the condition of your flocks, give careful attention to your herds;
20027024 for riches do not endure forever, and a crown is not secure for all generations.
20027025 When the hay is removed and new growth appears and the grass from the hills is gathered in,
20027026 the lambs will provide you with clothing, and the goats with the price of a field.
20027027 You will have plenty of goats’ milk to feed your family and to nourish your female servants.
20028001 The wicked flee though no one pursues, but the righteous are as bold as a lion.
20028002 When a country is rebellious, it has many rulers, but a ruler with discernment and knowledge maintains order.
20028003 A ruler who oppresses the poor is like a driving rain that leaves no crops.
20028004 Those who forsake instruction praise the wicked, but those who heed it resist them.
20028005 Evildoers do not understand what is right, but those who seek the Lord understand it fully.
20028006 Better the poor whose walk is blameless than the rich whose ways are perverse.
20028007 A discerning son heeds instruction, but a companion of gluttons disgraces his father.
20028008 Whoever increases wealth by taking interest or profit from the poor amasses it for another, who will be kind to the poor.
20028009 If anyone turns a deaf ear to my instruction, even their prayers are detestable.
20028010 Whoever leads the upright along an evil path will fall into their own trap, but the blameless will receive a good inheritance.
20028011 The rich are wise in their own eyes; one who is poor and discerning sees how deluded they are.
20028012 When the righteous triumph, there is great elation; but when the wicked rise to power, people go into hiding.
20028013 Whoever conceals their sins does not prosper, but the one who confesses and renounces them finds mercy.
20028014 Blessed is the one who always trembles before God, but whoever hardens their heart falls into trouble.
20028015 Like a roaring lion or a charging bear is a wicked ruler over a helpless people.
20028016 A tyrannical ruler practices extortion, but one who hates ill-gotten gain will enjoy a long reign.
20028017 Anyone tormented by the guilt of murder will seek refuge in the grave; let no one hold them back.
20028018 The one whose walk is blameless is kept safe, but the one whose ways are perverse will fall into the pit.
20028019 Those who work their land will have abundant food, but those who chase fantasies will have their fill of poverty.
20028020 A faithful person will be richly blessed, but one eager to get rich will not go unpunished.
20028021 To show partiality is not good— yet a person will do wrong for a piece of bread.
20028022 The stingy are eager to get rich and are unaware that poverty awaits them.
20028023 Whoever rebukes a person will in the end gain favor rather than one who has a flattering tongue.
20028024 Whoever robs their father or mother and says, “It’s not wrong,” is partner to one who destroys.
20028025 The greedy stir up conflict, but those who trust in the Lord will prosper.
20028026 Those who trust in themselves are fools, but those who walk in wisdom are kept safe.
20028027 Those who give to the poor will lack nothing, but those who close their eyes to them receive many curses.
20028028 When the wicked rise to power, people go into hiding; but when the wicked perish, the righteous thrive.
20029001 Whoever remains stiff-necked after many rebukes will suddenly be destroyed—without remedy.
20029002 When the righteous thrive, the people rejoice; when the wicked rule, the people groan.
20029003 A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father, but a companion of prostitutes squanders his wealth.
20029004 By justice a king gives a country stability, but those who are greedy for bribes tear it down.
20029005 Those who flatter their neighbors are spreading nets for their feet.
20029006 Evildoers are snared by their own sin, but the righteous shout for joy and are glad.
20029007 The righteous care about justice for the poor, but the wicked have no such concern.
20029008 Mockers stir up a city, but the wise turn away anger.
20029009 If a wise person goes to court with a fool, the fool rages and scoffs, and there is no peace.
20029010 The bloodthirsty hate a person of integrity and seek to kill the upright.
20029011 Fools give full vent to their rage, but the wise bring calm in the end.
20029012 If a ruler listens to lies, all his officials become wicked.
20029013 The poor and the oppressor have this in common: The Lord gives sight to the eyes of both.
20029014 If a king judges the poor with fairness, his throne will be established forever.
20029015 A rod and a reprimand impart wisdom, but a child left undisciplined disgraces its mother.
20029016 When the wicked thrive, so does sin, but the righteous will see their downfall.
20029017 Discipline your children, and they will give you peace; they will bring you the delights you desire.
20029018 Where there is no revelation, people cast off restraint; but blessed is the one who heeds wisdom’s instruction.
20029019 Servants cannot be corrected by mere words; though they understand, they will not respond.
20029020 Do you see someone who speaks in haste? There is more hope for a fool than for them.
20029021 A servant pampered from youth will turn out to be insolent.
20029022 An angry person stirs up conflict, and a hot-tempered person commits many sins.
20029023 Pride brings a person low, but the lowly in spirit gain honor.
20029024 The accomplices of thieves are their own enemies; they are put under oath and dare not testify.
20029025 Fear of man will prove to be a snare, but whoever trusts in the Lord is kept safe.
20029026 Many seek an audience with a ruler, but it is from the Lord that one gets justice.
20029027 The righteous detest the dishonest; the wicked detest the upright.
20030001 The sayings of Agur son of Jakeh—an inspired utterance. This man’s utterance to Ithiel: “I am weary, God, but I can prevail.
20030002 Surely I am only a brute, not a man; I do not have human understanding.
20030003 I have not learned wisdom, nor have I attained to the knowledge of the Holy One.
20030004 Who has gone up to heaven and come down? Whose hands have gathered up the wind? Who has wrapped up the waters in a cloak? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is his name, and what is the name of his son? Surely you know!
20030005 “Every word of God is flawless; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
20030006 Do not add to his words, or he will rebuke you and prove you a liar.
20030007 “Two things I ask of you, Lord; do not refuse me before I die:
20030008 Keep falsehood and lies far from me; give me neither poverty nor riches, but give me only my daily bread.
20030009 Otherwise, I may have too much and disown you and say, ‘Who is the Lord?’ Or I may become poor and steal, and so dishonor the name of my God.
20030010 “Do not slander a servant to their master, or they will curse you, and you will pay for it.
20030011 “There are those who curse their fathers and do not bless their mothers;
20030012 those who are pure in their own eyes and yet are not cleansed of their filth;
20030013 those whose eyes are ever so haughty, whose glances are so disdainful;
20030014 those whose teeth are swords and whose jaws are set with knives to devour the poor from the earth and the needy from among mankind.
20030015 “The leech has two daughters. ‘Give! Give!’ they cry. “There are three things that are never satisfied, four that never say, ‘Enough!’:
20030016 the grave, the barren womb, land, which is never satisfied with water, and fire, which never says, ‘Enough!’
20030017 “The eye that mocks a father, that scorns an aged mother, will be pecked out by the ravens of the valley, will be eaten by the vultures.
20030018 “There are three things that are too amazing for me, four that I do not understand:
20030019 the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a snake on a rock, the way of a ship on the high seas, and the way of a man with a young woman.
20030020 “This is the way of an adulterous woman: She eats and wipes her mouth and says, ‘I’ve done nothing wrong.’
20030021 “Under three things the earth trembles, under four it cannot bear up:
20030022 a servant who becomes king, a godless fool who gets plenty to eat,
20030023 a contemptible woman who gets married, and a servant who displaces her mistress.
20030024 “Four things on earth are small, yet they are extremely wise:
20030025 Ants are creatures of little strength, yet they store up their food in the summer;
20030026 hyraxes are creatures of little power, yet they make their home in the crags;
20030027 locusts have no king, yet they advance together in ranks;
20030028 a lizard can be caught with the hand, yet it is found in kings’ palaces.
20030029 “There are three things that are stately in their stride, four that move with stately bearing:
20030030 a lion, mighty among beasts, who retreats before nothing;
20030031 a strutting rooster, a he-goat, and a king secure against revolt.
20030032 “If you play the fool and exalt yourself, or if you plan evil, clap your hand over your mouth!
20030033 For as churning cream produces butter, and as twisting the nose produces blood, so stirring up anger produces strife.”
20031001 The sayings of King Lemuel—an inspired utterance his mother taught him.
20031002 Listen, my son! Listen, son of my womb! Listen, my son, the answer to my prayers!
20031003 Do not spend your strength on women, your vigor on those who ruin kings.
20031004 It is not for kings, Lemuel— it is not for kings to drink wine, not for rulers to crave beer,
20031005 lest they drink and forget what has been decreed, and deprive all the oppressed of their rights.
20031006 Let beer be for those who are perishing, wine for those who are in anguish!
20031007 Let them drink and forget their poverty and remember their misery no more.
20031008 Speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves, for the rights of all who are destitute.
20031009 Speak up and judge fairly; defend the rights of the poor and needy.
20031010 A wife of noble character who can find? She is worth far more than rubies.
20031011 Her husband has full confidence in her and lacks nothing of value.
20031012 She brings him good, not harm, all the days of her life.
20031013 She selects wool and flax and works with eager hands.
20031014 She is like the merchant ships, bringing her food from afar.
20031015 She gets up while it is still night; she provides food for her family and portions for her female servants.
20031016 She considers a field and buys it; out of her earnings she plants a vineyard.
20031017 She sets about her work vigorously; her arms are strong for her tasks.
20031018 She sees that her trading is profitable, and her lamp does not go out at night.
20031019 In her hand she holds the distaff and grasps the spindle with her fingers.
20031020 She opens her arms to the poor and extends her hands to the needy.
20031021 When it snows, she has no fear for her household; for all of them are clothed in scarlet.
20031022 She makes coverings for her bed; she is clothed in fine linen and purple.
20031023 Her husband is respected at the city gate, where he takes his seat among the elders of the land.
20031024 She makes linen garments and sells them, and supplies the merchants with sashes.
20031025 She is clothed with strength and dignity; she can laugh at the days to come.
20031026 She speaks with wisdom, and faithful instruction is on her tongue.
20031027 She watches over the affairs of her household and does not eat the bread of idleness.
20031028 Her children arise and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praises her:
20031029 “Many women do noble things, but you surpass them all.”
20031030 Charm is deceptive, and beauty is fleeting; but a woman who fears the Lord is to be praised.
20031031 Honor her for all that her hands have done, and let her works bring her praise at the city gate.
21001001 The words of the Teacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem:
21001002 “Meaningless! Meaningless!” says the Teacher. “Utterly meaningless! Everything is meaningless.”
21001003 What do people gain from all their labors at which they toil under the sun?
21001004 Generations come and generations go, but the earth remains forever.
21001005 The sun rises and the sun sets, and hurries back to where it rises.
21001006 The wind blows to the south and turns to the north; round and round it goes, ever returning on its course.
21001007 All streams flow into the sea, yet the sea is never full. To the place the streams come from, there they return again.
21001008 All things are wearisome, more than one can say. The eye never has enough of seeing, nor the ear its fill of hearing.
21001009 What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.
21001010 Is there anything of which one can say, “Look! This is something new”? It was here already, long ago; it was here before our time.
21001011 No one remembers the former generations, and even those yet to come will not be remembered by those who follow them.
21001012 I, the Teacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
21001013 I applied my mind to study and to explore by wisdom all that is done under the heavens. What a heavy burden God has laid on mankind!
21001014 I have seen all the things that are done under the sun; all of them are meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
21001015 What is crooked cannot be straightened; what is lacking cannot be counted.
21001016 I said to myself, “Look, I have increased in wisdom more than anyone who has ruled over Jerusalem before me; I have experienced much of wisdom and knowledge.”
21001017 Then I applied myself to the understanding of wisdom, and also of madness and folly, but I learned that this, too, is a chasing after the wind.
21001018 For with much wisdom comes much sorrow; the more knowledge, the more grief.
21002001 I said to myself, “Come now, I will test you with pleasure to find out what is good.” But that also proved to be meaningless.
21002002 “Laughter,” I said, “is madness. And what does pleasure accomplish?”
21002003 I tried cheering myself with wine, and embracing folly—my mind still guiding me with wisdom. I wanted to see what was good for people to do under the heavens during the few days of their lives.
21002004 I undertook great projects: I built houses for myself and planted vineyards.
21002005 I made gardens and parks and planted all kinds of fruit trees in them.
21002006 I made reservoirs to water groves of flourishing trees.
21002007 I bought male and female slaves and had other slaves who were born in my house. I also owned more herds and flocks than anyone in Jerusalem before me.
21002008 I amassed silver and gold for myself, and the treasure of kings and provinces. I acquired male and female singers, and a harem as well—the delights of a man’s heart.
21002009 I became greater by far than anyone in Jerusalem before me. In all this my wisdom stayed with me.
21002010 I denied myself nothing my eyes desired; I refused my heart no pleasure. My heart took delight in all my labor, and this was the reward for all my toil.
21002011 Yet when I surveyed all that my hands had done and what I had toiled to achieve, everything was meaningless, a chasing after the wind; nothing was gained under the sun.
21002012 Then I turned my thoughts to consider wisdom, and also madness and folly. What more can the king’s successor do than what has already been done?
21002013 I saw that wisdom is better than folly, just as light is better than darkness.
21002014 The wise have eyes in their heads, while the fool walks in the darkness; but I came to realize that the same fate overtakes them both.
21002015 Then I said to myself, “The fate of the fool will overtake me also. What then do I gain by being wise?” I said to myself, “This too is meaningless.”
